DOC.HEAD: Adoption Program: Fashion Show Helps Match Kids with Parents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Milton and Emmie Douglas had seen photographs of children who needed parents. They wanted a closer look, and got it at a special shopping mall fashion show. A 9-year-old boy who had been left on a doorstep as an infant won their hearts by walking offstage and asking, ``Y'all gonna be my mother and father?'' ``He just picked us out of the crowd,'' said Douglas. ``We don't know what drew him to us. ... but we're glad it happened that way.'' ``What made me think they were my parents was the way they looked at me,'' said Larry, now 11 and the Douglases' adopted son. ``Like, `This is a nice kid. Why couldn't he be our child?''' Using spring fashion shows as a way to find families for hard-to-place children may be unique to Louisiana. J.C. Penney's puts on the shows and for the past eight years has invited the state Department of Social Services to bring children who have been ruled free for adoption but don't have a family waiting for them. Penney's supplies clothes for the children to model, and a social worker tells shoppers about the need for foster and adoptive parents and says a sentence or two about each child. ``I'm not familiar with anybody else that does fashion shows. That doesn't mean it's not being done,'' said Mary Beth Seader, vice president of the National Committee For Adoption. Some viewers, like Gloria Mitchell, were offended. ``We're going back in time. This is like slavery,'' said Mitchell, who went to a show March 17 to see if an advertisement she'd read was real. ``We're auctioning off these kids.'' But state social workers say it finds families. And officials with other adoption agencies say that as long as the children understand there's no guarantee they'll find parents and are treated with sensitivity, it sounds like a reasonable technique. ``I would love to not have to have to do this. I would love it if we had more families than children. But that's not the reality,'' said Kerry Ermon, one of two family recruitment workers for the Social Services agency. ``Let me tell you, it is a very effective recruitment campaign.'' In the month after this year's shows, about 80 people called to ask about fostering or adoption as a direct result of seeing the shows or news reports about them, according to Ermon. Larry was one of hundreds of thousands of children around the country who were in state custody because they were orphaned, abandoned, abused or neglected, because their parents couldn't control them, or for some other reason. Most eventually are returned to their parents or raised by relatives, but more than 15 percent eventually are released for adoption, according to the National Committee For Adoption, a Washington, D.C.-based advocacy group. In 1985, the last year for which figures are available, an estimated 276,000 children nationwide were in what bureaucrats call substitute care, according to the organization. Of about 5,000 children in Louisiana's custody, 800 are eligible for adoption. Half will be adopted by their foster parents, but caseworkers are still trying to find homes for 416, said Bobby Ann Clark of the Department of Social Services. When Larry sauntered across the stage at a suburban mall, he had been in foster care for two years. Mrs. Douglas said he had been left as an infant on the doorstep of a couple who raised him for seven years. But after the woman died, state welfare workers decided the man was too old to take care of the boy, she said. Larry knew the fashion show didn't guarantee him parents. He was optimistic when he walked onto the stage, but became nervous when couples walked up afterward. ``I thought they were going to pick either Nina or Jerry, but they came and picked me,'' he said. ``I thought, `WOWWWWWW! I'll finally be adopted!' I was happy.'' Representatives of state and local adoption groups said their main concerns about the fashion shows were that all applicants for foster care or adoption be carefully screened, and that children be prepared for the show and treated during it with understanding and sensitivity. ``You don't want to expose the child to a situation where there may be embarrassment and a big letdown. If the child is prepared in a sensitive manner, I guess it could work very well,'' said Seader.

DOC.HEAD: Earth Day Celebrations, Protests Planned Sunday in 130 Countries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years after the environmental movement was launched, 130 countries on Sunday will mark Earth Day with parades and protests calling attention to garbage in Japan, rain forests in Brazil and pollution everywhere. At the United Nations in New York, 42 astronauts from l4 countries will participate in celebrations to include displays of earth photos taken from space 20 years ago and others taken recently. The effects of pollution, oil drilling and tree felling are clear. A transmission from the Soviet space station Mir will be projected on a large screen. At the Washington D.C. zoo, elephants will trample aluminum cans to promote recycling. In Eger, Hungary, there will be a parade of people dressed as trees and birds, and in Keszthely people will wear gas masks to protest auto emissions. British shoppers are being asked to return unnecessary and wasteful packaging to grocery stores for recycling. In the Himalayas, climbers from the United States, Soviet Union and China have set Earth Day as their target for reaching the summit of Mount Everest. They will collect garbage from past expeditions during the climb. Earth Day will last a week in the oil-rich Persian Gulf. Exhibitions, lectures and other activities are aimed at heightening awareness of the dangers of polluting the Gulf with offshore oil rigs and coastal industries. Gaylord Nelson, a former U.S. senator who founded the first Earth Day in 1970, said this year's celebration is likely to be ``the largest grassroots demonstration in history.'' Nelson, a counselor to the Wilderness Society, said it should create public uproar that ``shakes the political leadership of the world out of its lethargy and forces it to deal with global environmental problems.'' Japan will celebrate Earth Day for the first time. Events will include a festival on Yumenoshima, or ``dream island,'' in Tokyo Bay. The island was built on landfill, mainly garbage from Tokyo. Denis Hayes, international chairman of Earth Day, said on a recent visit to Tokyo that Japan was ``in a league almost with the United States in being viewed as an environmental outlaw, perhaps even more so because of its dependence on resources from overseas.'' Saving the Brazilian rain forests from development will be a major theme worldwide. The Japan Tropical Forest Action Network plans a ``rock for the rain forest'' concert to publicize Japan's position as the leading importer of wood from tropical rain forests. In Budapest, Hungary, ecologists will give the Brazilian Embassy a coffin filled with sawdust to protest the ``killing'' of the Amazon forests. In Britain, Friends of the Earth will tell people that massive Third World foreign debt contributes to destruction of rain forests. The environmental group is pushing for debt relief. Other activities worldwide will include: _ France: formation of a human chain of 500,000 people along the Loire River that will stretch about 520 miles. _ Hungary: in Vac, a dirty 4-yard sphere symbolizing the earth will be rolled into the main square and washed clean. _ The Netherlands: environmental groups will protest highways under construction and proposed tunnels to bisect the Amsterdam-Rotterdam corridor. _ Ireland: parades in Dublin and 10 other cities are planned. _ Britain: the Council For Posterity launches the Adopt-A-Planet competition in primary and secondary schools. Students will adopt a small piece of land, making improvements and taking ``before'' and ``after'' photographs. Cash prizes will be awarded in June 1991. _ Mexico: environmentalists will march four miles from Zocalo to Chapultepec Park. The theme will be the four elements: earth, wind, water and fire. A major issue is poaching and export of sea turtle eggs and skins. _ United States: in Arizona, students will plant hundreds of trees. Many communities will close streets to motorized traffic. Some chemical plants will hold open houses. But not everyone is enthusiastic: ``What Earth Day is going to be is an anti-technology, anti-business, anti-Western civilization orgy by people who have no serious concern about enviromental objectives,'' said Fred Smith, president of the U.S. Competitive Enterprise Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Army Despised in Poland, but Will Stay for Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Last year, Poles showered Soviet soldiers with rocks and bottles 21 times during a 210-mile training march. This year, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki opposes a speedy Red Army withdrawal. They have disdained Soviet soldiers for decades, but Poles seem to understand Mazowiecki's point. Poland has not joined Czechoslovakia and Hungary in the rush to be free of the Red Army _ not because it loathes the ``occupiers'' less, but because it fears the army of a reunited Germany at least as much. The Solidarity prime minister, leader of the first non-Communist government to take office in the former Soviet bloc, envisions a Soviet withdrawal only within an overall security arrangement for Europe. A survey by television's Center for Public Opinion Research in March indicated 47 percent of Poles felt the Red Army should go, but the date should depend on events in Germany. ``Maybe a year ago, people would say the Soviet troops shouldn't be here, that their presence was more like a political presence,'' said Franciszek Grzywacz, a magazine editor in the garrison town of Legnica. ``Now people are saying it is a kind of a shield against Germany.'' Poland's predicament is as old as its geographical position between Germany and Russia, and has led new voices to utter a version of the old regime's argument. For decades, the Communists used the danger from Germany, combined with the general threat from the West, to support Poland's alliance with Moscow and the Red Army presence. Most estimates put the number of Soviet soldiers in Poland at 40,000 to 45,000, well below the 380,000 in East Germany, 80,000 in Czechoslovakia and 65,000 in Hungary. Those in Poland, however, form the supply link from the Soviet Union to the East German frontier of the Warsaw Pact. One of the most important Soviet military headquarters, the Western Theater of Military Operations, is in Legnica, in southwestern Poland, 55 miles from East Germany. The headquarters would coordinate a Warsaw Pact offensive, using the Baltic fleet, air force support and troops from across Eastern Europe. Legnica, 250 miles southeast of Warsaw, is one of the few places in Poland where the Red Army is visible. The well-preserved painted brick architecture is a reminder of the town's place in the swath of Silesian territory taken from Germany after World War II. Most of its 100,000 people, however, are Poles uprooted from eastern territories annexed by the Soviet Union under Josef Stalin. That adds emotion to the atmosphere as Soviet officers stroll the streets and black Russian limousines rush commanders to and from prewar mansions in a vast Red Army compound enclosed by by a 7-foot concrete wall. Tales of Soviet army abuses are legion: secret installations in the forest, bombs gone astray, ditches running black with leaking fuel from military airports, low-flying planes buzzing farms. Russian-bashing is a popular sport: Soviet soldiers live rent-free and make slums of the scarce apartments denied to Poles, cover windows with copies of Pravda instead of curtains, throw garbage out the windows, favor strip shows, are above Polish law when they commit crimes or cause traffic accidents. ``If the Soviets go home, people in this town will have nothing to talk about,'' said Grzywacz, the magazine editor. Teacher Jolanta Tochinecka does not see the Red Army as a safeguard. ``Poles know they can rely only on themselves,'' he said. ``That was shown in 1939,'' when the German invasion of Poland started World War II. Scrawled slogans may say ``Tanks to the Volga,'' and one roughly translates to ``Soviets go back to your garbage,'' but the soldiers are an economic benefit to Legnica. There is a brisk trade in Soviet gold and television sets outside the elegant turn-of-the-century officers' center. Shopkeepers rely on the well-paid soldiers and their families, who relish the relatively comfortable five-year tours in Poland. Residents speak gratefully of access to sophisticated hospitals and some other facilities _ the Soviets have their own schools, police force, book stores and work crews _ but the communities are largely separate. ``There are not two sides of town,'' Grzywacz said. ``There are two cities.'' Soviet troops came to Poland ``temporarily'' under a 1956 agreement that contains assurances of Polish sovereignty and provisions that the Kremlin will pay for their upkeep. In Czechoslovakia and Hungary, negotiations already have turned Soviet soldiers toward home. The Red Army has been in those countries since it crushed Hungary's anti-Stalinist uprising of 1956 and the Czechoslovak ``Prague spring'' liberalization of 1968. It was Moscow that proposed talks on leaving Poland. Mazowiecki's government announced in March that discussions would begin on finances and the ``inconveniences'' suffered by communities where Soviet soldiers are stationed. The Polish subsidy for the troops amounted to 26 billion zlotys ($2.7 million) in 1989, according to statistics compiled by Radio Free Europe. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa has demanded the Soviets withdraw this year, but government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said in mid-March: ``Poland is at work on the proposals to be presented during the Vienna negotiations regarding the overall withdrawal of Soviet troops in the context of a new European security system.''

DOC.HEAD: Economic Plan Has Brazil's Wealthy Flocking to Psychiatrists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello's drastic economic plan has Brazilian psychiatrists working overtime to give the nation's wealthy a shoulder to cry on. ``I've been working 14 hours a day since the plan was announced. The rich feel a mixture of panic, astonishment, anger, and depression, and they want to talk about it,'' said Flavio Gikovate, director of the Institute of Psychotherapy. Collor decreed his plan Mar. 16, one day after taking office. It set an 18-month freeze on savings accounts of more than $1,200. It also limits withdrawals from money market funds to $600, or 20 percent of an account, whichever is greater. The measure froze about $115 billion _ 80 percent of all bank deposits. Most of Brazil's poor majority were not directly hit, as few had savings that were affected. And with record inflation drastically reduced during the past month, many of the worse-off say their salary is buying more. But the wealthy are hurting, financially and psychologically. According to the prominent newsweekly Veja, at least two deaths have resulted directly from Collor's ``New Brazil Plan.'' A Sao Paulo lawyer identified only as Walter Z. had his entire life's savings frozen in a bank and was unable to pay debts. He shot himself to death three weeks after the plan was decreed. And 39-year-old Altair Rodrigues, a married father of two who had almost all proceeds frozen from the sale of his Sao Paulo home and bar, died of a heart attack. While most wealthy Brazilians have adapted to their new circumstances with less trauma, many are still reeling from the blow. A joke making the rounds reveals the degree of anger many rich Brazilians feel toward the president. As the story goes, a businessman was waiting in a long bank line behind irate customers trying to sort out their financial affairs. The businessman finally lost patience, screaming: ``That's it! I'm going to kill Collor!'' An hour later he was back at the bank, explaining to the manager, ``The line was longer at the presidential palace.''' ``For the poor, money is simply a means of buying things. For the rich, money means status. Many of my patients are depressed because they can no longer afford the lifestyle they were accustomed to and feel their social standing has fallen,'' Gikovate said. ``Brazil's rich are very spoiled. The poor have always paid for the country's difficulties and the wealthy are not used to sacrificing,'' he added. Another Sao Paulo psychiatrist, Marcelo Burkhard Sobrinho, said his work load has increased 40 percent since the plan was announced. ``I thought I'd lose clients as they'd be short on money, but it's just the opposite. Those who can't pay now are begging me to keep them on, with promises that they'll pay as soon as possible,'' he said. The psychiatrist joked that the content of his sessions had changed so drastically, he was considering taking a class in economics. ``Before the plan, it was the usual talk of sex, love, careers, shyness, and insecurities. Now at least 70 percent of the time my clients talk about the economic plan,'' he said. Rio analyst Jorge Alberto Costa e Silva said the middle-class may have been harder hit than the rich. ``Twenty percent of $1,000 is nothing, while 20 percent of $1 million can go a long way toward easing the pain,'' he said, referring to the limit on money market withdrawals. Costa e Silva, who in May assumes the presidency of the Geneva-based World Association of Psychiatry, said the middle-class was ``orphaned'' by Collor's measures. ``Bank savings gave many people the opportunity to dream, to make plans for the future. That's been taken away and for many in the middle-class, life now means only eating, working, and going to bed,'' he said. The analyst said he knew of at least 10 suicide attempts that were related to desperation caused by the plan, a number he called ``frighteningly high.'' Wealthy Brazilians with AIDS are having an especially difficult time dealing wih the bank freeze. The government allows those who became unemployed because of their illness to make unlimited bank withdrawals. But that accounts for few of the 9,555 confirmed AIDS victims in Brazil, which has one of the the world's highest rates of the disease. ``AIDS is a terminal disease, and those who have it feel they may die at any moment. Knowing their money is blocked for the next 18 months causes tremendous anguish,'' said Lahire Dutra de Carvalho Neto, a therapist who counsels AIDS patients at a Rio hospital. He said many of his clients are bitter as they are unable to travel or make plans to enjoy the time they have left. ``AIDS patients feel that first they were robbed of their lives. Now they say the government is robbing them of their money,'' Carvalho Neto said.

DOC.HEAD: Progeny Of Nixon's Checkers Thriving In Utah
DOC.TEXT: Beau Rambo, a 1{-year-old cocker spaniel, has a heritage that would make any genealogical name-dropper take notice. His great-great-grandmother was none other than Checkers, the dog immortalized by Richard Nixon. In his 1952 ``Checkers'' speech, the then vice presidential candidate rebutted charges that he illegally accepted gifts from wealthy supporters. He cited the dog, a supporter's gift to his family, as one contribution he would keep. The family pet died in 1964 at age 12. The speech proved an overwhelming success, turning public opinion in favor of the GOP ticket: Dwight Eisenhower, who was running for president, and Nixon. Today, the lineage of the Nixon family pet carries on in Craig Patterson's Beau Rambo, who lives in West Point. Patterson discovered Rambo's lineage when he called the dog's Idaho breeder to obtain the pedigree. ``She said (Rambo) had some show dogs on his dad's side and she rattled off something about Nixon's Checkers,'' he recalled. Nikki Deines, a breeder in Emmett, Idaho, confirmed the lineage reads like this: Checkers Prize Package of Nixon fame begat Otis the Twelfth, who begat Miss Mollie Value, who begat Nikki's Beau Tamara, who begat Rambo.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Ready to be Tapped as Ambassador to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is expected to name a female career diplomat as U.S. ambassador to Nicaragua as that country prepares for a new era under President-elect Violeta Chamorro, according to informed sources. The sources said Thursday it is virtually certain the appointment will go to Melissa Wells, 57, currently ambassador to Mozambique. They said the administration believed a female ambassador could relate better than a man to Mrs. Chamorro, who takes office Wednesday. They also said the administration is eager to have more women in key posts. Only rarely have U.S. ambassadorships in Latin America gone to women. In choosing Ms. Wells, the administration passed over several male career diplomats with long experience in that region, said the sources, who asked not to be identified. Ms. Wells, who was born in Estonia, has no prior experience in Latin America. Her personnel record indicates she speaks Spanish. Wells' name was submitted to the White House by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for the Managua post, and approval is considered ``99.9 percent certain,'' one source said. The United States and Nicaragua have not had ambassadors in each other's capitals since July 1988. The Sandinista government expelled then-U.S. ambassador Richard Melton and seven other U.S. diplomats on the grounds they were interfering in Nicaragua's internal affairs. The Reagan administration retaliated by expelling Nicaraguan Ambassador Carlos Tunnermann and seven of his subordinates from the Nicaraguan embassy here. But a new era in U.S.-Nicaraguan relations is expected to open with the inauguration of Mrs. Chamorro, who defeated President Daniel Ortega in elections this February. Vice President Dan Quayle and a large congressional delegation are expected to represent Bush at her inaugural. The administration has asked Congress for $300 million in assistance to Nicaragua, part of which would be used for resettling Contra rebels. But the request has been stalled by Senate Democrats, some of whom believe that Eastern Europe has a greater claim on U.S. resources than Nicaragua. Wells' nomination as ambassador to Mozambique in 1986 encountered strong opposition from Senate conservatives who held up the appointment for 11 months in protest against U.S. policy toward that country. The nomination finally was approved in September 1987. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., a leader of the campaign to hold up Wells' nomination, said he wanted to pressure the administration into dealing with rightist guerrillas opposed to Mozambique's Marxist government. Mozambique has since moderated its policies and is now off the U.S. government's list of countries under Marxist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Acquitted Murder Defendant Awarded Damages for Time in Custody
DOC.TEXT: The government has decided to award at least $16,400 to a man acquitted of the 1986 killing of Prime Minister Olof Palme. Christer Pettersson had sought 2 million kronor, or about $330,000, in compensation for the 10 months he spent in custody after his arrest in December 1988. Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's Cabinet on Thursday set the minimum award at 100,000 kronor. The final sum will be negotiated by the justice chancellor and Pettersson's lawyer. A district court last July convicted Pettersson, 43, of Palme's killing and sentenced him to life in prison. An appeals court overturned the decision in October, citing insufficient evidence. Palme was shot on Feb. 28, 1986, as he was walking home from a movie with his wife, Lisbet. The lone gunman fled down a darkened street.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Blasts Damage Journalist's Home, Cause Panic at Stadium
DOC.TEXT: A bomb thrown from a car damaged the home of a journalist and another blast caused panic at a soccer stadium, authorities said. No injuries were reported in either incident Thursday. No one claimed responsibility for the explosions, and army Col. Hector Fonseca Lopez said there were no arrests. Authorities said one bomb exploded in a vacant lot 200 yards from a soccer stadium in Tegucigalpa and that hundreds of fans ran from the grounds in panic. Fonseca Lopez said the other blast destroyed an automobile and the front of the home of Gabriel Garcia Ardon in the northern city of San Pedro Sula. Garcia Ardon, 53, has had a television news program in San Pedro Sula for 20 years and is a congressman from the governing National Party. That bombing was the third attack directed at a Honduran journalist in six months. On Oct. 28, a bomb damaged the Tegucigalpa home and car of Diogenes Cruz Garcia, the sports editor of the daily El Heraldo and also a congressman. Two people shot and wounded Jose Elan Reyes, 25, a journalist with the private Radio America chain, on Nov. 8 as he waited for a taxi on a Tegucigalpa street.

DOC.HEAD: Young Still Key Contender in Georgia But Campaign Facing Problems
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young's campaign to become the nation's second black elected governor has run into a pair of obstacles _ slow fund raising and claims by his chief Democratic primary foe that he is soft on crime. The former Atlanta mayor, seeking to repeat in Georgia what L. Douglas Wilder did last year in Virginia, has attempted to avoid race as an issue. Recently, he said, voters at a campaign stop asked if he thought the state was ready for a black governor. ``I said that (when) the University of Georgia was ready to be No. 1 in football, they didn't care what color Herschel Walker was; they just wanted to know could the `big dog' run,'' Young said. ``And I said I'm about as close as you're going to get to Herschel Walker in politics.'' Young's major opponent, Lt. Gov. Zell Miller, has attacked him as soft on crime. Miller cites FBI statistics that showed Atlanta was the nation's big-city crime capital during the last two years of Young's eight-year tenure. Young left the mayor's office in January. He served in Congress from 1973-77 and was President Carter's U.N. ambassador after that. Young and Miller, the state's No. 2 official for the past 16 years, are the front-runners in a contest that includes former Gov. Lester Maddox and two state legislators. The primary is July 17, with a runoff Aug. 7 if no candidate wins a majority. The Democratic nominee will face the winner of a Republican primary contest, most likely state Rep. Johnny Isakson. Gov. Joe Frank Harris, a Democrat, is completing his second term and cannot seek re-election. Miller had raised $2.76 million through April 3, according to disclosure reports, and his campaign is believed to be the wealthiest. Young has not yet filed a disclosure report. He has said he is struggling to raise money from local businesses and has raised only about $1 million overall. Young said the crime statistics cited by Miller were skewed by a change in the reporting of crime information and other factors. Miller, who has proposed Marine Corps-type boot camps for young first offenders and other law-and-order measures, called the response a dodge. ``This election is going to boil down to a choice between Andy Young, who wants to run from the crime and drug problem, and Zell Miller, who wants to run right at it,'' Miller declared. But Franklin O. Greer, Young's consultant, predicted Miller's strategy would fail. ``Zell just wants to point fingers. People don't think that's a fair attack,'' said Greer, who helped manage Wilder's successful campaign in Virginia. Maxine Goldstein, vice chairwoman of the state Democratic Party, said she has not heard crime discussed as an issue in the rural middle part of Georgia. ``The whole focus of his crime control effort was Atlanta. For people down here, I don't think that's as strong as it would be in the metro area,'' she said. Added Rep. Larry Walker, Democratic leader of the state House of Representatives: ``Race is not the issue it once was.'' But Emory University political science professor Merle Black, who studies Southern politics, said the fact that Georgia has a larger black population than Virginia _ 27 percent to 17 percent _ will not necessarily work to Young's advantage. ``What we've found in the past is, as long as blacks remain a minority, as the black share of the population goes up, you do have an intensification of color consciousness on the part of whites,'' Black said. For example, he said, George Wallace's 1968 presidential campaign did best in rural Southern areas with ``substantial black populations, and Wallace was obviously not drawing votes from blacks.'' Young's platform stresses economic development for rural areas, where he hopes to recruit white voters.

DOC.HEAD: John Kelly: Turbulent Years in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: John Kelly, the U.S. official whom Lebanese kidnappers want to deal with, spent two turbulent years as ambassador to that country, during which he was shot at by Christian gunmen and once was reprimanded for his role in the Iran-Contra affair. A possible deal to release an American held hostage in Lebanon may have fallen apart this week over President Bush's refusal to have Kelly get involved. Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, a pro-Iranian group believed to be holding three American educators hostage, demanded that Kelly fly to Damascus to ``coordinate some final steps'' in the release of a hostage. But Bush refused, saying, ``The United States does not knuckle under to demands.'' Kelly, 50, is a career Foreign Service officer who worked in obscurity until President Reagan sent him to Lebanon as U.S. ambassador in 1986. He quickly found himself involved in ``back channel'' discussions with the White House on secret negotiations for the release of Americans held hostage. Kelly consulted with Robert McFarlane, the president's national security adviser; John Poindexter, the successor to McFarlane; Oliver L. North, a National Security Council aide; and Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force general who was in the arms business. McFarlane, Poindexter, North and Secord all have been convicted of crimes arising from the U.S. sale of weapons to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. The discussions involving Kelly were so secret that even Secretary of State George Shultz was kept in the dark about them. And when Shultz found out, he was ``shocked'' that Kelly had discussed the hostages and the use of arms sales as an ``inducement'' to win their release. Shultz summoned Kelly to Washington to reprimand him in person for dealing behind the secretary's back. The State Department said Kelly did not take part in ``unauthorized negotiations'' for the release of the hostages. Kelly was described at the time as a ``by-the-book'' diplomat who may have been under orders not to inform the State Department of his activities. In 1988, Kelly's bulletproof limousine was hit by gunfire in a brief shooting exchange between his bodyguards and a Christian militia patrol in East Beirut. He was not hurt, but less than four months later he left the country because of a heart ailment.

DOC.HEAD: Carpenter's Gavels Hush Windy Legislators
DOC.TEXT: It's carpenter Bill Beaton's job to make sure that when the speaker of the House of Representatives flies off the handle, the handle won't fly off his gavel. Beaton and his three-man crew in the U.S. Capitol carpentry shop produce about 50 hand-tooled gavels every year for the speaker's use in admonishing the often rambunctious House to shut up and proceed with business. It takes a sturdy gavel to silence a chamber full of legislators whose back-slapping gossip and guffaws are stealing an orator's thunder, but Beaton says his 14-inch gavels of American sugar maple are equal to the task. ``They can last for years if you don't abuse them,'' Beaton says. ``One handle cracked when the gavel was hit real hard years ago, I'm told, but I guarantee you the head will never come off the handle.'' The gavels are banged on a sounding board that's even tougher. Beaton fashions them from an expensive, imported wood called lignum vitae, or ironwood. Once used to make self-lubricating bearings for old ships, it's so hard and dense that it sinks in water. ``It's practically bulletproof, and it makes just the right sound,'' Beaton says. ``Other woods are too soft and won't echo, but when the speaker hits his gavel on this ironwood board, you can hear it all over the chamber.'' Even using a new, electrically powered lathe that shapes gavels from a pattern, somewhat like the machines that make duplicate car keys, the 45-year-old shop foreman spends up to two hours making a single gavel. Starting with a block of raw wood, Beaton makes grooves, bevels and flutes with an assortment of hand chisels and wood-burning devices and applies several finishing coats of clear, acrylic lacquer. Beaton follows a fixed design that he says has been traditional for a century or more, though nobody knows for sure. ``When I came here nearly seven years ago, I was told this is the way we've always made them, and I should make them just like this,'' he says. ``I've never done it any other way.'' The shiny, blond-hued gavels, which Beaton estimates are worth $75 apiece, are kept in a drawer at the speaker's marble-topped rostrum for the exclusive use of the speaker or the legislator he appoints to preside over the House during floor action on legislation. Although a Washington newspaper article published in 1923 claimed that ``some years ago it was not unusual for 100 gavels or more to be smashed in one Congress,'' broken gavels are a rarity today. Their replacement is necessary, instead, because the speakers like to autograph their gavels and present them as gifts to constituents, friends or to fellow legislators who have steered major bills to final passage. Veteran House parliamentarians recall that some House speakers, notably Sam Rayburn of Texas, have wielded their gavels with a heavy hand, but none has banged one into smithereens in recent memory. Former Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill, a big Irishman from Boston, frequently tapped gently with his gavel's handle to persuade lawmakers to quiet down. One of the loudest gavel-bangers was former Rep. Richard Bolling, D-Mo., who presided over floor debate and voting on scores of bills from the speaker's chair during his 34-year House career. Bolling, interviewed by telephone from his retirement home in rural Maryland, remembered breaking two gavels in those years. ``Fortunately, nobody got hurt,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Resolution is `Dangerous Nonsense,' Dole Says
DOC.TEXT: Two leading congressional Republicans are squabbling over who has the stronger credentials as a supporter of Israel. The dispute began on Thursday, after Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said a resolution recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel has damaged Middle East peace efforts. Dole cited the resolution as an example of hastily passed ``dangerous nonsense'' and accepted partial blame for its Senate passage on March 22. Four House Republicans, led by GOP Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., called a news conference to denounce Dole's statements and imply that he was out of step with Republican policy. The non-binding resolution stating that ``Jerusalem is and should remain the capital of the State of Israel'' was approved without debate two days after it was introduced. It is set for House action next Tuesday. Dole's Senate floor speech was just the latest in a series of actions this year that have worried Israel partisans. Dole first called for a cut in U.S. aid to Israel as part of an across-the-board trimming of foreign aid to free money for other friendly countries. Later, he questioned the need for $400 million in U.S. housing loan guarantees for Israel, and lashed out at the Israeli embassy for lobbying against a resolution on Armenian genocide. The four House Republicans, in a letter to Dole, took exception to his reported comments that the threat to Israel has lessened. They said the United States cannot undermine its security by cutting aid. ``We continue to firmly support, as do the vast majority of the elected members of our party, the Republican platform that recognizes the importance of our unwavering commitment to Israel,'' the lawmakers wrote. Besides Gingrich, the group included Reps. Duncan Hunter of California, Vin Weber of Minnesota and Bill McCollum of Florida. The news conference brought an angry response from Dole, who released a letter to Gingrich in which he said the lawmakers had based their criticism on comments misquoted or taken out of context. ``Unfortunately, some people seem to think that if you disagree with a single policy or practice of the Israeli government, or criticize anyone who lobbies on behalf of Israel, you should be characterized as `anti-Israel,''' Dole wrote. ``That is bunk, and I am surprised that you have joined in the narrow but shrill chorus of people who take that tack.'' In a postscript, Dole added that Gingrich seemed to have forgotten his ``private words of praise'' for Dole's proposal to cut Israel aid by 5 percent. ``Or weren't those words for public consumption?'' he wrote. In his criticism of the Jerusalem resolution, Dole said many of the measure's sponsors had not even read it. He conceded that he had made a mistake by joining 84 colleagues in sposoring the measure and by failing to realize its repercussions in the Middle East. During a trip last week to the Middle East, Dole said, leaders of four Arab countries _ Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Iraq _ all brought up the Jerusalem resolution during discussions which had been meant to explore prospects for pushing the peace process forward. The leaders feared the document was a signal that the United States might be headed toward granting legitimacy to Israel's occupation not only of East Jerusalem, but also of other lands occupied as a result of the 1967 Middle East war, Dole said. The resolution dabbles in a subject that ``our government and many outside observers see as better left to negotiations among the parties involved, rather than decided by unilateral action,'' Dole said. Jerusalem is revered by Moslems, Christians and Jews as a holy city, and each can point to history to buttress claims of sovereignty. The eastern half of the city was seized from Jordanian control by Israel in the 1967 war. ``The real point is not whether I believe, or even whether 100 senators believe, that Jerusalem should or should not be the capital of Israel,'' Dole said. ``The issue is whether the Senate should be jumping into the middle of an extremely sensitive situation without looking, or even thinking first.''

DOC.HEAD: Some National 1990 Drug Goals Met; Others Not, Especially Cocaine
With PM-Toons-Drugs, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cocaine's spread has kept the nation from meeting some of its goals for fighting drug abuse, according to a new report from federal health researchers. Goals set in 1980 for curbing drunken driving deaths, alcohol consumption and cirrhosis of the liver by the end of 1990 have been met, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. But goals set for teen-age and young adult abstinence from drugs and booze have been met only in part, amid a noticeable increase in cocaine use, the CDC said. ``The percentage of persons using cocaine at least once a week has increased from 5.3 percent in 1985 to 10.5 percent in 1988,'' the Atlanta-based CDC reported. ``Since 1980, substantial progress has been made toward increasing public knowledge and awareness of the adverse social and health consequences associated with the misuse of alcohol and drugs. Risk perception has generally increased.'' But, the agency said the increased use of cocaine among adolescents is ``of particular concern.'' The report noted previously published studies which say people who are younger when they first try drugs or alcohol have more substance abuse problems as adults. The goals for the end of 1990 were outlined in a 1980 report from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Of eight major goals for curbing drug and alcohol abuse, the CDC said, three have been met, one is likely to be met and four have been met only in part. Already achieved: _ Fatalities from all alcohol-related car crashes should be less than 9.5 per 100,000 population per year. That level was reached in 1988, after years of decline. _ Cirrhosis deaths should be less than 12 per 100,000 per year. The rate fell from 13.5 in 1978 to less than 10 by 1986. _ Per capita consumption of alcohol should not exceed the 1978 level of 2.7 gallons. By 1987, it stood at less than 2.6 gallons, the lowest level since 1958. Probable: _ More than nine in 10 women should be aware of the risks of pregnancy and drinking, specifically fetal alcohol syndrome. Such awareness, measured at 73 percent in a 1979 poll, had risen to 88 percent by 1985. Achieved only in part: _ Adolescents ages 12 to 17 abstaining from booze or drugs should exceed 1977 levels. Alcohol abstinence rose from 69 percent in 1977 to 75 percent in 1988, and marijuana abstinence rose from 83 percent to 94 percent. But cocaine abstinence fell 0.3 percent, from 99.2 percent of adolescents to 98.9 percent. _ Young adults ages 18 to 25 reporting frequent drug use _ five days a month _ should not exceed 1977 levels. Frequent use of marijuana in this group declined from 19 percent in 1977 to 7 percent in 1988, but frequent use of other drugs rose from less than 1 percent to 1.3 percent, ``primarily due to the increase in the use of cocaine.'' _ Adolescents ages 12 to 17 reporting frequent drug use _ five days a month _ should not exceed 1977 levels. Frequent marijuana use fell from 9 percent to 2 percent, but frequent use of other drugs, including cocaine, went from ``less than 1 percent'' to 0.8 percent. _ Eight in 10 high school seniors should perceive ``great risk'' with ``frequent, regular'' smoking, marijuana use, intoxication or barbiturate use. In 1988, 89 percent surveyed found great risk in regular cocaine use, but only 68 percent for smoking, 77 percent for smoking marijuana, 43 percent for intoxication, and 70 percent for barbiturate use.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Votes Aid to Farmers Cutting Chemical Use
DOC.TEXT: Farmers trying to reduce use of chemicals would get millions of dollars in help from the federal government under legislation approved by the Senate Agriculture Committee. The research section of the panel's 1990 farm bill, approved Thursday, includes $40 million annually during the five-year life of the measure for a new low-input, sustainable agriculture program. Sometimes called organic farming, the method employs natural methods for controlling pests and promotes crop rotation to sustain the soil. Traditionally, the government has promoted farming methods that encourage use of chemicals. This year, for example, it is spending only $4.5 million on sustainable agriculture. ``Farmers across the nation want to reduce chemical use and they want help from Washington to do it,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Agriculture Committee. ``It's time we offered some real help, not just idle words.'' The bill would also authorize $10 million each year for training the nation's 5,500 extension agents in non-chemical farming methods. Other provisions of the bill include: _Establishment of a groundwater office in the Agriculture Department to determine the extent of damage done by agricultural chemicals to drinking water supplies and what to do about it. _A USDA study of the effects of climate change on food crops and forests. _$400 million over five years for research grants to companies, institutions and individuals studying plants, animals, nutrition and health, natural resources and the environment, new products and marketing and trade. _Creation of partnerships among researchers, state and local governments, private businesses and the federal government for developing and selling industrial products made from farm and forest crops. _New funds for laboratory and on-site research, education and training. _A 50-50 state-federal matching grant program to encourage research. The Senate and House Agriculture committees have been working since January on the 1990 farm bill, which will set policy for virtually all federal agriculture programs during the next five years. The panels are in different stages of completion on the various parts of the legislation, which they hope to have before the full Congress by summer.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Sometimes it's Easier to Criticize Friends
DOC.TEXT: In the odd world of diplomacy, it's sometimes easier to lecture friends. So Israel is taking the heat right now while the Bush administration steps gingerly around the Soviet Union and the Islamic Jihad. The Soviets are putting the squeeze on Lithuania in a carefully calibrated scheme to choke off independence for the Baltic Republic. President Bush has threatened several times to retaliate if the Soviets cross a line that he has not delineated for the American public but said Thursday the Kremlin had no trouble perceiving. According to Lithuanian leaders, the Soviets have cut off supplies of oil and reduced the flow of natural gas. But Bush is holding his fire. The Islamic Jihad, meanwhile, is holding at least three Americans as hostages. On Thursday, the militants withdrew a promise to release one of them after the administration turned down a demand that Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly be sent to Damascus, Syria, to conclude the details of the release. Again, Bush, at a joint news conference with President Francois Mitterrand of France in Key Largo, Fla., kept cool. He reminded Iran, which many analysts think has considerable control over the Islamic Jihad, that ``goodwill begets goodwill.'' Otherwise, the president said simply that Kelly could not go to the Syrian capital because ``the United States does not knuckle under to demands.'' By comparison with the squeeze on Lithuania and holding innocent Americans as hostages, the actions by Israel that drew U.S. wrath are tame. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, in charge of the caretaker government, is going ahead with settling more Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza despite U.S. warnings that such settlements are an obstacle to peace with the Arabs. And Shamir reiterated in Jerusalem that he could not accept the formula proposed by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for negotiations with Palestinians in Cairo. That was not news to Baker. After months of patient dickering, Shamir last month did not submit the U.S. plan to the Israeli cabinet for approval. The hard-line prime minister objected to including in the talks Palestinians expelled from the West Bank or others who were residents of Jerusalem. Through Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, Baker on Thursday came down hard on Shamir without referring to him by name. ``It's our view that progress at this point depends on the emergence of a government that is capable of making decisions and willing to move forward on peace,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. The statement was issued while Israel was trying to form a new government to replace the ruling coalition, headed by Shamir, that fell apart over the Baker plan. It prompted Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman Yosef Amihud to remark, ``The process of forming a new government is currently under way in Israel. It is therefore to be expected that another country, be it as friendly as it may be, will not interfere.'' Criticizing Israel is virtually risk-free for the Bush administration. Everyone understands that the United States is Israel's best friend and trusted ally. But cracking down on the Soviet Union or on the Islamic Jihad is anything but risk-free. Bush and Baker do not want to jeopardize the political reform the Kremlin has ignited in Eastern Europe or the withdrawal of tens of thousands of Soviet troops and tanks. The two are aware that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is in a tough position, trying to prevent the disintegration of his country. They want Gorbachev to negotiate terms for Lithuanian independence. But they don't think backing him into a corner with U.S. pressure would help. The Islamic Jihad, meanwhile, is holding Americans captive. Eight Americans in all are hostages in Lebanon. The administration is following a delicate course. It does not want to deal with terrorists, or even appear to be cutting deals with them. But U.S. officials also are aware of the hostages' precarious plight. So the president and the secretary of state are not hurling threats at the Islamic Jihad or at Iran. And they are measuring their words to Moscow, although Bush said Thursday ``there are limits'' to his patience.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid covers U.S. diplomacy for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Food With a Conscience Served at Upscale Restaurant
LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Forget granola, bean sprouts and smoothies. A new restaurant called Evan's aims to sell health food as haute cuisine without giving up its mission to serve ``food with a conscience.'' Customers dine in candlelight on starched white tablecloths, but make their guilt-free orders from menus printed on recycled paper. All cleaners used in the restaurant are biodegradable _ aerosols are banned _ and ``Do it for the trees'' signs remind employees to separate trash for recycling. The atmosphere is decidedly upscale, with valet parking, original works of art and fresh flowers on the tables. And the food is fancier than most people expect from health food, says owner Evan Daily, who opened the restaurant this week in Houston's trendy Montrose neighborhood. ``A lot of people think that if it's healthy, they're not going to like it. Unfortunately, there's a certain stigma that's attached to it,'' Daily said. Flower petals and herbs adorn the entrees, made from organically grown foods whenever possible. The menu includes fresh vegetables, free-range chicken and beef, venison raised on a New Zealand farm, fish and even some desserts billed as healthy. Daily and chef Kathy Ruiz cook with infusions _ the essences of various foods such as red peppers, carrots and roses that are distilled in oil. The results include wok-charred tuna with mango, tomato and scallions; shrimp on lime jalapeno pasta; and salmon with a citrus vinaigrette. The house salad consists of mixed greens, herbs and flowers. ``This is the restaurant we've been waiting for,'' said Brian Long, an automobile executive who had dinner with his wife, Martha Butler, a dancer with the Houston Ballet Company. The couple went to the restaurant after a fellow dancer who had lunched there urged Ms. Butler to try it. ``It's good and it's good for you _ that's rare,'' Ms. Butler said. Opening night drew an unanticipated 175 people to Evan's. Daily said he hopes the eatery will become a mainstay for people who want to put Earth first, even when they're dining out. But he admits that's not an easy task in a city where barbecue and chicken-fried steak are considered culinary treasures. ``In Houston, people are meat and potato eaters. They want their red meat, their Jack Daniels and cigars,'' he said. ``We want to replace those cravings with suitable substitutes.'' Daily said he sacrificed some of his values to get more people in the door. When he first envisioned Evan's, he wanted it to be free of meat, alcohol and smoking. But there is a full bar and smoking is allowed in the restaurant, which seats up to 200. At 28, Daily long has been committed to environmental issues. His interest in cooking stems from his mother, who owns a cooking school in Houston. ``We're not a couple of leftover hippies who decided to get together to just do something fun,'' Daily said of himself and Ms. Ruiz. While he attempts to alter some eating habits, Daily also tries to set an example as an environmentally conscious business. Evan's uses recycled paper for business cards, stationery and toilet paper. Employees get a recycling manual and they sign an agreement saying they will do their best to separate wastes. Although the amount will be small, Daily says the money received from recycling will be added to employee benefits. The restaurant also uses a long-distance telephone company that donates 1 percent of its customers' net bills to non-profit, environmental groups.

DOC.HEAD: Most Industrial Toxic Pollutants Released Into Air
DOC.TEXT: More than half of the 4.6 billion pounds of toxic chemicals released by industry go into the air, demonstrating the need for tougher clean air legislation, federal officials say. The EPA reported Thursday that the amount of hazardous chemicals released by the nation's factories in 1988 declined about 9 percent, but the agency said that might only be because of better recordkeeping. In 1987, the first year under the reporting requirement, the amount of toxic chemicals released by industry was put at slightly more than 5 billion pounds with close to half going into the air. EPA officials cautioned that they are unable from the raw figures, the latest available, to assess the health risks to individuals. The figures do not take into account levels of toxicity, release concentrations and actual exposure. Nevertheless, federal officials have been surprised at the high volume of releases of toxic chemicals in 1987 and 1988. The reporting requirement covers 332 toxic chemicals. ``The figures are absolutely shocking,'' declared Rep. Gerry Sikorksi, D-Minn. ``This is almost 20 pounds (of hazardous chemicals) per man, woman and child.'' Sikorski and Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., said the volume of pollution demonstrates the need for tougher air pollution control laws. The Senate has approved a clean air bill that would require industry to equip factories with the best available control technology to cut releases of toxic chemicals. A similar bill is before the House. ``We need a tough, new clean air bill and action on pollution prevention,'' said Lautenberg. ``We've got to bring these pollution numbers down,'' agreed EPA Administrator William Reilly, who said the pending clean air legislation _ when enacted into law _ will significantly cut toxic emissions from factories. The releases reported to the EPA by 19,762 industrial plants nationwide are legal and within current federal or local requirements, officials said. The reports are required annually under a citizen right-to-know law that took effect two years ago. About 2.43 billion pounds of toxic chemicals were reported released into the air by industry in 1988, compared with nearly 2.7 billion the year before. The rest was put into on-site landfills, into lakes, rivers and streams, or injected far into the ground. Another 1.8 billion pounds _ not counted in the overall figure _ were sent away for treatment such as to municipal waste treatment centers or private treatment and storage facilities, the EPA said. EPA spokesman Sean McElheny said the 1.8 billion pounds is presumed not to have been released to the environment. The EPA, however, has been critical of the handling of industrial wastes at many municipal treatment facilities. Neither the municipal plants nor private wastehandlers are subject to the toxic release reporting requirement. Among the chemicals routinely emitted from industrial sources, according to the 1988 data, were 77 carcinogens. The most widely released cancer-causing chemical _ 115 million pounds _ was dichloromethane, a chemical often used as an industrial solvent and paint stripper. Industry released a total of 281 million pounds of carcinogens, including chemicals such as arsenic, benzene and vinyl chloride. Chemical and allied industries accounted for about half of the total releases. Two states with a concentration of petrochemical plants _ Louisiana and Texas _ accounted for more than one-fourth of the pollution totals. The EPA announcement provided only general release statistics as provided by 19,762 industrial facilities and no information on specific plants. But information released by Sikorski from data contained on EPA computer tapes showed that Amax Magnesium Co. of Rowley, Utah, had by far the highest volume of releases into the air _ nearly 110 million pounds. Amax was followed among the top five industrial air polluters in 1988 by Tennessee Eastman Co., Kingsport, Tenn., 40 million pounds; Avtex Fibers in Front Royal, Va., 34 million pounds; Triad Chemical, Donaldsonville, La., 27 million pounds, and Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, N.Y., 21.6 million pounds. The Avtex Fibers plant in Virginia closed in November after a lengthy battle with the state over pollution issues. The states with the largest volume of toxic chemical releases overall were Louisiana, 716 million pounds; Texas, 596 million pounds; Ohio, 229 million pounds; Florida, 226 million pounds; Indiana, 213 million pounds, and Tennessee, 203 million pounds, according to the EPA.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say AIDS Virus Protein May Kill Brain Cells
DOC.TEXT: Two of every three AIDS patients suffer a mental decline that may be caused by an AIDS virus protein that forces brain cells to absorb a lethal dose of calcium, Harvard University researchers said in a study published today. The study suggests that a calcium-blocking drug already in wide use may be able to protect the brain cells and prevent patients from developing what is known as the AIDS dementia complex. Dr. Stuart A. Lipton, a researcher at Harvard and the Children's Hospital in Boston, said more studies must be conducted, however, before the calcium-blocking drug could be safely used for AIDS patients. In the study appearing today in the journal Science, Lipton and three co-authors said a laboratory experiment proved that minute amounts of an AIDS virus protein _ gp120 _ can cause nerve cells to die by forcing the cells to absorb up to 33 times their normal amount of calcium. An additional experiment, Lipton said Thursday, showed that the calcium blocking drug nimodipine could protect nerve cells from the effects of gp120. Nimodipine ``not only blocks the rise of calcium, but also prevents cell death,'' Lipton said in a telephone interview. The experiment was performed in laboratory dishes using rodent nerve cells. Experiments using human nerve cells are planned, he said. Lipton cautioned that although nimodipine worked to protect the nerve cells in the laboratory, there is no proof that it would work on human cells or in human patients. ``Nimodipine would not treat the underlying infection but there is hope, and it's just hope, that it might prevent the neurological manifestations,'' he said. ``It's not a sure bet to work in these patients.'' Lipton said before nimodipine is used by AIDS patients, researchers need to make sure it would not affect the action of anti-viral drugs used to fight the AIDS infection. Many studies have shown that AIDS dementia complex develops as the immune deficiency disease progresses. The dementia effect can cause patients to lose the ability to walk, reason or function normally. The cause of the brain problem has remained a mystery because researchers have not been able to isolate the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, from the brain tissue of affected patients. The Harvard study suggests that the dementia is caused by a reaction to the gp120 protein and not by a direct viral infection of brain cells. Douglas Brenneman, a researcher at the government's National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, said his lab conducted experiments similar to the Harvard studies and also found that gp120 could kill some types of brain cells. ``I'm very pleased to see it (the Harvard study) because it confirms our finding,'' he said. ``A vanishingly small amount of gp120 is lethal to the nerve cells.'' Brenneman said the Harvard use of nimodipine to protect the cells ``is intriguing'' but that more study would be needed before the drug could be used on AIDS patients. Lipton said his group used two types of gp120, a highly purified form and a specimen removed from the blood of AIDS patients. The Harvard experiment showed that both types of gp120 would kill the nerve cells. The protein gp120 coats the surface of the HIV virus that causes AIDS. Lipton said the virus can shed this protein, ``like you would take off a coat,'' and the protein has been found in brain tissue from AIDS patients. Both Lipton and Brenneman said they don't understand precisely how gp120 forces nerve cells to absorb lethal levels of calcium. Lipton's co-authors in the study were Evan B. Dreyer, Peter K. Kaiser and Jeffrey T. Offermann, all with Harvard Medical School and related institutions. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: 9 Women Cited by Mother's Day Committee
DOC.TEXT: Former White House speechwriter Peggy Noonan paid tribute to woman who choose not to work at a ceremony that honored her and eight others as outstanding mothers of 1990. Noonan, author of ``What I Learned at the Revolution,'' a book about her speechwriting career for Presidents Reagan and Bush, said she wanted ``to say a small hurrah'' for ``mothers who don't get the satisfactions of working in the world, suffering at the cocktail party when they're asked what they do.'' Other winners of the National Mother's Day Committee's awards included: Marilyn Quayle, the vice president's wife; Judith Peabody, an AIDS activist and board member of Gay Men's Health Crisis Inc.; Brandeis University President Evelyn Handler; singer Melissa Manchester; Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger and Dallas Mayor Annette Strauss. Mrs. Quayle cuddled the 8-month-old daughter of honoree Donna Hanover, a TV anchorwoman and wife of former New York federal prosecutor Rudolph Giuliani, while cameras flashed at a news conference. The Mother's Day committee is a non-profit group that has been giving out the awards since 1979. Award recipient Elizabeth Glaser, a founder of the Pediatric AIDS Foundation, said she had to devote herself to ``any mother's most basic instinct, to save the life of her child.'' Glaser contracted the AIDS virus through a blood transfusion. Her daughter has died of the disease and her son has tested positive. ``To meet my goals as a mother, I must be a part of educating a country about a disease that oftentimes (people) don't care about,'' Glaser said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Army Helicopter Said Plagued by Problems
DOC.TEXT: They were considered six of the best Apache helicopters in the Army fleet, but during the U.S. invasion of Panama, electronic parts in the all-weather aircraft failed to work when wet. Congressional investigators described for Congress on Thursday an array of problems that have plagued the attack helicopter in both Army operations and the incursion into Panama last December. Citing those flaws, the General Accounting Office said the Army should not buy the last 132 Apache helicopters as planned and use the $1.49 billion already appropriated to repair the aircraft in the fleet. ``Why buy more headaches?'' Richard Davis, director of the GAO's Army Issues Group, told a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee. ``Use the money to operate and fix existing Apaches.'' Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone said the service did not dispute the GAO findings but is making progress in rectifying the problems. The Apache is ``the finest attack helicopter in the world, an aircraft that has given the United States a capability that is the envy of the world,'' said Stone, formerly the Army's top acquisition executive. The GAO reported that during the Panama invasion, hydraulic failure grounded one aircraft, a failed fuel cell stopped another and a target detection system forced yet another to return to the base. Complicating matters were the helicopters' sensitive electronic components that failed to work when rain and humidity caused a buildup of moisture. Troops were forced to dry the parts in kitchen ovens, the GAO said. ``The Betty Crocker approach to Apache maintenance,'' quipped Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn., a member of the subcommittee on oversight and investigations. The Army plans to buy 807 Apaches from McDonnell Douglas Corp. at a cost of $12 billion. Of that total, the service had received 534 Apaches from its first delivery in 1986 through last December. Investigators said the helicopter could perform all assigned missions an average of 49 percent of the time, a low rate for an Army helicopter. In addition, the GAO found that as the Apache flight hours increased, its ability to perform decreased. ``Reliability and maintainability have been a nightmare,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the investigations subcommittee. Members of the panel also questioned the Army's warranty with McDonnell Douglas. The GAO said the warranty is similar to a health insurance policy in which those requesting payments must meet a deductible before being paid. The Army has found 166 problems with the Apache and taken steps to solve 90, but none of the costs associated with fixing the problems has been passed on to McDonnell Douglas under the warranty, the GAO said. ``Not all failures count against the warranty,'' Davis said. ``Only those that come up to the depot for repair.'' Questioned about the threshold, Davis said it would take about 2,000 to 3,000 failures before the Army would be reimbursed for the cost of repairing the Apache. ``That's a ripoff for taxpayers,'' said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Income Closely Linked to Government Payments
DOC.TEXT: A sharp drop in government payments in recent years continues to bear heavily on farm income prospects. For example, according to Agriculture Department economists, in 1986 the net cash income of farmers rose 11 percent to a record then of $51.8 billion from $46.7 billion in 1985, the first time over the $50 billion mark. Meanwhile, direct federal payments to farmers soared 53 percent to $11.8 percent in 1986 from $7.7 billion the year before. ``Net cash income focuses on the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less all costs,'' the department's Economic Research Service said in the April issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. In 1987, net cash income continued its record-setting pace, rising to $54.5 billion, a 5 percent increase. Direct payments rose 42 percent to a record $16.7 billion. But drought ravaged crops in 1988 and forced market prices to shoot up. Although disaster payments soared, the overall effect was to cool off total federal payments to farmers. As market prices rose, that lessened the need for paying out so much as ``deficiency'' payments to help bridge the gap between market levels and target prices used to compute the subsidies. Nationally, according to USDA figures, net cash income in 1988 climbed to a record of $57.2 billion, while direct government payments edged down to $14.5 billion. One characteristic of the bulge in 1988 net cash income was that many farmers _ even some who lost crops to drought _ were able to sell commodities stored from previous harvests at the higher market prices. That counted as cash income in the calendar year. In 1989, with most commodity market prices still much higher than they had been before the drought _ and the consequent tightening of U.S. inventories _ farmers put more land back into crops, thereby incurring larger expenses. The upshot was a dip in net cash income in 1989 to around $53 billion, according to current USDA estimates. It was still much higher than at any time prior to 1986. Federal payments dropped to less than $11 billion in 1989, down 25 percent from 1988 and 33 percent below the 1987 peak. ``Payments are projected to drop another 15 percent this year,'' the report said. ``Most of the decrease reflects less disaster assistance.'' The disaster aid last year totaled nearly $3 billion but may be less than $500 million in 1990, barring widespread drought. According to a new outlook report for May, 1990 net cash income is expected to be in the range of $54 billion to $58 billion, unchanged from the April forecast. Federal payments could drop to between $9 billion and $10 billion.

The farm price of milk has dropped sharply from the record highs of last winter and probably will ease down further this year, a cording to an Agriculture Department report. Analysts said this is a time of ``conflicting indications of the supply-demand balance'' in the dairy markets. ``Milk production has resumed expansion, and falling international prices of non-fat dry milk have demolished opportunities for commercial exports,'' the report said Thursday. But domestic demand has been strong, both commercially and to rebuild depleted inventories. Milk prices at the farm probably will slip in the coming months, and ``the onset of seasonal increases may be delayed,'' the report said. Overall, the farm price of milk in 1990 may average 4 percent to 9 percent below last year's all-milk price of $13.51 per hundredweight. ``Cheese use is not expected to be strong enough to compensate for the loss of commercial exports of non-fat dry milk as well as a likely 2 percent increase in annual milk production,'' the report said. ``Although a surge in cheese sales would not be unprecedented, it has rarely occurred.'' Consumer prices of dairy products as a group in early 1990 rose more than 10 percent from a year earlier, greatly exceeding the overall increases in retail food and consumer prices. ``Retail dairy prices probably will trend down in coming months, although any signs of strength in wholesale prices will tend to lessen and delay retail price declines,'' the report said.

Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter says everyone should take part in Earth Day activities and consider the role of the nation's farmers. Yeutter on Thursday planted a tree and signed a proclamation formally asking ``the agricultural community and all people of the United States to celebrate American agriculture's dedication to productivity, profitability and environmental responsibility.'' The tree-planting in front of Agriculture Department headquarters was part of this week's events leading up to Sunday's 20th anniversary of Earth Day, first observed on April 22, 1970, as a celebration of conservation of and the environment.

DOC.HEAD: STATE 1988 1987
Jewish Activist Testifies Klansman's Image More Ominous With Mask
DOC.TEXT: A Klansman wearing a white mask and hood during a one-man demonstration struck a powerful chord of violence and should have to abide by Georgia's anti-mask law, a lawyer for a Jewish advocacy group said. ``The tradition of the Klan is a tradition of violence and terrorism,'' Charles F. Wittenstein, southern counsel for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, testified Thursday. ``I think it's hard to live in Georgia and not be aware of that history and tradition of the Ku Klux Klan. ``Somebody seeing that (mask) would indeed feel threatened.'' Wittenstein's testimony came during a hearing in Gwinnett County State Court on the Klan member's challenge to a 1951 Georgia law that prohibits wearing a mask in a public place. Klansman Shade Miller Jr., 27, of Calhoun is trying to have a misdemeanor charge dismissed, contending it violates the Constitution's guarantee of free speech. He testified Thursday he wore the mask because he feared for his safety and his family's safety. The offense for which Miller was arrested carries a maximum $1,000 fine or a year in prison. Judge Howard E. Cook said he will rule on the case in about a month. Miller was arrested in February after his demonstration in downtown Lawrenceville, northeast of Atlanta. He said he joined the Invisible Empire of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan in July 1988. Miller testified Thursday that he wore the mask with the Klan's white robe and hood because he feared for his job and was afraid of the consequences if his identity were known. ``A lot of people would most likely take my life if they knew who I was,'' Miller said. David Fuller, Gwinnett's chief assistant solicitor, said the truck driver wasn't employed at the time. Miller's lawyer, Michael Hauptman of Atlanta, asked him whether the Klan robe, mask and hood, which were displayed on a mannequin in the courtroom, had any symbolic meaning for him. ``Yes, it makes me feel very good,'' Miller said. ``I like it.'' Hauptman argued that the anti-mask law is vague and open to interpretation, and he called as a witness Edward K. Fields, a former Klan organizer who said he believed the use of masks and hoods helped people overcome fears of joining the KKK. State officials contend the law is clear and specifically targeted at hate groups such as the Klan. The law prohibits the wearing of a hood or a mask to conceal one's identity when on public property. Exceptions include holiday costumes on the day of the holiday masks for use in sports, theatrical garb or gas masks. Both Wittenstein and Earl Shinhoster, Southeast regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said they feared KKK membership would grow if the anti-mask law were repealed. Shinhoster said the Klan has a history of ``invoking terror, harassment, intimidation or carrying out acts of violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Cervical Cancer Deaths Falling, But Blacks Still at Greatest Risk
DOC.TEXT: Black women are more likely than white women to undergo testing for cervical cancer, but their death rate is more than twice as high, federal health researchers say. Annual cervical cancer death rates in the United States declined from 4.2 deaths per 100,000 women in 1980 to 3.4 in 1987, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. But although the rate among black women fell from 10.1 per 100,000 in 1980 to 7.6 in 1987, that remains more than twice the white rate, which dropped from 3.6 to 2.9. The racial difference in cervical cancer rates is ``substantial and persistent,'' the Atlanta-based CDC said. The CDC attributed the disparity in death rates to generally lower socioeconomic status among blacks and a higher incidence rate of cervical cancer. The racial disparity comes as preliminary CDC reports indicate that black women are actually more likely than whites to undergo cancer-screening Pap tests. ``A higher proportion of black women ... report having been screened,'' the CDC said, citing a yet unpublished study. Further details are not yet available, CDC researchers said Thursday. Lower screening rates for black women in previous years may be contributing now to higher death rates in older black women, said CDC cancer researcher Eddas Bennett. ``Previously, black women were screened less frequently than white women, and it takes some years for it to catch up (in decreased deaths),'' she said. But, the CDC said, ``for younger black women who were screened more frequently than their white counterparts, disparities in follow-up and treatment may have contributed to excess cervical cancer mortality.'' ``If you're screened, it often comes down to a question of whether you actually received the appropriate follow-up (treatment),'' Bennett said. Overall, the CDC said, deaths from cervical cancer in the United States dropped 11 percent in seven years, from 5,537 in 1980 to 4,951 in 1987, the latest year for which detailed reports are available. ``That's primarily from the increased use of screening,'' Bennett said. Virtually all cervical cancer deaths are preventable with early detection _ chiefly through Pap test screening _ and treatment when necessary, the CDC said.

DOC.HEAD: Jetliner Pilot Gets `Climb,' `Descend' Orders From Computer
DOC.TEXT: A system that uses a computer voice to tell a jetliner pilot how to avoid an impending midair collision is being installed for the first time in a commercial air carrier fleet. ``Climb! Climb! Climb!'' ordered a male voice generated by the Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System built into a new USAir jetliner. All large airliners must have the units by the end of 1993. A miniature air traffic screen in the cockpit showed a red dot, pinpointing a plane that was coming dangerously close. Ordinarily, pilots have to rely on what they see out the cockpit window or what air traffic controllers tell them is in the vicinity. With a series of maneuvers between a small plane and the Boeing 737-400 airliner carrying industry and government officials and news people Thursday, pilots demonstrated the system, known as TCAS II, that must be installed in all airliners with more than 30 seats by the end of 1993. Commuter airliners and other smaller passenger planes are required to have a less-sophisticated version, TCAS I, which emits traffic warnings when other planes come too near, but does not tell the pilot what to do. Congress has ordered that one-fifth of each carrier's airliners have the TCAS II units installed before the end of this year at a per-plane cost of about $125,000. The bill for the entire U.S. fleet is expected to exceed $450 million. Airlines put the cost at closer to $1 billion, figuring in labor and lost profits during installation, which takes about five days. Repeatedly on Thursday's flight from Washington National Airport, the small plane came on a collision course with the USAir jet. Each time, the TCAS screen showed the location of the intruding aircraft and a voice from a speaker in the cockpit ceiling gave quick, precise instructions to the pilot. They began with ``Traffic!'' and ended with `Clear of conflict'' as passengers watched the small plane whiz by within a few hundred feet of the airliner. If two TCAS computers meet in the sky, they communicate with each other, and one pilot is told to ``climb'' and the other to ``descend'' or maintain altitude. An even more sophisticated third generation of the system, TCAS III, is being developed to give pilots horizontal instructions as well. The TCAS system gives the pilot a miniature air traffic control system in the sky, displaying aircraft within a 40-mile radius. It can only detect planes with transponders that emit radar signals. All but the smallest private planes have transponders. USAir officials said their Boeing 737 is the first commercial airplane to be equipped and certificated by the FAA with the TCAS unit. Northwest, United and Piedmont, now apart of USAir, equipped planes with test versions of TCAS when the system was being evaluated by the FAA. Three companies manufacture TCAS systems that meet FAA specifications. The ones being put on USAir's fleet are made by Allied-Signal Aerospace's Bendix-King Air Transport Avionics Division. Other manufacturers are the Air Transport Systems Division of Honeywell Inc., and the Collins division of Rockwell International Corp. ``From the pilot's perspective, the new TCAS technology provides an added margin of safety,'' said Capt. Norman Bush, USAir flight training manager. He said pilots would have to undergo only about 90 minutes of training to learn to use the system, which is expected to be put into operation in the first dozen or more planes by mid-June. Tom McSweeney, an FAA official aboard the demonstration flight, said the system would have the added benefit of making it easier for pilots to maintain proper separation from other aircraft during landings and give them more information in areas not covered by air traffic controllers. The system, however, is seen only as a backup to controllers who monitor all flights and have responsibility for maintaining safe distances between aircraft, particularly those the pilots cannot see out of the cockpit window.
