The FAA originally required that all large airliners have TCAS by the end of 1991, but last week issued final rules which require them to be phased in by the end of 1993. The phase-in period will enable the FAA to evaluate the system after it has been installed in 20 percent of the fleet.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Who Seized Armory Gets Space for Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who commandeered a National Guard armory because he was fed up with turning criminals loose for lack of jail space has forced state authorities to provide a new temporary jail. Nine weeks after Hampden County Sheriff Michael J. Ashe Jr. seized the armory in Springfield, its 44 inmates were moved Thursday to a closed, renovated armory in the neighboring western Massachusetts city of Holyoke, authorities said. ``Our intent was to be able to implement sentences ... whether it requires the Springfield armory or the Holyoke armory,'' said Ashe, quietly savoring his victory. ``We're now able to sentence people and take them to jail in this county.'' Ashe, who is well-known for his innovative rehabilitation programs, dubbed his new jail a ``Community Service Center'' and assigned to it prisoners working on various projects around the county. Some of the prisoners work at an office furniture factory at the jail, others at the jail farm or picking litter along state roadways. A special contingent of 15 prisoners is being detailed to work on Holyoke projects, including cleaning vacant lots and helping street crews fix potholes in the financially strapped city, said jail spokesman Richard McCarthy. Ashe, who has a master's degree in social work, gave up asking the state for help and seized the Springfield armory Feb. 16. Since 1988, when the inmate population reached 724, his century-old lockup for 279 prisoners has been under a federal court order limiting occupancy to 500. Armed with a 17th-century statute allowing sheriffs to demand aid and assistance in the execution of their office, Ashe simply walked in and occupied the armory. His action on the eve of the three-day Presidents Day weekend caught state and National Guard officials by surprise. When they returned after the holiday, the sheriff had installed more than a dozen prisoners, obtained a court order prohibiting the state from evicting him, and had public opinion firmly in his corner. State officials initially condemned the move, but three weeks later proposed a compromise under which the sheriff agreed to vacate the facility being actively used by the National Guard, and move his overflow prisoners to the Holyoke armory, renovated with $118,000 in state funds. Most of the money went to fix up a basement in the 84-year-old building for a large inmate dormitory.

DOC.HEAD: Crackdown on Cheats Could Burden Honest Taxpayers, GAO Says
DOC.TEXT: Reducing the $100 billion-plus gap between the federal income taxes owed and paid on legal earnings could impose some unpleasant burdens on those who don't cheat, congressional auditors say. It could mean higher prices for a roof replacement or fresh vegetables, more paperwork for small businesses and perhaps even withholding taxes from interest and dividends. The Internal Revenue Service told Congress on Thursday that the tax gap is growing and likely to reach $100 billion this year and $127 billion by 1992. It's a pile of money that large draws heavy interest from lawmakers concerned about a lingering deficit and demands for new programs. ``There are no quick fixes,'' IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. reminded the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee. Closing the gap, he said, will require tougher enforcement efforts as well as better assistance to taxpayers. Paul L. Posner, associate director of the General Accounting Office, said catching the wayward dollars will require some risks. ``New administrative or paperwork burdens may be opposed by IRS and others,'' Posner said. ``Taxpayers' support may diminish when better enforcement, such as expanded information reporting, increases paperwork burdens along with the prices of goods and services from businesses and informal suppliers,'' such as roadside vendors and home-repair workers. The GAO, an investigative arm of Congress, offered these suggestions for improving enforcement: _Require that income taxes be withheld from some payments made to one-owner businesses. The GAO noted some non-government authorities are calling for restoration of withholding from interest and dividends, an idea that Congress approved in 1982 and repealed because of public opposition a year later. _Use information from local licensing records to identify informal suppliers who may not report income, including child-care providers and others who usually deal in cash. _Require that those who make certain payments to corporations file reports with the IRS, in much the same way that a bank now must report payment of interest to an individual. _Crack down on corporations that use taxes withheld from workers to support a failing business. Goldberg said the IRS will be able to close only about one-quarter of the tax gap with existing enforcement efforts. In 1987, the latest year for which complete figures are available, U.S. individuals and businesses should have paid $505 billion in income tax, Goldberg said. Without any prodding by the IRS, they paid $411 billion, leaving a gross tax gap of $94 billion. IRS enforcement measures, including audits and computer matching of earnings reports against returns, brought in $22 billion and left a net gap of $72 billion. The biggest causes of the tax gap were: informal suppliers' failure to report income, accounting for $24.3 billion or almost 26 percent of the gap; large corporations, almost $17 billion; failure to pay taxes due at the time a return is filed, nearly $8 billion; failure to file individual returns, more than $7 billion; cheating on capital gains, $6.7 billion, and overstated deductions and exemptions, over $6 billion. The tax gap includes only income tax on legal earnings. It does not count Social Security, excise or estate taxes on legal income or any type of tax on illegal earnings, such as drug peddling and prostitution. It also excludes taxes assessed by the IRS but left unpaid for several years; these accounts receivable now total a cumulative $87 billion. The IRS estimates that individuals voluntarily pay about 83 percent of what they owe, corporations about 88 percent. Rep. J.J. Pickle, D-Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee, said the tax gap is a major threat. ``American taxpayers who voluntarily pay their fair share of the country's revenue needs will not support a tax system that tolerates widespread cheating,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Found Buried in Concrete in Basement of House
DOC.TEXT: Police using sledgehammers spent four hours dislodging a body encased in concrete and hidden for five months in the basement of a house. A woman living there went to police and told them she ``could no longer live with the terrible secret,'' police Capt. Gabriel DiBernardo said Thursday. Elaine La Dolce told police that Chester Stawiasz, 36, died Nov. 7 when her boyfriend, Paul Garland, 40, forced him into a bath of scalding water because he was dirty, DiBernando said. LaDolce told police she heard the victim screaming from the bathroom but did not see what happened, DiBernardo said. Police said a blow with a blunt instrument fractured Staiasz' skull and caused his death. Garland turned himself in Thursday and was to be arraigned on second-degree murder charges today, police said. His 18-year-old son, Michael, who allegedly dragged the body into the basement, faced a charge of hindering prosecution. The victim shared the house with Garland and La Dolce in this city 10 miles north of Buffalo. Police said Garland poured concrete around the body and threatened to kill his girlfriend if she told anyone about the death. Garland allegedly tried to dig a grave in the basement but could not break through the floor, DiBernando said. Instead, he built a wooden vault around the body and encased it in concrete. DiBernardo, who called the case the most bizarre incident he has seen in 30 years of police work, said Garland and Stawiasz both worked in a Buffalo supermarket repairing shopping carts.

DOC.HEAD: Key Bills Stalled in Senate Over Tax Cut Threat
DOC.TEXT: A Republican threat to force Senate action on President Bush's proposed capital gains tax cut has stalled a pair of the biggest bills before Congress: child care and Central American aid. Sen. Robert Packwood, R-Ore., a leading backer of the Bush tax plan, said through a spokeswoman Thursday that he may try to force a vote on the tax cut when the Senate takes up child care. But Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, strongly opposes the capital gains change, and congressional sources said he decided this week to hold up action on aid Bush wants for Panama and Nicaragua until the threat to add the tax amendment is withdrawn. The administration wants to cut the tax on capital gains _ the profit on the sale of investments _ from the current 28 or 33 percent to less than 20 percent on the theory that it would help spur the economy. Although the Senate and House have already passed multibillion-dollar child care assistance bills, a parliamentary vote is needed in the Senate before negotiations with the House over a final version can begin. Julia Brim-Edwards, Packwood's press secretary, said the senator considers the child care bill ``a good vehicle'' for adding a child-care amendment. Fred McClure, the White House's liaison to Congress, told reporters that the administration had been informed that its request for $800 million for the two Central American countries would go nowhere unless the child care measure is released. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., also a supporter of the child care bill, said Wednesday that he hoped conferees would be named on the measure relatively soon but sidestepped the question of whether there was a problem the bill's progress. Mitchell's spokeswoman, Diane Dewhirst, said he hoped to get the child care bill into a conference committee quickly. The White House had hoped to have its supplemental aid package passed by next Tuesday, when Violeta Chamorro is sworn in as the new president of Nicaragua replacing the leftist Sandinista government strongly opposed by the Bush and Reagan administrations. But even before this dispute arose, the measure's progress had been slowed by a host of unrelated issues. The House late last month approved its child care bill, which would expand tax credits for poor families for the cost of child care and would provide federal money for local governments to set up new day-care programs in the public schools. It would also expand the Heat Start program for poor children and create a system of state-issued subsidy vouchers for parents who want to use religious day-care centers. The capital gains cut passed the House last year.

DOC.HEAD: London Subways Scented to Counter `Lavatorial Smell'
DOC.TEXT: Some London subway riders are sniffing the fragrance of apple blossoms and hyacinths instead of what one transport official calls ``the armpit atmosphere'' usually wafting through the city's dank tunnels. A pilot project that began Thursday will scent subway cars on the busy East London line, which carries 6 million people each year between Whitechapel and New Cross Gate, under the Thames River and through 6.1 miles of tunnels nearly 150 years old. Passengers generally approved of the new sweet smells, but not without reservation. ``It's better than the usual smell of wet dog,'' said John O'Connor, on his way to work at a London hospital. ``I just hope they don't put on too much.'' Ian Derbyshire, general manager of the East London line who is overseeing the project, said: ``We conducted a survey last year and people did not appreciate the armpit atmosphere. ``There was a certain lavatorial smell, which is a historic feature, especially in the stations near the river, that seemed to get stronger at low tide. ``We reckoned it would be better to have a nicer aroma ... like in a bathroom,'' he said, as a cloying chemical scent drifted up the stairway from the track. Like potpourri sachets buried in a lingerie drawer, small paper packets of fragrance have been hidden behind seats on each car. When a passenger leans back, the packet emits a whiff of apple blossoms, roses, hyacinths, lemons, mandarins, wood or a sea breeze. The scents were selected by CPL Fragrances for their ability to make people feel relaxed and friendly, said Tony Satchell, a salesman with the company, which provided the sachets free. ``Just think, when you are sitting at the seaside, you feel relaxed, don't you? Well, it's because of the way it smells,'' he said. Satchell is hoping that fragrances will soon be found throughout the London Underground, known as ``the tube.'' ``We'd like to go on to other smelly places, like Paris,'' Satchell said. ``I hear Austria smells, too.'' London Transport says this is the last part of a $16 million program to improve the East London line. More trains are being added, cars are getting coats of graffiti-resistant paint, signals and security are being improved and stations are being renovated. Officials insist the improvements are unrelated to the recent rise in the number of young professionals now riding the line, which runs through slums to the expensive Docklands housing and commercial development. Not all riders were delighted with the new olfactory ambience, however. Rosella Beltrane, a vacationing teacher from Italy, sniffed: ``I think they should clean the trains first. They are revolting. It is like a person who doesn't wash and puts on perfume instead. It's nice, but it's not enough.'' And not everyone noticed. ``My sense of smell is not that good,'' said A.C. Onile, on his way home from work as a night guard. ``I heard somebody say, `something smells.' But the only thing I can remember smelling on this train was vomit, so I didn't pay much attention.''

DOC.HEAD: Family of Ag Giant Spends Heavily _ In Unison _ On Campaigns
DOC.TEXT: Michael Dukakis was on the receiving end of the Andreas family's generosity on May 25, 1988 _ to the tune of $8,000. The eight $1,000 donations to the Democratic presidential candidate's campaign from members of the family came just a day after nine members contributed $1,000 each to another party cause, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. Those checks would barely have time to clear before the Republican Party got a $35,000 share of the Andreas family's wealth. On June 1, seven family members made $5,000 donations to the Republican National Committee. For the Andreas family, the bipartisan generosity was not at all unusual. Led by Dwayne Andreas, chairman of the grain-trading giant Archer Daniels Midland Co., family members are prolific donors to campaigns and causes associated with both major political parties, giving more than $500,000 in the past decade alone. The family's coordinated approach to campaign contributions is a textbook example of how major donors can enlist their families to broaden their political impact. Critics of the campaign finance system complain that these coordinated donations allow rich donors to circumvent contribution limits adopted after Watergate to lessen the influence of the wealthy. Indeed, even with contributions flowing from other members of the family, both Dwayne Andreas and his wife, Dorothy Inez Andreas, in the 1988 election cycle exceeded the $25,000 limit on contributions to federally regulated campaigns, according to an Associated Press review of FEC records. The AP review of FEC records for the past decade shows Dwayne Andreas exceeded the $25,000 limit in the last four election cycles _ 1981-82, 1983-84, 1985-86 and 1987-88 _ and is nearing the cap with six months left in the current two-year cycle. Andreas and his wife are by no means the only wealthy Americans to exceed the $25,000 limit, exposing what critics call a glaring weakness of the FEC's enforcement efforts. ``It is a difficult provision of the law for us to monitor,'' said commission spokeswoman Sharon Snyder. ``We don't always have the resources for that kind of audit work, particularly in election years.'' In fund-raising circles, Dwayne Andreas ranks among the elite of the ``switch-hitters,'' influential donors who spread their contributions among both major political parties. In business circles, he is a legend for his friendships with Washington's power brokers, including presidents dating back to Harry S. Truman, and more recently his private meetings with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Asked for comment, Claudia Madding, an aide to Andreas said: ``We do not discuss personal donations made by members of the Andreas family.'' Andreas himself did not immediately return a telephone message Ms. Madding said she would forward to him. Dwayne Andreas, once a major backer of Democrat Hubert Humphrey, more recently has emerged as a major supporter of Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, donating hundreds of thousands of dollars to Dole's campaigns, political action committee and tax-exempt foundation. When Dole was seeking the presidency in 1988, Andreas, his wife, children and their spouses gave $10,000 to the Dole effort but also contributed $30,000 to six other presidential hopefuls. The contributions included $9,000 to fellow Greek-American Michael Dukakis and $1,000 to the man who defeated Dole for the Republican nomination _ George Bush. Andreas later was among the $100,000 donors to the GOP's so-called ``soft money'' campaign. Archer Daniels Midland's political action committee also gave to four of the presidential candidates. FEC records show Andreas family members donated at least $550,000 to House, Senate and presidential candidates and political party organizations involved in elections over the last decade. The giving appeared to cross party lines indiscriminately while perhaps favoring lawmakers in states where Archer Daniels Midland has major plants, such as Illinois. One of that state's favorite sons, House Republican Leader Bob Michel, was the Andreas family favorite last Sept. 6. Seven family members in three states each donated $1,000 that day to the Michel's 1990 re-election. Before the day was out, another $7,000 came into Michel's coffers in $1,000 donations from seven Archer Daniels Midland officials. Three weeks earlier, the company's PAC had donated $2,000 to Michel, whose district abuts ADM's headquarters in Decatur, Ill. For Florida Sen. Bob Graham, a Democrat, his day as the family favorite would come two months after Michel's, on Nov. 10, 1989, when eight family members donated $500 each to his campaign. That $4,000 was dwarfed by the $14,000 received by Massachusetts Democrat Joseph Kennedy from the family on April 28, 1986. Kennedy, facing a primary race in his successful attempt to take retiring Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill's seat in the House, received $1,000 donations from 14 members of the Andreas family.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,835.44, down 109.97 or 0.37 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Studying Problems of Pregnant Addicts
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: A House committee that last year focused on helping children born addicted to drugs is shifting its attention to high-risk mothers. A former drug addict and alcoholic who blames her substance abuse for her daughter's retardation told her story Thursday as the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families launched an investigation into these women's needs. The woman, identified only as Kathleen X, said she was 14 when she began using heroin and alcohol. She said that over the next 16 years, she had five children. Two are normal, two died in infancy and one is mentally retarded, diagnosed this year as suffering from fetal alcohol syndrome. ``We now recognize that fetal alcohol syndrome is one of the greatest causes of birth defects and mental retardation in the United States,'' said Iris Smith, project director of the Georgia Addiction, Pregnancy and Parenting Program in Atlanta. Infants born to alcoholic women are often premature, have low birth weight and later display learning or behavioral disorders, growth retardation and deficits in memory or attention, Smith told the House panel. Kathleen X testified that she would promise her children she would stop using drugs and alcohol, ``but I could never keep that promise.'' She said she finally became clean six years ago when she entered a long-term treatment program. She is now regional director of community outreach and education for a drug treatment center in the Maryland suburbs of Washington. Committee Chairman George Miller, D-Calif., noted that Kathleen X is white and grew up in an affluent area. He said her story illustrated that the problem affects all socioeconomic groups. Dr. Sheila B. Blume of South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, N.Y., said efforts must be made to identify addicted women early. ``Pregnancy is the best time to treat an alcoholic woman or a chemically dependent woman,'' she said. ``The incentive to have the healthiest possible infant is the best motivator.'' Kathleen X concurred. ``When I became pregnant, I would stop using the illegal drugs because in my mind I said, `I cannot shoot heroin any more,''' she said. ``So I drank white wine. Back then no one said there was anything wrong with that.'' Education can work for some women at risk, Smith said. She referred to a 1986 study by the Emory University School of Medicine that found that 35 percent of women informed of the potential harm of alcohol use during pregnancy stopped drinking.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Searching For Girl Said Kidnapped by Babysitter
DOC.TEXT: Nicole Ravesi's baby sitter was awfully fond of the girl, so fond that her mother got a court order to keep the baby sitter away. But a week after Denise Ravesi told Kenneth Cole he could never see her daugher again, 5-year-old Nicole disappeared, and police say Cole kidnapped the girl. Police have received tips on Cole's whereabouts, Milford police Detective Edward Pomponio said Thursday night. In the meantime, Mrs. Ravesi is crossing her fingers. ``I have a lot of hope that the FBI is doing the best they can,'' she said. Cole, 24, was described as a quiet, shy young man. Mrs. Ravesi said he became obsessed with the little girl, for whom he frequently baby-sat. Nicole reciprocated Cole's affection, and neither Mrs. Ravesi nor investigators felt the girl was in danger. ``He has genuine strong feelings for her welfare. I don't think he would intentionally harm her,'' said FBI spokesman Paul Cavanagh. But Mrs. Ravesi is convinced that Cole intends ``to take her and raise her as his own girl.'' When Nicole was hospitalized for a hip infection, Cole visited often, and was seen kissing the little girl on the lips, hospital staff said. By February, Nicole's parents had become so concerned they obtained a court injunction prohibiting Cole from seeing their daughter for five days. But when the ban was lifted, Cole was still attached to the child. ``It was like an addiction,'' said Mrs. Ravesi, 34. ``He could never separate from her, that was a big deal, he could never just say `Hi' and `Bye' and everywhere he went, whatever he did, he needed Nicole nearby. Wouldn't that be obsession?'' In late March, the Ravesis told Cole he could never see Nicole again. Others told Cole the Ravesis planned to move from their suburban Milford home before the summer was out. On April 3, Cole allegedly abducted Nicole as she waited with her older sister in a parked car for Mrs. Ravesi, a school bus driver, to finish her route, police said. ``I think the biggest reason he did this was he felt she might forget him over time and he was right. In time, she would,'' Mrs. Ravesi said. Investigators found Cole's mother's car parked outside an Amtrak station in Providence, R.I., April 7. Hundreds of phone calls have come in since Nicole's story was featured on the television program ``America's Most Wanted.'' Mrs. Ravesi, who has taken a leave of absence from her job, said she wishes that Nicole would be allowed to contact her. ``The message I would give to him would be to allow Nicole to draw a picture and send it to me,'' Mrs. Ravesi said. ``A letter from her would be real nice, just so I know she's all right.''

DOC.HEAD: Thrift's Portfolio Had Millions in Hidden Losses, Court Told
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings and Loan Association's real estate and loan portfolio included hundreds of millions of dollars in unrecorded losses, says the regulator in charge of the institution's takeover. Keith Seibold of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. on Thursday countered charges by Lincoln's owner, Charles H. Keating Jr., that regulators arbitrarily reduced the value of the thrift's holdings. Seibold said officials spent three months evaluating the security of each loan and physically inspecting Lincoln's real estate holdings in Arizona, Texas, Colorado and other states. When they were through, they estimated the S&L was $631 million in the red at the end of June 1989, up from a negative net worth of $66 million only three months earlier, he said in U.S. District Court. The losses had swelled to $1.5 billion by the end of the 1989 and continue to mount at a rate of $20 million a month, he said Thursday, testifying in the 26th day of hearings in Keating's suit to recover Lincoln from regulators. Seibold also testified that regulators found records missing on the day of the takeover, April 14, 1989, and that they immediately were forced to stem a severe run by depositors. ``It is probably one of the most chaotic situations I have been involved with in my 20 years with the FDIC,'' Seibold told Judge Stanley Sporkin. To obtain missing loan documents and credit files, regulators had to resort to bartering with officials of American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, the parent company of Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln, Seibold said. He said they swapped artwork in Lincoln's offices for files in possession of the holding company. ``That's ridiculous,'' Keating told reporters later, dismissing Seibold's sworn testimony as ``total misstatement'' and ``lies.'' Seibold also said that Lincoln had so few assets capable of being easily sold that it became the first S&L forced to seek an emergency loan from the Federal Reserve Board to meet the demands of depositors, who withdrew $110 million in the first three days under government control. ``A run itself is not that unusual ... but this was something entirely different in ... the hostility and virtual panic on the part of depositors,'' Seibold said. ``We searched the asset structure to find some assets good enough to sell or pledge, but we couldn't find them.'' Seibold said only 3 percent of Lincoln's loans were traditional home mortgages. Most of the rest were construction and development projects. In 79 percent of the loans, Lincoln had either provided the borrower with the money to meet the first several years of interest payments or required no interest payments until the loan came due, he said. That disguised the fact that many were bad loans, Seibold said, adding that delinquent loans went from $182 million at the end of March 1989 to $1 billion a year later. Meanwhile, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, called on the Justice Department to seize the assets of S&L owners such as Keating ``living high on the hog off their ill-gotten gains.'' ``People like Charles Keating are free to fly first class across the nation, stay in luxury hotel suites, hire armies of attorneys and file suits against the federal government using funds that should be part of the recovery for the deposit insurance funds,'' Gonzalez said. ``The Justice Department does not have to stand by while the government's money is being dissipated in this manner,'' he said. Gonzalez made the Lincoln case prominent nationwide by holding hearings on the failure last fall. Keating asserted his constitutional protection against self-incrimination in refusing to testify to Gonzalez's panel, but he took the stand for eight days in his own suit. ``The congressman doesn't like to see the truth come out in the courtroom,'' Keating told reporters. ``It conflicts with his view of the case.'' Sporkin is holding the court hearings before ruling on the government's motion to dismiss Keating's suit. He has set today as the last day of testimony and scheduled closing arguments in the case for June 8.

DOC.HEAD: It Could Be Lights, Camera, Action at Your House
DOC.TEXT: If you've ever fantasized about sharing your bedroom with Tom Cruise or Kim Basinger, your videotape machine with Rob Lowe and your dark passageways with the likes of Stephen King, maybe your dreams can come true. Thanks to a company specializing in finding places to film movies and commercials, your ticket to stardom may be your home. Valerie Bulinski and Mark McCarville don't scout for talent. They shop for castles, gang-plagued neighborhoods and other locations preferred by movie and commercial makers trying to outfox a more discerning public. ``With commercials, we usually like large kitchens, large rooms (crew members) can work in,'' Ms. Bulinski said. ``But with a movie, it's a character, and you have to have some look that surrounds them.'' Ms. Bulinski and McCarville are partners in a 2-year-old company called Location Consultants. They've been to Wisconsin for farms and steam engines, Michigan for train stations, suburban Chicago for a castle and southern Illinois for a forest. Ms. Bulinski said TV and movie directors prefer real homes and places rather than stage creations because they want ``an authentic look.'' Viewers ``are getting a little too smart and look out a back window (of a filmed scene) and see the difference between real trees and a backdrop,'' McCarville said. Ms. Bulinski has been in the location-scouting business for five years; McCarville, 10. Starting pay for their clients, the people who host production crews, is about $700 a day and can climb to $1,600. The partners have worked on such movies as ``Midnight Run'' starring Robert DeNiro and ``Rent a Cop'' starring Burt Reynolds, and such TV programs as ``Crime Story'' and ``Lady Blue.'' Lynda Brooks is one of the company's busiest clients. Her Victorian home is filmed two or three times a year for commercials, an industrial movie and last spring a made-for-TV movie about the Howard Beach drama, ``Making the Case for Murder.'' ``They like my house because I have such a huge kitchen,'' said Mrs. Brooks, who lives in suburban Oak Brook. In the Howard Beach movie, her home was to belong to the film's New York prosecutor, portrayed by Daniel J. Travanti. ``They had to dress my house down,'' Mrs. Brooks said. ``I have a lot of art glass windows and they covered them with sheers because they didn't want the prosecutor to look like he was on the take.'' The movie crew shot only about 2{ minutes of the film at the house. Mrs. Brooks' pay: $1,600. Also, the host family and friends can watch filming if they stay out of the way. Mrs. Brooks, a theater major in college, said she'd love for Paul Newman or Robert Redford to star in a movie at her house. ``I'm crazy about movie stars,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Cruise Ship Industry Vulnerable to Major Accidents, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Americans who take cruises each year to rock in the lap of luxury are ignorant of dangers like crews unprepared for emergencies and a lack of qualified physicians, according to testimony at a congressional hearing. A disaster involving U.S. passengers is waiting to happen, National Transportation Safety Board Chairman James L. Kolstad said Thursday, arguing for greater U.S. control over safety and health conditions on foreign-flag cruise ships operating from this country. ``The passenger industry operating from U.S. ports has had accidents with a potential for large loss of life,'' he told a House Merchant Marine and Fisheries subcommittee. Kolstad mentioned an engine-room fire in November 1988, as well as two rammings by cruise ships of docked vessels and one ramming of a boardwalk, all happening in Florida last year. The subcommittee is considering tighter restrictions as a result of the blossoming of the domestic cruise ship industry in the last 15 years. According to testimony, 80 percent of the world's passenger cruise ships operate from U.S. ports, carrying American passengers. Although their owners are primarily U.S. companies, the ships sail under foreign registry, so-called ``flags of convenience,'' allowing them to avoid U.S. labor and tax laws. Those mostly Panamanian- and Liberian-registered ships are governed by the laws of their flag country when on international waters. Referring to the Scandinavian Star fire that killed more than 160 people in the North Sea, Kolstad said the NTSB would have been unable to investigate that accident had it happened in international waters off Florida. The NTSB investigated a major fire aboard the same ship two years ago in the Gulf of Mexico and ``identified some of the very problem areas survivors have reported this past week,'' he said. But the NTSB's recommendations were unenforceable, he said. Among the complaints voiced by Kolstad and echoed by other witnesses was that many ships lack licensed, certified doctors. Many ships, he said, rely on medical students or paramedics. Many of the doctors on ships cannot communicate in English, and the infirmaries often are ill-equipped, witnesses said. Kolstad noted that on most ships, the crews are so linguistically diverse that they can hardly communicate among themselves, let alone communicate with passengers in an emergency. Kolstad and other witnesses said crews often are not adequately drilled for emergencies. He argued for spot inspections in U.S. ports by the Coast Guard, rather than scheduled quarterly inspections. Opponents say the cruise operators would simply move to the Bahamas and offer cheap fly-and-cruise packages for Americans if they wanted to escape U.S. regulations. Coast Guard Rear Admiral Joel D. Sipes disputed many of Kolstad's assertions, saying that international agreements are addressing safety concerns. He said language is less important than training in emergency drills, and argued that the core of ship's officers often speak the same language. ``We find most ships to be in compliance,'' he said, urging respect for the ``national sovereignty'' of the ship.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Says War Isn't Over, Despite Accords to Dismantle Contras
LaserPhotos MGA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Despite a pact to disband the Contras, President Daniel Ortega said Nicaraguans can't be sure their 9-year-old civil war is over until the last rebel lays down his gun. The Contras signed an accord Thursday with the United National Opposition and the Sandinistas to begin turning in their weapons next Wednesday, the day the 14-party bloc and President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro are to take office. The Contras are to give up all of their arms by June 10, and all sides agreed to a cease-fire that went into effect at noon Thursday. There has been widespread speculation the Sandinista government might not transfer power as pledged _ despite its loss in Feb. 25 elections _ if the Contras did not disarm. The situation has created an atmosphere of mutual suspicion, and Ortega appealed for trust. ``We still can't say that peace has arrived, but we can say today that we are much closer to peace and are distancing ourselves from war,'' he said after a meeting with Bernard Aronson, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs. ``The war will have disappeared on the moment that all the Contras have disarmed, and the deadline is June 10,'' he said. Aronson made no comments during his one-day visit to Managua, except when he came out of Mrs. Chamorro's home and told reporters the two had discussed ``economics, the transition, the peace process'' and ``the economic assistance thing.'' President Bush has asked Congress to approve $300 million in aid to help Mrs. Chamorro revive Nicaragua's battered economy. An estimated 30,000 people were killed by the civil war in this country of 3 million. There are about 9,000 Contras in Nicaragua. They waged their insurgency against the Sandinistas from Honduran border camps and with U.S. aid. But the United States cut off military aid in February 1988, the fighting tapered to sporadic battles and most of the rebels have slipped back into the country. Mrs. Chamorro and Ortega had asked them to disband. ``I'm very happy; we don't want war any more, we want peace, we want reconciliation,'' she said after meeting with Aronson. ``Like I told Daniel (Ortega) yesterday ... all of us have to give each other a helping hand, forgive.'' Following 14 hours of talks, the Contras, the Sandinista-controlled army, UNO officials and Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo of Managua signed the accord. The agreement also calls for Sandinista military forces to complete their withdrawal from five rebel security zones and for the guerrillas to begin concentrating immediately in those areas. Another agreement between the Sandinista army and the Miskito Indian rebels, who are allied with the Contras, established a cease-fire that started at midnight Thursday in the sparsely populated eastern half of Nicaragua. It calls for the demobilization of the Indian rebel force by May 18. Missions of the United Nations and Organization of American States were charged with supervising the accords. The incoming UNO government seemed to gain the most. The Sandinistas had threatened general strikes and other actions if the Contras did not demobilize by inauguration day, and there was always the threat of armed clashes and even renewed civil war. Earlier, the Contras had demanded the Sandinista army be neutralized as a condition for disbanding their forces. Thursday's accords do not address that demand. However, under an accord with Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, the Sandinistas had already agreed to depoliticize the army and reduce its size. In exchange, the incoming government promised to ``respect the integrity and professionalism'' of the armed forces. The fears of disruption in the transfer of power have hinged largely on whether the army would be willing to yield authority to the new government. ``With this accord, we conclude the peace process that started with the elections,'' said Antonio Lacayo, senior negotiator for Mrs. Chamorro. ``Let it be clear that what has been signed here is something serious, something formal, and I think that we all have the good will to fulfill this signed document,'' said Oscar Sovalbarro, the Contras' senior negotiator. Sandinista army Gen. Humberto Ortega, the defense minister and brother of the president, said he was satisfied with what he called a peace effort reached ``in a profound, serious way, with a great spirit of responsibility.'' However, not all Sandinistas were happy with the idea of letting the Contras retain their arms after April 25, and a pro-Sandinista mob surrounded a U.S. Embassy station wagon carrying Aronson as it was leaving the Managua airport Thursday morning. The mob pounded on the sides and windows of the vehicle, demanding that the Contras demobilize immediately. No one was reported injured.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Moving to Restore Trade Benefits to Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate debate scheduled to resume at 10:30 a.m.; pre-noon lead expected.
DOC.TEXT: While not yet acting on President Bush's request for $300 million in aid to the incoming Nicaraguan government of Violeta Chamorro, the Senate is moving to restore trade benefits to the Central American country. On a voice vote without dissent, the Senate approved an amendment Thursday lifting trade sanctions imposed in 1985 as part of an embargo against the regime of President Daniel Ortega. The amendment by Sen. Christopher J. Dodd, D-Conn., was one of several to a bill making permanent the duty-free status given a wide variety of imports from 24 Caribbean and Central American nations under the Caribbean Basin Initiative. The House approved a similar bill last fall making the initiative permanent beyond 1995, when it is scheduled to expire. However, the House rejected attempts to expand the list of duty-free items to include shoes and clothing that would compete with U.S.-made products. Bush called for the aid package and the restoration of trade relations with Nicaragua after Ortega was defeated by Mrs. Chamorro in a Feb. 25 election. Mrs. Chamorro is to be inaugurated next Wednesday. The House approved the aid package before Easter. Among the trade benefits are restoring Nicaragua's sugar quota, which could bring the country $33 million by the end of the year, according to State Department officials. Prior to the embargo, Nicaraguan exports of coffee, bananas and other products to the United States totaled $57 million in 1984, and U.S. exports there totaled $112 million. By last year, two-day trade between the countries had dribbled to less than $5 million. Also without dissent, the Senate approved an amendment urging Bush to consider extending the duty-free status now enjoyed by the Caribbean and Central American countries to Peru, Colombia and Bolivia. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., said the amendment is intended to encourage the countries to develop economic alternatives to cocaine. ``The Andean region of South America is the source for 100 percent of the world's supply of cocaine,'' he said. ``We all agree that all routes to reducing cocaine production should be explored.'' Approved on a 90-3 vote was an amendment by Sen. William Roth, D-Del., making it easier for importers to win temporary suspensions of tariffs if no one raises valid objections. Such suspensions now have to be approved by Congress. Roth said some importers now must wait for years because of delays in acting on duty suspension requests by the House Ways and Means Committee, where trade and tax legislation must originate. The amendment would allow a president to suspend a tariff after an investigation by the International Trade Commission if Congress does not act on a request within a year. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., opposed the amendment, saying it forfeits to the president powers specifically delegated to Congress by the Constitution. Also voting against Roth's amendment were Sens. John Danforth, R-Mo., and Dave Durenberger, R-Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Divided on PAC Campaign Finance Limits
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republicans are divided on how far to go in trying to limit the influence of corporate, labor and ideological political action committees in election campaigns. But they say they are united in wanting to stop the so-called ``soft'' unreported money spent on campaigns by unions. ``We made, I think, substantial progress in developing a unified position,'' Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., said upon emerging from an hour-long GOP strategy meeting Thursday on campaign finance reform. However, others among more than 20 Republican senators who attended the meeting in party leader Bob Dole's office said there was no resolution on several issues. With Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, intent on beginning Senate debate next week on a campaign finance bill, Democrats were planning to huddle today on their strategy. ``This is the most partisan issue that the Senate will deal with this year,'' said McConnell, whose selection by Dole to manage the GOP side of the debate is viewed by several Democrats as an omen of a bitter fight ahead. McConnell was among the leaders of a Republican filibuster that Democrats failed to break two years ago when they unsuccessfully tried to establish taxpayer financing of campaigns and limit how much candidates can spend. Democrats want to impose a spending limit of $400,000 on House candidates and ceilings ranging from $950,000 to $5.5 billion in Senate races, depending on a state's voting-age population. Democratic leaders, however, have abandoned any attempt to win public financing. Lawmakers anticipate that after a few days of debate, party leaders and the administration will begin working on a compromise behind closed doors, just as they did with a clean air bill approved before Easter. Bush wants an outright abolition of PACs, which have tended in recent elections overwhelmingly to favor incumbent lawmakers. Since Democrats hold majorities in both the Senate and House, they have enjoyed PAC largess more than Republicans. The Democratic bill would retain the current $5,000 limit a PAC can contribute to a candidate for each primary, runoff and general election but impose a ceiling on the total PAC contributions a candidate can receive. ``We spent a lot of time talking about the PAC issue and how far to go in bashing them,'' McConnell said. ``We (Republicans) do have some strong defenders of PACs.'' McConnell divided members of his party into three camps on the issue: _Those who want to go along with Bush and abolish PACs outright. _Those who would reduce the amount a PAC can contribute to a candidate for each primary, runoff and general election to $1,000. _And those who want to abolish labor and corporate PACs but allow contributions of up to $1,000 from issue-oriented, unconnected PACs such as those of the National Rife Association and environmental groups. A few Republicans, McConnell said, also endorsed the idea of so-called flexible ceilings placing no limit on how much a candidate can raise from home-state residents but capping contributions from out-of-state donors. ``I still believe that the president _ a former chairman of the Republican National Committee _ will veto a bill that has spending limits, in or out of state,'' said McConnell, a strong opponent of ceilings. Republicans, he said, are united on abolishing the use of so-called ``soft'' unreported money by unions and other tax-exempt organizations for voter registration drives. Academic experts have estimated that unions spent up to $45 million of such money in the 1988 election _ almost all of it benefiting Democrats. And it was through a tax-exempt California voter registration project headed by the son of Senate Democratic Whip Alan Cranston, that Phoenix savings and loan operator Charles H. Keating Jr. gave $850,000 of the total $1.3 million contributed to five senators. ``If you're tax-exempt, you shouldn't be playing the political game,'' said Dole. ``If we're really concerned about cleaning up the campaign sewer money, then it's about time to spray the sewer stench with a big can of legislative Lysol.''

DOC.HEAD: Marla Maples: I Do Love Donald Trump
DOC.TEXT: Model Marla Maples declared her love for Donald Trump on national television, but declined to characterize her relationship with the developer whose billions are in the sights of his estranged wife. Maples, said to be the ``other woman'' in the much-discussed divorce case of Donald and Ivana Trump, was interviewed on a segment of ABC's ``PrimeTime Live'' that aired Thursday night. Her frosted blonde hair cascading in waves over the shoulders of her peach-colored suit, Maples spoke demurely, haltingly at times. But she never appeared flustered by the questions, even the meaty ones, which she politely declined to answer. She would not say how she met Trump, nor would she comment on a reported confrontation she had with Mrs. Trump in Aspen, Colo., where the Trumps vacationed last year. The segment was taped Wednesday in a house owned by Trump's friends, Jack and Caroline Davis, in Atlantic City, N.J., where Trump recently opened the glitzy Taj Mahal casino. Was she the reason for the Trump split? ``Only the two of them know what really went wrong with their marriage. But I'm not the reason for that marriage having problems,'' she said, adding: ``As Donald has said himself, `People just grow apart.''' Asked about a story in which an unnamed friend of Maples quoted her as saying ``the best sex I ever had'' was with Trump, Maples responded: ``It's just an absolute, total lie that I said it.'' When interviewer Diane Sawyer asked her straight out if it was the best sex she ever had, Maples said: ``Diane, that has nothing to do with why I'm here.'' Maples said Trump approved of her doing the interview, apparently her first since the divorce story broke in February. ``I made sure of that.'' Settlement of the divorce suit, in which Mrs. Trump is challenging the legitimacy of a marital contract that limited her alimony to a mere $25 million, might depend in part on questions of fidelity. ``Do you love him?'' Sawyer asked Maples. ``I do love him,'' answered Maples. ``Do you want to marry him?'' Sawyer asked. ``I'm taking my life day by day. I am just hoping to go on,'' Maples said. ``I mean who knows what life is going to bring in the future? I have no control over that.''

DOC.HEAD: WHO to Take Part in AIDS Conference
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization, which considered withdrawing as sponsor of an upcoming AIDS conference in protest of U.S. immigration policies, will participate but is urging the Bush administration to drop all entry restrictions on people with AIDS. WHO Director-General Hiroshi Nakajima, in a statement released in Geneva and in Washington on Thursday, welcomed the administration's effort to make it easier for people infected with the AIDS virus to attend the conference in San Francisco in June. ``However, WHO views the situation as not completely satisfactory and strongly urges the United States to continue its efforts to drop all travel restrictions against HIV-infected persons,'' the head of the United Nations agency added. The administration last Friday announced a new 10-day visa for foreigners attending certain White House-approved professional, business and scientific conferences in the United States. Travelers obtaining the visa will not have to reveal whether they are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. Pressure had been building on the administration to take action that would quell the growing protest of U.S. travel restrictions. Dozens of organizations and the governments of France and Switzerland have indicated they will not send representatives to the conference because of the restrictions. Additionally, the European Parliament has called on scientists not to attend the conference. Nakajima gave initial indications to the U.S. government on Wednesday that WHO would announce Thursday that it would remain co-sponsor of the conference but would delay a decision on whether to attend, said administration sources who demanded anonymity. However, after consulting with Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and others, Nakajima decided that WHO would attend, one source said. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said the administration has no plans to ease travel restrictions further, ``but obviously we continue to study the situation.'' Dana Van Gorder, a spokesman for the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, said the administration's announcement of the visa last week has had ``virtually no impact'' on the groups that have said they will boycott. ``I know of no organization that has changed its policy based on last Friday's announcement,'' Van Gorder said by telephone from San Francisco. He said that about one-third of the 7,000 delegates that have registered for the conference are from other countries. But he said he knows of about 100 organizations that have indicated they would not participate because of the travel restrictions. Van Gorder said he welcomed the WHO decision to attend as well as the organization's promise to continue efforts to get all travel restrictions ``WHO participation in the conference is important to the major goal of ours, which is distributing updated scientific information, particularly in developing countries,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Chairman: Anti-Pornography Minister Uses Distortion, Intimidation
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the National Endowment of the Arts is accusing a pornography-fighting minister of using distortion and intimidation to eliminate federal funding for his agency. John E. Frohnmayer said Thursday he was drafting a letter to the Rev. Donald Wildmon, founder and executive director of the American Family Association in Tupelo, Miss. ``I simply have suggested to the Rev. Wildmon that he should pay attention to the commandment against bearing false witness,'' the nation's top arts official said. ``I respect his right to speak freely on the issue but I do not respect his use of falsehoods or half-truths or intimidation,'' Frohnmayer said. ``I have repeatedly stated my opposition to obscenity in any form.'' Wildmon so objected to homosexual images from the catalogue of a federally funded exhibition at Illinois State University that he photocopied and mailed them to all members of Congress. Sealed inside envelopes marked ``extremely offensive material enclosed'' were 14 explicit photographs and drawings from the ``David Wojnarowicz, Tongues of Flame'' show mounted with a $15,000 NEA grant. The exhibition at the University Galleries in Normal, Ill., ran through early March. Wildmon's accompanying letter, which asked the lawmakers to ``clean up the NEA or abolish the agency altogether,'' included several distortions, Frohnmayer said. He said Wildmon wrote that the Illinois show went on view in January, after Frohnmayer's appointment and after Congress forbade NEA financing of art that ``may be considered'' obscene and without ``serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' But Frohnmayer said the grant was approved before the fall passage of the restrictions and prior to his appointment by President Bush. Since receiving Wildmon's mailing, several lawmakers have questioned whether to reauthorize the independent federal agency. It provides seed money for such mainstream activities as opera, dance and theater. Rep. James Saxton, R-N.J., says he's ready to deny funding to the NEA. ``They have got to adopt policies that keep this type of pornographic art from being displayed,'' Saxton said. His office received nearly 300 postcards from constituents contacted by Wildmon. His colleague, Rep. Dean Gallo, R-N.J., complained in a letter to Frohnmayer that in supporting the Illinois exhibit, the NEA jeopardized worthy local projects. ``Frankly, support for the NEA is fast disintegrating among members of Congress and our constituencies,'' Gallo wrote. But some lawmakers said they hadn't seen Wildmon's letter and the photos. The offices of three congressmen involved in arts funding, Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., and Rep. Bob Carr, D-Mich., reported Thursday that they had not seen the mailing. Staffers for Rep. Christopher Smith, R-N.J., said they threw it out before it reached the boss's desk. Such conservative lawmakers as Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., have attacked the NEA for supporting exhibitions of controversial art by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. In recent testimony before committees handling NEA reauthorization, Frohnmayer has proposed modifying the grant process to ``make sure we know exactly what we're being asked to fund ... before the money actually goes out.'' But overall, Frohnmayer says the issue has been distorted. ``It seems to me that the Rev. Wildmon and others have whipped up a fair amount of hysteria on the basis of a very few images,'' Frohnmayer said. ``We're talking about maybe 20 images out of a million that we funded. And maybe 20 to 25 grants out of 85,000 grants that we have given in the last 24 years,'' Frohnmayer said. ``To suggest that this agency is a purveyor of pornography or is somehow out of control simply ignores the 99.99 percent of the work that we have done that has received nothing but praise.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed slightly lower against the yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell moderately. The dollar ended the week at 157.60 yen, down 0.15 yen from Thursday's close of 157.75 yen. After opening lower at 156.78 yen, the currency ranged between 156.73 yen and 157.75 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 109.97 points, or 0.37 percent, closing the week at 29,835.44. The Nikkei index gained 696.35 points on Thursday. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese 10-year government bond was 86.33 points as of 3:00 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 86.45. The yield rose to 7.295 percent from the previous day's close at 7.270 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar's weakness followed from its overnight decline in New York, where it fell to 157.25 yen from 158.125 yen Wednesday. Many dealers attributed the yen's modest recovery after weeks of decline to a range of events, notably reported comments from U.S. Treasury officials that they viewed the dollar as too strong. Masaaki Tanahashi, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said trading was more active in cross-trading between the yen and West German mark rather than between the dollar and the yen. ``The dollar seems to be in a box range,'' Tanahashi said. Securities dealers said the yen's strength helped support the stock market. ``The stock market began making a full-fledged recovery in the past couple of days, though there remains some some mixed sentiment,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, an analyst with Daiwa Securities. Nishiguchi said investors were showing a ``strong hunting interest.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Testing `Sandwich Bag' Condom
DOC.TEXT: A non-profit company is testing a loose-fitting, plastic condom that could prove to be more resilient and comfortable than the standard latex variety. Family Health International would not reveal details about the contraceptive, but it is said to resemble a sandwich bag. ``Generally people's faces have a look of surprise or amusement when they see them,'' said Thomas Brookshire, a physician's assistant at Planned Parenthood in Raleigh, which is testing the device. ``They just don't look like condoms.'' ``We're testing for acceptability _ comfort, ease of use, how people like them,'' Brookshire said. ``We want to make sure they are not so weird no one will use them.'' The clinic has 25 couples participating in the test, he said. Family Health International has been researching the new condom for about a year and a half, said William Schellstede, senior vice president. The company provides family planning and AIDS-prevention assistance to developing countries and is seeking a contraceptive that has a longer shelf life than latex, which can deteriorate easily if not properly stored.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Winds Up 27,500 Loser for Prank in College
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maia in lead is cq.
DOC.TEXT: When she was made the butt of Charles Hurth III's prank, Maia Brodie vowed revenge, and she got it _ taking a $27,500 bite out of his wallet. ``I feel the damages were appropriate,'' Brodie said Thursday after jurors upheld her civil lawsuit against Hurth for biting her buttocks in a bar 2{ years ago. Brodie said the reward would help ease her humiliation. She was at the bar near St. Louis University, where she studied law, in September 1987 when Hurth grabbed her hips and bit her, Brodie testified. Hurth and his friends laughed, pointed and exchanged high-fives, she said. The bite broke the skin on Brodie's buttocks, causing ``searing and throbbing pain'' so severe she couldn't sit down for three days and was unable to attend classes, said Gerald Greiman, her lawyer. Hurth, a lawyer, admitted biting Brodie but said he did not mean to hurt her and considered his action a compliment. Hurth testified he had previously bitten the buttocks of two other women at fraternity parties in 1981 and 1982 while attending Vanderbilt University. Jurors deliberated about 90 minutes after hearing two days of testimony, awarding Brodie $2,500 in actual damages and $25,000 in punitive damages. David Hoven, who represented Hurth, described Brodie's injury and the lawsuit as ``superficial,'' arguing she should be awarded only the $9 she paid for medication to prevent infection.

DOC.HEAD: Wreckage of Plane Found Off Panama; No More Survivors
DOC.TEXT: Divers recovered 10 of 20 bodies from the wreckage of a twin-engine plane 90 feet underwater off a Pacific resort island near Panama, an aviation official said. The recovery operation near Contadora Island was suspended Thursday because of darkness, Panamanian civil aviation director Jaime Fabrega said at a news conference. There was no word whether the bodies of the four Americans had been recovered. Two people, a French boy and a Swiss woman, were rescued after the Aeroperlas Twin Otter en route from Contadora to Panama City crashed shortly after takeoff Wednesday. They were in stable condition in a hospital on Thursday. Divers found the wreckage no more than a mile north of Contadora Island, aviation officials said in a statement. They said the ocean's currents carried the wreckage from the crash site, three miles south of the island. ``The plane is practically intact except for the front part'' and was found in 90 feet of water, Fabrega said. He declined to confirm the airline's statement Wednesday that birds colliding with the right engine caused the crash. ``Something happened with the right engine, but anything I would say would be mere speculation,'' he said. Fabrega said the pilot had nearly 7,000 hours of flight time, and the plane was ``in perfect condition.'' U.S. military personnel, two Blackhawk helicopters and two 65-foot boats joined Panamanian planes and rescuers in the search. The U.S. Embassy identified the Americans as Karl Heck, a Panama Canal pilot and his wife, Anita, of Panama City; Lisa Langlow, 34, originally of Washington state, and whose family lives in Fox Island, Wash.; and Richard Dobson Poux, also of Washington state. Also killed were two French citizens and 14 Panamanians, most of whom worked on the island, where the late Panamanian leader Omar Torrijos gave refuge for several months to the Shah of Iran, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, after the shah's 1979 exile.

DOC.HEAD: Army Rejects Combat Test Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The Army has rejected a suggestion for a four-year test to see how women would do in combat-related jobs. ``The Army does not feel that a test is warranted. We feel our current policy reflects the intent of Congress by excluding women from the highest risk of direct combat,'' the Army said Thursday in a statement. The proposal from a test came last fall from the Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Services, a panel founded in 1951 to advise the Department of Defense on women's issues. In its statement, the Army said its policy of barring women from direct combat is ``in line with the other services.'' ``We currently offer women full career opportunities and maintain equitable advancement in schooling and promotion selection rates,'' the Army statement said. By law, women in the Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps can not be assigned on ``vessels or in aircraft that are engaged in combat missions.'' But it is Army policy, not law, that bars women from participating in its primary fighting elements such as infantry, tank and most artillery units. As experience in the invasion of Panama showed, women do serve in many of the Army's supply or support units that could place them in the thick of battle. Last fall the committee said the limitation denies women ``hands-on experience to learn and to progress in a specialty. ... The services can ill afford to continue to limit these women and their experiences in the face of the anticipated manpower shortages of the 1990s.'' At the end of 1989, there were some 229,000 women in the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines, or 11 percent of the 2 million-strong uniformed services.

DOC.HEAD: Three Soldiers Sentenced In Bread Case
DOC.TEXT: A religious soldier has been jailed for threatening to shoot two fellow soldiers who ate bread during Passover and made scathing remarks about a leading rabbi, the army said today. The devout soldier was sentenced to 28 days in the stockade for his threat, and the other two were given 14 days each for mocking the religious beliefs of a fellow soldier, an army spokesman said. The army bars the eating of bread on bases during Passover, which commemorates the flight of the Jews from slavery in Egypt. Jews eat unleavened matzah during the eight-day holiday to symbolize the hasty escape in which the Jews did not have time to make real bread. The confrontation came at a base in central Israel where the three soldiers were talking politics, Israeli newspapers and radio reported. When the two secular soldiers criticized Rabbi Eliezer Schach and began eating bread, the religious soldier cocked his gun and threatened to shoot them, according to the reports. The two secular soldiers calmed him down, the reports said. Schach, 96, is the spiritual leader of two ultra-Orthodox political parties. He has been at the center of a controversy over whether small religious parties have too much power in Israeli politics.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Statement Released by Group Holding Americans Hostage
DOC.TEXT: This is the text of the statement released Thursday by Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. It was translated from Arabic into English by The Associated Press in Beirut.

On the occasion of the international day of Jerusalem, the organization of the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine reminds Islamic nations throughout the world of the sacred central cause and calls upon the free revolutionary strugglers to mark this day with demonstrations and parades to whip up sentiments to uproot the cancer and continue the struggle against global arrogance. This year the issue of Jewish emigration is throwing an added burden on the shoulders of revolutionaries in the whole world, prodding them to exert efforts and take measures to stop it by suicidal operations against all who participate in this matter, especially those countries offering transit facilities. The organization serves this final warning after the advice had been handed down on all those participating in this matter, especially those countries offering transit facilities. All civilians should stay away from the airports, airlines and jetliners that will be the targets for operations mounted at times we deem adequate. It cautions the revolutionary holy warriors that the principal danger which threatens them is the deviationist proposals that undermine our people's uprising _ seeking to grab the helm of the uprising's leadership while it is in fact following a policy that gives Israel peacefully what it has failed to get up till now by war. The Palestinian deviationist leaderships will not be immune from the just revenge and punishment. Our people should realize that all schemes hatched by global arrogance for elections or for the destiny of the (West) Bank and the (Gaza) sector are aimed at shielding the Zionist Nazis and finishing off the uprising. They do not intend to help our people because the criminal arrogance seeks to slaughter this struggling people and not grant it any of its rights. Let no one imagine that he can achieve anything from Hosni Mubarak or the traitor King (Hussein) or deviationist Arafat or the others. Their treason shall remain stamped in our people's memory. The hands of the strugglers will reach all of them. On this occasion, we salute our brethren in Zionist jails. We shall spare no effort to liberate them and freedom, god willing, will be soon. We single out the struggling Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, whose detention stands as a slap to the cowards. As for the release of the American hostage, arrangements had been under way on the basis that they would be concluded and finalized. But (John) Kelly's failure to respond has so far frustrated the release, which made us postpone this operation until the picture is cleared. Until then, we hope that Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan, President Assad's envoy, will head to Beirut to wrap up the issue upon arrival of Kelly in Damascus.

DOC.HEAD: Bob Hope Grants 5,600 Acres to Land Conservation Agency
DOC.TEXT: Bob Hope is donating about 1,800 acres of his mountain property and selling another 3,800 acres for $20 million to a state agency to spare the rugged canyon country from development, his attorney says. ``This is a wonderful Earth Day present from Mr. Hope to the people of California and the wildlife of the Santa Monica Mountains,'' said Carl Pope, deputy conservation director of the Sierra Club. Sunday is the 20th celebration of Earth Day, the event that kicked off the environmental crusade. The agreement signed by Hope, yet to be finalized, will open his coastal parkland to hikers and allow it to continue to serve as a corridor for migratory wildlife. The 86-year-old comedian has endured negative publicity in recent months over his sale of mountain lands to prospective developers and his refusal to consider giving or selling the land to park agencies. Hope has been acquiring land in the region for 35 years. The $20 million price tag on some 3,800 acres in the Santa Susana Mountains is below market value, Hope's lawyer, Payson Wolff, said Thursday. Most of the property lies inside Ventura County, and the rest is in Los Angeles County. ``Once again, Bob Hope has proven to be a generous supporter of the city,'' Mayor Tom Bradley said. The deal is certain to be ranked as one of the largest parklands bequests in Southern California. Wolff credited Madge Schaefer, chairman of the Ventura County Board of Supervisors, with planting the seeds in Hope's mind more than a year ago that yielded his bequest. ``I'm delighted!'' Schaefer said Thursday night. ``It took quite a bit to ask him to give one more dime, but I'm glad I did.'' Hope's contribution will help create public parklands extending from the inland Santa Clarita Valley about 50 miles out to the Pacific Ocean, Schaefer said. Wolff said Hope's change of heart came after meeting with conservationists. ``I believe that he was motivated by the sincerity of some of the real, responsible conservationists who impressed on him and convinced him the importance of having this property preserved in public parklands forever,'' Wolff said. ``The criticism that's been leveled at Mr. Hope as not being charitable, as not being a good citizen ... was counterproductive,'' Wolff said. As recently as March, Hope told The Associated Press that the criticism ``bugs the hell out of me.'' The proposed agreement would transfer more than 80 percent of the entertainer's land to the Mountains Recreation and Conservation Authority, a public agency. The centerpiece of the deal is the 4,369-acre Runkle ranch that straddles the Los Angeles-Ventura county line. The rugged property above the Santa Susana Pass includes canyons, meadows and spectacular rock formations. In addition, the agreement would put an end to plans to build a golf course and country club on land Hope owns in Corral Canyon in the seaside colony of Malibu. Hope would proceed with the sale of adjacent land to a La Jolla developer, which still proposes a scaled-down residential development.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Dies in Plane Crash on Dallas Street
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine airplane crashed on a city street early today while attempting an emergency landing just after liftoff. The pilot was killed. The pilot, apparently the only person aboard the small Beechcraft plane, radioed a distress signal to air controllers after one engine failed and was trying to return to Love Field, airport operations manager Clifford York said. The plane clipped power lines, flipped and crashed about 1 a.m. on a street adjacent to the airport, three miles northwest of downtown Dallas. Authorities said no one on the ground was injured. York said did not know the pilot's identify, and was unsure where the aircraft had been headed. A witness, Ken Helms, 19, said he was parked at a traffic light when he saw the plane in distress. ``I was going to turn right, but when the light turned green I went straight. If I'd turned right, I'd have driven right into it,'' he said. ``The plane did a 180 in the air. The plane went upside down and exploded when it hit the ground. The flames just covered the whole street.''

DOC.HEAD: Kennedys Fight Historical Status for Estate
DOC.TEXT: The Kennedys are fighting plans to designate as an historical site the seaside estate where John F. Kennedy held Cabinet meetings and played touch football on the beach with family and friends. The Kennedy clan has hired a prominent local attorney to fight Palm Beach's efforts to give official landmark status to the $3 million ``La Guerida'' compound, which served as a winter White House three decades ago. But there can be no winner in the dispute, said James Sullivan, chairman of the Palm Beach landmarks commission, which today examines the town's proposal to designate the Mediterranean revival-style mansion and its grounds. ``No matter what happens, the damage has been done,'' Sullivan said. ``The Kennedys have lost an opportunity to acknowledge the significance of a home that played such an important role in our nation's history. ``And it's a slap to the local community who have welcomed the Kennedy family for years.'' If the commission approves the landmark status, a final vote will be taken by the Town Council on June 11. Elizabeth Burden, an attorney for Kennedy family matriarch Rose Kennedy, said she will fight the historical designation on the grounds that it violated Mrs. Kennedy's right to due legal process. The estate, built in 1925 for department store mogul Redman Wanamaker, will be among more than 30 structures up for landmark consideration, Sullivan said. ``It's very, very unusual for any homeowner to fight the designation, and none have done so to the extent of the Kennedys,'' said Sullivan. ``They have spent oodles of money on this, and I really can't figure out why.'' The Kennedy family maintains it wants to retain complete control over the estate, and that might be compromised by the landmark designation. Such a designation also could make the house less marketable to others desiring to change the property. Under town ordinance, residents considering more than $2,000 worth of structural or cosmetic changes to their homes must receive approval from one of two boards. If the home is deemed a historical site, the landmarks commission must authorize the changes. Although 99-year-old Rose Kennedy no longer spends winters in Palm Beach, the estate is still used by family members, including Sen. Ted Kennedy, D-Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Australians Return to Fabled Battlefield 75 Years Later
DOC.TEXT: Forty-six Australian veterans, some over 100 years old, left today for Turkey to commemorate the World War II campaign at Gallipoli, regarded as one of the great military defeats of the war. They flew on board a specially configured Qantas Boeing 747-300 jet that included a mini-hospital staffed by Royal Australian Air Force surgeons in case any of the veterans became ill during the trip. Prime Minister Bob Hawke and other members of the government sat in the back, and the veterans traveled first-class in front of the plane. The oldest was 103, and the trip was expected to be difficult for some of the veterans, all at least 90. To break up the journey, the group was to spend 30 hours in Singapore before flying to the site of the battles. The veterans were scheduled to arrive in Istanbul on Sunday. Jack Hazlitt, 92, was a ``runner,'' _ or dispatcher of military cables _ at Gallipoli. ``We thought it was a glorious chance to see the world for nothing,'' he said. ``That attitude didn't last long. Very few of us survived. You could say I'm one of the lucky ones.'' Australia lost more than 8,000 soldiers. Most of the Australian soldiers were called ``diggers,'' and 93-year-old George Mitchell said the term developed because ``all we did (when not fighting) was to dig, dig, and dig trenches.'' The veterans will take part in ceremonies on the Gallipoli Peninsula on Wednesday to commemorate the troop landings in 1915 by Australian, New Zealand, British, French and Indian troops. In World War I, the Ottoman Turkish Empire was allied with Germany and Austria against Britain, its dominions, France and Russia. The Gallipoli Peninsula lies on the northern side of the Dardanelles Strait in northwestern Turkey. The object of the campaign, which military historians call the first combined naval and land operation of modern warfare, was to open the Turkish straits to Russia; capture Istanbul, then known as Constantinople; and take the Ottoman Empire out of the war. Gallipoli was a battleground for nine months, until the invading forces were evacuated in December 1915 and January 1916. The total casualty list for the invaders was 33,532 killed, 78,518 wounded and 7,689 missing. Of these, 8,587 Australians were killed and 19,367 wounded. The battle gave the Turks a modern hero, Kemal Ataturk, who made his name as a military genius in Gallipoli. Australia commemorates the campaign each year with a national day of remembrance for those killed in the 1914-18 War and for those who gave their lives in other wars. ``In the Australian consciousness, two things stand out about Gallipoli,'' said Bob Carr, leader of the Labor opposition in the state of New South Wales. ``First, the courage and valor of our troops, and second, that it was a defeat, a military disaster.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Close Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost ground slightly against the yen today, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange recorded a moderate decline. The dollar closed the week at 157.60 yen, down 0.15 yen from Thursday's close of 157.75 yen. After opening lower at 156.78 yen, the currency ranged between 156.73 yen and 157.75 yen. ``The dollar was bought in the afternoon session for position adjustments with the approach of the weekend,'' said Norio Takeda, a dealer of the Bank of Tokyo. Takeda said the dollar seems to be in what dealers call a ``box range,'' when the currency's movement in either direction can trigger selling or buying for profit taking, loss cutting or technical adjustment. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told a news conference this morning that he remained concerned with foreign exchange market movements despite the yen's recent recovery. ``I expect the exchange market to stabilize with the yen appreciating (against the dollar) a bit more,'' Hashimoto said. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 109.97 points, or 0.37 percent, to close the week at 29,835.44. The Nikkei index gained nearly 150 points in the early morning session. A total of 700 million shares changed hands in the first section, down from 1 billion shares Thursday. The index ``fell nearly 300 points at one point in the afternoon session'' when news that an Osaka-based retailer went bankrupt with $445 million in liabilities, said Yoshiro Inoue, an equity analyst with Nomura Securities. Inoue said the company, Pari, suffered the debt because of losses on the stock market. For the past few years many Japanese companies have earned profits by putting surplus or borrowed funds into the booming stock market, a tactic not directly related to their main business. The market's main barometer so far this year has lost 8,970.46 points, or 23 percent, from a record 38,915.87 points registered at the end of last year. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese 10-year government bond closed at 86.36 points, down from Thursday's close of 86.45.
