The yield stood at 7.290 percent, up from the previous day's close at 7.270 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Another Minor Earthquake Felt in Upland
DOC.TEXT: The latest in a nerve-wracking series of aftershocks to a Feb. 28 earthquake rattled parts of Southern California, but no injuries or damage were reported. The temblor Thursday night, centered about 5 miles west of Upland, registered 3.5 on the Richter scale, said Robert Finn, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. ``We're becoming a model city for earthquakes, you know,'' police Sgt. Dan Milakovich said. ``We must be leading the nation.'' The tremor felt in areas of San Bernardino County and eastern Los Angeles County was an aftershock of a 5.5-magnitude quake that struck near Upland on Feb. 28, Finn said. Hundreds of noticeable quakes have shuddered through the area since the Upland quake, including a 4.6-magnitude temblor and several smaller aftershocks Tuesday. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 5.5 reflects a quake 10 times as strong as one of 4.5.

DOC.HEAD: Britain To Give Passports To 225,000 Hong Kong Residents
DOC.TEXT: The British Parliament voted to guarantee citizenship to about 225,000 Hong Kong residents, but China complained today the move will hasten an exodus from the colony before the Chinese takeover in 1997. Defying predictions of possible defeat, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative administration comfortably won a House of Commons vote on the issue Thursday night. The chamber approved the bill 313-216. Supporters triumphed over opposition from right-wingers in the governing party who oppose more immigration and leaders of the socialist opposition Labor Party who called the bill elitist. Because of that allied opposition, the bill was regarded as one of the toughest legislative tests for Mrs. Thatcher's government since she took power in 1979. It now will be examined by a Commons committee, but it is virtually assured of becoming law later this year. British officials say the bill would help prevent a mass flight of residents from the colony on the southeastern coast of China. Hong Kong is suffering a crisis of confidence because of worries over what will happen once Communist China takes over. More than 1,000 people are emigrating each week, including many who are among the colony's best educated. Home Secretary David Waddington has argued that giving British citizenship to 50,000 key Hong Kong residents and their families would prevent a brain drain and maintain confidence in the colony before it reverts to China in 1997. China has said the colony can keep its capitalist economy for 50 years after the transfer, and it has pledged to allow local autonomy. A statement released today in Hong Kong by the Xinhua News Agency, which is the Chinese diplomatic mission there, said the plan would be divisive and encourage more talented people to flee the territory. In the statement, released just hours after the vote, Xinhua reiterated that Beijing regards Hong Kong Chinese as its citizens whose nationality can be determined only by its laws. It said the British plan was a scheme to have British people governing Hong Kong after 1997, but it did not elaborate. China will ``reserve the right to take appropriate measures'' in response, the statement said, again without elaborating. Labor Party leaders had told their members to vote against the bill on grounds that only Hong Kong's elite _ business people, administrators, senior police officers and others _ would be given passports. A report today from the Henley Center, an independent economic forecasting group, said such immigrants would likely fill skill shortages in Britain in the coming decade because they are professional people who speak English. The report, commissioned by the British Broadcasting Corp., was written by economics Professor Bernard Corry of London University and two other professors. It said Hong Kong immigrants ``are likely to be highly adaptable. They should thus be quickly in a position to adjust to the new labor market circumstances in which they find themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Bars, Restaurants Sue Over Alcohol Risk Signs
DOC.TEXT: Owners of restaurants and bars where alcohol is served are fighting a law forcing them to post signs warning that beer, wine and liquor can cause birth defects, addiction and intoxication. The Florida Restaurant Association filed suit Wednesday in Circuit Court challenging the constitutionality of the Hillsborough County ordinance. The restaurants were ordered to post signs warning patrons not to drink during pregnancy, before driving or while taking either prescription or non-prescription drugs. The signs were to include the postscript: ``It can be fatal.'' Attorneys for the trade group claimed the signs will cause irreparable injury to the establishments. Restaurateurs complain that the warnings are ineffective and stigmatize moderate drinkers. ``If one person reads that sign and it prevents someone from getting hurt, that sign would be worth it,'' countered Commissioner Phyllis Busansky.

DOC.HEAD: Wet Weather in Much of U.S.
DOC.TEXT: April showers were in store for much of the nation today, and rising temperatures were in the offing. When the showers clear out, forecasters predicted, temperatures would climb into the 80s and 90s in the South and into the 70s throughout the rest of the country. The south-central United States, pounded by thunderstorms Thursday, faced more of the same today. Small hail fell in parts of Nebraska and Texas on Thursday, and recent heavy rains caused some flooding in parts of Oklahoma. The National Weather Service warned that severe flooding could occur in Okmulgee County, Okla., as the Deep Fork River rose toward an expected crest Saturday of 7 feet above flood level. A flood warning also was posted for Beaver Creek in northern Texas, which was nearly 3 feet above flood stage and rising. Showers and thunderstorms Thursday extended over parts of Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico, Colorado, Wyominc, Nebraska and South Dakota. Heavy thunderstorms were expected today in the southern Plains and from eastern Texas to Missouri. Scattered showers were predicted for the South and the Tennessee Valley and from Illinois to Maine. Showers also were to prevail in the West, with thunderstorms possible across the Coast Range and the Sierra Nevada. High temperature for the nation Thursday was 91 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Pitches New Deal to Latvia, Estonia
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has offered Latvia and Estonia ``special status'' in a new Soviet confederation in a bid to prevent them from following Lithuania's secession drive, Baltic journalists and officials said. However, an Estonian government official said his republic was unlikely to back down and declared that it was ``in the same boat'' as Lithuania. The Soviet president's proposals came at separate meetings in Moscow on Thursday with leaders of the two Baltic republics. However, Endel Lippma, Estonia's minister for inter-governmental negotiations, said Gorbachev also threatened the republic with economic action and said he would not negotiate unless the Estonians rescind a declaration that their republic is an occupied independent state. The Soviets have imposed an energy embargo on Lithuania, which declared independence March 11. Estonian and Latvia have not formally declared independence but have said they want to pursue it. Gorbachev reportedly told their leaders the republics could belong to a ``confederation,'' which could imply a major concession because the Russian word is used for a loosely allied organization like the British Commonwealth. Gorbachev previously spoke only of a ``federation,'' like the United States, where the states have specific powers but the national government is strong. However, Gorbachev did not define what he meant by ``confederation,'' Lippma said. Lippma reported in a telephone interview that Gorbachev said ``if some kind of blockade has to be imposed, part of the population might get very angry and there would be bloodshed, and in that case, he would impose presidential rule.'' ``And then we would find out what occupation really is,'' Lippma added. Presidential rule can include martial law and suspension of parliament. Lippma said President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia likely will heed Gorbachev's request that parliament formally reconsider the Estonian declaration, probably on Monday. However, he said a reversal was ``very unlikely.'' ``We have no clear-cut commitment of what we would get in return if we canceled it,'' he said. ``So Estonia and Lithuania are very much in the same boat.'' Similarly, Gorbachev told President Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia and his delegation that he would not talk further if they declare independence on May 3 as planned, said Aris Yansons, Gorbunov's assistant. Gorbachev has said he believes disintegration of the Soviet Union would lead to great ethnic violence. But that danger is considered more likely in the volatile south than in the Baltic region. Gorbachev's tone with the Latvians was highly critical, said Raimons Lochmelis of the information office of the Latvian People's Front. He based that assessment on comments on the meeting by another participant, People's Front President Dainis Ivans. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov also promised that if Latvia remains in the union, he would consider the republic's demand that its draftees serve in the Soviet Army only on Latvian soil, Yansons said. Lochemelis quoted Ivans as saying they found it very difficult to persuade Gorbachev that independence is supported by most Latvians, not just a few fanatics.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Catholic Anti-Abortion Campaign Begets Problem for PR Firm
DOC.TEXT: Plans by a large New York public relations concern to direct an anti-abortion publicity campaign for the nation's Roman Catholic bishops have incited rebellion in the company's ranks. Hill & Knowlton Inc. said Thursday it will go forward with the project, despite continued protest from its workers. The bishops intend to pay the firm up to $5 million over three to five years. About one-third of the company's headquarters staff signed a letter of protest, arguing that the bishops seek to deny women a basic right. Others have complained individually, and one quit. There could be other fallout: Two minor clients have withdrawn and many others have expressed disappointment, according to dissident executives who spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of jeopardizing their careers. Playboy Enterprises Inc., which has hired Hill & Knowlton in the past, is undecided about using it again. ``Our decision will be impacted by our principles. We've been longstanding supporters of reproductive rights,'' said Playboy spokeswoman Robyn Radomski. Whatever Playboy's decision, she said, ``We feel it's regrettable that such a big powerhouse PR firm has put itself in such a bad PR situation.'' The irony, dissident executives said, is that one of Hill & Knowlton's specialties is advising companies how to avoid just such turmoil. They said its own failure could reflect poorly on the company. ``We have used extraordinarily poor judgment in our very own area of expertise,'' one said. ``The firm violated everything we would advise a client to do about consulting employees. Every basic rule was violated.'' Hill & Knowlton conceded no error. ``I don't think we've made a mistake as a firm in taking on this account,'' said John Berard, a spokesman in the company's Washington office, which will handle the work. ``We knew it was going to be controversial.'' The reaction of the company's staff was ``reflective of society,'' Berard said. He said employees are not compelled to work on projects to which they object. Although some Hill & Knowlton employees objected primarily to the company's lack of consultation with its staff, the protest letter to Chief Executive Officer Robert Dilenschneider focused on the issue of abortion itself. ``For management to seek out as well as accept an assignment whose ultimate goal is to limit our fundamental rights leaves us with a stinging sense of betrayal,'' the letter said in part. ``Our rights, it seems, mattered less than the promise of additional revenue.'' Employees said 136 out of about 400 headquarters workers signed the letter. Moreover, they said, several employees have offered to provide free public relations advice to groups that advocate abortion rights. Berard would not specify how the firm was responding to its employees' concerns, saying that was an internal matter. ``We're certainly not denying that some of our people have raised complaints,'' he said. ``We're not ignoring the comments of some of our people. And we're moving forward to service our client.'' The public relations campaign for the bishops is undefined, but is to start with a public opinion poll to gauge attitudes about abortion, then proceed with ``a classic public information effort'' seeking to promote the bishops' anti-abortion views, Berard said. A spokesman for the bishops' conference had no comment on the Hill & Knowlton controversy.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: Military Doesn't Know What's Buried At U.S. Bases
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John Glenn is pressing the Pentagon to find out how much radioactive material is buried on military bases so the government can figure out cleanup costs and the impact on base-closing plans. ``None of the three services has a complete grip on what type and how much low-level radioactive waste it has generated,'' said Glenn, D-Ohio. On Thursday, he made public a report prepared at his request by the General Accounting Office. Glenn said he wanted the auditors to figure out how much it will cost the military to deal with its waste but they didn't have enough information to even attempt an estimate. All they could say with certainty was that the cost of disposing of the waste is going to skyrocket. The Army has found that surcharges tacked onto the cost of disposing of its low-level radioactive waste over the next few years will be higher than the actual disposal cost, the senator said. ``We can't even take a guess as to what the Navy and Air Force may have to pay because they don't have accurate records,'' Glenn said.

The House Budget Committee has approved a plan that preserves spending on the super collider at more than $300 million next year _ a level that falls short of the president's request but exceeds Democratic leaders' initial recommendations. A plan backed by Democratic leaders could have brought spending on the huge particle accelerator to $278 million in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, according to Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas. But Bryant said he was able Thursday to convince Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., to restore $40 million of a proposed $60 million cut in spending on Department of Energy science projects. Had the $60 million cut gone through, Bryant said two-thirds of it _ or $40 million _ would likely have been shaved from the super collider, bringing down SSC spending from $318 million to $278 million. Under the plan approved Thursday, the SSC would receive $304 million, said Bryant, a member of the committee. The SSC spending is part of a $1.24 trillion budget for fiscal 1991 approved on a 21-14 party-line vote. Debate in the full House was scheduled for next week. The budget resolution serves as a general guide for congressional authorizing and appropriating committees.
DOC.HEAD: New Colt Rifle Prompts Call for Ban on Domestic Assault Weapons
DOC.TEXT: With a new Colt semiautomatic rifle comes pressure on President Bush to support legislation banning domestically produced assault-type weapons. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, wrote Thursday to Bush saying Colt Manufacturing Co.'s new ``Sporter, just now arriving in stores, is only slightly modified from the AR-15 assault-style rifle which Colt Industries stopped producing for the civilian market last year. Colt Manufacturing Co., the successor to the Colt Firearms Division of Colt Industries Inc., says the Sporter differs substantially from the AR-15 and is not an assault-style weapon. ``When your administration banned foreign-made assault weapons last year, I said that it was a good first step toward protecting the lives of innocent crime victims in general and law enforcement officers in particular,'' Metzenbaum wrote to Bush. ``However, the failure to take the next logical step _ to implement restrictions on American-made assault weapons _ defeats the very purpose of your initiative,'' he said. Metzenbaum urged Bush to support a crime bill now in Congress that would ban domestic assault-style weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed In Unrest, Probe Into Police Killings Ordered
DOC.TEXT: Four people were killed in black factional fighting and police units firing tear gas and shotguns clashed with protesters and broke up demonstrations, police said today. A police statement said four blacks had died in factional battles in Natal Province during the previous 24 hours, including a youth killed when police opened fire on a crowd that attacked police with firebombs and rocks. Police used shotguns, pistols, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse protesters in clashes at Katlehong, Zeerust, Smithfield, Volksrust and other areas. Police gave few details but said several clashes broke out when crowds attacked vehicles or homes belonging to black police officers. Police also reported a hand grenade was hurled at the house of a black city official in the black township of Soweto outside Johannesburg and shots fired Thursday night. No injuries were reported. Police Commissioner Lt. Gen. Johan van der Merwe said today he had ordered a full investigation into the killing of four youths by police. Police opened fire Thursday on protesters near Viljoenskroon in the Orange Free State. The African National Congress, the black political organization, denounced the killings. ``This is disgusting behavior on the part of the police and we protest most strongly,'' said ANC leader Walter Sisulu. Police said five officers fired on a crowd of about 200 blacks protesting about rent costs and other local problems. Press reports today said the dead youths ranged in age from 13 to 16. ANC officials declined to say if they would take any action over the killings. The ANC pulled out of peace talks with the white government last month after police killed at least 11 blacks in March in the township of Sebokeng when they fired on a protest march. President F.W. de Klerk this week ordered an injuiry into the Sebokeng killings. The ANC later agreed to reschedule talks with the government May 2-4 to try to clear the way for full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The ANC is demanding an end to a state of emergency as a precondition for full talks. De Klerk Thursday pledged major changes in remaining apartheid laws as part of his plan for a new constitution that would include blacks for the first time. He reiterated plans for parliament to repeal this year the Separate Amenities Act, which allows for the segregation of public facilities such as swimming pools, buses and libraries. De Klerk also pledged major changes in three other apartheid laws, including the Group Areas Act, which segregates neighborhoods by race; the Population Registration Act, which classifies all citizens by race; and the Land Acts, which confine the black majority to 13 percent of the country's land.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Wants Renewed U.S., Soviet Ties
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Albania, Eastern Europe's last hard-line Communist state, has said he wants to restore ties with the United States and the Soviet Union. Communist leader Ramiz Alia also outlined economic reforms to increase production and improve supplies, including some private farming. However, he rejected any notion of following the reforms that have ended Communist rule in most Soviet bloc countries. Alia spoke at the closing session of a Communist Central Committee meeting Tuesday. An English translation was provided by the state ATA news agency Thursday. ``We have wanted, and want, friendly relations with all the countries, irrespective of their social system,'' Alia said. ``The problem of the re-establishment of the diplomatic relations with the United States of America and the Soviet Union is on the agenda,'' Alia was quoted by ATA as saying. Although the United States and the Soviet Union have offered diplomatic relations in the past, Alia charged that Moscow and Washington were responsible for the lack of ties. He said Albania was also interested in relations with Britain. Since becoming party leader in April 1985, Alia has pursued a policy of slowly opening the country, establishing diplomatic relations with dozens of countries. Albania, a country of more than 3 million, is considered the last bastion of Stalinism. It broke with the Soviet Union in 1961 over Moscow's policy of de-Stalinization and with China in 1978 because of Beijing's perceived deviation from Marxist-Leninist tenets. In his speech, Alia said Albania also is interested in establishing diplomatic ties with the European Common Market. The Communist leader said Albania's economic reforms would in some cases link wages to production, force some companies to become self-supporting and allow prices at least partially to be determined by the market. Alia said that in an effort to increase the food supply, peasants working on cooperative farms could decide for themselves whether they prefer to work individual plots.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Testifies White Youth Confessed to Killing Black Teen-ager
DOC.TEXT: A longtime convict claimed in court that a 19-year-old man who is on trial in the murder of a black teen-ager confessed he was the triggerman. Charles Brown, 32, a self-styled jailhouse lawyer, testified Thursday that Joseph Fama confessed to the slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, 16, when they shared a cell at the Brooklyn House of Detention the night of March 22. ``I shot him, I shot him,'' Brown quoted Fama as saying. ``I can't bring the guy back.'' Brown testified that Fama hoped to get off by pleading insanity. ``My lawyer's going to take care of it. I'm going to plead insanity,'' Brown quoted Fama as saying. ``I'm going to play like I'm crazy and don't know what happened.'' Fama is on trial with Keith Mondello, 19. Both were charged with murder and face 25 years to life if convicted, Fama as the alleged triggerman and Mondello as the alleged mastermind behind a mostly white mob that left the black teen-ager dead in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. Brown testified that he passed on the information about Fama to repay a favor to a prosecutor. The favor was not explained in court. Hawkins and three of his friends, all black, were accosted by the mob of bat-wielding youths last Aug. 23 when they went to mostly white Bensonhurst to look at a used car. Last October, Brown testified for Brooklyn prosecutors in another case, telling jurors that an inmate at Rikers Island, Frank DeChirico, confessed to him that he had shot a young art student during a mugging in September 1988. DeChirico was convicted of murdering Judith Anne Wrappe. In the Bensonhurst trial, Phyllis D'Agata testified Thursday that she was looking out a window of her second-floor apartment when she saw Mondello walk by with a bat and what appeared to be a gun shortly before Hawkins was slain. ``Inside his waistband, I saw a gun,'' Ms. D'Agata said. ``I didn't exactly see a gun. I saw an outline of a gun.'' Defense lawyers blame Mrs. D'Agata's daughter, Gina Feliciano, for the attack, saying she invited a group of her black and Hispanic friends to attend her 18th birthday party at her apartment. The mob mistook Hawkins and his pals for Miss Feliciano's friends and considered them to be troublemakers, defense lawyers say. Opening arguments began this week after two weeks of jury selection. Testimony was to continue today.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Generally Stronger, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against most major currencies in European trading this morning but was weaker against the Japanese yen. Gold was higher in light trading. The dollar closed in Tokyo today at 157.60 yen, down 0.15 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar fetched 157.50 yen. ``The dollar was bought in the afternoon session for position adjustments with the approach of the weekend,'' said Norio Takeda, a dealer at the Bank of Tokyo. Takeda said the dollar seemed to be in what dealers call a ``box range,'' when the currency's movement in either direction can trigger selling or buying for profit taking, loss cutting or technical adjustment. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.6811 West German marks, up from 1.6755 _1.4835 Swiss francs, up from 1.4815 _5.6485 French francs, up from 5.6325 _1.8890 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8820 _1,235.00 Italian lire, up from 1,231.25 _1.1615 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1618 The British pound was quoted at $1.6420, compared to $1.6448 late Thursday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $376.80 per ounce this morning, up from $376.55 per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $376.75, up from $376.25 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped 11 cents an ounce to close at $377.69 an ounce. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $5.085 a troy ounce, down from $5.10 per ounce late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Beirut Battles
DOC.TEXT: Shiite Moslem militiamen vying for leadership of the country's largest religious sect battled overnight in west Beirut, and Christian forces clashed in the city's eastern sector, police said today. They said five people were killed and 12 wounded in the Shiite violence, which also engulfed Iqlim el-Tuffah, or the Apple Province, above the southern port city of Sidon. The latest casualties raised the overall toll to 23 killed and 83 wounded since fighting between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal, Arabic for hope, broke out Monday. Fighting in the Moslem sector of Beirut eased after Syrian soldiers moved in and separated the combatants before dawn. But fierce battles raged in the south, police said. The two factions have been fighting intermittently for two years for dominance of the 1.2 million-member Shiite community, the largest of Lebanon's 17 sects. By police count, about 1,000 people were killed and 3,000 wounded in previous Amal-Hezbollah clashes. Police also said four people were wounded in intermittent skirmishes in east Beirut between troops loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces Christian militia. The inter-Christian showdown started Jan. 30 in Lebanon's 310-square-mile Christian enclave, which includes east Beirut and the surrounding hinterlands. That fighting has killed 893 people and wounded 2,392. It has forced about 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million residents to flee. Schools across Beirut, displaying rare unity, observed a daylong strike today to protest an attack on a school bus in which 11 children were burned to death. Three teachers and the bus driver also were killed in Wednesday's attack, and 10 others were wounded. The bus was carrying the children across the city's Christian-Moslem Green Line when it was hit in the Christian sector by an incendiary rifle grenade and caught fire. Aoun's command blamed the attack on the Lebanese Forces militia. The militia command blamed Aoun's troops.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Discord prevails in a planned name-change for an organization of women barbershop singers that no longer wants to be known as Sweet Adelines Inc. The group, which claims 30,000 members in a dozen countries, wants to be called Harmony International Corp., but an unrelated harmony group called Harmony Inc. has filed a lawsuit seeking to halt the change, saying the names would be too similar. The lawsuit, filed April 13 in U.S. District Court in Milwaukee, wants a judge to order the Sweet Adelines to remove a sign boasting the new name in front of its Tulsa headquarters. Officials of the Sweet Adelines say a trademark search was conducted after the board of directors voted for the name change in June 1989. Its application with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office is pending. Sharon Green, director of accounting at the Sweet Adelines' Tulsa office, said the group plans to pursue the name change. ``We feel like we're on fairly solid ground,'' Ms. Green said. The Sweet Adelines' lawyer, Joe Fulton, said the sign will not be changed unless a judge orders it changed. Sweet Adelines claims 651 chapters in countries that include New Zealand, Japan and Canada. The group was founded in 1945 for women who wanted to experience the bliss of barbershop harmony. Last month, Jorja Jacobs, communications director for the Sweet Adelines, said the group has come a long way since its founding and the adoption of the name from Harry Armstrong's 1903 song, ``You're the Flower of My Heart, Sweet Adeline.'' ``Some people don't think Sweet Adelines indicates what our organization is about,'' Ms. Jacobs said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS New York-dated fourth item in PM-Names to CORRECT spelling to Katharine, sted Katherine.
DOC.TEXT: Actress Katharine Hepburn has begun writing her memoirs and expects to be finished about August. ``I am full of prayer and hope it will be interesting,'' she said Thursday in a telephone interview from her Manhattan townhouse. She declined to give details of the book, tentatively titled ``Me.'' The book will be released in 1991, publishing house Alfred A. Knopf announced. The 80-year-old Miss Hepburn, whose ``The Making of the African Queen: How I Went to Africa with Bogart, Bacall and Huston and Almost Lost My Mind'' was published in 1987, said she usually starts writing about 7 in the morning. ``As long as I can think, I write,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: College Student Reports Assault by Four Schoolmates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors plan to seek indictments against four male students at St. John's University in the alleged sexual assault of a female student, a published report said. As many as three of the four students are members of the university's lacrosse team, New York Newsday reported today. The incident reportedly occurred March 1 at a house near the university in the borough of Queens, where the woman had gone with another student. Though her story varied, the woman basically said she had oral sex with the one student, and that several others sodomized her while others looked on, according to Newsday and the New York Post. At one point, the woman told authorities she heard the men saying, ``Let's get the video cameras and the condoms,'' but another student stepped in and stopped them. The woman reported the incident to the university on March 9 and the university notified police March 30.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Halts Appeals, Execution Scheduled for Saturday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to add that execution date was Butler's first. Subs final graf with 2 grafs to delete redundant age and add background.
DOC.TEXT: A murderer scheduled for execution Saturday has ordered a halt to his appeals after spending half his life behind bars, saying he wants to ``get it ver with.'' Jerome Butler, whose age is listed in prison records as 54 but claims to be several years older, has been on death row since November 1986 for the robbery and murder that June of a Houston taxi driver. Since last month, when his first execution date was set, Butler has refused to let lawyers file motions that could spare him from lethal injection. ``I just want to get it over with,'' Butler said at that time. ``They could take these cuffs off me and walk me back to (death row) and I still won't resist. There won't be no appeals.'' Bob Walt, an assistant attorney general, said Thursday that Butler did not appear to be backing down. Vic Pecorino, one of Butler's lawyers, said he had no plans to go ahead with legal efforts to spare Butler's life against his wishes. ``I think it's pretty clear and I don't think it's up to us to go ahead'' with appeals, Pecorino said. Butler, convicted of shooting Nathan Oakley, has been in and out of prison since 1959. Butler would be the 34th inmate executed in Texas and the 122nd nationally since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty. The last execution in Texas was Dec. 7.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Says Hostage Release Certain Despite Delay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Musawi quote, background. Edits to trim. Changes byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Shiite Moslem leader reputed to have influence with kidnappers holding three Americans said today the release of one captive is certain despite a ``cowboy mentality'' on the part of the United States. Hussein Musawi, who heads a pro-Syrian wing within the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, said in a telephone interview: ``The delay is certain, the complications are certain, but the release is also certain.'' On Thursday, pro-Iranian kidnappers said they would postpone indefinitely freeing an American hostage. Musawi said the delay was caused by Washington's rejection of the kidnappers' key demand _ that Assistant Secretary of State for the Near East John Kelly fly to Damascus, Syria, to finalize the release. ``But Kelly's failure to respond is not going to cancel the release. The hostage might be released in another manner, maybe dialogue. I cannot speculate further. I can't lie,'' Musawi said. Asked when he expected the release to take place, he said: ``That depends on how farsighted the Americans might become. So far, their behavior is arrogant and one of cowboy mentalty.'' ``If someone decides to return a hostage, the other side is supposed to take the hostage,'' Musawi said. Syria said late Thursday that it was working to secure the release of a hostage by this weekend. Musawi heads Islamic Amal, or Islamic hope, a faction within Hezbollah that advocates strong links with Syria. He is believed to be the mentor of the underground Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. The group holds professors Alann Steen, a native of Boston, who turns 51 on Sunday; Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho; and Robert Polhill, 55, of New York. The three were kidnapped from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987, by gunmen posing as riot police. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said Wednesday it would free a hostage by this evening if the United States met its conditions. But it announced Thursday that it was postponing its plans after the United States refused to dispatch Kelly. President Bush said: ``The United States does not knuckle under to demands.'' As ambassador to Lebanon during the Reagan administration, Kelly was involved in secret discussions with the White House on negotiations for the release of American hostages in return for arms sales to Iran. Kelly now is U.S. assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs. Peggy Say, the sister of American hostage Terry Anderson, said she was ``totally puzzled by the attitude of reluctance to move forward and get on with this. If they want John Kelly, send them John Kelly.'' M.T. Mehdi, president of the American-Arab Relations Committee in New York, said in a statement that the United States ``fumbled'' an opportunity to help gain freedom for a hostage. Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa expressed optimism late Thursday, however. He said his government had ``been exerting a great deal of influence'' to secure a release by Sunday. He would not elaborate. He spoke amid a series of meetings with the U.S. ambassador to Syria, Edward Djerejian. Djerejian, who had been at a diplomatic meeting in West Germany with Kelly, flew to Damascus Thursday. He did not speak with reporters. Syria and Iran have urged kidnappers to end the hostage crisis and free the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon. The announcement by the kidnappers that they would release one captive implied some sort of exchange was involved, and the communique was accompanied by an instant photograph of Turner, the first of him alone since three months after his abduction. The statement announcing the postponement was accompanied by an instant photograph of Polhill. The group also renewed threats to attack jetliners and airports used to transport thousands of Soviet Jewish emigrants to Israel. Much of the 500-word statement released Thursday was devoted to the rising number of Jewish emigrants, who Arab leaders say could strengthen Israel and displace Palestinians in the occupied territories. ``As for the release of the American hostage, arrangements had been under way on the basis that they would be concluded and finalized,'' the statement said. ``But Kelly's failure to respond has so far frustrated the release, which made us postpone this operation until the picture is cleared,'' it said. A senior U.S. official said Kelly's participation would have engaged the United States in hostage negotiations or at least given that appearance. The release would have been the first of an American since David Jacobsen, director of the American University hospital, was freed on Nov. 2, 1986, after more than 17 months in captivity. Eight Americans are among the Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian groups. The longest-held is Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Political Asylum for Chinese Hijacker
DOC.TEXT: A court today rejected an appeal for political asylum from a Chinese man accused of hijacking a Chinese airliner to Japan, lawyers said. If a final appeal to the justice minister fails, Zhang Zhenhai, 36, of China's Hebei province, will be extradited to China and could face execution, one of his lawyers said after the Tokyo High Court's decision was announced. In a statement released through his lawyers in January, Zhang said the hijacking was a last-ditch attempt to flee political persecution following his involvement in pro-democracy protests in Beijing last spring. Chinese authorities crushed the student-led protests in Beijing's Tiananmen square. Police said Zhang hijacked the plane on Dec. 16, threatening to blow it up with a bomb he did not actually have. The Boeing 747, on a flight from Beijing to New York with 233 people aboard, flew to Fukuoka in southwestern Japan after South Korea refused to let it land there. After landing, Zhang was shoved out of the plane by a crew member and hospitalized with a broken pelvis. The plane was returned to China on Dec. 17 with 208 passengers on board, including Zhang's wife and 13-year-old son. Yaeko Takeoka, one of three Japanese lawyers representing Zhang, said she was ``shocked that despite the evidence that Mr. Zhang was actively involved in the Tiananmen protests, they ruled against him.'' A pro-democracy activist, Yue Wu, testified during the trial that he had met Zhang three times in Beijing during the protests. Yue escaped China after the crackdown and was granted asylum in France. Prosecutors maintained, however, that Zhang was not involved in anti-government activities and that he hijacked the aircraft to escape criminal charges in China and seek work in Japan. China demanded that Zhang, who has been in police custody since Dec. 31., be returned to stand trial. China's state-run television has carried reports on the hijacking that said Zhang had been arrested in October on charges of embezzling from a factory. Chinese authorities have executed hijackers in the past. Ms. Takeoka said Zhang's lawyers were filing an appeal to the justice minister. However, she said she thought it would be difficult to overturn the decision on his extradition. Zhang's Japanese lawyers also said today's decision indicated the Japanese legal system was still slow in recognizing human rights. The Japan branch of the London-based human rights group Amnesty International said in a statement it was ``deeply concerned'' about the court's decision. It made an appeal to Justice Minister Shin Hasegawa. A Foreign Ministry official, however, defended the decision. Zhang ``should be tried for the hijacking. There is no evidence suggesting that he is a political refugee,'' ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said.

DOC.HEAD: Shops Close for Ramadan Strike in Occupied Lands
DOC.TEXT: Shops and offices were closed in the West Bank and Gaza Strip today in a strike called by Islamic fundamentalists who lead the uprising against the Israeli occupation. PLO-backed leaders of the Palestinian uprising also called for new tactics in the 28-month-old revolt, including using general strikes as ``confrontation days with Israeli authorities.'' ``Confrontation days'' typically include increased stone-throwing, blocking roads, slogan writing and anti-Israeli demonstrations. In the past, most Palestinians have stayed home during strikes, often making them calmer than other days in the occupied territories. During today's strike, which coincided with the final Friday of the Moslem fasting month of Ramadan, the Islamic fundamentalist movement Hamas, or Zeal, allowed taxis and buses to operate so they could carry Moslems to prayer services. The strike also closed businesses in Arab east Jerusalem. The call for ``tactical changes'' in the revolt against Israeli occupation came in a leaflet issued Thursday by the Unified Leadership of the Uprising. Among the new tactics is a call for Palestinians to turn out their lights for 15 minutes on May 5 to protest the continued closure of Palestinian universities. On April 28, drivers were asked to halt their vehicles and honk their horns for five minutes to show solidarity with Arabs deported by Israel. New modes of protest had been demanded by the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, which accused the united leadership of complacency and threatened to break away. The Marxist front and other factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which back the leadership, issued a joint statement earlier this week promising a change in tactics. The latest leaflet also called for new controls in dealing with Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israel. At least 207 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs since the start of the uprising, most on suspicion of informing on uprising activists. The leaflet said collaborators should be ostracized socially but there should be no killings without ``special orders issued by high-ranking circles.'' Aside from the collaborator deaths, Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed 674 Palestinians in the uprising, and 43 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Wins Vote of Confidence, Delivers Impassioned Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with Walesa winning confidence vote. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa won an overwhelming vote of confidence from Solidarity at the union's second national congress today after delivering an impassioned defense of his 10 years as the movement's leader. On the congress' second day and just 24 hours before an expected re-election bid, Walesa asked for a show of support. Delegates present responded with a vote of 357 in favor, one against and 22 abstentions. Walesa's earlier impromptu address highlighted internal tensions in the movement that weathered repression and toppled the Communist government since it last met as a whole in 1981. ``The victory I am giving to you, the mistakes are ours ... But all the mistakes we made, you should correct here and today,'' he said.. ``I did this only for Poland, not for myself ... It was our mutual victory ... I was only the driver.'' Walesa, still immensely important in Poland despite some slippage in popularity polls, accepted the vote of confidence with his arms extended in the traditional Solidarity V for victory. The crowd chanted the fond diminutive of his first name: ``Lechu, Lechu, Lechu.'' Walesa is to run for re-election as union chairman Saturday. He was likely to retain control of Solidarity as it struggles to decide how much of a union and how much of a political force it will be in post-Communist Poland. Parliament member Andrzej Malachowski appealed to fellow delegates to end intrigue saying, ``Stop it, please. Lech Walesa has well served the fatherland.'' Walesa called for the confidence vote in a second speech after delegates criticized his morning address. One delegate said it had served ``only to raise the temperature of emotions.'' The scheduled six-day meeting is being held in the same Olivia sports hall where the union met for 18 stormy days in the autumn of 1981. Communist authorities declared military rule to crush Solidarity only two months later, forcing the union into an eight-year battle to regain legal status and worker rights. Recalling how he led Solidarity's founding during a 1980 Gdansk shipyard strike, Walesa said today: ``It was just my luck that I jumped over the shipyard fence. But you liked my jump and that is why you chose me to lead this vehicle called Solidarity.'' ``From the begining ... Driving this vehicle was very hard,'' he said. ``Today, after 10 years of experience we still have trouble.'' Several times during the speech he acknowledged making mistakes. ``I thank all who worked together with me and against me. I apologize to all those I offended,'' he concluded. Before Walesa's speech, the congress voted to admit as non-voting guests all members of the 1981 union leadership not among the 487 elected delegates. Included were several who have broken with the mainstream of Solidarity. In the past, some accused Walesa of undemocratic rule. Others opposed any compromise with the former Communist government, including the negotiations that led to June's partly free elections and last fall's installation of the first non-Communist government in the East bloc. Walesa threatened to leave the hall if certain members of the former leadership showed up, although he did not specify who he meant. ``I will leave this meeting for all the offense, for distruction of the union, for talking about losing (ideals). I will not sit with those gentlemen at the same table,'' he said, to applause from the hall. Walesa then declined to offer the scheduled report on the union's activities since the last congress, and turned the microphone over to someone ``not so emotionally linked,'' Janusz Palubicki, a longtime Solidarity leader. Palubicki recounted the battle to preserve Solidarity amid jailings of its leaders and thousands of supporters, confiscation of equipment and public attacks by Communist authorities. Even as it faces deep questions about its future, Solidarity launched the congress Thursday celebrating its triumphs. Present for the first day was Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, once imprisoned for his Solidarity activism. The union regained legal status only on April 17, 1989, then after the June elections took control of the government. But Solidarity has managed to sign up only 2.2 million of the 10 million members it had in 1981. Opinion polls show confidence dropping as the public undergoes economic hardships associated with the strict austerity program being pursued by the Solidarity-created government. Economic restructuring is forcing plant closures and raising unemployment among the industrial workers who comprise the backbone of Solidarity. The delegates are expected to debate how much they want Solidarity to be confined to union issues, decide whether to create a Solidarity-linked political party and draw up a union program before the congress closes Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: New Lists of War Criminals for U.S., Australia, Germany
DOC.TEXT: A group hunting Nazi war criminals said today it will give the United States, West Germany and Australia the names of 223 Lithuanians and Poles believed to have taken part in the murder of nearly 200,000 Jews in World War II. Efraim Zuroff, Israel director of the Los Angeles-based Simon Wiesenthal Center, said the names were among 1,284 mentioned in documents given last year by Leibl Kunichowsky, an elderly Holocaust suvivor who now lives in Sunrise, Fla., to the archives of the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial. Kunichowsky, a civil engineer who lived in Kaunas, Lithuania, went from refugee camp to refugee camp in 1945-49, taking testimony from survivors. Each statement was signed and witnessed. Unlike other areas of Europe, where Jews died mainly in Nazi gas chambers, the interviews show that many of the Jews in Lithuania were shot by local partisans, Zuroff said. ``They weren't deported to death camps,'' he said. ``They were murdered locally, and the collaborators played an extremely significant role, often carrying out the killing themselves.'' The lists name Nazi collaborators suspected of taking part in the murder of nearly 200,000 Jews, he said. So far, Zuroff said, researchers have carefully examined only half of Kunichowsky's list. He said there was a chance of prosecuting only about one-third of the suspects because many have died, others are too old to stand trial, and some cannot be traced because full names and other details are missing. ``What we will be able to achieve (in bringing some to trial) is only symbolic justice which will serve as a warning to the murderers of tomorrow,'' he said. Zuroff said the names of 38 prime suspects will be sent to the U.S. Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations next week. The names of 130 other suspected collaborators will be turned over to the West German Embassy and 55 will be given to the Australian Embassy on Monday. Other lists of names will be sent soon to Canada and England. Kunichowsky had kept his material in hopes of writing a book, but he turned the documents over to Yad Vashem last year. The Weisenthal center researchers cross-checked the names with other records at Yad Vashem and files from an International Red Cross tracing service in West Germany. Some of those listed were already known as war crimes suspects, but most were new, Zuroff said. He said the names would not be made public so as not to tip off the suspects and because in some cases further investigation is needed to establish identity. The 1,683 pages of testimony were taken in Yiddish, the day-to-day language of many European Jews, and contain graphic accounts of the terror faced by 171 Jewish communities that were uprooted.

DOC.HEAD: Networks and Toons Team To Fight Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that only the three major networks simultaneously carry presidential speeches and press conferences, add that the industry cooperation is unprecedented. Picks up 4th graf ``They want...'.
DOC.TEXT: Bugs Bunny, Alf and the Slimer share an honor usually reserved for the president: They're appearing simultaneously on NBC, CBS and ABC. Four cable networks also will show the Toon talk at the same time. The TV program granted these State-of-the-Unionlike privileges is titled ``Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue,'' a half-hour special warning youngsters about drug and alcohol abuse. In what participants call an unprecedented show of industry cooperation, the networks, cable channels and more than 200 independent stations will show the program Saturday morning. ``They want to be able to reach every single kid who watches television, and we know from experience with kids that the way to grab their attention is to use characters they know to convey a story and a message,'' said Phyllis Tucker Vinson, NBC vice president for children's programming. The participating cable networks are Black Entertainment Television, the Disney Channel, Nickelodeon and the USA Network. Ted Turner's TBS and TNT cable networks, and Lifetime also will run the program, but at different times. ``All-Stars,'' which will have no commercials, tells the story of Michael, a 14-year-old drug abuser who is saved with help from Bugs Bunny, Garfield, the Chipmunks, Alf, Slimer, and other cartoon characters familiar to children. George C. Scott provides the voice of Smoke, a sinister, drug-pushing apparition. The program, financed with nearly $2 million from McDonald's Corp. and its charities, was produced under the auspices of the Los Angeles-based Academy of Television Arts and Science. In a speech in Los Angeles last month, President Bush praised the show and said that ``the days when popular culture glorified and glamorized drug use are fading fast.'' A 15-minute preview Thursday in Washington won applause from members of Congress _ with a hint of skepticism. ``I hope this doesn't devolve into a mere self-promotion activity in which we finally hear from Hollywood and this is the final shot,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich. ``Showing this once or twice isn't really going to change anybody's mind who's going to use drugs.'' Vinson, in a phone interview from her NBC office in Burbank, Calif., said there have been no discussions yet for further programs. ``We have not talked about it,'' she said. ``I think it will depend on what the reaction to this show is. But of course, there are other subjects that we could get involved in.'' Vinson, who has four children and expects her fifth next month, said she plans to watch the cartoon with her two oldest children ``and then I'll talk about it with them. I hope a lot of parents do that.'' Because the show is unsponsored, it won't be rated by the A.C. Nielsen Co., she said. ``I wish it were, so that we could tell how many kids were watching,'' she said. The show's Saturday air times in the different time zones are 10:30 a.m. EDT, 9:30 a.m. CDT, 8:30 a.m. MDT, and 9:30 a.m. PDT, according to the academy.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Urges Gun Club To Call Off Shooting of Prairie Dogs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to replace outdated summary line.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Roy Romer urged a gun club to call off a prairie dog shooting contest that has drawn protest from animal rights groups. Romer said he lacks the power to stop the July 14-15 event, billed as the ``Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot,'' but argued that ``it is wrong to make a spectacle of the killing of prairie dogs.'' Participants will compete in 50 two-member teams and attempt to kill the most praire dogs at the greatest distrance. The contest is to take place on private farms and ranches around Naturita and Nucla, two hamlets in western Colorado about 100 miles south of Grand Junction, organizers said. Hours before the governor made his announcement Thursday, U.S. Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, D-Colo., accused him of dodging the controversy. Romer had said Wednesday he wouldn't try to stop the event because it is a local issue. ``To think people would turn it into a bloody circus is macabre,'' said Campbell from Washington. ``I know it's an election year, but Roy should think about this again. This is something he should take a stand on.'' Stan Austin, one of the organizers, said of Romer's stance, ``Well, those things happen. We realize there are people on both sides of this issue.'' Austin said he doesn't understand how the contest could be regarded as a circus. ``It's a group of sportsmen competing,'' he said. ``I believe it's more humane to kill them with a rifle than poison.'' Residents of the area complain that prairie dogs multiply rapidly and create burrows in which cattle can break their legs. They also damage irrigation systems in a state where water is at a premium. Wide poisoning is banned by the federal government because the poison can be picked up by eagles and other predators of prairie dogs. An animal rights activist said the contest is promoting ``killing for killing's sake.'' ``I'm a vegetarian, but I have respect for people who eat what they kill,'' said Robin Duxbury, president of the Rocky Mountain Humane Society. ``But these people aren't hunting for any reason. I don't know anyone who eats prairie dog stew.''

DOC.HEAD: TMI Fuel Shipments Completed
DOC.TEXT: The process of shipping damaged nuclear fuel from the Three Mile Island reactor to the U.S. Energy Department's Idaho National Engineering Laboratory is completed. Officials at TMI said the final shipment, 20 canisters packed in three specially designed rail shipping casks, arrived at the laboratory Thursday. Since July 1986, 300,000 pounds of fuel and debris were shipped by rail from TMI to Idaho Falls in 22 trips. The operation cost the plant operator, GPU Nuclear Corp., $23 million, said spokeswoman Mary Wells. Scientists at the laboratory are studying the fuel to better understand the effects of the March 1979 accident at Three Mile Island, in which a combination of mechanical and operator errors allowed the radioactive core to overheat and partially melt. Workers are continuing to decontaminate the plant, and GPU Nuclear and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission are working on details of putting it into long-term monitored storage.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Musawi Interview on Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts of a telephone interview by The Associated Press with Hussein Musawi, a Lebanese Shiite Moslem leader believed to be the mentor of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. On freeing hostages: ``The delay is certain, the complications are certain, but the release is also certain.'' On the timing: ``That depends on how farsighted the Americans might become. So far, their behavior is arrogant and one of cowboy mentality.'' Also, ``If someone decides to return a hostage, the other side is supposed to take the hostage.'' Commenting on the U.S. refusal to send State Department official John Kelly to Damascus: ``... Kelly's failure to respond is not going to cancel the release. The hostage might be released in another manner, maybe dialogue. I cannot speculate further. I can't lie.'' Musawi spoke from his headquarters in east Lebanon's ancient town of Baalbek.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Crew and Families Remember 47 Killed in Blast
DOC.TEXT: The crew of the USS Iowa lined the rails of the battleship as families of the 47 sailor killed in a gun turret explosion came together on the anniversary of the tragedy. More than 300 family members attended Thursday's memorial service aboard the World War II battleship at the Norfolk Naval Base. The ceremony ended with the dedication of a plaque mounted on gun turret No. 2, where the explosion occurred. Capt. Fred P. Moosally, commander of the Iowa, praised the families for their support. ``There are many of the families of our fallen shipmates themselves, who realized that the crew was as much a victim as they were, and who, despite their own personal sacrifice, lovingly offered their own special support and encouragement,'' he said. The memorial service to mark the April 19, 1989, explosion was private but the Navy released copies of remarks. Among those attending was Kathy Kubicina, sister of the Iowa sailor accused by the Navy of causing the blast. Seven weeks after the explosion in gun turret No. 2, the Iowa left for six months in the Mediterranean, and Moosally said he and the crew were encouraged by the letters from the families. ``They lifted us up when we were down. They gave us understanding when we were being categorized in neat little sound bites. They helped us feel that we were not alone,'' he said. Likewise, the crew has remembered the families. Robert Jones of Newport News, whose son Brian died in the explosion, spoke before the ceremony of four Iowa sailors who drove all night from Norfolk to be at his son's burial in Kennesaw, Ga. ``Today, the loss of my son hangs deep within me, just as I know it does in the hearts of the 46 other families who lost their sons,'' Jones said. ``But when I am feeling low, I think of those four Iowa sailors, my son's shipmates, and what they did for us on that sad day almost a year ago. ``It is a memory that will remain with me forever,'' he said. Questions still remain about the explosion during gunnery exercises off the coast of Puerto Rico. A five-month Navy investigation concluded the explosion was sabotage by Gunner's Mate Clayton Hartwig, who died in the blast. A subcommittee of the House Armed Services committee held hearings and found the Navy's conclusion was not supported by the facts. Hartwig's sister and other families are trying to get the investigation reopened. Kreig Brusnahan, an attorney representing the Hartwigs and two other families, said his clients are considering suing the Navy. Some of the families are trying to get the Navy to donate the battleship for a museum. The ship is expected to be retired later this year. ``As far as I'm concerned, the ship belongs to us,'' said John Hague of La Mesa, N.M., whose stepson, Lt. j.g. Philip Buch, died in the explosion.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Calls For Summit on Jewish Immigration to Israel
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Liberation Organization today appealed for an emergency Arab summit to discuss the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel and what it called Western threats against Iraq. Azzam al-Ahmed, the PLO's representative in Baghdad, told The Associated Press that the 15-man Executive Committee met in an overnight session under chairman Yasser Arafat. He said the committee agreed that an emergency Arab summit was necessary ``to confront the influx of Soviet Jews, Israeli threats against Iraq and to esclate the Intefadeh,'' or Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation which has raged since December 1987. Western reports have suggested that Iraq is trying to build nuclear weapons. Iraq and other Arab countries said the reports were part of a campaign aimed at preparing international public opinion for an attack on Iraq. The official Iraqi News Agency said Arafat and the PLO officials supported Iraq's threat last week to use chemical weapons against Israel if it is attacked by Israel. The news agency quoted Arafat as calling the warning ``an assurance of a long-awaited Arab deterence in the face of Israeli arrogance and American hegemony.'' The Executive Committee authorized Arafat to contact Arab leaders on the need to convene the emergency Arab summit soon. Arafat arrived on Thursday from Amman, Jordan, where he discussed with King Hussein the Arab summit issue. He is expected to fly to Saudi Arabia on Saturday for similar talks with King Fahd. Arabs fear that thousands of Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel will settle in the occupied territories captured from Israel's Arab neighbors. They fear that the influx will lead to a forced exodus of Palestinians to Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Former German Communist Chief Criticizes Unification Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Communists walking out, Soviet comment; CORRECTS Parliament debate to today, sted Thursday; ADDS quotes; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The head of East Germany's former Communist Party today criticized the new government's plan for unification and said it would allow the country to be colonized by West Germany. Gregor Gysi, a respected lawyer who took over the battered Communist Party after its hard-line leaders were ousted last year, said both Germanys should instead work together to build a new nation. In Bonn, a spokesman for the West German government said the Soviet Union also has expressed misgivings about the quick unification that both Germanys favor. Lawmakers today debated the unification plans of the coalition government led by Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, whose Cabinet includes most of the major political factions in Parliament. There was wide support for much of de Maiziere's plans for a fast unification, but some opposition lawmakers said it gives East Germany too little say in creating a unified Germany. Gysi told fellow members of Parliament that East Germans must have a chance to ``go upright into unification.'' Gysi leads a reformed Communist Party now called the Party for Social Democracy, which finished third in East Germany's first free elections on March 18. His delegation walked out of the session after a member of the arch-conservative German Social Union, Joachim Hubertus Nowack, linked the new Communists to the former hard-line regime and compared that government to the Nazi dictatorship preceding it. Earlier, Gysi criticized the method under which East Germany would merely adopt the constitution of West Germany. He backed instead a much slower form of unification under which the constitutions of both nations would be abolished and new laws written for a united Germany. The present form backed by the de Maiziere government would amount to little more than annexation and ``colonization,'' Gysi said. But Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl denounced a slower process and said the nation should brook ``no more socialist experiments.'' Wolfgang Thierse of the left-leaning Social Democrats, who have joined de Maiziere's government, said the quicker process is ``the realistic way'' to unity. East Germany's economy is in shambles and, in the March elections voters overwhelmingly backed leaders advocating quick unification with the wealthy West. West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel confirmed reports Bonn had received a message from Moscow expressing misgivings about quick unification of the Germanys. West German media also reported last week that Kremlin officials had contacted de Maiziere and told him they opposed the quick method because it would allow East Germany to be integrated into NATO. East Germany now is in the Warsaw Pact. Also today, the head of the Department of Defense and Disarmament, Rainer Eppelmann, was quoted as saying he favors reducing the East German army from 135,000 members to about 50,000 and later eliminating the force entirely. Eppelmann spoke to the Express newspaper in Cologne, West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Married To The Mob?
DOC.TEXT: The son and future daughter-in-law of reputed mob boss John Gotti have applied for a marriage license for their wedding, according to New York Newsday. The next member of the Gotti clan is Kim Albanese, of whom little is known except that she lives on Long Island, according to today's editions of Newsday and the New York Post. She's tying the knot with John A. Gotti, son of the ``Teflon Don.'' The two went to Queens Borough Hall on Thursday to apply for the license, Newsday said. Law enforcement officials have alleged that the younger Gotti joined the mob last year. He is 26 and is said to be president of a Brooklyn trucking company; he has been arrested several times in bar fights. His father is reputedly head of the Gambino organization, which authorities say is the nation's most powerful crime family. The plans for Saturday's wedding remain shrouded in secrecy. The Daily News reported previously that nuptials at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Howard Beach would be followed by a reception for 200 people at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in Manhattan. ``I am not going to comment about any wedding plans that may or may not be upcoming,'' said attorney Bruce Cutler, who represents Gotti's father. ``I have nothing to say. No dice,'' said the pastor of Our Lady of Grace Church.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets AIDS Virus After Being Inseminated With Infected Husband's Sperm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that means of transmission can't be proven because couple also having sex and CORRECT erroneous reference to man getting AIDS through blood transmission; source not certain although hemophiliacs have become infected through contaminated blood-clotting products. Picks up 5th graf, `There are...'. Minor editing elsewhere.
DOC.TEXT: The wife of a hemophiliac with AIDS became infected with the deadly virus after undergoing artificial insemination in an effort to conceive a child, officials say. The national Centers for Disease Control said fertility specialists had attempted to remove the virus from the husband's sperm through separation and filtration, but the woman tested positive for the virus in January after inseminations last August, October and December. She did not get pregnant. How the woman became infected with AIDS can never be proven, but the couple was using condoms during sex and did not engage in oral or anal sex, which are high AIDS-risk behaviors, the CDC said Thursday. The husband, a hemophilia patient, had tested positive for AIDS infection since 1985; many hemophilia patients became infected in the first years of the AIDS epidemic through contaminated blood-clotting products. ``There are thousands of couples in this situation, and many of them are actively seeking some way of inseminating safely,'' Dr. Scott Holmberg, the CDC's chief of special AIDS studies, said Thursday. ``But there are clear CDC recommendations against doing this, and many physicians have continually counseled such couples not to run this risk,'' he said. The CDC said AIDS is transmitted through blood and semen, and ``there is no evidence that any procedure can reliably eliminate HIV from semen.'' The couple's identity was not disclosed. The CDC has received reports of at least two other couples who have tried artificial insemination despite one spouse's infection. One attempt resulted in pregnancy, and the other did not; no infection has been detected yet in the non-infected spouse. ``The outcome of doing this very risky procedure is by no means assured,'' Holmberg said. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: Estonia Rejects Gorbachev Threats, Offer of Special Status
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Estonia's foreign minister said today his Baltic republic rejects Soviet threats and inducements and refuses to rescind a declaration proclaiming itself an occupied, independent state. Lennart Meri told Finnish national radio that Estonia would ignore Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's threat on Thursday to impose economic reprisals unless the Estonians repealed the decision. In a carrot-and-stick approach, Gorbachev also offered ``special status'' within a Soviet confederation if Estonia abandoned its path toward independence. The Kremlin has imposed an oil and gas embargo on Estonia's Baltic neighbor, Lithuania, for refusing to rescind laws promoting independence. ``Gorbachev really should know that if a nation has elected its own parliament and that parliament has declared in the name of the people that Estonia is an occupied independent republic, then it is impossible for our parliament to repeal such a law,'' said Meri, who is on a previously unpublicized visit to Finland. ``We cannot elect ourselves a new nation,'' he added. Unlike Lithuania, Estonia did not declare independence but passed a resolution March 30 stating that it is a sovereign but occupied state that was illegally annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia in 1940 as part of a secret agreement between Josef Stalin and Adolf Hitler. Meri said Estonia would not continue negotiations with Moscow as long as Soviet authorities refused to recognize the declaration by the 105-member Estonian Supreme Soviet. Meri said Estonia's foreign policy is based on the 1920 Tarto peace treaty, in which the Soviet Union recognized Estonia as an independent republic.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Prisoners Held 5 Years Without Trial In Israeli Prison, Tortured
DOC.TEXT: Some inmates at a prison run by an Israeli-backed militia in southern Lebanon have been tortured and held as many as five years without trial, a British newspaper reported today. The Independent said some prisoners have spent months in total darkness and solitary confinement at the prison on a hilltop above the Christian village of Khiam in Israel's security zone. Israel set up the prison during its 1982-5 invasion of Lebanon. It is now run by the South Lebanon Army, which is trained and financed by Israel. In Jerusalem, an Israeli army spokesman declined to comment on the report. ``We do not deal with Khiam,'' he said. ``It is under the SLA. We do not represent the SLA.'' He spoke on condition of anonymity according to military rules. The Independent quoted unidentified former prisoners as saying suspected guerrillas held there had been tortured by having electric wires attached to their bodies, and that some had received savage beatings. The story named one present inmate as Selma Salam, 23, an interpreter for the United Nation's Norwegian battalion in southern Lebanon. It said three gunmen in plain clothes took her away in a car from her home at the Shia Moslem village of Blat last July 11. It said her mother has not been allowed to visit her and her U.N. employers had sought in vain for information about her from the Israelis and from the South Lebanon Army. The Independent said neither the International Red Cross, nor Amnesty International nor any other humanitarian organization has been allowed to visit the prison. ``Israel has refused the Red Cross permission to visit the jail on the grounds that it is controlled by the SLA _ but since the Israelis themselves control the SLA, Red Cross officials have privately told The Independent that they believe Israel's excuse is unacceptable,'' it said. It said kidnappers of Western hostages in Lebanon had repeatedly demanded the release of Khiam prisoners. The newspaper said about 325 men and women were held in the prison, some because they were suspected of anti-Israeli guerrilla activities and others because their families sympathized with the Lebanese resistance movement. It said the Israelis had suspended all family visits to the prison since spring of last year. ``Neither the Israelis nor the SLA provide lists of inmates, nor will they allow the Red Cross to compile such a list,'' it said. ``But The Independent has acquired the names of 58 prisoners, all of whom come from just seven small villages in the far southeast of Lebanon. Two men _ one 25, the other 30 _ have been incarcerated in Khiam for five years, it said. ``United Nations records show that they were originally escorted there not only by SLA men but by plain clothes Israeli Shin Bet agents. A 20-year-old has been held since January 1987, and 20 others since 1988. ``The SLA admitted that two prisoners were killed last year `while trying to escape.' United Nations officers have been told they were asphyxiated with tear gas during a riot.'' The Shin Bet is Israel's domestic security service.

DOC.HEAD: AP, British Media Ordered to Give Riot Film to Police
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered The photographers. The fourth organization, Fleet Street News Agency, made no objection. On March 6, Denison ordered 25 British newspapers and TV companies to turn over film of the riot, which engulfed London's theater district folowing a huge demonstration against a new tax. Police, who are still examining film, then sought film held by the agencies and London Weekend Television on the ground that it was needed to help identify rioters. Britain's 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act provides that a judge can order news media to turn over material in the case of serious offenses. The judge said AP, Press Association and London Weekend Television were right to oppose the application. ``Orders such as this should not be made as a matter of course,'' he said. ``It would be wrong if the media were to back down and concede every application that is made,'' he said. ``They are perfectly entitled to come to court and put their arguments.'' The order, which the judge is to sign Monday, means AP and Press Association must give police all negatives of the riot. The violence broke out after demonstrators, led by anarchists, tried to storm Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's 10 Downing Street office. They then attacked police and rampaged across London's West End. Nearly 500 police officers and 86 civilians were injured, and hundreds of shops were looted and cars burned. ``If applications routinely succeed, there is a loss of the perceived independence of the media,'' Robin Oppenheim, legal counsel for the three news organizations, told the court. In 1988, British television companies initially refused to hand police film of an Irish Republican Army funeral in Northern Ireland at which two British soldiers were murdered. The companies later released their film saying they had to comply with the law.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Orders U.S. Officials To Explain Mexican Doctor's Arrest
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered law enforcement officials to explain how a Mexican doctor was brought to the United States to face trial in the slaying of U.S. drug agent. Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, a suspect in the 1985 torture-slaying of Enrique Camarena, was arrested April 3 in El Paso, Texas. DEA officials have denied published reports and allegations by Alvarez's lawyer that he was kidnapped in Mexico by bounty hunters paid as much as $100,000. ``It is my understanding,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Manuel Medrano, ``that for a significant time the United States has had standing offers on the street in Mexico and Guadalajara of rewards for the capture and delivery to the United States of any fugitive in Mexico in connection with the Camarena case.'' U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie on Thursday ordered proseuctors to bring witnesses to court who could explain the arrest in detail. Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said Wednesday the incident might hinder U.S.-Mexico cooperation in the drug war. A senior Mexican government official told The Associated Press that officials believe Alvarez was abducted by bounty hunters and that Mexican police were not involved. Mexico has asked for an explanation, and Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said an investigation is being conducted. Medrano said no U.S. agents entered Mexico to participate in the arrest. A confidential informant called DEA agents on April 2, saying Alvarez was in custody and would be taken to El Paso the following day, he said. Alvarez' attorney, Robert K. Steinberg, said he would argue that his client could not be prosecuted because of how he was brought into the United States. Steinberg told the judge his client was kidnapped from his Guadalajara office by men who identified themselves as Mexican police and who said he was under arrest for performing an illegal abortion. Alvarez was taken to Texas aboard a private plane, Steinberg said. He said Alvarez told him one of six men on the plane identified himself as a DEA agent. In today's editions of the Los Angeles Times, the newspaper said sources in Mexico reported that bounty hunters were paid $100,000 to deliver Alvarez to DEA agents. The El Paso Herald-Post on April 11 quoted unnamed federal sources as saying the DEA paid $50,000 to a pilot and an assistant who flew Alvarez into the United States. The U.S. government has alleged that in 1985 Alvarez gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torturing before his slaying. Alvarez is among 18 people accused in Camarena's kidnapping and murder. Prosecutors say Camarena was tortured and killed by members of a drug trafficking operation that distributed tons of marijuana and cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Serving Political Prisoner Pardoned
DOC.TEXT: Adem Demaqi, believed to be Yugoslavia's longest-serving political prisoner with a total of nearly 28 years in detention, has been pardoned, a senior official announced today. The name of 54-year-old Demaqi, an ethnic Albanian, was included on a list of 108 political prisoners pardoned Wednesday, said Stipe Suvar, a member of the collective leadership. Demaqi was one of 103 ethnic Albanians among them.
