Two Yugoslav republics are holding free elections this month in line with the wave of reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, and the pardons were seen as indicating some relaxation of Communist rule on the federal level. Another 190 political prisoners will remain in detention, Suvar added. He said that some will be granted amnesty, however, and their number will be reduced to 70 before 1991. Demaqi was one of the key ethnic Albanian activists in Kosovo province, the site of historic tensions between Slavs and Albanians. He was sentenced to three years in jail in 1958 for attempting to set up an illegal separatist organization. Six years later he was sentenced to 15 years in prison for founding the Revolutionary Movement For the Unification of Shiptars, as Albanians call themselves. He served 10 years of his second sentence before he was given a concurrent 15-year term in 1975 for conspiring against the people and the state. He had been due for release in October. Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians comprise a 90-percent majority, was rocked in March by violent protests over constitutional amendments giving Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, nearly complete control over the province. The amendments were said to be necessary to protect Slavs in Kosovo from alleged harassment by ethnic Albanians and to prevent the secession of Kosovo from Yugoslavia. Yugoslav authorities lifted a state of emergency in Kosovo on Wednesday at Serbia's request, after Serbia completed its takeover of the province's police. Serbia had charged that local police were inactive during the unrest that claimed more than 60 lives. Demaqi's pardon also appeared to be part of a recent move by the federal government to cool Albanian tempers in Kosovo. On Thursday, charges against Azem Vlasi, the popular former Kosovo Communist Party chief, were modified to remove the threat of execution. He is accused of fomenting unrest among fellow ethnic-Albanians last year. The move was seen as preparing the ground for Vlasi's release and an eventual start of negotiations with the ethnic Albanian opposition _ something hard-line Serbian leaders have rejected so far.

DOC.HEAD: College Profs Espouse Rival Racial Superiority Theories
DOC.TEXT: Clashing theories of racial superiority espoused by two tenured professors _ one white and one black _ have prompted an inquiry by City College into the limits of academic freedom, The New York Times reported in today's editions. The school's student body is 39 percent black, 28 percent Hispanic, 17 percent white and 16 percent Asian. The white teacher, Michael Levin, a professor of philosophy, has written at least three articles for academic journals contending that ``it has been amply confirmed over the last several decades that on average, blacks are significantly less intelligent than whites,'' the Times said. Levin has argued that a deficiency in intelligence, rather than discrimination or poverty, accounts for the underrepresentation of blacks in fields like medicine, engineering and philosophy,'' the Times said. Levin holds a doctorate in philosophy. The black professor, Leonard Jeffries Jr., chairman of the black studies department, calls people of European ancestry ``the ice people'' and portrays them in his classes as fundamentally materialistic, greedy and intent on domination. He calls people of African descent ``the sun people'' and says they are essentially humanistic and communal, the Times said. He has passed out booklets to his students that argue that an abundance of skin pigment gives blacks intellectual and physical advantages over whites. In a class Wednesday, Jeffries said ``rich Jews who financed the development of Europe also financed the slave trade,'' the Times said. Jeffries has a doctorate in public law and government. Levin has been rebuked by the faculty senate and barred for one semester from teaching an introductory philosophy course. Dr. Bernard W. Harleston, the college president, said Thursday he had decided to name a committee to ``review the question of when speech, both in and outside the classroom, may go beyond the protection of academic freedom and may become conduct unbecoming a faculty member.'' He said the committee would review both cases.

DOC.HEAD: Legendary Estate of Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks Razed
DOC.TEXT: Pickfair, the legendary estate of Hollywood film stars Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, has been razed so actress-singer Pia Zadora and her multimillionare husband can build a palace. The rambling estate, first built as a hunting lodge, was dubbed the Buckingham Palace of Hollywood. Albert Einstein, Charlie Chaplin and the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were some who passed through its doors. Prima ballerina Anna Pavlova danced there. Maurice Chevalier sang there. Rudolph Valentino, Clark Gable and Joan Crawford attended parties there. Originally surrounded by 15 acres of gardens, lawns and tree groves, the property now takes up less than three acres. Douglas Fairbanks Jr., the actor's son from another marriage, was saddened by the demise of Pickfair. ``I regret it very much,'' Fairbanks said Thursday. ``I wonder, if they were going to demolish it, why they bought it in the first place.'' The Beverly Hills Historical Society raised no objections when Miss Zadora and husband Meshulam Riklis announced plans to demolish the home to make way for a Renaissance-style Venetian palazzo. ``I've got a funny feeling about it, because it's no longer Pickfair to me,'' said Phyllis Lerner, historical society president. ``It really wasn't a pretty house, but my God, the guest list!'' ``The house has been changed through the years a number of times so that it no longer is the original Pickfair,'' Paul Selwyn, chairman of the city Planning Commission, said last summer when the commission approved the project. Contractor Rob Myers said the ravages of time and termites made demolition inevitable. ``Once we got into it, it was like cancer,'' Myers said. ``We kept cutting away at the bad stuff, trying to get at the good stuff until we got down to the foundation. And the foundation didn't have any steel in it, so we couldn't build on that and we had to keep going.'' Miss Zadora and Riklis bought the estate from Los Angeles Lakers owner Jerry Buss in 1988 for $6.6 million. The couple reportedly plan to spend $5 million to build their tile-roofed palazzo, adding 2,754 square feet to the original 13,421 square feet of interior space. Miss Pickford appeared in such films as ``Pollyanna,'' ``Tess of the Storm Country'' and ``Little Annie Rooney.'' Fairbanks was the swashbuckling hero of ``Zorro,'' ``The Thief of Bagdad'' and ``Robin Hood.'' Miss Pickford and Fairbanks divorced in 1934. After she retired from acting, her third husband, Buddy Rogers, opened the estate for charity fund-raisers. She died in 1979 at age 86. Miss Zadora appeared in the films ``Lonely Lady'' and ``Butterfly,'' two phenomenal flops in the early '80s, but has since launched a successful career singing torch songs from the '40s and '50s. Her husband is head of Riklis Family Corp., which was No. 47 on Forbes magazine's 1989 list of top 400 privately owned companies.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Jewish Settlers to Remain in Complex For Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with court allowing settlers to remain. Pickup 6th graf, `Uzi Atzmon ...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Supreme Court today allowed 150 Jewish settlers to remain in a compound in the city's Christian Quarter until the high court hears more arguments in the case. The high court ruled in response to an order by Attorney General Yosef Harish on Thursday that the settlers immediately leave the 72-room, four-building complex inside Jerusalem's walled Old City. The settlers created a furor and ignited demonstrations by both Christians and Moslems when they moved into the building owned by the Greek Orthodox Church on April 11. The church claims that a former tenant illegally sold his user rights to the building to the settlers. Harish, backed by two lower court decisions, on Thursday ordered the settlers to leave because their presence had harmed Christian-Jewish relations in Jerusalem. But the three-judge Supreme Court panel issued a restraining order against the eviction today and asked Harish to show at a hearing next Thursday why his order should not be annulled. ``The settlers will be allowed to stay until there is a final decision by the high court,'' said attorney Dan Avi-Yitzhak, who represents a Panama-based company that bought the rights to use the complex. Yohanan Altbauer, an attorney representing the church, said the judges offered a compromise under which the settlers would have left the building, but a few company representatives would have remained until lower courts decided on tenancy rights. ``Both sides rejected the compromise,'' Altbauer said. Uzi Atzmon, an attorney for the settlers, said on Thursday that a second appeal would be filed with the court challenging the entire eviction process. Also Thursday, a leaflet issued by the underground leadership of the Palestinian uprising threatened to execute the former tenant, an Armenian, and others involved in the deal. The leaflet said, however, that the order ``will not be carried out until further notice.'' In Athens, Greek Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras instructed Greece's representative in Israel to urge the Israeli government to carry out the lower court's eviction order immediately. Tensions rose because the settlement upset the traditional division of the religious communities in the Old City. There are about 50,000 Moslems, 7,000 Christians and 4,000 Jews in the old, walled city. The settlement also has political implications, since the Old City is part of the area captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel annexed the area into its capital, but most countries, including the United States, do not recognize Israel's claim to sovereignty. Palestinians have demanded Jerusalem become the capital of their would-be independent state. When attorney general Harish told the settlers to leave Thursday, he said he took the action to prevent a further deterioration of relations between the Christian and Jewish communities in Jerusalem. However, Supreme Court Justice Gabriel Bach stayed Harish's order, allowing the Jews to remain.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Storm Printing Plant; Lithuanians Argue Over Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with report on number injured, crowd of 500 people gathering outside plant. Pickup 10th graf, `In Key Largo...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of Red Army soldiers stormed into a printing plant today and beat civilian guards in a renewal of the Kremlin's strong-arm tactics against Lithuania's independence drive, witnesses said. In another development, Lithuania's Communist Party chief appealed for compromise on pro-independence decisions after the Kremlin extended its embargo to more goods and raw materials, threatening widespread unemployment. And the foreign minister of the neighboring Baltic republic of Estonia said it rejects Soviet threats and inducements and refuses to rescind a declaration proclaiming itself an occupied, independent state. The soldiers, some armed with truncheons and assault rifles, forced their way into a Communist Party printing plant in the center of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, said witness Angele Guobiene. The soldiers beat some of the several dozen armed civilians who have been on guard for several weeks, said Guobiene, who works for the trade union journal Darbas Ir Poilsis which is printed at the plant. Algimantas Cekuolis, a newspaper editor, said about 12 people were hurt, including a legislator who tried to keep the soldiers from entering. Two or three people were hospitalized, Cekuolis said. Police did not allow reporters who arrived after the incident to enter the building. Soldiers were visible behind a black iron gate in the courtyard of the building and some workers barricaded themselves near printing presses and looked out open windows from second- and third-floor windows. A crowd of 500 people gathered on the street below, singing nationalist songs and carrying the hammer and sickle of the Soviet Union merged with the Nazi swastika. Soldiers began occupying buildings in Vilnius a month ago, among them the republic's Communist Party headquarters and a plant that prints the republic's newspapers. The plant occupied today prints the trade union journal, a humor magazine and other non-political magazines. Soldiers also beat some Lithuanians last month as they rounded up army deserters. Today's crackdown came amid an energy embargo the Kremlin has imposed on Lithuania in an effort to force it to rescind laws asserting independence. In Key Largo, Fla., President Bush and visiting French President Francois Mitterrand both said they were ``deeply disturbed'' by the Kremlin's energy embargo. Bush told reporters he was ``considering appropriate measures to be taken in light of Soviet actions.'' Lithuanian Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas urged compromise in the confrontation with Moscow. ``In two weeks we will have a critical situation,'' he told the Lithuanian parliament. ``The price for independence must have limits.'' Deputies of the Supreme Council, Lithuania's parliament, immediately accused him of trying to slow their Baltic republic's independence drive. ``You're raising a white flag,'' charged Kazis Saya, a writer. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis told reporters his republic must be prepared for a long embargo, such as the 900-day Nazi siege Leningrad suffered during World War II. ``They accepted strict rationing. They helped each other. They didn't think about capitulation,'' Landsbergis said. The Soviets tightened their economic noose on Lithuania Thursday by shutting off more than 80 percent of its gas supply following a complete cutoff of oil the previous night. Lithuania, forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940, has rejected Soviet demands to rescind its March 11 declaration of independence. It is entirely dependent on Moscow for oil and gas, which it receives at below-market prices. The government today imposed an eight-gallon per month limit on gasoline for private cars, and some large factories that normally open on Saturdays planned to give workers a day off. But republic officials took no other steps to conserve. On Thursday, Lithuanian officials said the first to lose their energy supplies will be Soviet military bases and the 96 factories run by Moscow ministries, according to the parliament's press office. The energy embargo left Lithuania with only 15 percent to 17 percent of the 18 million cubic meters of natural gas it uses daily for homes and industry. Lithuanians say they have enough oil to last six weeks to three months. Brazauskas, chief of the Lithuanian Communist Party and chairman of the parliament's emergency energy committee, said many Lithuanian factories would have to close not only because of the fuel shortage but because Soviet factories have cut supplies of goods and raw materials ranging from tires to electric motors, cables and packaging. This will undoubtedly lead to great unemployment and some factories are considering giving workers early vacations, he said. ``People of the highest rank must go to Moscow to negotiate,'' he said, uring lawmakers to make a political decision ``to take us out of this dead end.'' A delegation of Lithuanian officials plans to travel to Moscow on Monday in hope of meeting with Kremlin officials to discuss the standoff. Gorbachev has refused to negotiate with the Lithuanians until they rescind their independence declaration. He demands that Lithuania roll back legislation to stop conscription into the Soviet army, attempts to seize property of the Soviet Communist Party and the introduction of identity cards for citizens. These are the demands that Brazauskas indicated the republic should compromise on. Lithuania normally produces its own electricity at a nuclear power plant at Ignalina, but it is shut for repairs. Daina Kalendra of the parliamentary press office said the republic has suffered no electricity shortage, and other plants are operating, including a hydroelectric plant near Kaunas. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene was in Norway to discuss contracts for expensive Western oil. The Norwegian oil company Statoil said it would sell to Lithuania for hard currency, but Mrs. Prunskiene said the republic would need credit to buy the oil. Gorbachev met leaders of Latvia and Estonia in separate meetings in the Kremlin on Thursday and alternately tried concessions and threats to stop their drives for independence. He offered both republics ``special status'' in a ``confederative'' Soviet Union if they quit trying to secede, Baltic officials and journalists said. In Helsinki, Finland, today, Estonian Foreign Minister Lennart Meri said Estonia rejects Gorbachev's threatened sanctions and refuses to rescind a declaration proclaiming itself an occupied, independent state. Foreign reporters, whom Moscow officials had barred from Lithuania at the end of last month, were allowed to return in limited numbers Thursday on a trip organized by the Soviet Foreign Ministry. Free travel by foreigners to Lithuania is still largely banned.

DOC.HEAD: Abernathy to Be Buried in Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, the civil rights leader and confidant of Martin Luther King Jr. who died this week, will be buried in a northwest Atlanta cemetery near his home, his family announced Friday. Abernathy will be buried at Lincoln Cemetery, said his niece, Brenda Russell. Lincoln Cemetery is a tree-shaded, historically black cemetery located about two miles from Abernathy's home. Abernathy, a native of Linden, Ala., died Tuesday of a heart attack after he developed a blood clot in his lung. He was 64. Funeral services are scheduled for noon Monday at West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where Abernathy was pastor for 29 years.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with brother-in-law saying he is the bidder, not Ms. Basinger. Picks up 4th graf of item, `The station...'.
DOC.TEXT: Kim Basinger's brother-in-law said today it is he, not the actress who is negotiating to buy an Albany television station whose principal owner is plagued by legal problems. The station's president and general manager, Manny Cantu, said Thursday that Ms. Basinger was among several bidders for WFXL Channel 31, a Fox affiliate. But Gary Guyer of Atlanta, Ms. Basinger's brother-in-law and president of the Brazelton Group, said today the actress is not involved. ``Everybody knows I'm affiliated with Kim, but in this case it's my deal,'' said Guyer, whose firm helped the 36-year-old actress purchase most of the northeast Georgia town of Braselton. ``She is not buying that station.'' The station has been owned since 1988 by New South Group Inc., headed by 44-year-old Timothy Brumlik of Orlando, Fla. He was arrested in September after accepting $1 million from an informant pretending to invest profits for Columbian drug dealers, officials said. Investigators have said they have no information that the millionaire channeled any of the allegedly laundered funds into television stations. Ms. Basinger, a Georgia native, in January purchased 1,800 acres in northeast Georgia, including much of downtown Braselton.

DOC.HEAD: Rose Pleads Guilty to Cheating on Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Rose pleading guilty, court hearing. No pickup. Version moved on sports wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering.
DOC.TEXT: Pete Rose pleaded guilty today to felony tax charges for failing to report income, including winnings from his illegal gambling that led to his banishment from baseball. Rose, former player and manager of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team, admitted that he did not report $354,968 in income over four years. The two felony counts of filing false federal income tax returns carry a maximum penalty of three years in jail on each count. He also could be fined up to $250,000 on each count. The government agreed not to pursue any other tax charges against Rose in return for the plea. U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel accepted Rose's guilty plea, but gave no indication when he might sentence Rose. Rose stood with his hands folded and clearly answered ``Yes, sir'' to questions the judge asked before accepting the guilty plea. He made no comment as he walked from the courtroom to meet with probation officers. Last August, Rose accepted a lifetime ban from the game after admitting he bet through bookmakers, although he denies betting on baseball or his team. The plea agreement ends a one-year investigation by federal prosecutors into whether Rose claimed all of his income from gambling, autograph appearances and memorabilia sales. Assistant U.S. Attorney William Hunt said the probe found no evidence of involvement by Rose in the drug activities of his former associates, but did show that Rose was ``a chronic gambler'' who hid large amounts of income from his financial advisers. Hunt said, for example, that Rose owned a share of a $47,646 racetrack payoff and that he sold the baseball bat he used for his 4,192nd hit _ which made him baseball's all-time hits leader _ for $129,000. As part of his plea agreement, Rose admits he underreported his income from 1984-87. He reported a total of $4.6 million in income for those years, paying $2 million in taxes, but hid $354,968. Hunt said Rose has repaid the Internal Revenue Service $366,042.86 in back taxes, interest and penalties. Thursday, Rose said he was unconcerned about a possible jail sentence. ``I know I'm not a bad person, but I did make some mistakes and it's in the eyes of the judge,'' Rose said, during his weekly talk show Thursday night on WCKY-AM in Cincinnati. ``All you can say is it's up to the judge.''

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Proposes Higher Defense Spending Than House Democratic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `Sen. Sam ...' to CORRECT difference between Nunn proposal and budget committee to $1.5 billion sted of $2.5 billion.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that President Bush's 1991 military budget must be slashed, but not as severely as proposed by the Democrati-controlled House Budget Committee. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., proposed defense spending of $297 billion for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, $1.5 billion more than the committee approved on Thursday. Bush has proposed a $303 billion defense budget. ``I believe this range is a realistic and responsible target,'' Nunn said in a speech on the Senate floor. Nunn proposed limiting spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative to about $4 billion, the amount Congress appropriated for the anti-missile shield last year. The Armed Services chairman also called for delaying the Pentagon's plans to move the multiple-warhead, MX nuclear missile from fixed silos to railroad cars. ``In the first element of the new military strategy _ nuclear deterrence _ these and other actions could save on the order of $3 billion to $3.5 billion in fiscal 1991 and between $20 and $30 billion over the next five years,'' Nunn said. House Democrats plan to bring their proposed $1.24 trillion 1991 budget to the floor next week in what looms as a test of their plan to begin slashing tens of billions of dollars in military spending. The House Budget Committee approved the spending package on a 21-14 party-line vote, as majority Democrats dealt a blow to Bush's plans to only slightly trim the defense budget. The action marked the formal beginning of the battle over how federal spending priorities should be reshaped in response to the dismemberment of the Soviet bloc. ``We live in a far different world from the one which we have known for most of our lifetimes,'' said committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. The defense figures are supported by Democratic leaders and are meant as a compromise between the party's liberal and conservative wings. Nonetheless, the size of the cuts is distasteful to conservatives, raising questions about whether their support can be counted on for final passage next week. With Democrats holding a 258-176 House majority, defections by large numbers of the party's conservatives could make approval uncertain. Republicans want the budget to be written after negotiations between the White House and congressional leaders, and virtually all GOP lawmakers are expected to oppose the Democratic package. ``It gives a lot of us conservatives real heartburn,'' Rep. Jerry Huckaby, D-La., said of the defense proposal. ``At this point, there isn't a conservative consensus about whether we'll be able to support the'' Democratic measure. Huckaby estimated there were 40 conservative Democrats who shared his concerns. Panetta predicted passage of the proposal, arguing that conservatives would ultimately see the defense figures as bargaining positions in future negotiations with the Senate and perhaps the White House. Overall, the Democratic package claims to trim the deficit by $36 billion to just less than $64 billion, just within the target required by the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law. Besides defense cuts, it relies on $13.9 billion in new taxes _ the same figure Bush wants _ and $1.4 billion in user fees. It also calls for $9.3 billion in savings from a combination of sources: improved tax collections by the Internal Revenue Service, user fees that congressional committees have rejected in the past and other efforts. An additional $3.8 billion would be saved by limiting the growth of Medicare and other benefit programs. The Budget Committee had said it expected to save $4.2 billion in this category, but leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee _ which oversees Medicare _ said they did not want such deep cuts in the health care program for the elderly. The proposal would also boost federal aid for scientists, aviation safety, and the Head Start program for poor pre-school children. The Senate Budget Committee hopes to begin working on its own version of the spending plan next week. The budget, which does not require the president's signature, lays out a fiscal blueprint. Congress will consider separate bills that will make the final spending and tax decisions.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Finishes Recharging Space Telescope's Batteries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `NASA planned...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with payload bay doors opened.
DOC.TEXT: The Hubble Space Telescope's batteries have enough power after 130 hours of recharging to permit five launch attempts next week of the craft that will carry it into space, NASA says. ``We're right on schedule,'' Lisa Malone, a spokeswoman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said Thursday. ``There are no problems.'' The shuttle Discovery is due to lift off 8:31 a.m. EDT Tuesday. The space agency has until April 28 to launch the shuttle, carrying the $1.5 billion telescope. Otherwise, the mission must be delayed eight days so the telescope's six nickel-hydrogen batteries can be recharged more. Recharging the batteries in a laboratory from Sunday through Thursday provided enough strength for ``one additional contingency day'' for a launch attempt, said NASA spokesman George Diller. ``It's a full charge. We got everything that we set out to get,'' Diller said. NASA finished recharging the batteries at noon Thursday. Technicians then prepared the batteries for transfer from a laboratory to the launch pad. NASA opened Discovery's payload bay doors today and the technicians began installing the batteries in the telescope. The batteries were to be tested late tonight and early Saturday, and the payload bay sealed Sunday in preparation for Tuesday's scheduled liftoff. ``They haven't had any problems and they are running ahead of schedule,'' Malone said. The batteries will power the telescope, NASA's most expensive and complex payload, from the time it is disconnected from the shuttle's power system until its energy-collecting solar panels are unfurled in space. The countdown to launch was to begin Saturday afternoon. Discovery's five astronauts were to arrive Sunday. Once in orbit 380 miles above Earth, Hubble will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers expect to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has been traveling for 14 billion years, close to the beginning of time.

DOC.HEAD: 13 Killed as Truck Overturns
DOC.TEXT: A truck packed with sacks of salt and about 100 passengers overturned in southeastern Nepal, killing 13 people and injuring 47, a newspaper reported Friday. The English-language Rising Nepal said the accident occurred late Thursday in Mirchaiya, 85 miles southeast of Katmandu. Twelve people were killed instantly and one person died Friday in Janakpur Hospital where the injured were being treated, the newspaper said. Because of inadequate public transport, people often travel by trucks and tractors in Nepal, one of the world's poorest countries with a per capita annual income of $150.

DOC.HEAD: Three Missing After Panamanian Ship Sinks Off Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Three crewmen were reported missing after a Panamanian freighter sank Friday following a collision with another Panamanian vessel about 75 miles east of this British colony, the government said. A statement said 16 crewmen from the Regent Kapuas were rescued by the Ocean Blessing, a container ship that was involved in the collision. It said a Royal Navy patrol craft picked up the survivors _ 15 Filipinos and one Japanese _ from the Oceas up to two hours making a single gavel. Starting with a block of raw wood, Beaton makes grooves, bevels and flutes with an assortment of hand chisels and wood-burning devices and applies several finishing coats of clear, acrylic lacquer. Beaton follows a fixed design that he says has been traditional for a century or more, though nobody knows for sure. ``When I came here nearly seven years ago, I was told this is the way we've always made them, and I should make them just like this,'' he says. ``I've never done it any other way.'' The shiny, blond-hued gavels, which Beaton estimates are worth $75 apiece, are kept in a drawer at the speaker's marble-topped rostrum for the exclusive use of the speaker or the legislator he appoints to preside over the House during floor action on legislation. Although a Washington newspaper article published in 1923 claimed that ``some years ago it was not unusual for 100 gavels or more to be smashed in one Congress,'' broken gavels are a rarity today. Their replacement is necessary, instead, because the speakers like to autograph their gavels and present them as gifts to constituents, friends or to fellow legislators who have steered major bills to final passage. Veteran House parliamentarians recall that some House speakers, notably Sam Rayburn of Texas, have wielded their gavels with a heavy hand, but none has banged one into smithereens in recent memory. Former Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill, a big Irishman from Boston, frequently tapped gently with his gavel's handle to persuade lawmakers to quiet down. One of the loudest gavel-bangers was former Rep. Richard Bolling, D-Mo., who presided over floor debate and voting on scores of bills from the speaker's chair during his 34-year House career. Bolling, interviewed by telephone from his retirement home in rural Maryland, remembered breaking two gavels in those years. ``Fortunately, nobody got hurt,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: MiGs Bomb Namibian Border Area
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet-made MiGs dropped phosphorous bombs near an abandoned military base close to the Angolan border, police said Friday. Police Brig. Gen. Siggi Eimbeck said no one was hurt when the planes bombed the area some 12 miles inside Namibia on Thursday. Planes believed to be Angolan air force jets have bombed Namibian territory three times in the past four months. The Angolan government is battling U.S.-backed guerrillas in the southern part of Angola near the Namibian border.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Return After Lawmakers Approve $230 Million Education Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with quotes, union thank-you rally canceled by rain, union endorsing education plan sponsor's Democratic gubernatorial bid, no count available today on school closings. Picks up 8th graf, `State education...'.
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma teachers returned to classrooms today after their four-day strike forced state lawmakers to forge a compromise on education spending that would raise teachers' minimum salaries. ``It shows that with solidarity the system works. Now we can go back to school,'' said Carolyn Meyer, an elementary music teacher in Stillwater. The Democratic-controlled Senate approved an emergency clause Thursday that allows a $230 million education reform and tax bill to become law as soon as it is signed by Republican Gov. Henry Bellmon. The governor said he will sign the bill. ``Everybody's just feeling great,'' Stillwater Superintendent Bill Hodges said. The emergency clause had been a stumbling block to the package and the Senate's failure to pass it last week prompted the 31,000-member Oklahoma Education Association to call for a five-day walkout. Republicans opposed the bill. It calls for spending $68.1 million to raise minimum teacher salaries by $1,500 a year for four years. Oklahoma teachers say they rank 48th in pay among the states, making $22,000 a year compared with the national average of $29,648. The teachers' association said the passage would end the walkout, except for teachers in schools already set to close today. A ``thank-you rally'' that had been planned for the Capitol was canceled because of the rain. Also today, the union voted to recommend its political action committee endorse House Speaker Steve Lewis, chief architect of the school bill, for the Democratic nomination for governor. Two delegates spoke against the recommendation, but it passed by a wide margin. The association said schools in 145 districts were closed Thursday. Among those were Tulsa, Oklahoma City and Lawton, the three largest districts in the state with about 95,000 students. The union did not have a count today on the number of districts closed. State education officials have said the walkout has affected about 60 percent, or 343,200, of the state's 572,000 students. The state has 606 school districts. The education package was enacted by a 32-14 vote after five Senate Democrats switched their votes in return for support for a bill that would give low-income families a tax break. The package needed 32 votes to pass. Sponsors said the measure will put Oklahoma in the forefront of education reform. ``It's going to connect us to the rest of the country,'' said Sen. Stratton Taylor, a Democrat. ``We're not going to be a Third World state.'' ``A new day is dawning for education in Oklahoma,'' said the governor, who supported the education plan but drew virtually no backing from the Senate's Republican minority. ``Oklahoma will no longer take a back seat among the states where education is concerned,'' Bellmon said. ``From now on, others can look to Oklahoma for leadership in education.'' The union's president, Kyle Dahlem, said teachers had never had such a comprehensive program with which to work. ``Now it's up to the people of Oklahoma to make us accountable for seeing that the program works,'' she said. The measure was passed after an eight-month special session.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Accused in Killing of Drug Agent Won't Be Returned Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs `The arrest ...' to ADD LA judge ordering prosecutors to explain how Alvarez was arrested. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Attorney General ...' This incorporates material from PM-Camarena-Doctor, a0544
DOC.TEXT: A Mexican physician accused of participating in the 1985 killing of a U.S. drug agent won't be returned home even if his arrest violated Mexican sovereignty, the Justice Department said today. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said he ``did not foresee any circumstances'' under which Humberto Alvarez Machain would be returned to Mexico rather than face charges in Los Angeles of participating in the 1985 kidnapping and murder of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena. Alvarez's attorney charges that the Guadalajara gynecologist was kidnapped and taken to El Paso, Texas, where he was arrested by DEA agents. The arrest sparked a diplomatic protest from the Mexican government. In Los Angeles on Thursday, U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered prosecutors to explain how Alvarez was brought to the United States. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who returned Thursday from a hemispheric drug enforcement conference in Ixtapa, Mexico, has ordered DEA to give him a full report on the arrest. Runkel said talks Thornburgh had with Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo before he left Ixtapa assuaged Mexican officials, who had threatened to stop cooperating with U.S. anti-drug efforts. ``We were assured that relations between Mexico and the United Sates remained strong and that cooperation on drug law enforcement would continue,'' Runkel told reporters. ``Any threat, if one existed, to continued cooperation was substantially lessened as a result of the bilateral talks in Ixtapa,'' Runkel said. The Mexican attorney general said Wednesday that the arrest might hinder continued cooperation by his country with U.S. authorities in the war on drug trafficking. On Thursday, Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had unusually strong words for the United States in a speech to the Ixtapa conference on drug trafficking. Mexico ``will not permit anybody, not drug traffickers nor their pursuers, to violate Mexican rights,'' he said. ``In the fight against drugs, the law is rendered useless by illegal actions, or by trying to measure justice with a ruler of one country in foreign territory,'' Salinas said. Runkel said Thornburgh and his Mexican counterpart held their final meeting after Salinas' speech. Thornburgh assured the Mexican attorney general that ``he had insisted upon a full, complete and immediate investigation into the circumstances surrounding the apprehension'' of Alvarez. ``Appropriate action would be forthcoming when a report of the results of that investigation was in hand,'' Runkel said. But Runkel said federal authorities would not return Alvarez to Mexico if Thornburgh had determined that DEA had violated any Justice Department policies, Mexican sovereignty or law. ``I don't foresee any circumstances under which he would be returned to Mexico,'' Runkel said. ``He faces criminal charges in this country.'' A long line of U.S. court decisions have held that a fugitive can stand trial in this country even if his arrest overseas was improper.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Booby Trap Death, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0548,0352
DOC.HEAD: Handyman Faces Possible Murder Charge In Booby-Trapped Warehouse Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with defendant denied bond. Picks up 6th graf, `Michael McComb...'.
DOC.TEXT: A handyman accused of setting a shotgun booby trap that killed an intruder in his warehouse turned himself in to face a possible murder charge, and was ordered held without bond today. Philip Connaghan, 46, was booked at the Denver County Jail for investigation of first-degree murder Thursday. Denver County Judge Larry Bohning denied him bail this morning, leaving the district attorney's office three days to decide whether to press charges. District Attorney Norm Early said before the court hearing that he would make no recommendation about bail. ``We don't want to rush to judgment,'' Early said Thursday when he announced Connaghan was in custody. ``Whatever the judge feels is an appropriate bond is fine with me.'' Early said that if Connaghan were allowed to post bond, there would be no deadline for filing charges, which he said could range from ``first-degree murder to nothing.'' Michael McComb, 19, of Denver was shot in the chest Saturday night by a 12-gauge shotgun inside the warehouse Connaghan leased. Three youths who were with McComb said they entered the warehouse for an adventure not as thieves. They were booked for investigation of burglary and released to their parents. Police said the shotgun was attached to a trip wire they believe Connaghan rigged. The front door of the warehouse bore the inscription: ``Danger _ Enter at own risk.'' Connaghan was in Kansas when McComb was killed and told police the next day in a telephone conversation that he had no knowledge of the booby trap. The warehouse had been burglarized eight times since 1987. The handyman lost more than $7,000 in tools during a burglary last July. Early said he has received hundreds of calls and a lot of unsolicited advice on how to handle the case, ranging from ``give the man a medal to hang him up.''

DOC.HEAD: Guards Admit to Having Sex with Inmates at County Prison
DOC.TEXT: Nine male guards have resigned after a monthlong investigation into sexual misconduct with women inmates at a county prison, the state corrections commissioner said. Three guards admitted having sex inmates at the Rankin County prison; the six others resigned rather than proceed with the investigation, Commissioner Lee Roy Black said Thursday. ``No force was used by the employees. Participation by the inmates was fully voluntary,'' Black said in releasing details of the investigation at the 660-bed prison. He said many of the inmates received money in exchange for sex but that it was not ``a prostitution ring.'' Five other guards were cleared of sexual misconduct allegations, he said. The prison, which opened in 1987, has 166 guards. It holds the state's female inmates and a workforce of male inmates. The investigation of 14 guards and 12 inmates began in early March after prison officials received a tip. Officials said the early-morning sexual rendezvous took place in the guard towers, empty cells and the infirmary. Prison Superintendent Don Cabana said some sort of disciplinary action would be taken against the inmates. Cabana's report recommended that guards not be allowed to carry more than $5 cash onto prison grounds, that inmates not be allowed to carry cash, and other changes. Black said the report will undergo further review by the department before changes are put into effect.

DOC.HEAD: Every Day is Earth Day For Sims Ranch
DOC.TEXT: A family that has been ranching for four decades has learned that becoming more environmentally sensitive deosn't mean sacrificing profits. The Sims family, headed by 84-year-old patriarch Roy Sims, is one of a few Wyoming ranch owners using an innovative grazing technique that increases profits as it improves the land. ``We're trying to make a living, but not at the expense of the land,'' said 35-year-old Scott Sims, who with his brother, Olin, and father, Don, own and operate the 10,000-acre McFadden Land and Livestock Co. The family was awarded Wyoming's 1989 Outstanding Conservation Farmer and Rancher Award and sees this Sunday's Earth Day 1990 as an opportunity to illustrate that ranchers care about the land. ``We've got environmentalists accusing livestock men of tearing up the earth,'' Olin Sims said. ``I hope it's a time environmentalists realize ranchers are environmentalists, too.'' A visit to the southern Wyoming ranch on a warm April afternoon found bawling calves stumbling alongside their mothers on meadows that have only recently turned from a frozen gray to spring green. Cottonwoods and elms cast long shadows across a frothing creek bulging with snow melt. But a closer look reveals that the ranch operations are not typical. Last year, Scott and Olin Sims began using the intensive grazing technique. Instead of allowing their hundreds of cows to roam freely over large expanses, they sliced the land into small pastures so cattle graze each section intensively for two to three days before being moved onto another plot. With 300 cows denuding 300 acres, instead of one cow on 40 acres munching here and there, grass is allowed to regrow and much erosion is eliminated. ``We're `severe grazing.' You go back the next year and it's the nicest grass on the ranch,'' Scott Sims explained. On the heavily grazed sections, the cows act as rototillers with their trampling and fertilizers with their manure, thus encouraging healthy new growth. Rain is absorbed more efficiently on the trampled fields rather than running off hard, overgrazed land, and noxious weeds are inhibited and so fewer pesticides are needed. On the smaller plots, bothersome flies that usually hatch in manure piles on the open range are trampled to death, saving 50 cents per head in fly abatement costs. The Sims say the healthier, lusher grass growth adds an average of 20 pounds per weened calf. ``If we can double the grass production, we can double our cattle numbers,'' Olin Sims said, adding that the increased fencing pays for itself. ``It's nice to see these cows cultivate the land and make money for you, too.'' With this ``holistic resource management'' technique, ``we never allow that cow to bite that plant a second time before it's fully recovered,'' he said. Since the cattle are restricted to 5 percent of the ranch at any one time, the rest of the range is open to wildlife. The Simses also plant 150 trees each year, use solar power for the electrified fencing and water pumps, and maintain enough water in the creeks for fish to survive. With some environmentalists calling for a cattle ban on public lands, or ``Cattle-free by '93,'' Olin Sims said he has to be careful. A small part of his ranch is leased from the state and federal governments. ``I'd like to keep the ranch in the family for years and years,'' he said. ``When you've got Congress and Earth Firsters breathing down your neck to forbid grazing on public lands, you've got to be careful. It's worth it.'' Asked what his grandfather thought of the changes he and his brother have made, Olin Sims said, ``That's the way this whole ranch family has been _ always looking for a better way and not getting stuck in a rut.''

DOC.HEAD: Papal Visit to Czechoslovakia Begins Saturday
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II's weekend visit to Czechoslovakia, the first by a pope, will be a symbolic release for many of the nation's Roman Catholics from their Communist past. It also marks a further step in the Vatican's move into Eastern Europe as new non-Communist governments restore long-broken ties. ``In my opinion this is a truly historic event,'' President Vaclav Havel said in an Easter Sunday radio broadcast. ``It is happening one week after Easter. Let us contemplate about the importance of Easter, sacrifice, resurrection and redemption.'' It was Havel who invited the Polish-born pontiff to visit Czechoslovakia. He issued the invitation only two days after taking office Dec. 29. The pontiff is to arrive Saturday. Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution toppledthe hard-line Communist leadership of Milos Jakes in 10 days of street protests and mass rallies. It practically coincided with the canonization of St. Agnes, a Czech, by the pope Nov. 12, and Havel drew a playful link between the two events. ``Many believers think it all went so well because it was a bit of a miracle from St. Agnes ... I am sure you feel the symbolic relation,'' Havel said in his radio speech. The sterility of the Communist dogma brought about a Christian renaissance in the late 1980s that was unparalleled in recent Czechoslovak history. ``The past rulers had nothing to offer,'' Vaclav Maly, a former underground priest and human rights activist, said of the religious rebirth. ``After some time, the natural longing for dignified life led to the creation of a community where people can trust one another.'' On March 25, 1988, police used dogs and a water cannon to brutally disperse thousands of believers peacefully rallying in downtown Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, for more religious freedom. The crackdown became a symbol of religious persecution in Slovakia, the eastern and strongly Catholic part of Czechoslovakia. The same year, more than 600,000 believers signed a petition for greater freedom of worship. While constraints on religious freedom were tightened followed the crushing of the 1968 Prague Spring reforms, the roots of church-state conflict go back to the late 1940s, after the Communists seized power. Authorities suspended diplomatic relations with the Vatican on April 24, 1950. They increased pressure on Catholics, whose allegiance to a ``foreign power'' _ the Vatican _ was seen as a threat to stability. Christianity was erased from official history, religious education was banned in schools. The state often refused to give state licences to bishops appointed by the Vatican, leaving up to 10 of Czechoslovakia's 13 bishoprics vacant. In 1970, fearing increasing diplomatic isolation, officials launched talks on possible renewal of ties. It was not until Czechoslovakia's revolution opened the way to spiritual freedom that relations with the Vatican warmed considerably. On March 29, 1990, an official Czechoslovak delegation in Rome presented Pope John Paul II with a request to renew diplomatic ties. They were formally restored Thursday. Czechoslovakia was the third Warsaw Pact nation to restore relations with the Holy See, after Poland and Hungary. In his drive to strengthen the church in the East, John Paul has visited his native Poland three times as pope and has scheduled trips to Hungary and Poland next year. For Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, 90, the visit will be a vindication of decades of courageous resistance to Communist pressures. ``It will be a great awakening of consciousness,'' said Tomasek, who spent four years in a labor camp in the 1950s. Some 3 million believers from Czechoslovakia as well as neighboring Poland and Hungary are expected to flood Prague, Velehrad and the Slovak capital of Bratislava over the weekend, when John Paul gives his blessing to the country's estimated 9 million Catholics. The visit also has an indirect political dimension, coming 50 days before the country's first free post-Communist elections on June 8-9. It could significantly boost the popularity of the increasingly strong alliance of Czechoslovak Christian Democrats, who dominated elections in East Germany and Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: White House Calls Hostage Demands `Smokescreen'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 7-8, In remarks, with new grafs 7-9m with speech delivered.
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today that new terrorist demands over the promised release of an American hostage were a ``smokescreen'' and part of a troubling pattern. ``They do it every time,'' presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said when asked if kidnappers holding three Americans were toying with the United States. ``Syria still believes there's a possibility of release. We'll just have to wait and see if they're sincere and hope that they are,'' Fitzwater said President Bush on Thursday defended his decision not to send a U.S. envoy to Syria, as the kidnappers demanded before they would release a hostage. ``The United States does not knuckle under to demands,'' the president said. Fitzwater spoke aboard Air Force One as Bush flew here today from Key Largo, Fla., to help raise money for an underdog Republican candidate for the Senate. Bush was in Birmingham for a fund-raiser for state Sen. Bill Cabaniss, a conservative businessman trying to oust incumbent Democratic Sen. Howell Heflin. He was then flying to Orlando, Fla., for another political fund-raiser before returning to Key Largo for a weekend of fishing. In his speech at the Cabaniss fund-raiser, Bush renewed his plea for passage of a capital gains tax cut, from the current 33-percent top to 19 percent or lower. The tax in Japan on stocks and bonds is only 1 percent, Bush said, and other Asian trading rivals ``don't tax them at all.'' ``Once again I call on the Congress to pass that bill. It's time we stop giving the edge to (other) countries,'' said Bush. He also called for ``rejecting the ideas of extremists on both sides'' of the environmental debate, and passing a Clean Air bill that doesn't throw people out of work. More than 1500 people attended the event, which raised over a half million dollars for the candidate. Asked about the complaint from the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine that Bush had not dispatched the envoy they requested to Syria, Fitzwater said, ``That was just a smokescreen.'' He said the United States had an ambassador in Damascus capable of conducting any talks that were necessary. He called the terrorist demand, which came after they had proomised to release an American by today, part of ``troublesome patterns that we've seen before.'' He cited the terrorists' release of a photograph of one hostage one day, and of another hostage a day later. ``The pattern is very much the same,'' Fitzwater said. ``They announce the release, put out pictures for videotape or letters and then there's some demand or reason why it can't happen. So our attitude is to be prepared to take all the precautions and the preparations necessary to facilitate it if it does happen, but not to get overly optimistic.'' On the crisis in Lithuania, Fitzwater said U.S. officials were still talking with allies around the world about appropriate responses to intensified Soviet pressures on the breakaway republic. ``There's still a lot of unknowns we're trying to work out,'' Fitzwater said. At a marathon waterside news conference in Key Largo Thursday with visiting French President Francois Mitterrand, Bush indicated he is moving cautiously on the Lithuanian crisis because of the importance of the U.S.-Soviet relationship to arms control and freedom for Eastern Europe. But ``there are limits'' to U.S. patience, said Bush. The Lithuanian and Middle East hostage situations overshadowed other topics that Bush discussed at his Key Largo meeting with Mitterrand, who paid a nine-hour visit to the United States. The United States is consulting with France, West Germany and other allies on what steps to take, but Bush was unwilling to signal his hand. ``My reluctance stems from trying to keep open a dialogue and discussion that affects many, many countries'' on such sensitive issues as arms control and the growth of democracy in Eastern Europe, he said. ``I am greatly concerned by this escalation in terms of using energy to push the Lithuanians into line,'' said Bush. He added it still was not clear exactly whether the oil and gas supplies to Vilnius have been cut off. On the hostage situation, the president said, ``We've been disappointed before, hopes raised only to have them dashed by excessive speculation.'' Asked why he had not sent John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Middle Eastern affairs, to Syria to facilitate the release, Bush said, ``The United States does not knuckle under to demands.'' Eight Americans are among the 17 Western hostages believed to be held in Lebanon. Bush praised Syria ``for trying to play a constructive role'' in the hostage release. He repeated the overture to Iran first made in his inaugural address 15 months earlier: ``Goodwill begets goodwill.''

DOC.HEAD: Water-skier Reclaims Artifical Arm Caught By Angler
DOC.TEXT: It lay at the bottom of the Mississippi River for 9{ months, but Chuck Rollins says his artificial arm will be as good as new with a couple of straps and a cable. Rollins, 66, was waterskiing in July when his artificial arm came off after his son-in-law accelerated the boat too quickly. He had a new limb made, but knew that someone would find the flesh-colored arm and wonder where the corpse was. The $2,000 prosthesis with stainless steel hooks surfaced on the end of Corene McCallson's line as she fished Tuesday near Brownsville in southeastern Minnesota. ``I was completely surprised,'' she said. McCallson, 20, of Hokah, called police. Word of her catch quickly made news and reached Rollins, a retired Caledonia construction worker who lost his limb about 13 years ago when a loader tipped over. On Wednesday, he walked into the Houston County sheriff's office and announced, ``Well, I'm the corpse that belonged to that arm.'' ``That's just like winning the U.S. lottery,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Foreign Service Official Arrested For Suspected Espionage
DOC.TEXT: A spy scandal that has rocked the Foreign Ministry escalated Friday with the arrest of a fourth official who allegedly passed secrets to East Germany's ousted Communist rulers. The arrest, and others, have come with the help of a former high-level German intelligence officer who is ``telling all,'' a security official said on condition of anonymity. He gave no further information on the East German. During the past month, five alleged East German agents have been arrested. Four of them were with the foreign service and the fifth worked for the federal border police. The security official said on condition of anonymity the string of arrests is ``far from complete.'' In the most recent case, a 59-year-old veteran diplomat with the initials ``L.P.'' was arrested on suspicion of supplying secrets to the East Germans for at least 15 years. Rolf Hannich, spokesman for the federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe, said the suspect has been with the Foreign Ministry since 1955. He said the diplomat held posts in Belgrade, Yugoslavia; Liverpool, England; Edinburgh, Scotland; Palermo, Italy; and Salzburg, Austria. Since 1987 he has worked at the Foreign Ministry in Bonn as a specialist in international communications and transportation, and international tourism. ``Since at least 1975 the suspect has obligated himself to conduct intelligence activities for the Ministry of State Security,'' said Hannich, referring to East Germany's intelligence service. The service is being disbanded. The diplomat is suspected of delivering ``up to thisth of documents and knowledge available to him baid Hannich. The information was delivered in personal meetings with East Germans and by mail, Hannich said. He did not reveal what kind of information was handed over. A day earlier, Hannich announced the arrest of a 54-year-old foreign service official who had been posted in Sri Lanka, Egypt, Japan, Britain and Austria. The arrests of two other diplomats _ one who had been posted at NATO in Brussels, and the other at West Germany's UNESCO office in Paris _ and of the federal border policeman were announced earlier this month. All are suspected of having spi for East Germany over many years. The Hamburg-based Spiegel magazine identified the official assigned to West Germany's NATO mission as Heinz-Helmuth Werner. It said he had been paid by East German intelligence since 1969. According to the Spiegel report, Werner delivered more classified information to tGermans and the Soviet KGB than East German spyGuillaume. Guillaume was a top aide to then-Chancellor Willy Brandt. Brandt resigned in 1974 after Guillauas unmasked. Guillaume was sentenced to 13 years in prison in 1975 and six years later was traded in a spy swap to East Germany, where he now lives.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Noncommittal on Retaliation Against Japan
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials said Friday they would prod Japan to import more U.S. automotive parts, but refused to say whether retaliatory action would be taken. Japanese automakers have shown no serious commitment to increasing purchases of U.S. parts, despite recent announcements of changes in their procurement system, said Mary A. Toman, deputy assistant commerce secretary. Although the U.S. motor vehicle trade deficit with Japan has narrowed slightly, the parts deficit continues to grow and hit $10.5 billion in 1989, she said. ``Until there are significant increases in sales, we will not be convinced that Japan truly has opened its markets to the world,'' Ms. Toman told the Senate subcommittee on innovation, technology and productivity. Richard J. Roberts, whose Mount Clemens, Mich., company manufactures molds for plastic auto parts, said his efforts to break into foreign markets had been rebuffed. ``This is most discouraging to a company that wants to grow and have the same opportunity their companies receive here in the United States,'' Roberts said. Under a 1988 law , the administration can restrict imports from countries that engage in unfair trading practices. The next round of import restrictions is scheduled to be announced by the end of the month. Ms. Toman and Assistant U.S. Trade Representative Don Phillips declined to say whether Japanese auto parts would be on the list. Japanese and U.S. negotiators agreed on a plan April 5 to reduce trade friction by making broad reforms in both countries' economies. President Bush has praised Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu for promising vigorous efforts to open his nation's markets. Ms. Toman said the Japanese had taken some steps toward improving the situation, citing Toyota's plan to increase its imports of parts 250 percent by 1992. Talks begun in 1986 helped boost U.S. auto parts exports to Japan from $214 million that year to $638 million last year, although the trade deficit widened at the same time, she said.

DOC.HEAD: California Higher Education Chancellor Resigns Amid Pay-Raise Furor
DOC.TEXT: The head of the 20-campus California State University system abruptly resigned today at a special meeting of the trustees, who then rolled back large pay raises she had given herself and top executives. Chancellor Ann Reynolds, who heads the nation's largest four-year and graduate-level university system, would have had her annual salary rolled back $59,000, from $195,000 to $136,000. The trustees voted to cut salaries for 26 executives to last July's levels, meaning college presidents will earn $110,000 instead of $145,000. A trustee subcommittee recommended the rollback Thursday after taking testimony on raises that ranged from 43 percent for Reynolds to 17 percent and 26 percent for deputies and college presidents. The raises sparked a furor in part because the salaries of the best-paid professors at CSU campuses scattered around the state rose only 4.8 percent. Committee members on Thursday focused their protests on the process in which the raises were approved in private. Trustees, who had delegated authority for salaries to Reynolds and board Chairwoman Marianthi Lansdale, complained they were not consulted. Board members said they were kept in the dark about a consultant's study of comparable higher education markets and salaries commanded by their top executives. Reynolds, chancellor since 1982, said her resignation would be effective Dec. 31, 1990, but she told trustees she intends to take a leave of absence beginning Oct. 1 and become a professor in the future. Before her resignation, Reynolds had apologized for the controversy, but stood behind the salary raises. She said they were years overdue, but that she failed to get that information out. ``I think I was remiss in recognizing the impact this would have,'' Reynolds said at Thursday's meeting. ``I take responsibility for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Memo Warns Workloads Could `Overwhelm' Social Security System
DOC.TEXT: The Social Security Administration is seeing warning signs of deteriorating service and rising workloads that could ``overwhelm'' the system, a top agency official says in an internal memo. ``There are signs of this early warning pattern developing in all areas of SSA's basic operations,'' said the March memo to Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King. Deputy Commissioner Herbert R. Doggette Jr. wrote the memo shortly before he retired last month. He said both the numbers of claims pending and the length of time needed to process them increased in 1989. ``When this pattern appears, it is an early warning of deterioration in levels of service,'' Doggette wrote. ``The possibility clearly exists that at some point workload growth could overwhelm our ability to respond, given our limited resources,'' the memo said. The memo, obtained Friday, was first described in a report in The Washington Post. The number of claims pending at Social Security field offices rose 4 percent in 1989, resulting in longer processing times for three of four claims filed, Doggette reported. The number of cases pending in the agency's six major service centers rose 14.3 percent, and processing times in the agency's Office of Disability Operations rose 6 percent, the memo said. Staffing levels at the Social Security Administration were slashed from 80,000 to 63,000 during the Reagan years as part of a campaign to streamline and modernize the system. Many agency employees have complained that the cuts left them overworked and unable to provide good service to the public. Mrs. King, who took over the agency last August, this year has dispatched ``strike teams'' to visit Social Security field offices and approve hiring additional employees, paying overtime and obtaining more equipment where needs are the greatest. She said Friday the agency is adding about 500 workers. ``I'm confident now that, with the changes we made, by the end of this fiscal year we will have our workloads well under control,'' Mrs. King said. She added that with the recent release of $48 million by the presidential Office of Management and Budget, ``We're fine where we are right now. If I see that our workloads are increasing even more, then we'll go back for even more.'' Mrs. King said the administration's budget request of $4.2 billion for the Social Security Administration in the coming fiscal year appeared adequate. However, seven senators on Friday sent a letter to members of the Senate Appropriations Committee requesting an additional $120 million for 4,000 more employees. ``The results of understaffing can be devastating for our most vulnerable citizens, such as poverty-stricken elderly, blind and disabled recipients of Supplemental Security Income,'' the senators wrote. The senators said demands on the Social Security Administration could balloon next year due to a Supreme Court decision requiring the agency to review an estimated 250,000 children for SSI eligibility, and as 100,000 babies addicted to crack are born each year who may qualify for SSI. ``From past experience, we all know how service delivery problems can hurt public confidence in the Social Security program,'' the senators wrote. ``We should act now to prevent further erosion of confidence in this vital program.''

DOC.HEAD: Crowded Asian Cities Face More Problems in Future, Says U.N.
DOC.TEXT: The already crowded and polluted cities of Asia face massive population increases that will exacerbate their problems in the decades ahead, a U.N. study said Friday. Many of the world's largest cities will be in the Asia-Pacific region by the year 2000, according to the report released in Bangkok. The United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific will hold its 46th annual meeting of 48 nations in the Thai capital June 4. Bombay, with 11.79 million and Shanghai, with 11.96 million, are among the region's largest cities, said Mohammed Rahmatullah, chief of the Human Settlement Unit of the commission. And with urban population growth at between 3 percent and 4 percent a year in the Asia-Pacific region, several other cities will soon pass the 10 million mark, the report said. Jakarta, Manila, Karachi, Tehran and Bangkok are all expected to top that figure by the century's end, Rahmatullah said. Bombay is projected to have 16 million people, Shanghai 13.26 million, Jakarta 13.25, Karachi 12 million, Manila 11.07 million, Bangkok 10.71 million and Tehran 10 million, Rahmatullah said. ``Migration to the metropolis will not ease in the foreseeable future,'' the report said, pointing to higher salaries, more jobs, and better health and education facilities in urban areas. Migration is exacerbating already pressing urban problems such as pollution, slums, housing shortages, excessive traffic, and shortages of water and electricity. Most Asian cities have slums. In some cities, 50 percent of the population lives in shanties, squatter settlements or illegally divided houses. Some slum communities are as big as cities, it said. The report called for new low-cost housing, land distribution, and ``innovative financing'' to allow urban poor access to bank loans. But urbanization is not an entirely ``negative force.'' Cities contribute more than half a country's gross national product, the report said. ``Economic development fuels urbanization and urbanization in turn fuels other economic development,'' it said. The challenge for authorities is to promote economic growth and at the same time find ways to solve urban problems, Rahmatullah said. The commission recommends governments encourage settlement of ``secondary cities,'' set up factories near smaller cities, and improve job opportunities and services in rural areas.

DOC.HEAD: Forestry Section Included in Senate Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee responded to concerns about global warming Friday by including a forestry section in a farm bill for the first time. ``In light of the numerous issues that have developed pertaining to forestry _ global warming, timber production, threatened and endangered species, air and water quality _ it is time we re-examine our commitment to state and private forestry and the numerous owners of small, private forests,'' said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga. Fowler is chairman of the subcommittee on conservation and forests and comes from a state where small, privately held forest acreage generates about $9 billion and provides 80,000 jobs. ``Including forestry in the farm bill underscores an important fact,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the agriculture committee. ``The total value of our timber harvests exceeds that of any crop, including corn, soybeans, wheat and hay.'' About half the timber used commercially in the United States comes from the 482 million acres of private forests, most of which grow wild. About 21 million acres are managed to assure certain timber supplies are available. The national forests, which supply the rest of the nation's timber, are carefully managed by the federal government. Leahy said one goal of the legislation is to put another 25 million acres of private forestland under management programs. The bill, which will be in the version of the 1990 farm bill that goes to the full Senate, makes the most significant changes in forestry laws in 14 years. It would: _Set up a public-private partnership with 8 million private forest owners so the private sector could get technical assistance already available to government foresters. _Establish an easement program through which the government would buy development rights from forest owners to assure that environmentally sensitive forestlands aren't threatened by commercial building. _Create federal, state and local coordination committees to help carry out the programs offered by the bill. Money for the programs would be determined later. The House has not acted on any similar legislation in the version of the farm bill it is writing.

DOC.HEAD: Heinz Calls for Census Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., is calling for immediate Senate hearings on problems surrounding the 1990 census. ``The stakes are too high and the implications too far-ranging for Congress not to take an active role in responding to the problems,'' Heinz said Friday. His comment came only a day after a group of House members took the Census Bureau to task. Mail-back response to the census has been slower than expected and problems were experienced in getting forms delivered to 4.8 million people in several areas. This is being corrected, Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant told a House census subcommittee meeting on Thursday. She said the accuracy of the count is not in danger. But she estimated it will cost at least $100 million more than originally planned to count people who haven't responded by mail. Subcommittee chairman Thomas Sawyer, D-Ohio, said the cost overrun could be $150 million or more, and others have put the figure as high as $190 million. The 1990 census is expected to cost a total of $2.5 billion, with $1.3 billion being spent this year. Although the bureau has not yet begun its detailed door-to-door effort to count people who did not respond by mail, several House members expressed concern that the final count will be inaccurate. ``I think we are facing a crisis,'' said Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., who has been pressing for establishment of local census coordinators to be appointed by each member of Congress. Democratic national chairman Ron Brown said Thursday that the possibility of adjusting the final numbers to account for those who are overlooked should be considered. The Commerce Department, parent of the Census Bureau, has resisted the idea of adjusting the final figures, but says it is still considering the possibility. Heinz's call for a hearing on Census problems came in a letter to Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, head of the Governmental Affairs Committee.

DOC.HEAD: 50,000 March in Manhattan to Protest Bias Against Haitians
DOC.TEXT: More than 50,000 loosely organized marchers converged on lower Manhattan today, closing the Brooklyn Bridge to protest a federal AIDS policy they say discriminates against Haitians. By early afternoon, traffic was badly snarled, even by Manhattan standards. ``The Brooklyn Bridge, Manhattan Bridge and all local streets in the area of lower Manhattan, City Hall and Federal Plaza are rapidly going to be gridlocked,'' Fred Feldman, spokesman for the city Department of Transportation, said. Lt. Ray O'Donnell, a police spokesman who provided the crowd estimate, said a lack of organization and leadership among the marchers created the traffic disruption. The march was called to protest a Food and Drug Administration policy prohibiting anyone who has emigrated from Haiti from giving blood, as a precaution against spreading AIDS. Dr. Joel L. Solomon, director of the FDA's Division of Blood and Blood products, said emigres from Haiti and some African countries are excluded because the AIDS-related virus is so widespread there. Also, AIDS is transmitted largely through heterosexual activity in those countries, meaning that the immigrants would not be covered by the FDA ban on blood donations by men who have had homosexual contacts. The immigrants from the countries affected are mostly black, and some have charged racism. One of the protesters carried a sign reading, ``Let's Fight AIDS, Not Nationality.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Debates Path Toward German Unity
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's new parliament on Friday debated the path toward unity with its rich Western neighbor in a session that highlighted fears about the impact of the planned merger. In an interview to be published Saturday, East Germany's finance minister, Walter Romberg, warned that 70 percent of the country's factories would need huge support or would not survive economic union. And the chief of the former Communist Party criticized the government's plan for unity and said it would allow West Germany to colonize East Germany. At the parliamentary session, lawmakers united behind Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's desire for East Germany's currency to be valued at the same rate as the mighty West German mark. But differences quickly emerged over the speed of reunification. Taking advantage of the newly found freedom of protest, the reformed Communist Party walked out of the chamber after a member of an arch-conservative party likened the communists to the hard-liners who ruled East Germany 40 years. The arc-conservative, Joachim Hubertus Nowack of the German Social Union, compared the ousted government to the Nazi dictatorship that preceded it. The Farmers' Party, one of the many factions in the 400-seat parliament, threatened a blockade of openings in the crumbling inter-German border if agricultural markets were threatened by a flood of imports during the moves toward a market economy. Gregor Gysi, who took over the battered Communist Party and oversaw its name change to the Party for Social Democracy, urged a slow merger and said East Germans must have a chance to ``go upright into unification.'' He said the constitutions of both Germanys should be abolished and a new series of laws written for a united nation. Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl rejected this with the comment: ``No more socialist experiments.'' The coalition government led by de Maiziere has proposed that East Germany adopt the existing West German constitution. Wolfgang Thierse of the left-leaning Social Democrats, who advocated the slower process before it joined the government coalition, said the quick route is the ``realistic way'' to unity. But he said the Social Democrats would ``fight'' for revisions to the constitution to include the right to housing, employment and education currently laid down in basic East German law. The chairman of West Germany's Social Democrats, Hans-Jochen Vogel also cautioned against rapid unification. ``It would be terrible if we made mistakes because we proceeded too quickly. Mistakes that the people must put right again,'' Vogel told reporters. He was visiting East Berlin for the parliament session and a meeting with de Maiziere. In an effort to calm fears about massive unemployment, de Maziere said Friday that planned tax incentives and new investment laws would help create 500,000 new jobs in middle-sized enterprises this year. That would compensate for job losses in large state concerns. In an interview in Saturday's edition of the West German ``Neue Westfaelische'' newspaper, finance minister Romberg was quoted as saying only 30 percent of East Germany's industrial concerns could handle competition in a free market economy. He said that 20 percent would survive only with ``very heavy capital expenditure'' while 50 percent needed ``a lot of investment.'' The text of the article was released in advance to other news media.

DOC.HEAD: AP, British Media Ordered to Give Riot Film to Police
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press, two British news agencies and a television company must hand over all film of a March 31 riot in London that left about 580 people injured, a judge ruled Friday. At a hearing in the Old Bailey Central Criminal Court, Judge Neil Denison granted the police application. He rejected arguments that freedom of the press is paramount. He said the right of the press to report freely and the need to trace serious offenders clashed and one had to give way. ``There are two conflicting areas of public interest,'' Denison said. ``They have to be weighed and balanced one against the other, and in a sense they are irreconcilable.'' The AP, the British domestic news agency Press Association, and London Weekend Television opposed the application on grounds it made them appear an arm of the police and endangered their photographers. The fourth organization, Fleet Street News Agency, made no objection. ``If applications routinely succeed, there is a loss of the perceived independence of the media,'' Robin Oppenheim, legal counsel for the three news organizations, told the court. Police had sought help from news organizations in identifying those who participated in the riot that engulfed Trafalgar Square and London's theater district. The riot broke out after a demonstration against a new tax. Britain's 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act allows a judge to order news media to turn over material in the case of serious offenses.
