On April 6, Denison ordered 25 British newspapers and TV companies to turn over their film to help identify rioters. Police then asked for film held by news agencies and London Weekend Television. The order, which the judge is to sign Monday, means the AP and Press Association must give police all negatives of the riot. But the judge said the AP, Press Association and London Weekend Television were right to oppose the application. ``Orders such as this should not be made as a matter of course,'' he said. ``It would be wrong if the media were to back down and concede every application that is made,'' he said. ``They are perfectly entitled to come to court and put their arguments.'' The violence broke out after demonstrators tried to storm Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's 10 Downing St. office. They then attacked police and rampaged across London's West End. Nearly 500 police officers and 86 civilians were injured, and hundreds of shops were looted and cars burned.

DOC.SECOND: Senators Propose Amendment To Overturn Supreme Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Two Republican senators proposed a constitutional amendment on Friday to overturn a Supreme Court ruling that local government officials could be ordered to increase property taxes to finance school desegregation. The 5-4 high court ruling on Wednesday involved a Kansas City, Mo., school desegregation case. Sens. John Danforth and Christopher Bond, both Missouri Republicans, introduced the proposed amendment, which states: ``Neither the Supreme Court nor any inferior court of the United States shall have the power to instruct or order a state or political subdivision thereof, or an official of such state or political subdivision, to lay or increase taxes.'' Ratification of a constitutional amendment requires a two-thirds majority approval by the House and Senate and then must be ratified by three-fourths of the states. Danforth, in a statement, said he viewed the Supreme Court decision as empowering federal judges to personally impose taxes and contended that the Constitution gave the power of taxation exclusively to the legislative branch. ``That decision flatly contradicts a fundamental premise of American democracy which predates the Constitution itself,'' Danforth said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Bars AIDS-Infected Boy from Sunday School
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts to reflect that state officials confirm only the boy is infected, not that he has become sick as a result.
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old boy infected with the AIDS virus has been barred from attending Sunday school classes at a church while the pastor decides whether the boy may return.
DOC.HEAD: The boy's, 2nd graf
Lithuanians Seek Oil From Norway
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister came to the heartland of Norway's petroleum industry Friday and suggested a trade of farm products for oil to help the Baltic republic survive a Soviet energy blockade. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, asked about reports Soviet soldiers stormed a printing plant and beat civilian guards in Vilnius, denounced the Soviets. ``It's not so easy for the Soviet army to provoke conflicts and clashes, although it is often clear that this is their aim,'' Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters. ``We can only say that these clashes are very unpleasant, but the situation ... has happened before,'' she said. She also said she had been told by Lithuanian authorities in Vilnius that a trip she planned to the United States and Canada at the end of April had been canceled, apparently to avoid a conflict with the U.S.-Soviet summit set to begin May 30. ``I got the idea that my trip was too close to the summit meeting in America, but I'm not sure this is why the trip was postponed,'' she said after receiving a cable from the Foreign Ministry in Vilnius. The Soviet Union, trying to prod Lithuania to recant on secessionist moves, has cut off crude oil supplies and most of its natural gas supply. Mrs. Prunskiene came to this west coast oil town to meet managers of the government Statoil company. The company has said it is ready to sell oil to Lithuania on a normal commercial basis. The Norwegian government told the Lithuanians they are welcome to buy its North Sea crude, but it has given no promises of aid or credit. Mrs. Prunskiene suggested that Lithuania and Norway could trade agricultural products and other products for oil, though ``we don't know if Norway is interested in buying our products.'' ``It would be natural for those who buy oil to also pay for it. But our situation is different. As you know, the hard currency has always been taken from Lithuania to Moscow,'' she told reporters. The Soviet embargo ``means the time has come in Lithuania ... to find new sources of oil deliveries and look to other countries,'' she said. ``This looking for new possibilities may start in this city.'' Norway, which pumps 1.5 million barrels a day from North Sea oil fields, is the second-largest oil exporter outside the OPEC oil cartel. It also produces natural gas but has no way to deliver it to Lithuania. Mrs. Prunskiene said her delegation would explore the possibility of refining Norwegian crude oil in Lithuania, though it would take several months to set up an infrastructure to transport the oil to the refinery. She said the small republic, which lacks hard currency, would seek foreign markets for dairy produce and other farm products previously sold through Soviet authorities. In exchange, Lithuania gets energy supplies at below-market rates. ``If the Soviets cut off oil deliveries, it's natural that Lithuania will answer with its own coin,'' she said. Lithuania also would seek export credits, which she said would not necessarily have to be given by the exporting country. The delegation leaves Norway on Saturday for Denmark. It made hasty arrangements for a stop in Sweden on Sunday before returning home.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Home After `Routine' Exam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs `Matlin said ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT name to Matalin, sted Matlin
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Committee chairman Lee Atwater returned home Friday after a one-day hospital stay, an RNC spokeswoman said. ``It was one of a series of routine examinations'' Atwater must have as part of therapy for a brain tumor, said Mary Matalin, Atwater's chief of staff. The tumor was found last month. In New York earlier this month, surgeons implanted radioactive isotopes in the tumor in an effort to kill it. The isotopes were removed after several days. Atwater also has been receiving physical therapy and undergoing daily radiation treatments. Physicians have described the tumor as aggressive. Matalin said Atwater, who has had difficulty walking, entered George Washington University Medical Center on Thursday for a ``routine leg scan.'' He returned home by noon Friday, she said. The Washington Post had reported that Atwater was hospitalized after experiencing ``renewed weakness'' on the left side of his body.

DOC.HEAD: Air Helicopter Gunships Raid Southern Village
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli air force mounted its third raid on Lebanon in two days Friday, blasting strongholds of pro-Iranian fundamentalists in the western Bekaa Valley, police reported. They said four helicopter gunships fired 12 air-to-ground rockets into the village of Ein al-Tineh, three miles northeast of Israel's self-designated security zone. Police said there was no immediate report of casualties from the village. It is controlled by the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, whose guerrillas have frequently raided the Israeli-held enclave. The air strike lasted five minutes. On Thursday, Israeli fighter-bombers twice raided a tunnel complex used by Syrian-backed Palestian guerrillas above the coastal town of Naameh south of Beirut. Two people were wounded. The new raid raised the number of Israel's air assaults on targets in Lebanon to 12 this year. A total of 10 people have been killed and 31 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Rally for Handyman Held in Booby-Trap Killing at Warehouse
DOC.TEXT: A handyman accused of setting a shotgun booby trap that killed an intruder in his frequently burglarlized warehouse was ordered held Friday while authorities decide whether to prosecute him for murder. Denver District Attorney Norm Early said hundreds of callers had offered unsolicited advice ranging from ``give the man a medal, to hang him.'' Friends of Philip Connaghan, who surrendered Thursday, say they have received offers of help for him. Connaghan, who was in Kansas when the youth was killed, appeared before Denver County Court Judge Larry Bohning, who ordered him held without bond for investigation of first-degree murder. Prosecutors have until Tuesday to file formal charges. Michael McComb, 19, of Denver, was shot in the chest late Saturday while leading three juveniles in an apparent burglary attempt at the downtown warehouse. The three juveniles, who were booked for investigation of burglary and released to their parents, told police they were looking for adventure. Police said the shotgun that killed McComb was attached to a trip wire they believe Connaghan rigged at the warehouse, which has been burglarized of his tools eight times since 1987. The front door of the warehouse bore the inscription: ``Danger _ Enter at own risk.'' Tim McComb, father of the slain youth, declined comment, other than to say, ``I'd just as soon let it be.'' The mother of one of the unidentified youths told The Denver Post: ``They were talked into doing this. It's quite devastating. Our kid got led into something he shouldn't have gotten led into.'' Early has said Colorado's ``Make-My-Day'' law, which allows people to use deadly force to defend themselves in their homes, probably does not apply. The law was nicknamed after a line from a Clint Eastwood movie. Friends of the 46-year-old Connaghan, meanwhile, have rallied to his defense. They began taking up a collection Friday to replace his tools and provide legal fees. Kevin Corbin, owner of the nearby Skyline Cafe, said he's received calls from across the country offering to help raise the $10,000 lawyers have demanded for his legal fees. ``People here support Connaghan 100 percent,'' Corbin said. ``He put bars on the windows, put up steel doors and even welded them shut and he couldn't keep the burglars out. He even had a danger sign on the front, saying enter at your own risk, and that didn't keep them out.'' Connaghan lost more than $7,000 in tools during a burglary last July. The warehouse also holds auto parts, acetylene torches and truck camper shells. ``Nearly everyone here has had their cars broken into or their houses broken into, and they're just fed up,'' said Corbin. ``Police wouldn't do anything about it, or couldn't do anything about it. They couldn't just stop their patrols to guard one building. ``Something's wrong, maybe it's the whole system. But people are fed up and so far, all of the callers are saying it's time we did something about it. I haven't had one person say they thought it was wrong,'' Corbin said. Corbin said Connaghan often brought his granddaughter to the restaurant while he drank coffee. ``He'd give you the shirt off his back, and I'm sorry to see him go to jail for people who took everything he owned,'' he said. ``If he goes to the penitentiary for this, crime will just go up in the area because criminals will know they can get by with a slap on the wrist.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to restore slug line
Senators Propose Amendment To Overturn Supreme Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Two Republican senators proposed a constitutional amendment on Friday to overturn a Supreme Court ruling that local government officials could be ordered to increase property taxes to finance school desegregation. The 5-4 high court ruling on Wednesday involved a Kansas City, Mo., school desegregation case. Sens. John Danforth and Christopher Bond, both Missouri Republicans, introduced the proposed amendment, which states: ``Neither the Supreme Court nor any inferior court of the United States shall have the power to instruct or order a state or political subdivision thereof, or an official of such state or political subdivision, to lay or increase taxes.'' Ratification of a constitutional amendment requires a two-thirds majority approval by the House and Senate and then must be ratified by three-fourths of the states. Danforth, in a statement, said he viewed the Supreme Court decision as empowering federal judges to personally impose taxes and contended that the Constitution gave the power of taxation exclusively to the legislative branch. ``That decision flatly contradicts a fundamental premise of American democracy which predates the Constitution itself,'' Danforth said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Press Back in Lithuania _ Briefly
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About two dozen foreign correspondents were back in Lithuania on Friday _ but only for a few days, on a trip organized by the Soviet Foreign Ministry. The Soviet government expelled virtually all foreign correspondents from Lithuania on April 1 under threat of losing their accreditation in the Soviet Union. No explanation was given for that order, or for the special Foreign Ministry-sponsored trip. About 20 to 25 journalists who were given permission to stay in Lithuania until Sunday. The trip came just as Moscow cut oil and gas supplies to the Baltic republic in its latest attempt to force Lithuania into rescinding its March 11 declaration of independence. Journalists said it appears that the small Lithuanian Communist Party faction loyal to Moscow was behind the trip, hoping to win coverage of its party congress Saturday. This group has orchestrated the intimidation tactics of Soviet troops, including the occupation of public buildings in Lithuania's capital, Vilnius. The Moscow loyalists seemed unhappy when some of the journalists arriving in Vilnius on Thursday night immediately left their care to cover the story of the Kremlin embargo. Most correspondents were too busy to consider the party leaders' offer of a city tour Friday. But several attended a news conference where the Communist group's leader, Vladislav Schved, repeated his demands for imposition of presidential rule. That could include martial law and dissolution of the parliament that so infuriates him. Other journalists went to a briefing with military officers. On Saturday, the party's congress faces major competition for the journalists' attention. On the same day, the pro-independence movement Sajudis will hold its own congress, and it claims more than 10 times the Schved group's 35,000 members. Journalists said Soviet officials have not interfered with their work. But all must leave on Sunday and the republic remains off-limits for regular travel. Participation on this week's trip was restricted, but apparently arbitrarily. The New York Times, The Washington Post and Cable News Network all asked to go and were told they were not included on the trip. All also requested permission to travel to Vilnius on their own simultaneously with the Foreign Ministry excursion. They were denied permission.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania Bjt
Soviet Envoy Sees Better Chance for Lithuanian Talks
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin said Friday that chances for a ``fair and honest dialogue'' with breakaway Lithuania were improved by the Soviet parliament's adoption of legislation implementing the constitutional right to secede. But Dubinin repeated the Kremlin's position that the next step toward dialogue cannot be taken until Lithuania withdraws its unilateral declaration of independence and enters talks based on the Soviet Constitution and the new Soviet law of secession. ``I would like to say once more that the Soviet government would like nothing more than to settle this problem by an open and honest dialogue,'' Dubinin told reporters at the Soviet Embassy. ``There would be no one in the globe more interested in this than we are,'' he said. Because of the adoption of the new law, he said, ``the conditions are now there to go forward in the spirit of perestroika and the rule of law.'' Meanwhile, at the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Secretary of State James A. Baker III raised the issue of Lithuania at a meeting on arms control issues with Dubinin and Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Viktor P. Karpov. Baker restated the U.S. position that the independence crisis in Lithuania should be resolved peacefully and that a process should be started leading to dialogue, Ms. Tutwiler said. She said the United States continues to consult with its allies on the situation in Lithuania. The United States has declared that reprisals can be expected if the Kremlin uses force or coercion to force Lithuania into line. Dubinin said he had seen no sign the Lithuanians were willing to begin a dialogue on the terms spelled out by Moscow. ``At the present time I have no indication of their willingness to do so,'' he said. ``Until now, the Lithuanians do not accept this element,'' he said. ``The answer has to be given by Vilnius,'' the Lithuanian capital. The new Soviet law of secession calls for independence to be ratified by a two-thirds majority in a referendum. Such a vote would be followed by a five-year transition period. Responding to a question, Dubinin said that while it is true the Soviets have sharply reduced the flow of natural gas into Lithuania in an attempt to force the withdrawal of the Lithuanian parliament's independence decree, gas is still reaching the country ``at the level necessary to assure each day's needs of the population.'' ``It is at a lower level, but sufficient to assure normal life,'' he said. Moscow completely cut off oil supplies to Lithuania on Wednesday night. Dubinin spoke during ceremonies in which he accepted a gift on behalf of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The gift, a large cross fabricated of black walnut and bronze, was presented by officials of Architectural Metalwork Inc., of Tarpon Springs, Fla., to show support for Gorbachev's policies of democratization, expanded free enterprise and increased religious freedom. The cross bears the Russian word ``Mir'' meaning ``Peace.'' Pat Shrader, one of the owners of the company, said she and her associates thought it was important that a message of support for Gorbachev's policies come from ``just grass roots and non-famous people.'' ``Our individual lives are degraded or improved by the conditions surrounding us,'' she told Dubinin, saying the group's wish for Gorbachev is ``wisdom and success.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical Reform Economist Elected Moscow Mayor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gavriil is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A radical reform economist, Gavriil Popov, was elected Moscow's mayor Friday by the new city council, the official Tass news agency reported. The city council was dominated by reformers in recent elections, which were the first multi-candidate elections for local representative bodies in the Soviet Union. The split between progressives and their opponents on the council was reflected in the 280-162 vote for Popov. He has captured national attention for his leadership of the country's first parliamentary opposition group, the progressive InterRegional Group of the Congress of People's Deputies. Soviet officials are allowed to hold two elected posts simultaneously. The election of the 54-year-old reformer portends drastic change for the Soviet capital, which has fallen into extreme disrepair under decades of neglect. He strongly supports a market economy and has suggested rationing during the transition period to allocate scarce items fairly. In a nationally televised speech in December, Popov harshly criticized Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov's economic reform plan for continuing central planning for five more years. He noted it went so far into micro-management as to set the number of eggs to be produced per person. Popov suggested that if bureaucrats want to increase egg production, they should raise chickens. Popov is a member of the Communist Party, but as a supporter of the Democratic Platform wing he is in danger of being ousted by hard-liners.

DOC.HEAD: Inventories Up 1 Percent in Last Year
DOC.TEXT: Cattle feedlot inventories in the nation's 13 leading beef states totaled 10.1 million head as of April 1, up 1 percent from a year ago and 4 percent more than two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Officials said it was the largest April 1 feedlot inventory of cattle since 1978. Nebraska was No. 1, edging Texas, the usual leader. Increases from a year ago were reported in Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma and Washington. California and Minnesota were unchanged. Decreases were reported for Arizona, Colorado, Idaho, Illinois, South Dakota and Texas. Marketings of fed cattle for slaughter during January, February and March totaled 5.58 million head, down 1 percent from the same period of 1989 and 5 percent below 1988, the report said. The placement of new cattle and calves on feed during the first quarter of the year totaled 6.09 million head, down 2 percent from 1989 but 5 percent more than in 1988. Cattle feeders indicated they expect to market 6.09 million head during April, May and June, up 1 percent from last year's second quarter and 4 percent more than in 1988, the report said. It would also be the same number as feedlot placements in the first quarter. State feedlot cattle inventories are listed here for the 13 states, which account for about 85 percent of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of April 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.

Arizona 213 90 California 390 100 Colorado 900 98 Idaho 195 89 Illinois 300 86 Iowa 1,020 109 Kansas 1,700 102 Minnesota 330 100 Nebraska 2,150 110 Oklahoma 320 102 South Dakota 270 98 Texas 2,110 98 Washington 165 101

DOC.HEAD: March Deficit Is a Record Monthly High
DOC.TEXT: The government posted a $53.34 billion budget deficit in March _ a monthly record _ pushing the imbalance past the Gramm-Rudman 1990 target in just six months, the Treasury Department reported Friday. The March gap between spending and revenues produced a deficit of $150.85 billion for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, 17.5 percent more than the $128.4 billion imbalance during the first half of 1989. Revenues last month were down 4.9 percent from March 1989 to $64.82 billion, while spending rose 13.6 percent to $118.16 billion. The $53.34 billion difference was the widest monthly gap since a $39.4 billion imbalance was posted in May 1986, according to James Blum, assistant director of the Congressional Budget Office. Louis Crandall, an economist with R.H. Wrightson of New York, said the deficit so far this year points to a return to $200 billion imbalances that existed until recently. Crandall attributed most of the March deficit to Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. payments, spending by the Resolution Trust Corp. to bail out failed savings and loans, expedited income tax refunds as a result of electronic filing systems and Federal Reserve losses because of the falling value of its foreign currency reserves. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law set a target of $100 billion for the total fiscal 1990 deficit. But the law sets no pentalities if the actual deficit ends up exceeding the target, an eventuality that has occurred every year since Gramm-Rudman was enacted in 1985. The Bush administration budget last January estimated the 1990 deficit to be $123.8 billion. The Congressional Budget Office in March projected the deficit would be $159 billion. For the six-month period, revenues totaled $458.29 billion, up 3.9 percent from the first six months of 1989. Spending totaled $609.15 billion, a 6.98 percent increase. As usual, the biggest spending categories in March were for the military, Social Security and other programs in the Department of Health and Human Services and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $28.69 billion in March and $145.47 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $286.79 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $20.33 billion for the month and $119.38 billion for the year so far. They are expected to total $244.59 billion for the year. Other HHS programs including Medicare and Medicaid totaled $17.40 billion in March and $191.17 billion for the year. Interest on the national debt totaled $17.54 billion during February and $254.85 billion for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Party Orders Steps to Revive Popular Support
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese Communist Party said in a rare public release of a major internal document Friday that it must resist ``the corrosive influence of the decaying ideologies'' to maintain close ties with the people. The pledge belied the party's deep anxiety over its ability to continue its 41-year rule over the world's most populous nation in the wake of plunging public support. ``The danger of alienation from the masses may spring up if the party ... does not use its power properly and consciously resist the corrosive influence of the decaying ideologies of the bourgeoisie and other exploiting classes,'' said the document. It was approved by a party Central Committee meeting last month and issued via the official Xinhua News Agency. ``The rise or fall of the party and the state depends on whether flesh-and-blood ties with the masses can be maintained and developed,'' the Central Committee document said. Central Committee documents are rarely made public, and the release of this one appeared intended to dramatize the seriousness of the party's repeated calls for tightening discipline, rooting out corruption and improving its public relations. The Communists, who took power in 1949 with widespread support, lost some popularity in the 1950s with forced collectivization and in the 1960s with the violent, far-leftist Cultural Revolution. But public disillusionment and cynicism have reached a new high since the leadership used the army in June to put down pro-democracy protesters, killing hundreds and possibly thousands. The fall of hard-line Communist governments in East Europe and ethnic clashes on the edges of this vast nation, most recently in the Moslem west, have further undermined the party's stature. ``Our party and state are presently at a crucial period of historical development,'' it said. ``Unhealthy tendencies such as bureaucracy ... and individualism, and corruptive practices such as seeking personal gain through abuse of power, have emerged among some party cadres in recent years. ``We must resolutely rid all malpractices that cut us off from the masses ... (and) boost our party's cohesive force and fighting power,'' it ordered. Among other things, the document told party officials to ``go deep down to the grass roots'' and take part in production so as to learn problems first-hand. They should ``shun formalism ... Mix with the masses, treat them as equals, be willing to learn from them and avoid putting on airs,'' it said. Party officials must not use public funds to hold banquets and must refuse gifts, it added. In recent years, bribes have become an implicitly accepted part of doing business in China. The orders invoked the spirit of the revolutionary era, when Communist soldiers were famous for helping the peasants and not taking anything in return. Since last year's protests, the party's aging leaders have spoken nostalgically of that era and the wartime virtues of austere living, personal sacrifice and patriotism. The document said leading officials who hold themselves aloof and ``evoke dissatisfaction from the masses'' should be fired, but it did not name anyone. One of China's least popular officials is Premier Li Peng, who signed the order imposing martial law in Beijing last year during the protests. There was speculation he might be removed to placate the public, but at the recent annual session of China's legislature he appeared firmly in power. The document, reflecting senior leader Deng Xiaoping's policy of allowing ``small democracy,'' said party officials should listen to the opinions of ordinary people and not retaliate against criticism. But it made clear that ``big democracy'' _ pluralism and an end to absolute party control _ is not under consideration. Instead, it ordered an increase in Marxist education, closer supervision of the party's 18 million members, tightened discipline and absolute obedience to central party officials.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Assistance Provided
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Agency for International Development sent $4 million to Nicaragua on Friday to help victims of the war in the Central American country. The money will be used for health care, food, surgery and other medical help, a statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Calls Lying To Congress A Threat To Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Concealing covert government operations from legitimate congressional inquiries poses a danger to democracy, Iran-Contra prosecutor Lawrence Walsh said Friday. In a speech at the University of Oklahoma, Walsh said ``the need for truth in important human affairs ... is critically needed for the checks and balances of our Constitution.'' When the Reagan administration's secret Contra and Iran initiatives were threatened with exposure in 1986, ``disturbingly, the reaction ... among some of our most sophisticated intelligence operatives and superiors were not unlike those of more simple-minded conspirators,'' said Walsh. ``First some lied separately. Then some lied in concert. Then some destroyed documents and notes.'' The independent counsel has been investigating the scandal since December 1986. He obtained the conviction of former national security adviser John Poindexter on five felony charges April 7. Poindexter was found guilty of covering up from Congress Oliver North's secret Contra resupply operation and the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. North is appealing his conviction of last year on three felonies in the affair. ``The obstruction by some administration officials of legitimate congressional inquiries ... illuminates the need for the rule of law to function in the sphere of covert government activities,'' said Walsh. He said ``the claim that congressional inquiries into intelligence activities might be answered by lies has been rejected by two district judges and two juries.'' The need for secrecy is increasing to meet threats to U.S. security, said Walsh. But that means ``an ever-higher premium must be placed by Congress and the public on the truthfulness of executive branch officials'' who conduct covert operations. Walsh said Reagan administration officials covered up North's Contra supply network because ``truthful responses ... would have invited ... legislative actions designed to end all secret support to the Contras.'' The prosecutor said the Iran arms sales presented ``an even more dangerous threat of hostile congressional reaction'' because the Reagan administration's ``proclaimed ... policy'' was that the U.S. ``would not pay ransom for hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Dominate in Number of New U.S. Patents
DOC.TEXT: More Japanese than American companies ranked among the top 10 recipients of U.S. patents in 1989, the Commerce Department said Friday. Half of the top 10 spots went to Japanese firms and four of those companies outranked any American company, the department's Patent and Trademark Office said. Three U.S. companies were in the top 10 for the fiscal year which ended last September 30. The largest number of patents went to Japan's Hitachi Corp., marking the fourth year in a row that a Japanese company has occupied the top position. Hitachi, which received 1,053 patents, was followed by three other Japanese companies in the top spots. Toshiba received 961 patents; Canon, 949, and Fuji Photo Film had 884. General Electric Co., which had held the top spot from 1969 until 1986, was the top American company on the list with 818 patents, dropping to fifth place from fourth last year. Other American companies in the top 10 were International Business Machines Corp., No. 9 with 623 patents, and Eastman Kodak in tenth place with 589 patents. Other foreign companies in the top 10 were Japan's Mitsubishi Denki in sixth place with 767 patents; U.S. Philips Corp., the subsidiary of a Dutch firm, in seventh place with 745 patents, and the German manufacturing firm Seimens in eighth place with 656 patents. U.S. industrial experts have said the trend of foreign companies, especially the Japanese, dominating U.S. patents is another demonstration that American companies are not adequately investing in the research and development necessary to keep the United States competitive in overseas markets in coming years. The patent office said it issued a record 102,712 patents in 1989, a 23 percent increase from the 83,584 patents issued in 1988. While foreigners obtained almost half of all patents issued last year, the percentage was down slightly from 1988. In 1989, foreigners received 46.7 percent of all U.S. patents, compared to 47.3 percent in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: East Europeans Jam Yugoslav Borders After New Currency Policy
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia on Friday began requiring East Europeans to change about $200 in Western money to Yugolslav currency, a move that virtually closes its borders to former Communist neighbors. Thousands of Romanians, Bulgarians, Soviets and other East Europeans clogged border crossings early Friday, hoping to cross before the measures took effect, according to reports. Yugoslav television showed hundreds of cars, some waiting more than 12 hours, at the Vatin border crossing with Romania. Quarrels and occasional fist-fights broke out between customs officials and impatient travelers. Starting Friday, East European and Soviet citizens entering Yugoslavia through its borders with Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria, had to change the equivalent of $200 in Western currencies to Yugoslav dinars. Many Eastern Europeans do not generally possess convertible Western currency. Officially, the strict money policy was introduced to prevent East Europeans from bringing in large quantities of cheap goods without paying import duties and selling them at Yugoslav flea markets. The Borba daily, however, said the measure was introduced after Western nations suggested Yugoslavia ``should become a filter zone'' for East Europeans seeking asylum in the West. The shortest road from Romania and Bulgaria to Austria and Italy is through Yugoslavia. Over the past two years, thousands of East Europeans have poured into Yugoslavia selling tools, canned foods, spare parts for Soviet-built cars, household utensils and other items at cut-rate prices. The influx of East Europeans increased markedly this year after the dinar became freely convertible. This made Yugoslavia a particularly attractive venue for East Europeans who in their own countries find it hard to get their hands on large amounts of hard currency. In Yugoslavia, after selling their wares for dinars, they can easily exchange the currency for U.S. dollars or West German marks.

DOC.HEAD: Black Unrest Hurts Negotiation Efforts, SAfrica's de Klerk Says
DOC.TEXT: Four blacks died in factional fighting and in clashes with police who fired tear gas and shotguns to break up demonstrations, police said Friday. A police statement said the four were killed in Natal Province over the previous 24 hours, including a youth killed when police fired on a crowd that attacked officers with firebombs and rocks. President F.W. de Klerk told Parliament in Cape Town the unrest was damaging his efforts to launch negotiations on a new constitution. Violence has killed more than 600 blacks this year. ``Constitutional development through the swing of a panga (machete) cannot be obtained,'' de Klerk said. ``I call on all responsible leaders ... (to) use their influence and disciplinary powers to ensure that the violence comes to an end.'' The police statement said officers used shotguns, pistols, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse protesters in several areas. Police gave few details, but said clashes erupted when crowds attacked vehicles or homes belonging to black police officers. Police Commissioner Lt. Gen. Johan van der Merwe said Friday an investigation would be made into a shooting Thursday near the central town of Viljoenskrron that left five black youths dead. The African National Congress, the black political organization, denounced Thursday's killings. ``This is disgusting behavior on the part of the police and we protest most strongly against the killings,'' said ANC leader Walter Sisulu. Police said five police officers fired on a crowd of about 200 blacks protesting rents and other local problems. Four youths, age 13 to 16, died Thursday. A fifth died in a hospital on Friday, local residents said. Youths erected street barricades, set houses afire and threw stones at police in the same area Friday. Officers responded with tear gas, but no injuries or arrests were reported. The ANC pulled out of peace talks with the white government last month after police killed at least 11 black protesters March 26 in Sebokeng, a township south of Johannesburg. De Klerk ordered an inquiry into the incident. The ANC later agreed to reschedule talks with the government May 2-4 to try to clear the way for full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The ANC wants an end to a state of emergency as a precondition for full talks. De Klerk pledged major changes Thursday in remaining apartheid laws as part of his plan for a new constitution that would include blacks for the first time. However, he reiterated his opposition to black majority rule, saying it would lead to domination of the whites. South Africa has 5 million whites, 28 million blacks, about 3 million colored (mixed race), and 850,000 Asians and Indians.

DOC.HEAD: Congresswoman Says Moscow Plans Total Withdrawal From Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has assured Vietnam that all Soviet troops will be out of the Asian nation by 1992, a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee said Friday. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., who headed a seven-member congressional delegation that visited the Western Pacific and Southeast Asia last week, issued a report that described Soviet intentions in Vietnam and discussed U.S. bases overseas. ``Vietnam Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach told the delegation that all Soviet troops would be out of Vietnam by 1992,'' Schroeder said in the 44-page report. ``This is good news.'' The Soviet Union moved into the U.S.-built base at Cam Ranh Bay at the conclusion of the Vietnam War in 1975, but Pentagon officials said in January that the Soviets had withdrawn some fighter planes and bombers. In an interview with reporters, Schroeder said the Soviets no longer are basing their planned withdrawal from Cam Rahn Bay on whether the United States remains at the Subic Naval Base in the Philippines as they have said previously. Leases on six U.S. installations in the Philippines expire in 1991 and American officials anticipate difficult negotiations for continued base rights there. The Colorado congresswoman also said Thach disputed recent reports that the Vietnamese would allow the United States to use Cam Rahn Bay as a military base. ``The Vietnamese have no interest in permitting the United States to use Cam Rahn Bay,'' Schroeder said the foreign minister told the group. ``He said that nations with friendship agreements with Vietnam could ask to use the facilities. And, he hopes that Vietnam and the United States could in the future commence friendly relations.'' Earlier this month, Rep. Thomas Ridge, R-Pa., said Vietnamese officials privately suggested allowing the U.S. military to return to the base if relations between the countries continued to warm. Ridge met with Vietnamese officials during an Indonesia forum sponsored by the Henry R. Luce Foundation and attended by several lawmakers and a group of top-ranking officials of Vietnam's communist government. Schroeder said officials in many Asian and Western Pacific nations count on U.S. support but are not eager to have American troops stationed on their soil. ``It's clear they want us in the region not so much because they fear the Soviet presence but because they fear a power vacuum not knowing who might move in,'' she said. ``They'd like us in the region but not in their country.'' Based on this reaction, Schroeder said she will introduce legislation next week calling for ``dual basing'' in which most of the Army, Air Force and Marine Corps units would be stationed in the United States unless some operational requirement exists to place them overseas. The units would be sent on short-term assignments ranging from a week to six months for exercises and training. ``The passage and implementation of this legislation would permit the closure of the vast majority of the 86 major and 37 minor overseas installations,'' said Schroeder, who heads the House Armed Services subcommittee on military installations and facilities. The congresswoman has been critical of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's list of candidates for base closing, charging that the list is partisan and fails to include enough overseas bases.

DOC.HEAD: Government To Hold Hearing On Safety Defect In Mini-Motorhomes
DOC.TEXT: Some 25,000 compact pickup trucks converted into small motorhomes have a defect that could cause their rear wheels to come off, according to federal highway safety officials who plan a hearing on the problem. In the first such action in six years involving a vehicle on U.S. roads, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration upgraded a 2-year-old defects investigation into ``an initial determination that a safety defect exists.'' The action taken earlier this week could lead to a recall, but none has yet been ordered, said NHTSA spokesman Tim Hurd on Friday. Manufacturers usually issue recalls on their own before the government forces the issue, but the motorhomes are built by 30 different companies, he said. The last step before a recall order will be a public meeting May 23 in Washington at which anyone may testify The agency determined that the motorhomes have overloaded rear axles which can cause failure of wheel bearings or axle shafts and result in the vehicle's wheels coming off. The vehicles have prompted 440 reports of problems, including 16 accidents with injuries and 63 instances in which wheels fell off the axles, according to George Reagle, NHTSA associate administrator for enforcement. The small motorhomes are nearly all modified versions of Toyota mini-pickup trucks, with double wheels installed in the rear. About 25,000 were sold between 1977 and 1986, NHTSA said. Reagle warned owners of the homes to take precautions until the issue is settled. He recommended that they avoid unbalanced loads, minimize weight on the rear axle, keep water tanks nearly empty while traveling, and avoid towing anything or using a roof rack. Tire pressure should be checked frequently, with inside tires at a slightly higher pressure than those on the outside, he said, also recommending that rear wheel bearings be inspected every 10,000 miles and that a competent mechanic be asked to inspect the whole rear axle and rear suspension. The 30 manufacturers of the units identified by NHTSA are Blue Marlin, Coachman, Damon, Esquire, EZ Rider, Four Seasons, Gardner-Pacific, Granville, Huntsman, Keystone, Leisure Odyssey, Odyssey, Mirage of Elkhart, Monterey Leisure, National RV (Dolphin and Seabreeze,) New Horizon, New World, Perris Valley Campers, Ranger, RBR, Rockwood, Saddleback, Sandtana, Shasta, Sun-Land Express, Sunline, Sunrader, Travette, Voyager and Western RV.

DOC.HEAD: School Bells Ring Again in Oklahoma After Reform and Funding Bill Passes
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma teachers expressed hope Friday that the largest reform and funding bill in state history would end the ``no more pencils, no more books'' crisis they said they had faced for years. Most teachers and their students were back in classes Friday after an unprecedented four-day walkout that brought thousands of protesting teachers to the Capitol to push for passage of the education bill. ``That's one of the things that got us this bill,'' Gerald Hoeltzel, state school superintendent, said of the funding crisis. ``As the amount of money available for education dwindled over the past few years, some school districts flatly told teachers there was no money for instructional materials and others made just small amounts available to the teachers.'' As a result, Hoeltzel said, teachers had to dip into their own pockets to buy construction paper and supplemental books. ``We ran a little survey last year and we found out that the average Oklahoma teacher was spending $354 of his own money for supplies for his students,'' Hoeltzel said. The National Education Association ranked Oklahoma 48th in teacher salaries and 46th in total funding for public schools. The Oklahoma Education Association urged teachers to return to classes Friday after passage of the education bill. Neither the association nor Hoeltzel was able to say how many schools remained closed. Those that did not reopen Friday were expected to resume classes Monday. The $230 million bill passed by the Senate provides the largest infusion of funds to public schools in state history. The bill calls for spending $68.1 million to raise minimum teacher salaries by $1,500 a year for four years. Additional money may be spent on salaries at the discretion of the school districts. Oklahoma teacher salaries average $22,000 annually; the national average is $29,648. ``It is not uncommon to find a single-income teacher whose family can qualify for reduced-price lunches,'' Hoeltzel said. Thousands of teachers deserted the classrooms and walked the picket line at the Capitol to pressure the Senate for final passage of the bill as well as the emergency clause, which makes the bill go into effect as soon as Gov. Henry Bellmon signs it, instead of the usual 90-day wait. Bellmon, a Republican, called the special legislative session to address school funding and said he would sign the bill. The signing is expected next week. A two-month stalemate was broken late Thursday when five Democratic senators switched and voted for the emergency clause. The bill got only one Republican vote, a fact Bellmon said ``is nothing to be proud of.'' Although the bill will provide $230 million for education in its first year, part of that will be siphoned off for a sales tax rebate for poor people. That was the concession made to get the necessary five votes for the emergency clause. The OEA represents 31,000 of the state's 35,000 school teachers. An estimated 20,000 teachers took part in the walkout at various times and education officials said about 60 percent, or 343,200 of the state's 572,000 students, were affected by the walkout.

DOC.HEAD: Army Grounds All Chinook Choppers
DOC.TEXT: The Army said Friday it grounded all 290 of its CH-47D ``Chinook'' cargo helicopters after cracks were found in barrel nuts in a chopper undergoing routine maintenance. None will fly again until each of its four barrel nuts is inspected, the Army said. The Chinook is the Army's only medium-lift helicopter. It has twin engines, tandem rotors and is designed to move ammunition, repair parts, petroleum, troops, artillery and special weapons about the battlefield. The chopper, built by Boeing Helicopter Co., was designed in the 1950s and fielded in 1962. A modernization program was begun in 1975 to upgrade the chopper's three models to the newest `D' version. The modernization included such changes as adding new fiberglass rotor blades, new transmission and drive systems and modernized hydraulic and electrical systems. In a statement, the Army said the grounding was ordered because ``cracks have been found in the barrel nuts associated with the aircraft's forward transmission.'' Four of the nuts are used to secure the transmission to the airframe, the statement said. ``It is estimated that approximately 300 of the suspect barrel nuts are currently in the Army's inventory,'' the statement said. Last August and again in October, the Army grounded most of its Chinook fleet after problems were found in the helicopter's transmission oil cooling fan.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Make Gesture to Republicans on Campaign Finance Reform
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats, offering an ``olive branch'' to spur serious negotiations with Republicans on campaign finance reform, retreated Friday on their demand for fixed ceilings on how much candidates can spend. Caucusing behind closed doors for nearly two hours, Democratic senators also agreed to embrace proposals by Republican Sen. John Danforth of Missouri for reducing the cost of TV advertising and discouraging negative campaign tactics. ``We're trying to send a signal to Republicans. I hope they'll look upon it as a signal,'' said Oklahoma Sen. David Boren, the author of a Democratic campaign reform bill that the party's leaders want to bring to the Senate floor late next week. The Democratic meeting followed a similar GOP meeting Thursday among more than half of the Senate's 45 Republicans on campaign reform. Senators planned to huddle again in party caucuses next Tuesday. Boren and Kentucky Sen. Mitch McConnell, a GOP point man on the issue, both plan to have revised porposals on behalf of their parties prepared by early next week. ``Before you can have real negotiations, you have to have each side say, `here is our starting point,''' Boren said. ``We know we're not going to enact a law by picking off people on the other side. Fundamentally, it is going to have to be a bill that is not passed on party lines.'' However, one new obstacle to a possible consensus emerged Friday among the 20 Democratic senators up for re-election in 1992. Several among them, including some of the nine who swept seats formerly held by Republicans in 1986 to return the Senate to Democratic control, objected to any new restrictions until after the '92 election. ``Everybody's for it in the abstract _ and wants it to take effect next time,'' quipped Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Democrats would exchange ideas over the weekend on how to ``grandfather'' exemptions for candidates ``who have already raised and spent'' so much they face exceeding the limits well before the 1992 election. While Boren said such exemptions would obviously apply to challengers as well, minority Republicans can be expected to raise vigorous objections because incumbents easily amass large campaign chests early in the six-year Senate election cycle. The development could throw the 1986 class of freshman Democrats in the Senate into an unusual alliance with House Republican campaign officials, who already are building a warchest for the 1992 election. Because 1992 is the first election after congressional districts are reapportioned based on this year's census, Republicans look upon it as a better opportunity than 1990 to cut significantly into the 258-176 majority that Democrats now enjoy in the House. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., according to sources, has even suggested to his GOP counterpart, Rep. Bob Michel of Illinois, that Democrats might consider delaying implementation of any new campaign spendig law until after 1992 as a concession to Republicans. Mitchell said Friday there has been no such talk among Senate Democrats. Boren said the revised Democratic package will include ``flexible'' ceilings that would restrict how much candidates can raise from out-of-state donors but impose no limits on small contributions from in-state residents.

DOC.HEAD: Accord Gives New Gov't Opportunity An Opening to Start in Peace
LaserPhotos SJO2,MGA4
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The cease-fire in Nicaragua's 9-year-old civil war and an agreement to dismantle the rebel army have bought time for the incoming U.S.-backed government to show it can solve the country's problems. A pacified Nicaragua is essential to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose inauguration Wednesday will end a decade of leftist Sandinista rule. Mrs. Chamorro's promises of reviving the moribund economy were a key reason for her electoral rout Feb. 25 of President Daniel Ortega's Sandinistas. ``I'm very happy,'' Mrs. Chamorro said after the agreements were signed Thursday, ``because we don't want war anymore, we want peace and reconciliation.'' The history of peace and cease-fire pacts in Central America is not encouraging, but the agreements appear to have a better chance than most of succeeding. For one thing, the negotiations involved one of the Contra's senior field leaders, Oscar Sovalbarro. Most previous agreements have been about the Contras without actually involving them, giving them no stake in compliance. The Sandinistas appear to have decided to play the part of a democratic opposition after their electoral defeat; they are moving to change from a narrowly defined revolutionary party to a broader political movement. In the two days of talks, there was little of the posturing that suggests the parties are playing for publicity. Only one photographer was allowed into the signing ceremony, unlike past scenes of wall-to-wall photographers. ``Let it be clear that what has been signed here is something serious, something formal, and I think that we all have the good will to fulfill this signed document,'' Sovalbarro said. Sandinista army Gen. Humberto Ortega, defense minister and brother of the president, said he was satisfied with what he called an agreement reached ``in a profound, serious way, with a great spirit of responsibility.'' But nine years of civil war and 30,000 deaths in a country of 3 million have left a legacy of suspicion. Guns have always meant power in Central America, where democracy has no tradition, and neither side wants to be the first to put down its weapons. On Thursday, President Ortega said the agreements brought the nation ``much closer to peace'' but the pacts still had to be carried out. ``The war will have disappeared on the moment that all the Contras have disarmed,'' he said. For its part, the Sandinista Party controls not just the army but also cooperative farms, unions and other peasant and worker organizations that have weapons. Cadres at neighborhood party headquarters are also armed. The Sandinistas fear the Contras would become a right-wing military force and help overturn reforms in health, education and land distribution; the Contras fear continued Sandinista control of the army would lead to an overthrow of Mrs. Chamorro. Both sides fear a wave of vendettas if families seek the return of seized farms or revenge for those slain in the fighting. The bitterness was visible only hours after the accords were signed, when a senior U.S. State Department envoy was surrounded by a mob pounding on his car's windows, demanding the Contras be demobilized at once. Washington backed the Contras in their war. It then supported Mrs. Chamorro in the election and backed her call for the Contras' dissolution. An additional problem is finding jobs for demobilized fighters: the Contras number about 9,000 and the Sandinista army is much larger, although it has suffered from desertion. Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition alliance is pressing the United States for $300 million in aid, with a good chunk to be devoted to disbanding the Contras. But even if the aid arrives quickly, the government won't be able to ease the chronic economic problems, including unemployment. The cease-fire took effect Thursday and the Contras agreed to dismantle by June 10, 6{ weeks after Mrs. Chamorro takes office Wednesday. That represented a concession by the Contras, who had refused to even consider talking about disarming until Mrs. Chamorro took power. The Sandinistas had been demanding the Contras disband by inauguration day, but Gen. Ortega said June 10 was soon enough. The lag will also allow each to assess the other's sincerity. Mrs. Chamorro's alliance and the Sandinistas signed an agreement March 27 that called for shrinking and de-politicizing the army in exchange for government recognition of the army's ``professionalism.'' Mrs. Chamorro's coalition views the Contras as both allies and problems, and some Contras suspect the new government would like nothing more than for the Contras to go away now that electoral victory has been achieved. The coalition gained the most from Thursday's agreement, even if it only postpones the issues of disarming and demobilizing. The agreements give the new government some _ not much, but some _ political breathing space. If it can show that it is in control, those who are dissatisfied may find themselves isolated and the disarmament agreements will have a better chance of sticking and bringing peace, at last, to Nicaragua.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Doralisa Pilarte, an Associated Press correspondent based in Managua, has reported on Nicaragua and Central America since January 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Helen Hayes Cuts Cake for Steamboat Company's 100th Anniversary
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: The calliope blared, Pete Fountain and his Half-Fast Walking Club strutted and actress Helen Hayes had a few nice things to say as Delta Queen Steamboat Co. celebrated its 100th year on the Mississippi River. ``My favorite form of recreation is riding the river. I've just completed my 12th journey on the Mississippi River,'' Miss Hayes told about 150 guests and a few hundred people attracted by the hour of Dixieland music that preceded the ceremonies. ``I've seen them all, all the rivers. But this is the greatest _ the Mississippi,'' she said. The four-deck Delta Queen, white with green decks and gleaming wood doors, window frames and railing, was the backdrop for the platform where Miss Hayes spoke. The steamboat was designated a national landmark in 1989. Docked next to the Delta Queen, was the seven-deck Mississippi Queen, which carried Miss Hayes from New Orleans to Vicksburg and back. Flags of the 14 states that line the Mississippi River system and a United States flag fluttered behind the platform, which also bore a 5-foot-high cake decorated like the ``floating wedding cake'' _ the steamboat _ behind it. Grammy-award winner Aaron Neville sang ``Happy Birthday'' and Miss Hayes, grasping a long cake knife, posed with U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs, D-La., company president Patrick Fahey and Gordon C. Greene III, grandson of the company's founder. Earlier, the crowd heard from President Bush, whose letter was read by U.S. Rep. Bob Livingston, R-La., and from Gov. Buddy Roemer, Mayor Sidney Barthelemy and Roger Durrett, who rides the riverboats and emceed the ceremonies in the character of Mark Twain. Twain piloted paddlewheelers when they were still the fastest and most reliable way for goods and passengers to move along the Mississippi River. By the time Greene's grandfather founded the Greene Steamboat Company in 1890, they were giving way to railways, which ran regardless of snags or water levels. Despite that, the first Gordon Greene made an excellent business of steamboats. He, his wife, Mary _ who stood watches with her husband during their honeymoon and later became a pilot and captain _ and their sons eventually owned a fleet of 28 boats. In 1946 their son Tom bought the Delta Queen at an auction from the U.S. Maritime Commission. The 285-foot-long boat had been built for $875,000 in 1926 as a Sacramento River luxury shuttle, but was taken over by the Navy in 1940, painted gray and renamed Yard Ferry Boat 56. Tom Greene bought the boat for $46,250, but had to pay another $750,000 to scrape off the Navy paint and restore the Delta Queen. The company was renamed the Delta Queen Steamboat Co. in 1973. The flagship's captain for the past 14 years has been Gabriel ``Gabe'' Chengery, 42. ``I've been in love with these paddlewheelers since I was 7 years old,'' he said while Fountain led his jazz band and ``walking club,'' a group of Mardi Gras revelers who were dressed in purple and pink pirate costumes. ``Are you the captain of the Delta Queen?'' a tourist mistakenly asked Rear Adm. Maurice ``Moss'' Bresnahan, whose rows of medals were bright against his Navy whites. ``No, but I'm flattered,'' the commander of the U.S. Navy Reserve Surface Fleet answered with a smile.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Wants to Limit Star Wars Spending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY limiting spending on Star Wars and MX plan among several proposed reductions. INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf pvs, `He projected..' to ADD background on Nunn
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's 1991 defense budget could be cut nearly $6 billion through reductions including Star Wars spending and delaying a plan to put MX nuclear missiles on rail cars, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said Friday. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., called for a military budget of $297 billion to $298 billion for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Bush wants a $303 billion budget, including an additional $1 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as Star Wars. ``Assuming SDI is redirected into a coherent and rational research program, I believe it should be funded at roughly the current appropriated level,'' Nunn said in a speech on the Senate floor. Congress approved about $3.8 billion for the anti-missile shield in 1990's $296 billion defense budget. The SDI total marked the first reduction in the program in six years. Nunn's overall budget proposal is about $1.5 billion more than the cut adopted Thursday by the House Budget Committee and some $6 billion higher than the figure suggested by Senate Budget Committee chairman Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn. ``I think the fight will be to try to keep defense even at the levels I'm talking about,'' Nunn said. He projected defense savings of about $3 billion to $3.5 billion this year from the changes in the strategic programs and between $20 billion and $30 billion over the next five years. Nunn's comments on the budget were the first by the powerful chairman of the Armed Services Committee. He is the leading defense expert among conservative Democrats. Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, White House budget director Richard Darman dismissed all Democratic defense proposals and argued that lawmakers' affection for pet defense project in their districts will prevail over the cuts. ``As it gets much more clear what it means for particular congressmen's districts, you'll see the political system, independent of defense strategy, start to put a bottom on that defense cut,'' Darman said. Nunn called his budget range a ``realistic and responsible target.'' He said there should be a delay in placing multiple-warhead MX missiles on railroad cars and criticized the purchase of trains while the Pentagan is still conducting tests. The Bush budget calls for $2.2 billion to put 50 MX missiles on rail cars. Sens. Carl Levin, D-Mich., and James Jeffords, R-Vt., introduced legislation Friday that would cut $1.6 billion of the administration proposal for the MX. That total represents all the procurement and military construction funds in Bush's budget for MX. ``The MX rail-garrison funding plan is a classic example of the flawed `buy before you fly' policy that has cost the country so much money in recent years,'' Levin said in a speech on the Senate floor. Nunn reiterated his support for the single-warhead Midgetman missile, but suggested deployment in existing silos with mobile launchers a later option. He repeated his opposition to development of a new short-range nuclear missile in Europe and questioned buying a new Trident submarine each year and Trident D-5 missiles with nuclear warheads in short supply. Nunn reserved comment on the B-2 stealth bomber until after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney briefs members of Congress on the Pentagon's review of major aircraft programs. However, Nunn said the B-2 program of 132 planes at a cost of $72 billion ``must be made more affordable.'' Nunn called for slashing Bush's defense budget authority to $289 billion to $291 billion, about $18 billion less than the president has proposed for fiscal 1991. Because budget authority represents the amount that can be spent over several years _ such as in a long-term contract to purchase warships _ the cut would force reductions in future Pentagon spending plans.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Gives Chiles 34-Point Lead Over Nelson
DOC.TEXT: A poll released Friday puts former Sen. Lawton Chiles 34 points ahead of U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. The poll was released two days after the third candidate dropped out. Chiles also has a 6-point edge over Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, according to Mason-Dixon Opinion Research, which interviewed 618 registered voters. The poll's margin of error was 4 percentage points. State Sen. George Stuart dropped out of the Democratic race on Wednesday, eliminating the need for a runoff, and threw his support behind Chiles the next day. The poll was conducted between Monday and Wednesday, but surveyed people's preferences between two candidates. Chiles last week said he was inspired to end his self-imposed retirement by Vaclav Havel, the formerly dissident playwright who is now president of Czechoslovakia. The Mason-Dixon poll also found that voters generally weren't concerned about Chiles' admission that he is taking the commonly prescribed anti-depressant drug Prozac. The 60-year-old former chairman of the Senate Budget Committee underwent open-heart surgery in 1985 and has been treated for depression since late last year. Chiles said last week that he first noticed the condition sometime before retiring from the U.S. Senate in 1988. Stuart launched his run for governor in early 1988, but trailed Nelson in polls and campaign contributions. He endorsed Chiles after announcing that he would instead run for state treasurer and insurance commissioner. Martinez, Florida's second Republican governor since Reconstruction, is seeking a second four-year term.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Rally for Oil Drilling Ban
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's silence on environmental policies affecting Florida's Keys during his visit has not been matched by activists. They're using his vacation as a forum to call for an offshore oil drilling ban. Several organizations have announced plans for demonstrations this weekend in Islamorada, where Bush has scheduled a fishing excursion and a ceremony honoring a coral reef preservation group on Sunday. One group has promised daiquiris mixed in solar-powered blenders. Also, some officials have criticized the administration's inaction on the oil drilling issue and Sunday's upcoming Earth Day celebrations to assail Bush, who proclaimed himself the ``environmental president'' while campaigning. ``For Bush to remain silent when all of the Florida Keys is opposed to offshore oil drilling is appalling,'' said Ann Whitfield, executive director of the Florida Public Interest Research Group. ``This would have been the time to act, but he missed an opportunity to show he has a real interest in the environment.'' Bush has said he is willing to ban drilling in some environmentally sensitive areas, but stopped short of guaranteeing protection of the Florida Keys. Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., urged Bush to ban oil drilling and support a Coast Guard plan to move shipping lanes farther from fragile reefs off the Keys, where three freighters ran aground last year. ``You know all the arguments and I look forward to the day when we will spend our time telling fish stories instead of debating the issues,'' Fascell said in a letter to Bush issued Thursday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday that Bush will not make a policy announcement on the oil drilling issue this weekend. Fitzwater said a task-force report on oil drilling off Florida and California needs more study. The special presidential task force issued its report in January, but the findings have not been disclosed. A temporary moratorium on oil exploration on key tracts off the California and Florida expires Oct. 1. There are 73 leases issued to oil companies off Florida's southwest coast affected by the present moratorium. In California, oil companies have proposed developing millions of acres off the state's central and northern coasts. On Saturday, Greenpeace and several others groups will hold a mock ``before and after'' protest to illustrate the damage an oil spill would have on the Keys' sensitive coral reefs and mangrove coastline. The following day at the lodge where Bush is staying, members of Environmental Solutions Inc. have scheduled an exhibit to show energy alternatives to oil. An invitation to the event promises daiquiris mixed in solar-powered blenders. Among the proposals endorsed by environmental groups is revoking the 73 oil leases and permanently banning off-shore drilling south of 26 degrees north latitude, a bill co-sponsored by Florida's two U.S. senators. That latitude runs across Florida roughly from Naples to Fort Lauderdale. A ban on oil drilling in the Everglades is scheduled to be considered next month by Gov. Bob Martinez. ``We have a unique opportunity here as environmentalists _ to solve a problem before it becomes a problem,'' said Ms. Whitfield. On Key Largo, the threat of an oil spill from a tanker or off-shore rig is particularly worrisome to those who make their livings off the reef and the clear waters. ``One oil spill _ one mistake _ and the Keys as we know them are gone,'' said Anthony Greene, who operates snorkling tours. ``It's goodbye Keys, hello New Jersey.'' Studies of a 1986 oil spill off Panama show severe damage to coral reefs and oil seeping deep into the sediment in the mangrove areas, said Lisa Speer, senior scientists at the New York-based Natural Resources Defense Council. ``A spill in the Keys would be quite different than the Valdez spill in Alaska,'' said Ms. Speer. ``Without the pounding wave action, the oil filters down and remains there. It would be a huge tragedy.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Carrying Two Danish Journalists Missing
DOC.TEXT: Air and land rescue teams searched dense, mountainous jungle in southern Costa Rica Friday for a light plane carrying two Danish journalists who were making a film about the country's national parks. The single-engine Cessna disappeared Monday after leaving San Jose for Corcovado National Park, according to Civil Aviation operations chief Jose Trejos. He said the search began about three hours after the plane disappeared. Park director Eliecer Arce identified the journalists as Johnny Kosten, 45, and Bo Kristian Pedersen, 38. He said they had been filming in the area for Danish TV for three weeks. Their Costa Rican pilot was Miguel Cespedes, 35. Meanwhile in Panama, divers on Friday brought up the last of 20 victims of a plane crash in the Pacific, civil aviation authorities there said. The victims included four Americans. A 14-year-old French boy and a Swiss woman were the only survivors of the Wednesday crash of the Aeroperlas Twin Otter aircraft. The wreckage lay 90 feet down a mile north of Contadora Island. The plane crashed after taking off from the tourist island for Panama City. A U.S. Embassy official identified the Americans as Panama Canal pilot Karl Heck and his wife, Anita, both of Panama City; Lisa Langlow, 34, whose family lives in Fox Island, Wash.; and Richard Dobson Poux, also of Washington state. No other ages or hometowns were available, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Three Doctors Overprescribed Drugs to Elizabeth Taylor, DA Says
DOC.TEXT: Three physicians who treated Elizabeth Taylor overprescribed narcotics for their ``demanding, famous client'' but will not be criminally prosecuted, the district attorney's office said Friday. ``It is clear that the prescribing practices of these physicians fell below the accepted standard of medical practice,'' Deputy District Attorney Daniel Feldstern wrote in a report. ``However, it is equally clear that these physicians, in trying to resolve the patient's medical condition, were also attempting to deal with her addiction through alternative means of therapy and treatment, and that their conduct was lacking in the requisite criminal intent,'' it said. Miss Taylor was battling pneumonia at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in nearby Santa Monica. She remained in stable condition Friday, her spokeswoman, Lisa Del Favaro, said from New York. The illness is not believed to be linked to the prescriptions. The 58-year-old actress was expected to remain hospitalized through the weekend, said Ms. Del Favaro. She said Miss Taylor was in good spirits, receiving a stream of cards and letters from well-wishers. Los Angeles County District Attorney Ira Reiner declined to prosecute Drs. William Skinner, Michael Gottlieb and Michael Roth, but will refer the case to the state medical board for possible disciplinary action, the report said. Messages left with the doctors' exchanges Friday were not immediately returned. In 1983, Miss Taylor acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and painkillers prescribed for health problems. She was treated at the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage for alcohol and drug abuse that year. From mid-1987 to October 1988, Skinner, Gottlieb and Roth were treating Miss Taylor for a painful, chronic back condition and cumulative effects of addictive medication, the report stated. Skinner is medical director of the chemical dependency center at St. John's. Gottlieb is the immunologist who reported the first AIDS cases in the United States, and Roth was once Gottlieb's partner. Skinner, who was instrumental in having Miss Taylor admitted to the Ford clinic, wrote hundreds of the prescriptions investigated, Gottlieb wrote dozens and Roth wrote prescriptions infrequently, the report said. Among drugs Skinner prescribed were Demerol, Percodan, Valium, Ativan, Xanax, Preludin and Dilaudin. Demerol is the brand name for meperidine, a strong narcotic analgesic similar to morphine. The evidence concerning Miss Taylor's treatment was reviewed for Reiner's office by Dr. David Smith, referred to in the report as an authority in addiction medicine. Smith found that ``over-prescribing was clearly documented,'' the report stated, but it pointed out that the doctors also tried to ``detoxify the patient'' and to convince her to re-enter the Ford Center in November 1988. ``I recommend that some appropriate administrative action be taken so that the physicians in question, no matter how well intended, learn that following appropriate prescribing guidelines coupled with established principles of chemical dependency apply even to a demanding, famous client,'' Smith wrote. Dave Thornton, a senior investigator with the Board of Medical Quality Assurance in Sacramento, said discipline could range from a reprimand to license suspension. Miss Taylor was hospitalized with a sinus infection April 9 at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital. She was transferred to St. John's on Monday because of a persistent fever and pneumonia. The actress had a near-fatal bout of pneumonia in 1961, the year she won an Oscar for ``Butterfield 8.''

DOC.HEAD: Panel: New Gov't Enjoys Support, But Rights Violations Persist
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The new civilian government has considerable popular backing in its push to end a history of human rights abuses and to hold elections, the head of an international rights panel said Friday. But rights violations persist following the ouster of a military government in March, and panel members would not say whether conditions were conducive to holding the first free and fair balloting since Haiti gained independence 186 years ago. ``Any country which is going toward elections is a country which is moving away from violations of human rights,'' said Oliver Jackman, chairman of the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights of the Organization of American States. Jackman said the new government ``enjoys a considerable measure of popular support and has the specific mandate to create the conditions for elections,'' which are expected this year. However, another member of Jackman's delegation, Patrick Robinson, said: ``In some respects, the situation has not improved (since the last visit by the commission in August 1988).'' In March, 83 Haitians were killed and more than 120 injured in rights abuses, the Haitian Center for the Defense of Rights and Liberties said in a report this month. The nine-member OAS commission, in Haiti since Monday, interviewed Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the former Supreme Court justice who took over when Prosper Avril quit and fled the country last month following a weeklong popular uprising. The commission also talked with her chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Herard Abraham, and other government officials, political and rights activists, members of the press, and other civic and religious leaders. It said it was told of the necessity to disarm paramilitary thugs, break up the repressive country sheriff system and separate the police force from the army, as provided for in the 1987 constitution. On Nov. 29, 1987, an attempt at free elections was canceled after at least 34 voters were shot or hacked to death at the polls by thugs in collusion with the army. In September 1988, Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, considered responsible for the attack on the voters, was ousted in a palace coup. Avril, Namphy's successor, had promised reforms but jailed opponents and encountered severe criticism over rights policies. Under the civilian caretaker government that replaced Avril, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot governs with a 19-member Council of State. Elections are expected before the end of this year, and will be organized and controlled by a nine-member independent electoral council and probably supervised by U.N. and OAS election monitors.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 7:45 p.m. EDT Friday
DOC.HEAD: Five Waterways Targeted For Cleanup
With AM-Bush-Environment, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush designated five environmentally troubled waterways Friday for intense review and development of cleanup plans, including the bay that leads into Boston's polluted harbor. The president said the waterways in Maine, Massachusetts, Louisiana and Florida would become part of the National Estuary Program and be eligible for some of the $16 million in federal funds under the program. Congress established the National Estuary Program in 1987 to help protect and improve the environmental quality of significant estuaries. Twelve estuaries already are in the conservation program. Under the program, federal and state money is used for a five-year study and planning effort aimed at identifying key environmental problems and ways to resolve them. States must provide some matching funds. The five waterways singled out by Bush are Tampa Bay and the Indian River Complex, both in Florida; the Barataria-Terrebonne Estuarine Complex in Louisiana; Casco Bay in Maine, and Massachusetts Bay in Massachusetts. Massachusetts Bay leads into Boston Harbor, which became a subject of debate in the 1988 presidential campaign after Bush criticized Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis for not cleaning up the harbor. Since then, some environmentalists have criticized the Bush administration for not providing federal money for further harbor cleanup in Boston. Bush, speaking at a fund-raising dinner for Florida's Republican Party in Orlando, said he was pleased to make the announcement on expanding the estuary program ``as we head into the Earth Day.'' ``It's a good first step,'' Rudy Rosen, an expert waterway conservation problems for the National Wildlife Federation, of the president's action.
