But Rosen added that the designation would mean little if not followed by further action. ``Designation is great, but it's got to be backed with regulatory enforcement, both state and federal, and the money to do the job,'' he said in an interview. Paul Pritchard, president of the National Parks and Conservation Association, called the announcement ``a good step'' but said on many environmental areas the president has ``backtracked badly'' from campaign promises. Bush also came under attack Friday from congressional Democrats who accused the president of not following his rhetoric with action on environmental issues. A group of Democratic senators, including Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine, criticized Bush for not moving more aggressively to deal with global warming, opting instead to call for additional research. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., said Bush failed to ``provide the leadership'' earlier in the week at an international White House conference on global warming. European delegates have sought commitments on specific reductions in carbon dioxide emissions, while the White House has said more research is needed for such pollution controls should be sought. ``President Bush refused to call the nation to action on the serious problem of global warming, rather he used (the conference) to call attention to all of the obstacles,'' said Mitchell at a news conference to discuss Earth Day. In the House, Democrats called on Bush to celebrate Earth Day by declaring his support for legislation that would force federal agencies to comply with the same environmental laws the government imposes on industry. ``The federal government has operated under a ``do as I say, not as I do'' rule,'' more than 80 House Democrats said in a letter to Bush. Although Bush promised during his campaign to bring the government agencies into compliance with federal environmental laws, the White House has opposed efforts in Congress to mandate such compliance as part of a bill elevating the Environmental Protection Agency to cabinet level.

DOC.HEAD: Marla Maples Boosts ABC's `PrimeTime Live'
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples, who declared her love for married billionaire Donald Trump on ABC News' ``PrimeTime Live,'' proved a ratings bonanza for the show, preliminary Nielsen audience estimates showed Friday. Not only did the show win its time period for the first time since it made its debut in August, the ratings were the show's highest since its October special on the San Francisco earthquake, which killed 67 people. Thursday's ``PrimeTime Live'' with the Maples interview averaged a 14.2 rating, compared with a 12.6 rating for the show's earthquake broadcast. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Network programs competing with the ABC News exclusive _ NBC's rerun of an ``L.A. Law'' episode and a CBS special, ``Learned Pigs and Fireproof Women'' _ averaged a 13.0 and an 8.7 in the ratings, respectively. Diane Sawyer, who co-anchors ABC's show with Sam Donaldson, conducted the interview with Maples. Maples is said to be the ``other woman'' in Trump's life. The developer is estranged from his wife, Ivana. Maples declined in the interview to characterize her relationship with Trump. But when Sawyer asked if she loved him, the actress-model replied, ``I do love him.''

DOC.HEAD: Indians Protest as Approval of Giant Water Project Looms
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian utility representative spoke of kilowatts, reservoirs and big savings to taxpayers, but the grand chief of the Cree Indian tribe saw a giant hydroelectric project in a different light. ``It will be a cultural genocide for us,'' said Cree Grand Chief Matthew Coon-Come. ``Our main diet is fish. They tell us we cannot eat the fish.'' ``America, you are the builder. Wall Street is financing. It's time the little guy starts speaking up,'' Coon-Come said Thursday after he and other Indians paddled up in a canoe and climbed onto a lower Manhattan dock in the shadow of skyscrapers. It was the last stop on a 1,300-mile trip from their Quebec homes. Coon-Come and Robert Brunette, a vice president of the government-owned Hydro-Quebec, differ about how much land the project would affect. Estimates range as high as several hundred thousand square miles. Most of the power generated would benefit Canada. But up to 10 percent would be exported to various of the United States. The project requires reversing the course of three rivers. And it means building six more dams along five rivers that flow into James Bay in northern Quebec. The contracts to finance the project and sell the power have been signed. The only remaining obstacles are approval from Canada's National Energy Board and an avalanche of bad publicity brought on by the 10,000 Cree and Inuit Indians who live along the James Bay. Brunette conceded that some species of fish would be made inedible by mercury contamination. ``There is jubilation in my heart and also I cry,'' said Coon-Come, relieved at completing his journey but predicting doomsday for his home environment. ``Some people call us primitive,'' Coon-Come said. ``We still hunt and fish as a way of life. We have protected that land.'' He drew sympathy from Dennis DeLeon, New York City's Human Rights commissioner, and from city Councilwoman Miriam Friedlander, who said people ``continue without thinking to destroy fragile parts of the earth.'' The New York Power Authority says that buying hydroelectric power from Quebec since 1978 has saved more than $600 million and eliminated the need for nearly 6 billion gallons of oil. The state would be able to start drawing power from the new project in 1995, saving about $3 billion over 20 years, said Power Authority Chairman Richard Flynn. He said the project would cause significantly less environmental damage than the coal-burning plants that would have to be built otherwise. As for the Indians, Flynn said, ``We really think it's an internal affair for the Canadians.''

DOC.HEAD: NRC: Arson Fire at Inspector's House Worst Violence Against Agency
DOC.TEXT: A fire that gutted the home of a Nuclear Regulatory Commission inspector is the most serious case of violence in the agency's history, an NRC official said Friday. ``I'm not aware of anything of this magnitude in the past,'' said Ken Clark, an NRC spokesman in Atlanta who has been with the agency since its inception in 1975. The fire Thursday destroyed the home of Ken Jenison, the NRC's chief resident inspector at Sequoyah Nuclear Plant, hours after he received threatening telephone calls. Specifics of the calls weren't released. The fire was ruled an arson Friday, said Hamilton County arson investigator Jimmy Swafford. A basement window was found broken and it appeared fires were started in the basement and on the second floor. Nobody was injured, but officials estimated damage at $150,000. Jenison was scheduled to be transferred later this month and the house was listed for sale at $110,000. Jenison, who was at work when he heard of the fire, tried to leave the plant, but discovered that the lugs on his car wheels had been loosened. The FBI, Hamilton County arson investigators and the Tennessee Valley Authority, the federal utility that operates Sequoyah, are all investigating the fire. ``Every agent in the southern part of the state is working on this,'' said William Baugh, special agent in charge of the FBI's Knoxville office. The blaze occurred less than a week after the NRC fined the TVA $240,000 for harassing whistleblowers at its Watts Bar Nuclear Plant and recommended a $75,000 penalty for failing to correct a safety problem at Sequoyah. ``It is always a possibility that someone will take offense at something that happens as a result of some action an NRC inspector takes,'' Clark said. Jenison had received harassing but unintelligible phone calls at his home Wednesday night, and someone called him at his office twice on Thursday, Clark said. ``It was something to the effect that they were going to burn his house and it had to do with his being an NRC inspector,'' Clark said. ``But I don't know the specifics.'' Jenison was not in his office Friday and could not be reached for comment. Clark said it was not uncommon for NRC officials to receive harassing phone calls, but he said he could not recall any other serious acts of violence. Jenison had not received any other harassing calls before Wednesday _ although his house was burglarized in January _ and there have not been any threats against the NRC's two other inspectors at Sequoyah, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Say Barry Put Crack in Pocket Before Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Friday that Mayor Marion Barry put crack cocaine in his jacket pocket and spoke of previous cocaine use with ex-model Rasheeda Moore the night he was arrested by the FBI. In court papers, the U.S. attorney's office said the Washington, D.C., mayor and Moore ``talked of their previous times together, including their past cocaine experiences,'' when they met in a hotel room Jan. 18. The government filed the papers in opposition to Barry's motion for dismissal of the charges against him. Barry argues that his Fifth Amendment right to due process was violated because the government ``manufactured the crime'' against him. Barry's lawyers said in an earlier filing that ``the facts ... depict a conspiracy to distribute cocaine'' by the government, with Barry's due process rights being violated by ``the lawless conduct of ... police.'' The prosecutors said Barry's ``conversation confirms that he had drugs on his mind as soon as he arrived'' in the room at the Vista Hotel, where the mayor was the target of an undercover sting operation. ``Once he was alone in the room with Ms. Moore, he asked her in their coded vocabulary if she was still using drugs,'' said the 23-page court filing. Once crack cocaine was obtained from an undercover agent posing as a friend of Moore's, Barry ``took a portion of the crack and placed it inside his jacket pocket which was hanging on a door knob nearby,'' said the papers. ``After taking two hits from the pipe, he put on his jacket and called his security officer by walkie-talkie as though he was ready to leave,'' they added. Barry ``asked for the crack; he eagerly accepted it; and he appeared to be quite adept at smoking it,'' said the prosecutors. Law enforcement officers then entered from an adjoining room and arrested the mayor. The prosecutors also said that at the start of their conversation, Barry ``indicated'' to Moore that ``he wanted cocaine powder, not crack.'' But when the undercover agent left the room to get powder, Barry told Moore to get the crack instead, said the court filing. Moore called the undercover agent back in the room; Barry gave money to Moore, and Moore bought a bag of crack. Barry faces trial June 4 on five counts of cocaine possession and three counts of allegedly lying to a federal grand jury by denying he had been involved in drugs with Charles Lewis, a former city employee. Lewis is now the government's chief witness against Barry. The prosecutors also asserted that Barry showed very little liquor in his blood, making it difficult for him to argue that ``the government plied him with liquor in an effort to overcome his resistance.'' ``Actually, during the 45 minutes that he was in the hotel room, cognac was poured sparingly from a bottle three times and only in small amounts,'' said the prosecutors. ``He nursed his drink during the duration of the visit.'' His blood alcohol content was .005 after his arrest and ``would have had to have been 20 times higher to reach even the threshold legal limit for driving under the influence,'' said the government.

DOC.HEAD: Mary Alice Williams Named Co-Anchor of NBC's ``Sunday Today''
DOC.TEXT: Mary Alice Williams was named Friday as the permanent co-anchor of NBC's ``Sunday Today'' show, succeeding Maria Shriver, who left the show two weeks ago to spend more time with her family in Los Angeles. NBC's announcement had been expected. But negotiations continued with NBC News for Williams also to be named anchor on the network's Sunday night newscast, said NBC source who spoke on condition of anonymity. The news division's president, Michael G. Gartner, was not available for comment. His office said he had left to spend the weekend at his Iowa home. ``I'm thrilled she's been given `Sunday Today' and some other assignments,'' said Williams' agent, Richard Liebner. Liebner, who also represents Shriver, referred to occasional substitute anchoring that Williams also will do on the weeknight ``NBC Nightly News'' when the regular anchorman, Tom Brokaw, is away. She is scheduled to anchor that newscast next Thursday and Friday, as well as next weekend's editions of the newscast, NBC said. Liebner declined to comment about whether he was still negotiating with Gartner to make Williams the permanent anchor of the Sunday newscast. NBC's annouuncement said that in addition to ``Sunday Today,'' Williams also will serve a substitute anchor on other NBC News programs and do special assignments. One of CNN's original anchor staff, Williams joined NBC News in March a year ago. Married to CNN correspondent Mark Hafeli, she gave birth to a daughter, their first child, in January. Williams co-anchored ``Sunday Today'' with Garrick Utley last week. She returned to work in March after a three-month maternity leave. Shriver, who had co-anchored the show since it began in 1987, also is a new mother. Married to actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, with whom she lives in Los Angeles, she gave birth to their first child, also a daughter, in December. After a maternity leave of nearly four months, she returned to ``Sunday Today'' two weeks ago only to say that she was leaving it, but would continue working at NBC News. She cited as reasons for her move a desire to spend more time with her family and the strain of her weekly commute East to do the show and anchor Saturday's ``NBC Nightly News.'' In a statement, Gartner said Williams ``has done a terrific job for NBC News over the past year. These (new) assignments will enable us to better utilize her talents and expand her already hefty contributions to NBC News.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Ambassador Criticizes Bush China Policy
DOC.TEXT: Former Ambassador Winston Lord says President Bush's China policy is wrong and marked by ``tawdry symbolism.'' He said Bush should not have sent Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, to Beijing after the suppression of pro-democracy forces in Tiananmen Square last June. Lord also said the president should not have relaxed sanctions against China. Lord, who was U.S. ambassador to China from 1985 until just before troops attacked protesting students, said Bush is disappointed his overtures to Beijing were not reciprocated. ``I don't think anyone would claim that they've achieved anything,'' Lord said. The long-time China scholar made his remarks in an interview on the PBS-TV program ``American Interests.'' It will be aired in Washington on Saturday. ``First of all, I think we should keep contact,'' Lord said. ``But I think it should be a working-like relationship as long as they are crushing the Chinese people.'' He said it ``shouldn't include high-level emissaries going to Beijing.'' Lord's stand puts him at odds not only with Bush but with former President Richard M. Nixon and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, both of whom support strong U.S. ties to China despite the Beijing government's actions. Nixon has warned that if the United States withdraws from a close association with China ``it leaves the field to the Soviet Union and Japan.'' Lord, who held a key State Department post in the Nixon administration and accompanied Kissinger on his trips to China in the 1970s, disagreed. ``He's just wrong on this,'' Lord said. ``There is no way the Chinese and the Soviets are going to get very close together,'' he said. ``You have geopolitical disputes. You have ethnic populations across a disputed boundary. You've got competition around the world.'' Japan's occupation of China in World War II has left ``real scars'' even a half-century later, Lord said. ``Those are not going away and China will always want us in Asia to balance off Japan and the Soviet Union,'' he said. Lord did not propose Bush break ties with China. And, he said, the president acted in good faith in twice sending Scowcroft to Beijing. ``He knew the Scowcroft missions would be unpopular at home,'' Lord said. ``He tried to break the logjam in China.'' Lord said U.S. policy should be to maintain contact with Beijing but it should be ``a cool, working type relationship, and not one filled with tawdry symbolism and high-level contacts and unilateral gestures.''

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Wines Withheld After Discovery of Illegal Ingredient
DOC.TEXT: Scientists on Friday ordered stocks of 14 Chilean wines withheld from sale after discovering unacceptably high levels of a sweetener in them. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food said scientists found unacceptable levels of sorbitol, a sweetener found naturally in apple or pear juice but banned from wine because it can change the flavor. The Wine Standards Board, which enforces European Community regulations, ordered the 14 wines to be withheld while more tests were carried out, said a ministry spokesman, who by custom was not identified. ``The ministry is acting to safeguard the integrity of wine. The presence of sorbitol suggests that fruit juice was added in making the wine or that sorbitol was added,'' said the spokesman. Local authorities have also been asked to carry out checks to see if stocks in stores broke the rules, the spokesman said. Chile is the largest South American exporter of wine to Britain, selling 2 million bottles a year, according to the Wine and Spirits Association. In March 1989, the United States ordered Chilean grapes held in U.S. ports or removed from store shelves after traces of cyanide were found in two grapes. No further contamination was found, and shipments resumed. About 6 million crates of grapes were dumped during the health scare.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Stresses Warsaw Pact Obligations Will Be Honored
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann, hoping to ease Soviet concerns on German unification, on Friday stressed that East Germany will honor its Warsaw Pact commitments. Meeting with the Warsaw Pact's top commander, Gen. Piotr Lushev, Eppelmann said security interests of eastern neighbors would play a key role in reunification talks, the official East German news agency ADN said. West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel said Friday that Bonn received a message from Moscow expressing concern about a quick unification. Eppelmann told the Soviet commander that even if a united Germany was part of NATO, no troops from the Western military alliance would be stationed between the Oder and Elbe rivers pending formation of a pan-European security agreement, ADN said. The Elbe River forms part of the border between the Germanys while the Oder separates East Germany from Poland. In a speech to parliament Thursday, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere also underlined East Germany's duties toward the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. He avoided direct reference to NATO, although the coalition government supports a united Germany's membership in the Western alliance. The Soviet Union opposes NATO membership. But West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has said the merged country must remain in NATO. The NATO-Warsaw Pact question will be discussed at the forthcoming ``four-plus-two'' talks between wartime allies, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France, and the two Germanys. ADN also said Eppelmann, a former peace activist who was last week named as East Germany's first civilian defense and disarmament minister, had accepted an invitation to visit Moscow on May 9.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Agrees to Return 18th Century Bible to Last of Mohicans
DOC.TEXT: The last of the Mohicans, who fought beside Massachusetts farmers in the Revolutionary War and embraced their Christianity, will get back a historic Bible presented to the tribe in the 1700s. ``We felt it was the right thing to do,'' Frederic Winthrop Jr., director of a private historical group which has the Bible in its museum here, said Friday after trustees agreed to return it to the Stockbridge-Munsee tribe in northern Wisconsin. The remnants of the Mohican tribe became known as the Stockbridge-Munsee after they were driven from the Berkshires. ``We are pretty elated,'' said Reginald Miller, tribal chairman. ``And the trustees know that we will take even better care of it than they have, because it means so much to us.'' Miller said the tribe, which first approached the Mission House Museum 15 years ago, would display the Bible in its own museum in Bowler, Wis. The museum chronicles the tribe's history from the time it sought shelter in the Berkshires from marauding Mohawks and embraced Christianity in the 1700s. The two-volume gold-embossed folio Bible was presented to the tribe in 1745 by the Prince of Wales. Heiress Mable Choate, who financed the restoration of the Mission House built by John Sergeant, the first missionary to the Stockbridge Indians, bought the Bible from an impoverished church in Red Springs, Wisc., in 1930 for $1,000. She willed it to the Mission House in 1948. The agreement still needs approval by the Probate Court and it could be months before the Bible is actually returned, Winthrop said, ``but we feel that it would be what Miss Choate would want. ... She bought the Bible as a good faith gesture to help the tribe.'' Winthrop, whose own family dates from the beginnings of the Massachusetts colony, said the trustees were finally persuaded by the inscription, which says the Bible was ``given to the Rev. John Sergeant to remain to the use of the successors of those Indians from generation to generation.'' ``A lot of lawyers could have had a lot of fun with this, I suppose,'' Winthrop said. ``But we have become convinced that since there is a question of title, the benefit of doubt should rest with the tribe since this religious artifact is very important to their cultural heritage. For nearly 200 years they took very good care of it and brought it with them on their long journey from Massachusetts.'' The tribe left Stockbridge in 1785, forced out by the settlers who were buying up their land. They moved to New York and Indiana before settling about 60 miles north of Green Bay, Wis. The town of Stockbridge, later painted by Norman Rockwell, was founded in the 1730s as a mission to the Indians at the invitation of Chief Konkapot. The colonial legislature granted the tribe six square miles. In return, the tribe was the only one to formally enlist on the colonists' side in the Revolution. The Stockbridge unit fought from the opening of hostilities at Concord in April 1775 until the war's conclusion.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Rain and More Rain
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rain in Texas, Arkansas and Tennessee on Friday, and rain drenched portions of Oklahoma, Missouri and Illinois. Heavier rainfall totals included more than an inch at Fayetteville, Ark., and Dyersburg, Tenn., an inch at Abilene, Texas, and three-quarters of an inch at McAlester, Okla. Showers and thunderstorms developing in the warm and moist air ahead of an upper level weather disturbance extended from north-central Texas to eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas in the afternoon. A flash flood watch was in effect for much of Texas, west-central and extreme northwestern Arkansas. Rainshowers prevailed from Missouri and Illinois to Wisconsin and Michigan. Rainshowers were also scattered across the lower Great Lakes region and the upper Ohio Valley. A few showers were over western Washington state. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with sunny skies from Arizona and New Mexico to Minnesota and the northern Plains region. Temperatures were in the 70s across much of the north-central United States and reached the 80s across southern Texas, Louisiana and Florida. Readings were only in the 50s in the Great Lakes region and the upper Ohio Valley, with 40s and 50s in New England. In the desert Southwest, temperatures reached into the 70s and 80s. The nation's low Friday morning was 27 degrees at Hibbing, Minn., Sturgeon Bay, Wis., and West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Quizzes Independence Leader
DOC.TEXT: A Kashmiri independence leader accused by the United States of supporting terrorism denounced the Indian and British governments at a Friday news conference. Afterward, he said he was interrogated by the FBI. Amanullah Khan, chairman of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, told reporters that he had not been officially notified about cancellation of his visa. The State Department said Thursday that it had revoked Khan's visa because of his ``support for terrorist acts.'' Khan said Friday's meeting with the FBI was his second. He described his conversations with the agency as ``an inquiry sort of thing ... sort of a background check'' about himself and the Liberation Front that had nothing to do with the announcement of his visa being canceled. FBI official N.M. Michnyak declined to say whether the agency had questioned Khan. At the news conference at the National Press Club, Khan said ``Indian forces have as much right to be in Kashmir as the Russians in Afghanistan.'' Disputing Indian charges that Pakistan provides training and funds for his organization, he said Kashmiris want to be free of both countries and to form an independent Asian ``Switzerland'' open to visitors from throughout the world. Incorporating predominantly Moslem Kashmir into British India, the British ``sold us like cattle'' to the Hindu feudal nobility that ``ruled us ruthlessly for 101 years.'' Kashmire was made part of independent India in 1947. Khan said he arrived in the United States on April 1 in quest of political and diplomatic support for his group's aim to get India to uphold a 1947 agreement to a self-determination election in Kashmir. He said the FBI agent who met him at the end of his news conference had questioned him Wednesday, then telephoned him Thursday. They agreed to meet at the Press Club, and Khan said they spoke for about 90 minutes. Khan said he has visited the United States seven times and that his current five-year multiple visa is valid until 1992. The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service said Khan's visa cancellation does not become official until the attorney general is notified. That action could come next week, said INS spokesman Richard Kenney. Meanwhile, a source at the Indian Embassy said the Indian government wants the United States to extradite Khan. The Indian government alleges Khan is responsible for several killings and attempted murders, kidnappings and terrorist activities.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen Killed, Two Injured in Latest Attack on Church in Egypt
DOC.TEXT: Attackers threw explosives at a Coptic Orthodox church in a southern village, killing a sergeant and injuring two other police guards, a security officer and the Middle East News Agency said Friday. The slaying Thursday was the first in a series of attacks _ most blamed on Moslem extremists _ on churches and Christian-owned property in southern Egypt. The attacks have raised fears of increasing intolerance toward Christians in the Moslem-dominated nation. The attack occurred at dusk, when Moslems traditionally break daylong fasts during the holy month of Ramadan, which ends next week, said the Al-Akhbar newspaper in Cairo. Brig. Ahmed Galal said the identities and motives of the assailants were unknown. More than 200 alleged Moslem extremists were arrested after the previous incidents. The attack occurred Thursday night in the village of Sanhour near the provincial capital of Fayoum, 60 miles south of Cairo. Galal, speaking by telephone from Fayoum, said assailants hurled explosives at the church entrance where policemen stood guard, killing the sergeant but not damaging the church. The state-owned news agency said three attackers on a motor bicycle hurled an explosive device at the church. Fayoum, the hometown of a blind preacher, Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman, has been a focus of violence by Moslem militants for years. He is widely thought to lead Al-Gamaa Al-Islamiya, a Moslem group that demands immediate implementation of Sharia, the 1,400-year-old Islamic religious and ethical code. The government has assigned police to Egypt's 1,500 churches since an upsurge of Islamic militancy in the late 1970s that culminated in the 1981 assassination of President Anwar Sadat by Moslem extremists. Recently, Moslem militants have been active in the southern provinces of Fayoum, Assiut and el-Minya, where there have been riots, clashes with police, as well as arson and stoning attacks on churches and other Coptic properties. Of Egypt's 55 million people, at least 5 million are Christians, almost all Orthodox Copts. The evangelist St. Mark founded the Coptic church in A.D. 40. There has been scattered strife between Egypt's Christian minority and the Moslem majority since the seventh century Arab conquest brought Islam to Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Legendary Mansion of Film Stars Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks Demolished
LaserPhotos LA5, LA6
DOC.TEXT: Pickfair, the romantic estate where legendary movie stars Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks once reigned over Hollywood, has been demolished to build a palatial home for actress Pia Zadora. Cherubs still guarded the gate Friday and vines and flowering shrubs draped the curving wall surrounding the estate, but inside, beyond a thicket of trees, stood only portions of the mansion amid bins of rubble. Sounds of hammering and shouts of construction workers echoed across the hillside where ``America's Sweetheart'' once hosted parties for virtually all the legends of Hollywood's Golden Age as well as royalty and presidents. The 2.7 acres that remain of the original 15-acre estate are now owned by Miss Zadora and her millionaire husband, Meshulam Riklis. They are building an elaborate mansion that will incorporate a living room from the old house. ``A person hates to see part of an era, a very famous era, the Pickfair, just sort of disappear very suddenly. But it's my feeling it's not the end of an era,'' said Matty Kemp, longtime associate of the late silent film star. It was not the house itself but Miss Pickford and Fairbanks, as well as the company that Tinseltown's ``king and queen'' kept, that made Pickfair what it was, said Kemp, who runs the Pickford Co., which continues to handle the late actress' films. ``The glamour came from the people, the celebrities of the day. You name them _ Valentino, Swanson _ that's where the glamour was at Pickfair.'' Miss Pickford made her first movie in 1909, ``The Violin Maker of Cremona,'' directed by D.W. Griffith. She was in more than 100 silent films, including ``Polyanna'' and ``Poor Little Rich Girl,'' before making her first talkie, ``Coquette,'' in 1929. It won her an Oscar for best actress. She followed that with ``Taming of the Shrew'' and ``Kiki'' before ending her career with 1933's ``Secrets.'' The motion picture academy gave her a special Oscar in 1976 for contribution to the industry. Pickfair was built shortly after Miss Pickford married Fairbanks in 1920. What was once a stable in the country and then a hunting lodge was transformed into a gracious home that _ with some exaggeration _ became known variously as the Buckingham Palace of Hollywood or the White House. ``It was as famous as the White House in Washington,'' said Kemp. ``Mary, during her reign as the queen, she was the most popular woman in the world. My God, there wasn't anyone that didn't know Mary Pickford.'' An invitation to Pickfair meant you had arrived. Rudolph Valentino and Gloria Swanson were just two names on a startling guest list: Maurice Chevalier, Anna Pavlova, Charlie Chaplin, Clark Gable, Joan Crawford, Norma Shearer, Jack Dempsey, Albert Einstein, Amelia Earhart, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Henry Ford, Babe Ruth, Lillian Gish and H.G. Wells. Miss Pickford was 86 when she died in 1979. Her marriage to Fairbanks had ended in 1934 and she hadn't made a movie in nearly 50 years. But the mystique of Pickfair lingered on until the end. Her third husband, actor Buddy Rogers, several times called reporters to the mansion to dispel rumors that Miss Pickford, who became reclusive in the mid-1960s, was locked up. She spoke from an upstairs room, using a tape-recorded message or telephone. ``I'm feeling so good that I'm ready to go back to work,'' she said in one such interview in 1978. The mansion at that time was reported to be ``in splendid repair, fully staffed and brimming with legend.'' After her death Rogers decided to sell Pickfair and built himself a new house on a portion of the property. He called it Pickfair Lodge and still lives there. Rogers, who was out of town Friday, sold the house to Jerry Buss, owner of the Los Angeles Lakers, for $5.4 million in 1980. He sold it to Miss Zadora and her husband in 1988 for $6.67 million. The couple announced last July that they were embarking on a two-year remodeling project to transform the house into a Renaissance-style Venetian palazzo with tile roofs, leaded windows, balconies and verandas. The demolition work has been going on since the beginning of the year. Now, however, only a separate guest house-servants quarters and the old house's living room remain standing. The rest had simply begun to crumble. ``I understand they ran into some problems with the foundations, termites,'' said Kemp.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Crew Anxious To Get Discovery Up
DOC.TEXT: The astronauts who will operate an observatory aboard the shuttle Columbia next month said Friday they expect to beat the Discovery's Hubble Space Telescope in sending back celestial clues. ``One of the things we've frequently reminded the space telescope crew is that we will be sending down science data while space telescope is still doing engineering checkout, and so we should be able to beat them to the punch on getting down the first science data,'' said mission specialist Robert Parker. ``We're looking forward to being able to do that.'' The $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, NASA's most valuable payload, is scheduled to head into orbit aboard Discovery on Tuesday. Its first launch attempt was scrubbed shortly before liftoff April 10 when a shuttle power unit failed. The two-week delay has pushed the shuttle Columbia's May 9 launch date back a week or two. In addition to seven astronauts, four of them astronomers, Columbia will be carrying a $100 million observatory called Astro that is intended to complement Hubble's work. NASA plans to roll Columbia out to the launch pad Sunday, 1.6 miles from where Discovery awaits a Tuesday liftoff. It will be only the second time that both of Kennedy Space Center's shuttle launch pads have been occupied at the same time. Columbia and Challenger occupied the launch pads in January 1986. Ten days after Columbia landed, Challenger exploded. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is waiting for Discovery to go up before setting a new launch date for Columbia. ``We tease the Hubble crew that if they don't get out of the way, we're going to go ahead of them,'' said Air Force Col. Guy Gardner, Columbia's pilot. Discovery's payload bay doors were reopened Friday, and technicians began the daylong task of installing Hubble's batteries. NASA completed 130 hours of recharging the six nickel-hydrogen batteries in a laboratory on Thursday. NASA planned to test the batteries Saturday and seal the payload bay later in the day. The countdown for Discovery was to begin Saturday afternoon, with the five crew members returning to Kennedy Space Center on Sunday. At a news conference, Columbia's astronauts readily agreed Friday that the much-touted Hubble is the ``crown jewel'' of NASA's astronomical endeavors. But they said Astro's three ultraviolet instruments and broad band X-ray telescope also will shed light on galaxies, black holes and quasars during the nine days of the mission. While Hubble will be able to discern objects in space with extraordinary clarity and allow astronomers to look back to almost the beginning of time, Astro will have a wider field of view and be better able to detect ultraviolet light. Astronomers expect Astro to uncover targets on which Hubble can focus during the telescope's 15 years in orbit. Columbia mission specialist Jeffrey Hoffman insists ``it's not a competition'' between Hubble and Astro or between the crews. Still, he can't resist ribbing Discovery's astronauts every now and then. ``We get to be astronomers,'' he said. ``All they do is throw out a telescope. Anybody can do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Temporary Ban On Milk Hormone Sent to Minnesota Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The legislation...,' to DELETE redundant reference to Wisconsin and Minnesota.
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate voted 34-23 Friday to give final approval to a one-year ban on a hormone used to boost cows' milk output, making Minnesota the second major milk-producing state to do so. The Minnesota House passed the ban Thursday 68-59 despite protests from the state's dairy farmers that the action would put them at a competitive disadvantage. The measure follows a similar one approved by the Wisconsin Legislature last month. Minnesota and Wisconsin combined produce about 24 percent of the nation's milk. Rep. Chuck Brown, who led the charge for the moratorium in the Minnesota House, said he has received assurances that Gov. Rudy Perpich will sign the measure into law. Under the legislation, non-medical use of bovine growth hormone, known as BGH or bovine somatotropin, would be banned for a year. The protein is a synthetic version of a hormone that naturally appears in cows and is expected to win approval of the Food and Drug Administration for commercial use later this year. Brown and state Sen. Steve Morse urged the ban, saying more time is needed to study the potential effects of the drug on animals and humans. The legislation would keep the ban in effect as long as Wisconsin enforced a similar moratorium or if a consortium of states representing at least 40 percent of the nation's milk production adopted a ban on BGH. The Wisconsin Legislature approved a temporary moratorium last month that is awaiting the signature of Gov. Tommy Thompson. He has not said whether he will sign the measure. The companies that produce the hormone, Monsanto Agriculture Co., Eli Lilly Co., Upjohn Co. and American Cyanamid, have lobbied against such measures, saying the hormone has been more than adequately tested. Supporters of the synthetic hormone, including dairy farmers, a pharmacist and a veterinarian, took issue with opponents' contentions that the drug may not be safe and argued against legislative impediments on new technology. ``There's no credible evidence that there's any health hazard,'' said Rep. Jim Girard. ``This is just another tool to allow farmers to increase their production.'' Rep. Harriet McPherson likened BGH to milk machines, embryo transplants and other technological advances that have increased milk production.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Says Majority Supports Federal Aid for Controversial Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, Wildmon said, with Frohnmayer comment. Inserts 2 grafs after 13th graf pvs, Of those, with reaction from Kennedy and Rohrabacher.
DOC.TEXT: An anti-censorship lobbying group said Thursday that a new nationwide poll shows Americans overwhelmingly support the National Endowment for the Arts and oppose conservative lawmakers' efforts to curb federal support for controversial art. The poll results were released by the liberal People for the American Way as a pornography-fighting preacher sent members of Congress envelopes containing what he called ``filthy'' pictures of homosexual acts from an Illinois art exhibit mounted with a $15,000 grant from the endowment. ``We're spending $175 million in this area that benefits primarily the rich and the perverted,'' said the Rev. Donald Wildmon, founder and director of the American Family Association of Tupelo, Miss. Wildmon said he hopes the reproductions of 14 images from the ``David Wojnarowicz, Tongues of Flame'' show at the University Galleries at Illinois State University in Normal will persuade Congress to eliminate funds for the NEA. In an interview, endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer accused Wildmon of using ``falsehoods or half-truths or intimidation'' to whip up anti-NEA hysteria, and suggested that he ``pay attention to the commandment against bearing false witness.'' Frohnmayer said the Illinois art exhibit grant was made before Congress banned federal support for obscene art. In any case, he said, Wildmon was wrong to suggest that the NEA ``is a purveyor of pornography or is somehow out of control.'' The endowment, an independent federal agency with a budget of $171.3 million, supports a wide variety of artists and artistic institutions with tax-paid grants that must be matched by private donors. The NEA has been the target of attacks by conservative lawmakers led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., since last summer for its support for exhibits of controversial works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. Last fall, Congress voted to forbid NEA financing of art that ``may be considered'' obscene and without ``serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' The lawmakers also ordered a special commission created to review the NEA's grant-making procedures, and withheld $45,000 from the NEA as a penalty for supporting the Mapplethorpe and Serrano exhibits. Officials of People for the American Way Action Fund, which describes itself as a ``constitutional liberties organization'' fighting censorship, said their poll showed that ``the public overwhelmingly opposes censorship of controversial art, even if they find it personally offensive.'' The poll was conducted for the group by Research & Forecasts Inc. of New York, which conducted random telephone surveys of 1,200 adults in late March. The firm said the poll showed that 68 percent of the public supports federal financing of the arts and that only 30 percent agrees that ``government funding to avant garde or leading-edge artists should be stopped because a few people feel their work is controversial.'' The poll takers said 81 percent of those surveyed agreed that ``Congress should not pass laws that interfere with our rights to free expression.'' They said 93 percent agreed that ``even if I find a particular piece of art objectionable, others have the right to view it.'' Of those surveyed, they said, 61 percent take the NEA's side in favoring the current system of having citizen panels make grant decisions. Only 13 percent, they said, supported Helms' efforts to slash funds and tighten controls over the endowment. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., hailed the poll results as ``a welcome vote of confidence in the arts endowment'' and proof that Americans ``reject the know-nothing censorship the right wing is trying to impose.'' But Rohrabacher said censorship was a phony issue. ``What we are talking about is whether standards should be established so that federal funds cannot be used to finance obscene or indecent art or art that attacks religion,'' he said. Former Rep. John H. Buchanan, R-Ala., chairman of People for the American Way, said he will circulate the poll results in Congress to show that ``the American people say yes to the arts, yes to the NEA and no to any government censorship of the arts or any other form of free expression.'' But Wildmon's anti-NEA campaign appeared to be succeeding among some legislators. An aide to Rep. James Saxton, R-N.J., said his office had received up to 300 pieces of mail in the past week as a result of Wildmon's letters to constituents. ``At this point, it's going to be very difficult for us to vote to fund the NEA,'' said the aide, Jeff de Korte. Meanwhile, a joint Soviet-American exhibi of contemporary art opened Thursday at the Corcoran Gallery of Art minus three works by New York artist Annette Lemiuex. She boycotted the show's Washington appearance to protest the Corcoran's cancellation of the Mapplethorpe exhibition last summer.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Stubbornly Independent in Face of Soviet Embargo
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shaken hours after watching soldiers take over her workplace Friday, journalist Maria Gediene swore that Mikhail Gorbachev had met his match in Lithuania's stubborn, non-violent resistance. ``He's a big actor,'' the middle-aged journalist said, a tear rolling down her cheek. ``I see his game and it doesn't interest me any more.'' ``He doesn't know what the ending of this play will be, and that's too bad for him,'' she added in a trembling voice. ``It will be worse for him than for us.'' Lithuanians interviewed on a dimly lighted street near the requisite Soviet-era statue of Vladimir I. Lenin pledged they would endure, despite an embargo on oil and natural gas that the Lithuanian government said was spreading to tires, cable, packaging and some food items. Lithuania imposed stiff gas rationing earlier Friday, limiting each car to slightly under eight gallons a month. Long lines waited at the gas pumps. Attendants stamped each car's registration as they doled out the months's share. Officials warned of huge unemployment as factories are shut down due to a lack of fuel, parts and raw materials from the Soviet Union, which is continuing its opposition to Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. Citizens interviewed in the pleasant, cool spring evening said they have not noticed any hoarding in expectation of shortages. Mrs. Gediene was present as Soviet Interior Ministry soldiers took over a Communist Party publishing plant and beat some of the civilian guards Friday afternoon. ``I don't know whether I'll be working there on Monday or not,'' she said. Daffodils and red carnations were placed at the foot of the Lenin statue on a street that until recently was named for the Soviet founder. Some traffic rumbled down what is now Gedimo Street, named for an ancient Lithuanian king. An 18-year-old history student Vitas Batsis, tall, blond and smiling, said few Lithuanians care about Lenin anymore. ``For Russians, he is God,'' said Batsis. ``That's understandable. But for us, he's not God.'' ``Let them do what they want,'' he said. ``We have only one weapon, the truth.'' Asked what would happen in the future, the student said: ``I think there will be presidential rule, or we'll starve. But we'll endure. We'll learn, like we're learning now.'' Ethnic Russians agreed this Baltic republic of 3.8 million people was headed for hard times, but charged it was all the fault of the Lithuanian government. Two ethnic Russian women strolling arm-in-arm down the street criticized the Lithuanian government for moving too fast. ``Before declaring independence, you have to be able to stand on your own feet,'' said 41-year-old teacher Lina Polotnova. ``It would be bad for all of us, but the Lithuanian government is at fault,'' she said. ``Moscow is no way at fault.'' The two women were both born in Lithuania, and Mrs. Polotnova said she had no plans to leave despite the impending difficulties. But her friend, Vita Vishnyevskaya, said she and many other Russians would leave if they could get new apartments somewhere in Russia. Housing, most of it allocated rather sold, is in short supply all over the Soviet Union. Both women said they were still able to buy in Vilnius stores without any discrimination because they speak Lithuanian. And they said they experienced no particular difficulties in everyday life. However, the ethnic strain was starting to show on 22-year-old student Daira Arnshite of Klaipeda. ``I hate the Russians,'' she said. ``They turned us into horrible people. We couldn't go anywhere, we didn't know anything, we couldn't buy anything.'' She and the other Lithuanians agreed that no possible solution existed to the dispute with Moscow except full independence. ``We can negotiate about anything except independence,'' said Mrs. Gediene. ``I don't think our parliament would be so bold as to do that. The people would curse them.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Bars Boy With AIDS, Then Reverses Itself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 1-3 to reflect that foster mother says boy has AIDS infection, not just virus, CORRECTS name to Moody Church; INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th, `The church...' to UPDATE with comments from foster mother. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Earlier, the...'; SUBS 16th graf pvs, `The Ruckers...' to UPDATE with mother's confirmation. Picks up 17th pvs, `John Hammell...'
DOC.TEXT: A church barred a 5-year-old boy with AIDS from Sunday school, then reversed itself Friday after an uproar. ``We love (him) and we want (him) back in our Sunday school and (he) will be back in our Sunday school,'' the Rev. Erwin Lutzer, senior pastor of the Moody Church, said at a hastily called news conference. But Lutzer said other parents would be notified that a child with AIDS would be attending Bible class, ``and they will have the freedom to keep their children from Sunday school.'' ``Our position and our concerns have not changed,'' Lutzer said. ``We have decided to shift the burden of responsibility from us as a church.'' The church had drawn fire when its decision to bar the boy became public, a few weeks after the death of young AIDS victim Ryan White. ``I'm pleased that they reversed themselves. ... I don't feel any bitterness,'' the Chicago boy's foster mother, Terry Rucker, said in a telephone interview Friday afternoon. Mrs. Rucker said she had not decided whether to return to the church on Sunday. ``I have made no plans to go elsewhere,'' she added. On Thursday, Mrs. Rucker had said the church officials' initial decision stemmed ``from fear and ignorance.'' Before announcing the reversal, the pastor said the 65-year-old church had decided to bar the boy ``to give us time to think it through.'' His secretary, Evelyn Rankin, said officials of the non-denominational evangelical church acted out of concern over how AIDS is spread and fear it could be passed on through saliva. There has never been a documented U.S. case in which AIDS, which cripples the body's defenses against disease, was spread through saliva, said Charles Fallis, a spokesman for the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. ``We are well aware of Ryan White and the implication of his death,'' Lutzer told reporters Friday. White, who had been barred from his school near Kokomo, Ind., after he contracted AIDS through a blood transfusion, died April 8 at age 18. He had fought a long and public battle aimed at increasing understanding of the disease. ``We thought with Ryan White, all that had been settled,'' Walt Rucker said of his foster son. Rucker asked that the child's name be kept private. ``That's just crazy,'' agreed Carrie Van Dyke, a friend and spokeswoman for White's family in Indianapolis. ``Where is their humanity to fellow man? ``I would think that they would be a little more introspective about what they're doing.'' The boy was born with the AIDS virus, said David Schneidman, a spokesman for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. The agency removed the boy from his mother, who has AIDS, out of concern she could no longer care for him, Schneidman said. The Ruckers took the boy in two months ago. Mrs. Rucker confirmed that he has contracted AIDS from the virus. John Hammell, director of the AIDS and Civil Liberties Project of the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois, said the church's decision to bar the child likely would not have withstood a legal challenge. ``It's very sad, especially ... since this is a religious (institution) and should be a compassionate institution that this still happens.'' Rucker, a psychologist, said earlier that he and his wife, a nurse, have belonged to Moody Church for 10 years. ``We strongly support the church's position on pro-life,'' Rucker said. ``We do not support the church's position on not taking a child with AIDS.'' The boy had been told only that he was ``not going back to Bible class anymore,'' said Mrs. Rucker. ``This is a Bible-teaching church, and they cannot justify their fears.'' A receptionist at the church said the Moody Church and the Moody Bible Institute are ``separate entities'' connected only in that Dwight L. Moody founded both the church and the institute. She said that while the institute contributes money to the church, the church also helps the institute financially. AIDS is spread by a virus transmitted mainly through sexual intercourse, shared hypodermic needles and from infected mothers to their infants before or during birth. Health officials have said there has been no evidence that it can spread by casual contact.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Wins Vote of Confidence from Solidarity Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Walesa's name, others submitted for election, vice-chairman still possibility. Pick up 9th pvs, `Walesa's address...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GDA50,GDA51
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa won an overwhelming vote of confidence from Solidarity's second national congress Friday after delivering an impassioned defense of his 10 years as union leader. ``I am not the wisest guy, but we are wise because we now have a democracy,'' Walesa said. Delegates responded by voting 357-1 in favor of a report on the leadership of Walesa and the union movement's National Commission since 1981. There were 22 abstentions. His name was later submitted to a union commission for re-election, aides to Walesa said. Members of the election commission said several other names had been submitted, but they declined to provide details. Some have accused Walesa of undemocratic rule. Apart from the election of its leadership, the trade union movement also was expected to try to clarify its union and political roles in post-Communist Poland. Walesa's re-election appeared virtually certain. ``Walesa will guarantee that the union will not fall apart,'' said Ryszard Musielak, a delegate from the central city of Torun. ``It is very important that we passed this vote of confidence because it shows there are no serious objections to Walesa's activities among the delegates,'' said Antoni Bielewicz of the Warsaw region. Later, the congress rejected a motion to create a vice chairman who would take over if the chairman assumed other duties. But the post still could be introduced if union statutes were changed. Last week, Walesa raised the possibility of running for president. Walesa's address came on the second day of Solidarity's six-day congress, the second one it has held. Since the first congress in 1981, the movement has survived martial law, negotiated an end to Communist dominance, and won elections to take control of the government. Recent public opinion polls, however, show Solidarity losing popularity as Poland undergoes austerity measures that have increased unemployment. Walesa, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1983 for his efforts as Solidarity leader, remains very popular. In an emotional speech Friday, Walesa acknowledged mistakes had been made. ``The victory I am giving you. The mistakes are ours and you should correct all the mistakes we've made here and today,'' Walesa said. ``I did this only for Poland. ... It's not my victory, it's our mutual victory. I was only the driver of it all,'' he said. Several delegates later accused Walesa of diminishing the achievements of others who helped found the union. Parliament member Andrzej Malachowski, however, received a standing ovation when he called for an end to backroom politicking. ``Of course you, Lech, have enemies, but some game is being engineered here,'' Malachowski said. ``Stop it, please. Lech Walesa has well served the fatherland.'' After the confidence vote, the delegates changed ``Lechu! Lechu!'' as Walesa raised his arms in a victory salute. Walesa, an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard, became leader of Solidarity in 1980 by climbing over the shipyard fence during a strike to galvanize the workers. ``Due to bad luck, I jumped over the shipyard wall,'' he said Friday. ``You liked my jump and that's why you elected me to drive this vehicle called Solidarity.'' Before Walesa's speech, the congress debated more than an hour before voting to admit as guests all members of the 1981 union leadership who no longer were delegates. The guests would not be permitted to vote. The former leaders include several radicals who have broken with the Solidarity mainstream. Some had accused Walesa of undemocratic rule. Others had opposed any compromise with the former Communist government, including the negotiations that led to elections in June. That vote resulted in the East bloc's first non-Communist-led government. Walesa threatened to leave the hall Friday if certain members of the former leadership showed up. He did not specify who he meant. The union regained legal status April 17, 1989, then took control of the government after partly free elections in June. Solidarity has since managed to sign up only 2.2 million of the 10 million members it had in 1981. Opinion polls show confidence dropping as the public undergoes economic hardships associated with the strict austerity program of the Solidarity-led government. Economic restructuring is forcing plant closures and raising unemployment among the industrial workers who are the backbone of Solidarity's support. Walesa has criticized the pace of political reforms, saying Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's team is not moving quickly enough to dislodge Communists from power in state enterprises and government ministries. The delegates are expected to debate how much they want Solidarity to be confined to union issues and whether to create a Solidarity-linked political party.

DOC.HEAD: Southern, East European Homosexuals Meet at Conference
DOC.TEXT: Homosexuals from southern and eastern Europe on Friday met in Leipzig for a three-day conference to discuss problems gays face in Communist and former Communist nations. Criminal prosecution and forming a ``minority'' in society were high on the conference agenda, the official East German news agency ADN said. Leipzig was the center of many of last year's East German protests against 40 years of hard-line Communist rule. Despite reform in Eastern Europe, ADN said homosexuals from the Soviet Union were attending secretly, using cover addresses. Albania, Bulgaria, Romania and the Soviet Union are among countries where homosexuality is a criminal offense. For many years homosexuals were persecuted in East Germany, although the hard-line government of former Communist chief Erich Honecker relaxed its attitude and allowed cafes and clubs catering to gays to open in 1987. Homosexuality was legalized in East Germany last year, ADN said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Read their lips _ the people competing in the 17th annual National Whistlers Convention take the art seriously. ``We once thought that this was a rural kind of art found in small towns or Americana,'' said Allen De Hart, founder and director of the competition held in Louisburg, about 30 miles north of Raleigh. But he said the contest attracts people of all ages and economic and ethnic backgrounds. ``Obviously the art is like the art of music _ it has no limitations,'' he said. ``People with all kinds of interests and backgrounds whistle.'' On Saturday, the 1989 national grand champion whistler, Sean Lomax, a 28-year-old computer specialist on a submarine based at Pearl Harbor, will defend his title. He won last year by whistling ``Dance Boheme'' from ``Carmen'' and ``The Entertainer'' from the movie ``The Sting.'' Lomax will open this year's contest with the national anthem. The 58 contestants competing this year range in age from 3 to 88 and come from 20 states. Categories include best child whistler and best supporting whistler. Prize money this year totals $2,500, which won't make anyone wealthy, but De Hart says winners receive national attention. ``All of our whistlers sooner or later get on some kind of a show, either the Johnny Carson show or the David Letterman show,'' De Hart said.

Liz and Len Zedel are sleeping in the living room these days because the occupants downstairs are noisy and smell like fish. The couple rent a cottage in this Victoria suburb two blocks from the ocean and near a small creek. About two weeks ago, they heard puppy-like whimpering under the bedroom floor. ``We thought it was 'coons or something,'' says Zedel, an oceanographer at the Institute of Ocean Studies. Then one day, ``I was brushing my teeth, looked out the window and was nose-to-nose with an otter,'' he said. The couple soon found that a whole litter was being raised under the house. The landlord tried to block off the entrance to the lair with boards, but the adults dismantled the obstruction in five minutes, Ms. Zedel said. Ms. Zedel, an opera singer who performs under the name Elizabeth Planje, said she practices scales and arias every morning and it doesn't seem to bother the river otters. However, she's had to use some potpourri to freshen up the bedroom, which she said smells ``a bit fishy.'' The couple said they would sleep in the living room until the young otters grow up and move out. Wildlife expert Alex Matheson said that should take about three months.

Jerry Lewis and Jerry Erwin have $500 riding on a hair-raising bet they made in 1963: Which man will shave off his beard first? The winner, if there ever is one, undoubtedly will claim victory by a whisker. The wager began 27 years ago when both men decided to grow beards in honor of West Virginia's 1963 centennial celebration. Both shaved when the festivities were over, but soon grew back their beards because, as Lewis explained, ``when I shaved if off, I felt naked.'' To make things interesting, Lewis and Erwin bet $100 on who would be the first to shave. Neither has since, and as the beards have grown, so has the pot, to $500. ``That's because of inflation,'' Lewis said. Lewis keeps his beard trimmed to about 5 inches. Erwin's, without a moustache, is about 9 inches long. Neither Lewis nor Erwin, who work together at a Boone County automobile towing shop, will predict who'll be the first to come clean-shaven. When asked recently, both just smiled and stroked their fluffy beards.

DOC.HEAD: US Official Returns, Rules Out Bowing To Hostage-Holders Demands
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly returned home on Friday and ruled out yielding to the demands of hostage-holders. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine had called for Kelly to go to Damascus, the capital of Syria, to handle final details of the release of an American hostage. When the request was turned down by the Bush administration, the militant group said the release had been postponed. Kelly, in a statement at Washington Dulles International Airport, said Edward P. Djerejian, the U.S. ambassador to Syria, was at his post and ``fully capable of handling all the details of bringing a hostage out safely, and quickly, and efficiently.'' Kelly and Djerejian had been in West Germany attending a conference of American diplomats. Kelly's statement did not indicate with whom the Bush administration was prepared to have Djerejian deal. Administration spokesmen have flatly ruled out negotiating with hostage-holders. Kelly evidently was referring to Syria, which is serving as an intermediary for the United States. In his statement, the American diplomat stressed there would be no yielding to the demands of hostage-holders. ``You know American policy is that we do not make concessions to those who hold the hostages,'' he said. ``We want the hostages out, but we are not going to bow to the demands of the hostage-holders.'' Kelly voiced hope a hostage would be released. He described Djerejian, an Arabic and French-speaking career diplomat, as ``a very competent, seasoned, professional ambassador'' knowledgeable about Lebanon and Syria. Explaining why he did not go to Syria, the assistant secretary of state said ``there was no particular utility in my going to Damascus because Ambassador Djerejian is fully capable of handling all the details there.'' Kelly has also served in Lebanon as U.S. ambassador. His explanation was milder than that given by U.S. officials earlier in the week. They said sending Kelly to Damascus would have meant yielding to demands of the Islamic Jihad and that even if Kelly did not engage in negotiations his presence in Syria might give that impression. President Bush on Thursday said the United States ``would not knuckle under to demands.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Authorities Will Prosecute in Alleged Drug Snatch
With AM-Mexico-Camarena
DOC.TEXT: Mexican authorities will prosecute anyone responsible for the purported abduction of a Mexican doctor to the United States to face charges in the murder of a U.S. drug agent, the attorney general said Friday. Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo also reiterated an earlier threat that Mexico will stop cooperating with the United States in the war on drugs if further abductions take place on Mexican territory. ``There must be respect. Otherwise, there is no cooperation,'' he said. Alvarez del Castillo said no charges are pending in Mexico against Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, 42, who has been indicted in the United States in the torture-murder of Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique Camarena. Alvarez Machain's lawyer says he was abducted from his office in Guadalajara and flown to El Paso, Texas, where DEA agents arrested him. Alvarez Machain pleaded innocent to any involvement in the 1985 Camarena killing near Guadaljara, capital of western Jalisco state. The attorney general said anyone suspected of involvement in a kidnapping will be prosecuted no matter what their rank, position in government or nationality. ``We are investigating thoroughly, and anyone found to be responsible will be investigated, arrested and prosecuted,'' Alvarez del Castillo told a news conference. He said chances of returning Alvarez Machain to Mexico are ``very complicated'' but refused to comment further. In Washington, a Justice Department spokesman said Alvarez Machain would not be returned even if he was kidnapped. U.S. courts long have held that a fugitive can stand trial in the United States even arrested improperly abroad. Alvarez del Castillo spoke at the end of a four-day conference on drug-fighting by the Organization of American States, over which he presided. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh attended the conference opening and returned to Washington on Thursday. He ordered the DEA to give him a full report on the Alvarez Machain arrest. Justice spokesman David Runkel said Thornburgh had reassured Mexican officials, including Alvarez del Castillo, and that the Americans ``were assured that relations between Mexico and the United Sates remained strong and that cooperation on drug law enforcement would continue.'' Mexican officials at the conference have been privately criticizing the idea of apprehending drug suspects abroad, based on a U.S. Supreme Court decision that such arrests are legal. Without mentioning the United States by name, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on Thursday criticized the police, saying nations should not take drug-fighting as an excuse for such illicit actions abroad. ``In the fight against drugs, the law is rendered useless by illegal actions, or by trying to measure justice with a ruler of one country in foreign territory,'' Salinas told the conference. The conference was attended by justice ministers, or their representatives, from 32 OAS member nations.

DOC.HEAD: US Won't Return Mexican Doctor Accused in Drug Agent Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT after 4th graf bgng,``The Mexican,'' five grafs to add a statement from Thornburg; pick up 5th graf bgng, ``The defense.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Friday it has no plans to return to Mexico a doctor accused of participating in the murder of a U.S. drug agent even if his capture violated Mexican sovereignty. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said he ``did not foresee any circumstances'' under which Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain would be returned to Mexico rather than face federal charges in Los Angeles. But the judge overseeing the case ordered the Justice Department to explain the circumstances leading up to Alvarez' April 3 arrest in El Paso, Texas, on charges of participating in the 1985 murder of drug agent Enrique Camarena. The Mexican government also has demanded an explanation for what an embassy spokesman here called the ``illegal detention'' of the Guadalajara gynecologist. Attorney General Dick Thornburg issued a statement on the apprehension of Dr. Machain, that was read by spokesman Dan Eramian: ``Although the Drug Enforcement Administration has not completed its investigation of the circumstances surrounding the apprehension of Dr. Machain, it has been confirmed that no DEA personnel were present when he was taken into custody in Mexico or when he was boarded onto an aircraft in that country. ``In addition, no DEA personnel were aboard the aircraft that brought Dr. Machain to the United States. ``The first encounter DEA agents had with Dr. Machain was when they took him into custody at the El Paso, Texas, airport.'' Eramian refused the answer questions. The defense lawyer in the case charges that Alvarez was kidnapped and flown by private plane to El Paso, where he was arrested by DEA agents. DEA officials have denied published reports that it paid bounty hunters to capture Alvarez and bring him to the U.S. border. DEA officials have declined to describe how they arrested Alvarez. A prosecutor handling the case, however, said in court Thursday in Los Angeles that the U.S. government ``has had standing offers on the street in Mexico and Guadalajara for rewards'' for the capture of those involved in the Camarena murder. The arrest has sparked a diplomatic protest from the government of Mexico. The Mexican attorney general, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, said it could end U.S.-Mexican cooperation on drug enforcement. Runkel said that threat was dispelled by talks between Thornburgh and his Mexican counterpart this week in Ixtapa, Mexico, the site of a hemispheric conference on drug enforcement. ``We were assured that relations between Mexico and the United States remained strong and that cooperation on drug law enforcement would continue,'' Runkel said. ``Any threat, if one existed, to continued cooperation was substantially lessened as a result of the bilateral talks in Ixtapa,'' Runkel said. Thornburgh has asked DEA for a full account of the arrest and assured Mexico that ``appropriate action would be forthcoming when a report of the results of that investigation was in hand,'' Runkel said. A spokesman for the Mexican Embassy here said future cooperation on drug enforcement would have to await the result of the investigation into the circumstances surrounding Alvarez's arrest. ``There is cooperation to find who the real violators of the Mexican law are in this case of the illegal detention of Alvarez Machain,'' said Javier Trevino, the embassy's press attache. ``Once this investigation is over and those responsible are duly punished cooperation will continue,'' Trevino said. Runkel declined to say what action might be taken by the attorney general once he received DEA's report. But he said ``I don't foresee any circumstances under which he would be returned to Mexico,'' Runkel said. ``He faces criminal charges in this country.'' A long line of U.S. court decisions have held that a fugitive can stand trial in this country even if his arrest overseas was improper or illegal. A Justice Department legal opinion issued earlier this year said the FBI had the authority to grab fugitives in other countries without the permission of the host government.

DOC.HEAD: Whole Theater, Nurtured By Olympia Dukakis, Suspends Operations
DOC.TEXT: It's curtains for The Whole Theater, which rose to national prominence with a push from Oscar-winner Olympia Dukakis, it was announced Friday. ``We're hoping that it's not a sign of things to come for other theater groups, but we have to realize the state is seeing some tough times,'' said Laura Aden, executive director of the New Jersey Theater Group. The Whole Theater was founded in 1973 by a group of married theater couples, including Ms. Dukakis and her husband, actor Louis Zorich. It won national acclaim for original programming and quality acting, and attracted even more attention with the Academy Award won by Ms. Dukakis in 1988 for her role in ``Moonstruck.'' In a plot twist laced with irony, however, the theater that lived by Ms. Dukakis may die by Ms. Dukakis. The Whole Theater's association with the actress may have lulled would-be donors into believing it was financially sound, said theater spokeswoman Bonnie Kramen. ``Some people may have thought that with the increased visibility, there were increased dollars coming in, and that didn't turn out to be the case,'' Ms. Kramen said. The theater's Board of Trustees determined Wednesday that the building would have to be sold to pay off debts of about $450,000, Ms. Kramen said. ``Our Town'' was the theater's first production in 1973. Ms. Dukakis could not be reached directly for comment, but issued a statement. ``However much I regret that this decision had to be made, I feel the board of trustees of Whole Theater made the most responsible decision possible under these circumstances,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake in Western China Caused 1,300 Homes to Collapse
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale that hit far western China near the Soviet border caused the collapse of 1,300 houses, seismology officials said Friday. However, only two people were injured in the Tuesday morning quake in the mountains of West Wuqia, in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. The official Xinhua News Agency, quoting the Xinjiang Seismology Bureau, did not say how seriously the two were injured or why the extent of damage wasn't worse. It also said 47 head of livestock were killed by the quake. The area affected by the quake has been closed to foreign travelers and journalists in recent weeks following reports that Chinese troops had been called in to put down rioting by Moslem ethnic groups. A bureau official said the quake was about 40 miles southwest of Wuqia and 60 miles from the Soviet border. He said residents of Kashgar, a famed bazaar town of about 100,000 people about 60 miles from the epicenter, reported little structural damage. Much of the quake damage was to homes constructed of mud bricks and flimsy roofing materials.

DOC.HEAD: Important Dates in the Michael Milken Case
With Milken
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major developments in the prosecution of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond chief Michael Milken: Nov. 14, 1986 _ Stock speculator Ivan Boesky pays $100 million to settle charges of insider trading on information supplied by investment banker Dennis Levine in 1985 and 1986. He also agrees to cooperate with investigators and to plead guilty to a single criminal charge. Boesky later is sentenced to three years in prison. Late 1986 _ Published reports link Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. high-yield bond financier Michael Milken to an illegal insider trading network led by Boesky. Sept. 7, 1988 _ The Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Drexel, Milken and three others of violating a wide range of securities laws, most of them in connection with Boesky. Dec. 21 _ Drexel agrees to plead guilty to six felonies and pay a record $650 million in fines and restitution to settle the biggest securities fraud case in history. Drexel also must settle related SEC charges and cooperate with the government investigation. March 29, 1989 _ A federal grand jury indicts Milken, his brother, Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Lee Newberg on 98 counts of racketeering and fraud largely based on information supplied by Boesky. Potential penalties and fines under the counts amount to about $12 billion plus possible prison terms. April 7 _ The Milkens plead innocent. Newberg enters an innocent plea later. April 13 _ Drexel and the SEC announce a settlement of the civil fraud case that subjects the firm to federal monitoring for three years and forces it to sever ties with Milken. June 15 _ Milken resigns after 19 years at Drexel to form his own consulting firm. Lowell Milken quits to return to practicing law. Sept. 11 _ Drexel pleads guilty to six felonies and begins paying more than $650 million in fines, penalties and interest. Feb. 13, 1990 _ Drexel's parent company files for federal bankruptcy court protection after failing to meet short-term debt payments. The securities firm, once the nation's fifth-largest, starts laying off its 5,400 employees. March 19 _ Prosecutors promise to bring a new indictment with broader charges against Milken by the week of April 16. April 4 _ Boesky is released from federal custody after completing two years of a three-year term. April 19 _ Four months of negotiations intensify between the government and Milken for a possible plea bargain to settle the case as a deadline looms for the new indictment. April 20 _ Sources say Milken agrees to plead guilty to six felony counts and pay fines and restitution totaling $600 million under a plea agreement with prosecutors.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Lays Off Mechanics, Cites Strike-Reduced Work Load
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `The latest...' to UPDATE with violence on Wednesday. Picks up last graf, `The company...' Longer version moved on financial wire
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound said Friday that a reduced workload caused by a 7-week-old strike by bus drivers has forced it to lay off almost one-fifth of its maintenance force. Union officials said the layoffs were a sign the company is struggling. ``Because of the present volume of business, we have more mechanics than we need,'' said Greyhound Lines Inc. spokesman George Gravley. ``It's not that we can't pay them, we don't want to pay them if there's no work to do.'' He said 275 of the current 1,395 mechanics, mechanics helpers, storekeepers, truck drivers and service workers were being laid off beginning Monday. Before the strike, Greyhound had 2,165 maintenance workers. Of those, the 690 represented by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers remained on the job. Gravley said 695 ATU members also ignored the strike. The layoffs are spread throughout the country and involve 120 Machinists and 155 ATU members, he said. The workers would be recalled as work loads increase, he said. ``Every indicator points to financial disaster for Greyhound Lines Inc.,'' said James La Sala, international president of the Amalgamated Transit Union. ``Greyhound management is now at a crossroads. It can either negotiate a settlement to this contract dispute, or allow this country's only national bus system to slide into financial ruin.'' The ATU, which also represents about 6,300 drivers and 1,660 office workers, has been on strike since March 2, walking out in a dispute over wages and job security. There have been no negotiations since mid-March. Greyhound has refused to meet with union representatives until seven straight days have passed without violence. The latest incident occurred Wednesday, Gravley said, when a bus traveling from Dallas to Oklahoma City, Okla., was struck by two bullets.
