The company has been operating reduced schedules, using replacement workers and crossovers, and says it currently is carrying about two-thirds as many passengers as it was at this time last year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Chicago-dated item to UPDATE with church reversing itself, reflect that foster mother says boy has AIDS infection, not just virus, CORRECTS name to Moody Church; CORRECTS spelling of Erwin, sted Irwin.
DOC.TEXT: A church barred a 5-year-old boy with AIDS from Sunday school, then reversed itself Friday after an uproar. ``We love (him) and we want (him) back in our Sunday school and (he) will be back in our Sunday school,'' the Rev. Erwin Lutzer, senior pastor of the Moody Church, said at a hastily called news conference. But Lutzer said other parents would be notified that a child with AIDS would be attending Bible class, ``and they will have the freedom to keep their children from Sunday school.'' ``Our position and our concerns have not changed,'' Lutzer said. ``We have decided to shift the burden of responsibility from us as a church.'' The church had drawn fire when its decision to bar the boy became public, a few weeks after the death of young AIDS victim Ryan White. ``I'm pleased that they reversed themselves. ... I don't feel any bitterness,'' the Chicago boy's foster mother, Terry Rucker, said in a telephone interview Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Farmland Prices Continue To Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB and CORRECT 2nd graf, bgng ``the department's,'' to delete $597; pick up 3rd graf, bgng ``An 11-month.'' ^By DON KENDALL
DOC.TEXT: Farmland prices rose again last year but at a slower pace than in 1988, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The department's Economic Research Service said that as of Jan. 1 the average value of U.S. farmland, including buildings, was $693 per acre, up 4 percent from Feb. 1, 1989. The February figure was not given. An 11-month period was used because the agency is switching from Feb. 1 to Jan. 1 as the reporting date. ``Although below the 6 percent gain in 1988, last year's rise was the third straight increase,'' the agency reported. Despite the annual increases, U.S. farmland values are still 16 percent below the record of $823 per acre in 1982. Prices sank to a 19-year low of $548 per acre in 1987 before gaining 3 percent in 1988. Analysts said 1989 was a good income year for farmers nationally and that debt was down 29 percent from its earlier peak. Farm real estate interest rates in 1989 were about the same as in 1988. Thus, they said, farmland values ``should have increased strongly'' last year. But there were other factors at work, too. ``The combination of a relatively modest increase in farmland values with the positive income and debt indicators suggests farmland investors anticipated the 1989 conditions, and the farmland value increases in 1987 and 1988 reflected those anticipations,'' the report said. ``Also, uncertainty about changes in the capital gains tax, changes in income and price supports, movements in interest rates, and outcomes of the (global) trade liberalization negotiations may have made investors cautious about projecting 1989 income levels into the future,'' it said. No state breakdown of farmland values was included in the report. But analysts said farmland values rose in eight of the 10 farm production regions, although there was a wide variation. Corn Belt land values averaged 2 percent higher on Jan. 1, far below the 10 percent gain of the previous year. The Mississippi Delta states were about 1 percent higher, while the Northeast was about unchanged. ``Led by a 15 percent gain in South Dakota, values in the Northern Plains rose 8 percent, about the same as a year earlier,'' the report said. ``Value increases also were similar to a year ago in the Southeast (8 percent), Appalachia (7 percent), the Lake States (6 percent), and the Pacific Region (6 percent).'' Farmland values in the Mountain region were reported up 5 percent, compared with 2 percent a year earlier, including a 16 percent gain in Montana and 14 percent in Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Gallipoli Veterans to Return to Famous WWI Battlefield
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ages 90 to 103 are correct
DOC.TEXT: Veterans of World War I who fought in the Gallipoli campaign left Friday for Turkey to commemorate one of the worst Allied defeats in the ``war to end all wars.'' The 46 Australians, aged 90 to 103, took off on a specially outfitted Qantas Airways Boeing 747-300. The plane was equipped with a mini-hospital, including Royal Australian Air Force doctors, to care for the veterans in case of medical emergency. The journey for the ceremonies on Wednesday will include a 30-hour stop in Singapore to give the veterans a rest break. The trip, scheduled for arrival Sunday in Istanbul, is expected to be difficult for some. Unlike their crowded wartime trip in a troop ship, the veterans traveled first class in front of the plane while Prime Minister Bob Hawke and other government representatives sat in the rear of the jet. Some reflected on their first voyage. ``We thought it was a glorious chance to see the world for nothing,'' said 92-year-old Jack Hazlitt, who was a ``runner,'' or military cables dispatcher. ``That attitude didn't last long. Very few of us survived. You could say I'm one of the lucky ones.'' Gallipoli is the Turkish peninsula on the northern side of the Dardanelles Strait. Allied forces consisting of the Britain, Australia, New Zealand, French and Indian troops invaded in 1915 in an attempt to open the straits to Russia, capture Istanbul, then known as Constantinople, and sever the Ottoman Turkish Empire from its ally, Germany. Allied forces fought unsuccessfully for nine months and were forced to evacuate in December 1915 and January 1916. Allied casualties were 33,532 killed, 78,518 wounded and 7,689 missing, including 8,587 Australians killed and 19,367 wounded. Most of the Australian soldiers were called ``diggers,'' and 93-year-old George Mitchell said the term developed because ``all we did (when not fighting) was to dig, dig and dig trenches.'' The battle gave the Turks a modern hero, Kemal Ataturk, who made his name as a military genius in Gallipoli. Australia commemorates the campaign each year with a national day of remembrance for those killed in the WWI and for those who died in other wars. ``In the Australian consciousness, two things stand out about Gallipoli,'' said Bob Carr, leader of the Labor opposition in the state of New South Wales. ``First, the courage and valor of our troops, and second, that it was a defeat, a military disaster.''

DOC.HEAD: Secretary-General to Visit Albania in Mid-May
DOC.TEXT: Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will visit the isolated Stalinist country of Albania in mid-May, U.N. officials confirmed Friday. It will be the first trip by a U.N. secretary-general to Albania, the last bastion of hard-line Communism in Eastern Europe. In recent weeks, Albania has made several recent moves to increase ties with the West, including the re-establishment of telephone communications with the United States and several other Western nations. Albanian Foreign Minister Reis Malile invited Perez de Cuellar to travel to his country when he visited the U.N. General Assembly in October. The visit had been announced officially last month and there were no further details available Friday except that the officials said the U.N. chief is expected to spend two days in Albania. U.N. officials said Perez de Cuellar was also planning trips in May to Czechoslovakia and Hungary, two East bloc countries that have moved to end four decades of Communist rule. A visit to Albania, a nation accused of serious human rights abuses, would make Perez de Cuellar one of the most senior international officials to visit the rigid Communist state in recent years. Albania, lying between Greece and Yugoslavia on the Adriatic Sea, is one of the most isolated countries in the world. Albanian authorities strictly limit foreign visitors and tightly control access to foreign broadcasts and books. Despite the restrictions, there have been indications of moves toward opening to the outside world since the death in 1985 of Albanian hard-line leader Enver Hoxha. Hoxha broke relations with the Soviet Union in 1961 because of Nikita Krushchev's dismantling of Stalinism.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Sentenced in Hearin Kidnap Case
DOC.TEXT: A Florida lawyer charged with plotting the 1988 kidnapping of a millionaire heiress was sentenced Friday to 19 years in prison without parole. Annie Laurie Hearin, the 74-year-old wife of Jackson multimillionaire Robert M. Hearin, has not been seen since she disappeared from her home July 26, 1988. Newton Alfred Winn, 65, a St. Petersburg, Fla., lawyer, was convicted of conspiracy for having a ransom letter mailed from Atlanta on Aug. 11, 1988. He also was charged with extortion and lying to a federal grand jury about his knowledge of Mrs. Hearin's disappearance. No one has been charged with the actual kidnapping. Winn and 11 other people once associated with Hearin's School Pictures business allegedly split the $1 million that was demanded for Mrs. Hearin's release. Winn returned his check to Hearin. U.S. District Judge Tom S. Lee. imposed the 19-year, seven-month sentence and added five years' probation. Hearin declined to answer questions after the sentencing. Prosecutors contended during the trial that Winn blamed Hearin for his financial losses in School Pictures of Mississippi Inc., in which Hearin was a primary stockholder and former chairman. Prosecutors said the business deal led Winn to bankruptcy and the loss of his law office. At Friday's hearing, Winn criticized the FBI, saying it had made a scapegoat of him. ``The FBI is the culprit in this case,'' Winn said. ``I have no personal knowledge of this crime. I am not guilty of anything in this matter.'' He said the FBI ``by hook and crook'' found people to testify against him and the jury believed ``the uncollaborated and false testimony.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of last item to CORRECT spelling of Patti.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Gospel singer Sandi Patti says she felt victimized by the arson attack that destroyed her office. The anonymous caller told the Anderson Herald Bulletin her group started the blaze because Patti had ``put herself on the pedestal of God.'' ``It's one of the most paralyzing feelings I have ever felt in my life,'' Patti said outside her charred office Thursday, two days after the fire. ``There's a tendency to just kind of sit at home and close the door and think `I will never be able to walk outside again.' I don't want to feel like that the rest of my life,'' she said. A group, calling itself the ``Equal Religious Coalition,'' claimed responsibility for the fire. Anderson police said they had never heard of the group but were taking the claim seriously. An unidentified woman said the fire was set in the office ``in objection to Mrs. Patti's blatancy to continue to put herself on the pedestal of God.'' Patti, her husband, John Helverling, and their four children are getting protection from off-duty officers. The office, operated by Helverlin, handles mail distribution of Patti's records, tapes and T-shirts, but master recordings of Patti's albums survived in a vault.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Announces Details of Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Westhead did...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with his comment. A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: The family of the late Hank Gathers filed a $32.5 million lawsuit Friday against Loyola Marymount University, coach Paul Westhead and 12 others, accusing them of negligence in the basketball star's death. The lawsuit alleges, among other things, that Gathers' heart medication was reduced at Westhead's request because the player's performance was suffering; that Gathers was not made aware of the risk he faced if he continued to play basketball, and that he was not treated quickly enough when he collapsed March 4 during the Lions' West Coast Conference tournament game. Gathers, the nation's leading scorer and rebounder a year earlier, died of heart disease hours later. Loyola Marymount spokesman Joan Gaulene said university officials expect to be vindicated. ``Loyola Marymount University is deeply saddened by the charges leveled at the university and the university staff in the suit filed today by attorney Bruce Fagel on behalf of the family of Hank Gathers,'' she said in a statement. Gaulene said the university's lawyers had not had enough time to review all the allegations and could not comment further. Westhead said in a statement Friday: ``As his coach, I did my best for Hank Gathers. I was never part of the medical decisions concerning Hank. I did not decide what medication to prescribe or what dosage to take. ``I feel badly that my relationship with Hank and his family could be distorted with this legal action.'' Contained in the lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court, was the excerpt of a letter sent by one of Gathers' doctors, Vernon Hattori, to another, Dr. Michael Mellman, on Jan. 29 stating that the initial dosage prescribed to control the player's irregular heartbeat was reduced because he was not playing well. Hattori was at lunch when Fagel's news conference on the lawsuit ended, said a spokeswoman for his office exchange. Mellman's whereabouts were not immediately known. The letter stated that a dosage of 240 milligrams of Inderal a day almost completely controlled Gathers' erratic heartbeat. But it went on to say, ``His dose was diminished ... after a rather dismal performance in his first game against Xavier. On a lower dose, he apparently performed incredibly against St. John's. ... ``However, his performance was obviously still being unfavorably affected by his medication so I decreased his Inderal.'' The lawsuit was filed in Los Angeles Superior Court on behalf of Gathers' mother, Lucille; his brothers Derrick and Charles; and his aunt, Carole Livingston. Hattori and Mellman are among the defendants, who also include Loyola Athletic Director Bryann Quinn, team trainer Chip Schaefer and a number of other doctors who treated Gathers. Another part of the letter quoted in the lawsuit said that Hattori met with Gathers the week before his death and that the player said he was satisfied with his level of performance with the changes in medications. `` ... Later on over the weekend I got a call from his coach, indicating that his athletic performance was still substantially sub-par and that he felt strongly that the medication should be changed.'' Hattori said in the letter that Gathers felt decreasing his dosage of Inderal would be preferable to changing medication, which could make him miss a game while he adjusted. The last recorded dosage was 40 milligrams twice a day, far below the 240 milligrams initially prescribed. Westhead has denied having any conversation in which he instructed that Gathers' medication be reduced or changed. ``I don't have a clue about medications. Why would I tell a doctor what is best for Hank Gathers?'' ESPN quoted Westhead on Thursday as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Unanimous Approval for Plan To Speed Up Drug War in the Americas
With AM-Mexico-Camarena
DOC.TEXT: The United States and 31 other member nations of the Organization of American States on Friday formally signed a wide-ranging plan to speed up the hemisphere's war against drugs. The 20-point Declaration of Ixtapa, unanimously approved Friday by the countries' top law enforcement officers, made no mention, however, of extradition. Extradition of suspects _ especially to the United States _ has been a touchy issue in Latin America in recent years, made even touchier this month by the alleged abduction of a Mexican doctor to stand trial in Los Angeles in the 1985 murder of a U.S. drug agent. The Declaration of Ixtapa calls for better education and prevention, starting in grammar schools; greater coordination in police actions; improvements in information exchange, and tougher laws against the drug trade. It calls for stronger measures against money-laundering and illegal sales of weapons and explosives and of lab equipment and chemicals used in making drugs. The plan includes a project for economic aid through the Inter American Development Bank and like financial institutions to help farmers substitute legal crops for high-paying illicit crops such as coca leaf, poppies and marijuana. The declaration called for greater cooperation by governments ``for adequate control of their borders,'' with ``absolute respect for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of states.'' According to some news reports, bounty hunters snatched Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, 42, from his gynecologist's office in Guadalajara for a large reward put up by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Alvarez is one of 19 Mexicans indicted by a U.S. grand jury in the torture-slaying of DEA agent Enrique Camarena. Mexico demanded an explanation and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh asked DEA director William C. Bennett for ``a full and immediate'' investigation. Similarly, President Virgilio Barco of Colombia has been criticized and threatened for extraditing Colombian drug suspects to the United States. Experts from the OAS nations unanimously concluded in a report to the assembled justice ministers at the four-day meeting that nowhere is the drug problem more serious and pressing than in the Americas. Latin America is a leading grower and producer of the three principal drugs _ cocaine, heroin and marijuana _ and the United States is the world's leading consumer and center for money-laundering. Enormous profits derived from the drug trade ``are making it possible for transnational criminal organizations to penetrate government structures,'' the experts said. These criminal elements are ``penetrating legitimate business activities, and society at all levels, corrupting and contaminating them ... and undermining the foundations of states,'' the report added.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped Grandson of Former Military Leader Found Dead
DOC.TEXT: The 3-year-old grandson of a former Panamanian military leader has been found dead nine days after being kidnapped for ransom, a police official said Friday. Marcos Rodriguez Justines was the grandson of ex-Col. Marcos Justines, former military chief of staff in the Panamanian Defense Forces. The boy's body had begun to decompose when it was found Thursday afternoon, said Leslie Loaiza, director of the Judicial Police. The official said he did not know the motive for the killing, nor would he say whether the $1 million ransom demanded by the kidnappers had been paid. ``We will find out,'' Loaiza said. He would not provide details of the case except to say that the kidnappers had been in contact with the family. The boy was kidnapped last week from his home in the Villa de las Fuentes neighborhood of Panama City, the capital. Justines is in jail, as are many former military and government officials after the U.S. invasion in December in which dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega was overthown. Noriega was replaced by civilian rival Guillermo Endara, who won presidential elections in May 1989. Gen. Noriega, former Defense Forces chief, had halted ballot-counting and voided results of that election when it became apparent that Endara was winning. Noriega is in a Florida jail awaiting trial in the United States on charges of drug trafficking and money laundering.

DOC.HEAD: Government Failed To Make Fraud Case Against Ford, Lawyer Says
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Harold Ford lived well, borrowed heavily and gave political support to two Tennessee bankers, but none of that means he broke the law, his lawyer said Friday at the congressman's bank fraud trial. ``If you are to remove a political leader for his politics or his lifestyle, that is to be done at the ballot box, not the jury box,'' William McDaniels said in his closing argument to Ford's trial jury. Ford, a Memphis Democrat, has been on trial since Feb. 12 on conspiracy, bank and mail fraud charges. He is accused of taking political payoffs from former bankers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr. The government says Ford got loans totaling more than $1 million from the Butchers between 1976 and 1982 and he was not expected to repay many of those debts. The Butchers' banking empire collapsed in 1983 and only then did Ford begin trying to settle his loans, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Clancy. ``He did not have the ability to repay all this stuff,'' Clancy said in his closing statement Thursday. The government claims Ford took Butcher payoffs to finance a lavish lifestyle. Prosecution witnesses said Ford bought a $35,000 car, $10,000 worth of oriental rugs and contracted for $94,000 in home renovations while heavily in debt to the Butchers and other bankers. Ford puts his Butcher loan total at $650,000 and says all of the debts have been settled. He settled his obligations on one loan, a $350,000 debt assigned to a company called Tenn-Ford Inc., by paying $25,000 to a bankruptcy trustee. The congressman is on trial with three former Butcher aides, accountant David Crabtree and lawyers Karl Schledwitz and Douglas Beaty. They are accused of helping him get and hide Butcher payoffs. The case is expected to go to the jury early next week. Ford, who has been in Congress since 1974, could face up to 95 years in prison if convicted on all 19 counts of an indictment issued in Knoxville three years ago. The defense rested its case without calling any witnesses. Ford said he decided not to take the witness stand because he regarded the government's case as weak. His lawyer said the government failed to show what Ford supposedly did in exchange for Butcher payoffs. Prosecutors say Ford helped the Butchers in their business and political ventures and was called upon to help find federal money for a Memphis bridge to Butcher-owned property.

DOC.HEAD: Greece: Cylinder Intended for Iraqi Weapons System Seized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with British company claiming manufacture, other shipments apparently reaching Iraq, report of truck detained in Turkey, details. Pick up 10th pvs, `British officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Customs officials have seized a huge cylinder that Iraq ordered from Britain for an artillery system, Greece said Friday. The announcement came seven days after Britain seized a shipment of steel tubes it said Iraq had ordered to make an enormous gun for firing missiles. Customs officials in Greece's western port of Patras seized a British truck Thursday that ``was conveying to Iraq a part of an artillery system weighing 29.5 tons,'' the Finance Ministry said it a statement. It said documents listed the cargo as a copper cylinder. Sotirios Sotiriou, Patras' chief customs official, said the cargo contained a 17-foot-long cylinder with a base for connecting it to a gun carriage. Sotiriou said that the driver of the truck, Paul Ashwell, 25, of Northampton, England, had been arrested and would be charged with illegally importing arms into Greece. Sotiriou said the British truck arrived in Greece by ship on April 11 bound for Iraq. Officials held it up because of a missing stamp on its documentation. The officer said customs officials became suspicious because of reports about the shipment seized in Britain and that it was intended for a huge Iraqi gun. Greek customs officials requested help from the British government, Soritiou said. He said an unidentified British customs expert later examined the cargo and determined it also was intended for the same big gun Britain believes the Iraqis intended to build. Walter Somers Ltd. of Halesowen, near Birmingham, said they had shipped the consignment but said two trucks were detained in Greece. Sotiriou confirmed Somers originated the cargo, but insisted only one truck was seized. The domestic British news agency Press Association later quoted David James, chairman of Somers' parent Eagle Trust, as saying another truck had been detained Friday in Turkey. But Turkish officials, including the customs director in the port Mersin, where the truck was rumored to be, denied the reports. Somers said the last of 12 steel tubes ordered by Iraq at a cost of more than $1.6 million left the factory ``by shipment'' March 15. ``Until a few hours ago, we thought it had all gone by sea,'' a company spokesman said. ``We now learn that two lorries (trucks) detained in Greece were each carrying one and possibly two of our pipes. ``It would be fair to assume that at least six of the others forged by Walter Somers Ltd. have got through to Iraq.'' Customs investigators were believed to have been trying to intercept the road freight for more than a week as it made its way from Birmingham to Iraq. British officials seized eight steel tubes on the Middlesbrough docks in England on April 12. The tubes were parts for a gun that would be 130 feet long with a bore of nearly 40 inches, British customs officials said. The Iraqi government and the British manufacturer of the tubes, Sheffield Forgemasters, have said they were designed for a petrochemical plant. There was no immediate comment from Iraq on the Greek shipment. Tony Peck, a spokesman for Sheffield Forgemasters, said in London that he assumes the shipment confiscated in Greece ``is ancillary equipment for the same Iraqi contract that has already been widely reported.'' Weapons experts have said a gun built from the parts confiscated in Britain and Greece could fire nuclear or chemical missiles hundreds of miles, far enough to reach Israel and Iran. Nicholas Ridley, Britain's trade and industry secretary, said on Thursday his government ``is entirely satisfied that these tubes form part of a gun and that the customs action was correct.'' Britain banned arms shipments to Iran and Iraq when the two countries were at war, and the ban remains in effect.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Allows Jewish Settlers to Stay in Christian Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Greece reaction, INSERTS two grafs after 12th pvs, `Most countries...' Pickup 13th pvs, `In Friday's...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TLV2
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Supreme Court on Friday blocked the eviction of Jewish settlers living in a compound in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City, temporarily setting aside an order by the attorney general. The 150 settlers can remain in the four 100-year-old buildings near the Church of the Holy Sepulcher until the high court hears more arguments next week on an appeal for the settlers to remain. Attorney General Yosef Harish on Thursday ordered their immediate eviction from the 72-room complex, owned by the Greek Orthodox Church. Harish said he wanted to prevent further deterioration of Jewish-Christian relations. The church claims a former tenant illegally sold his user rights to the building to the settlers. The April 11 move by the settlers into the Christian quarter sparked angry protests by Arab Christians and Moslems. They fear the group is leading a campaign to eventually push all Palestinians out of the walled Old City. After the high court allowed the settlers to stay, a half dozen Greek Orthodox priests carrying candles staged a protest vigil outside the complex. Black flags fluttered from the Holy Sepulcher and the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate. Right-wing Parliament member Hanan Porath, a mentor of the settler group, said even though the court treated the case as a simple tenancy dispute, it was a political confrontation. ``The motives of all sides are political. This is a struggle over the rights of Jews to live everywhere in Jerusalem,'' he told The Associated Press. ``This is one of the most sensitive places in the world,'' Avraham Sochovolsky, attorney for the church, told the three-judge panel. ``There is no quiet moment there now. We have to douse this fire.'' Anger over the move has been heightened by the fact that Arabs cannot buy land in the Old City's Jewish Quarter under Israeli law. The settlement also has implications concerning Israel's sovereignty over Jerusalem. The Christian quarter is part of east Jerusalem, which Israel seized from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Most countries, including the United States, do not recognize Israeli sovereignty over the disputed area. The Palestinians hope east Jerusalem will be the capital of their would-be state. Greece on Friday strongly criticized Israel in the matter. ``We condemn the stand taken by Israel, which so far has failed to take proper measures for removal of the occupiers,'' Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras said in a statement. ``Moreover the regrettable incident has taken place in occupied territory.'' In Friday's hearing, the Supreme Court made no reference to the religious and political dimensions of the case. Chief Justice Meir Shamgar scheduled a hearing for next Thursday, during which Harish must show why his immediate eviction order should not be annulled. ``The settlers will be allowed to stay until there is a final decision by the high court,'' said attorney Dan Avi-Yitzhak, who represents the Panama-based company SBC, which leased the building to the settlers. SBC claims it gave Martyros Matossian, an Armenian who has lived in the complex more than 40 years, $3.5 million for the user rights. Matossian left for Geneva before the settlers moved in. Attorney Yohanan Altbauer, who represents the church, said Matossian had no right to sublet the building. He said the church has been trying since 1982 to evict Matossian and that the case was pending. A decision is not expected for another six months, Altbauer said. The Supreme Court will not make a ruling on the tenancy dispute, but only on whether the settlers can remain while the lower court sorts out the tenancy rights. Altbauer said the Supreme Court judges offered a compromise under which the settlers would leave and only a few SBC representatives would remain until the tenancy dispute is decided. ``Both sides rejected the compromise,'' Altbauer said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Decries New Soviet Action in Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs to UPDATE with final appearance of the day and include color; ADDS 2 grafs to include political quote from Orlando event.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration criticized Moscow's escalating crackdown on Lithuania as ``another unfortunate step'' Friday and saidPresident Bush would summon leaders of Congress next week to discuss possible retaliatory action. The situation in the break away Baltic republic darkened amid reports that Moscow was blocking food shipments after sharply reducing fuel supplies. Witnesses in the capital city of Vilnius also said Red Army soldiers stormed into a printing plant and beat civilian guards. ``We are increasingly concerned by news reports today of an economic crackdown on Lithuania,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, accompanying Bush on a political trip to Birmingham and Orlando. Bush, himself, was silent on Lithuania. He avoided the subject as he made a political appearance in Birmingham, Ala., and visited a model recycling plant, and again in Orlando where he campaigned for the GOP and also fed a bottle of food to a 235-pound orphan manatee at Sea World. ``Although our information is sketchy, we are disturbed that this signals another unfortunate step in the pressure being brought to bear by the Soviet Union on Lithuania,'' Fitzwater said, reading from prepared remarks. This statement represented a toughening of the administration's rhetoric intended to match the increase in Soviet action and put pressure on Moscow to relax tension. By delaying any U.S. response until next week, Bush in effect gave Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev a few more days to reconsider his tactics to force Lithuania to drop its efforts to succeed from the Soviet Union. Bush, during a tour of Orlando's Sea World park, was asked why he was waiting until next week to respond to Soviet actions. ``A lot of consultations going on,'' he replied. Hopeful of preserving U.S.-Soviet relations and prospects for nuclear arms negotiations, Bush has reacted cautiously over the last few weeks to Soviet intimidation of Lithuania. ``We continue to urge the Soviet Union to pursue a peaceful course of dialogue in the hopes that this matter can be resolved in a responsible manner,'' Fitzwater said. He said Bush had stepped up consultation with allies about actions the United States would take and steps that other nations might adopt. Fitzwater said the president would complete his deliberations next week. ``At that time President Bush would meet congressional leaders to advise them on our consultations and to discuss possible courses of action,'' Fitzwater said. Asked if Bush would announce after the meeting with congressional leaders what he plans to do, Fitzwater said, ``I would assume that we would be prepared to announce actions fairly soon after that.'' When asked why Bush needed more time to frame a response, Fitzwater replied, ``Because many of the actions that we would contemplate taking would involve other countries, would have international implications, and we therefore think it's important that we touch base with our allies on this issue.'' The administration already has signaled that the most likely U.S. action against Moscow would be in the economic field, such as trade, rather than a slowdown in arms negotiations or discussions of regional disputes. Earlier Friday, Fitzwater indicated the administration held out hope for release of an American hostage in Lebanon but cited ``troublesome patterns we've seen before.'' With the hostage situation still uncertain _ and Kremlin tactics turning to violence in Lithuania _ Bush followed a business-as-usual approach, blending politics with environmentalism and a touch of personal recreation. After an early-morning jog and a speedboat ride in Key Largo, Fla., Bush jetted to Birmingham to help raise money for Bill Cabaniss, a conservative businessman struggling to unseat incumbent Democratic Sen. Howell Heflin. The next stop was back in Florida for an Orlando fund-raiser to boost Gov. Bob Martinez' re-election hopes and to help other Republicans. After that, Bush was flying back to the Florida Keys for a weekend of fishing. In his public remarks, Bush stayed away from the Mideast and Lithuania situations, instead celebrating the defections of 215 Democratic politicians, mostly in the South, to Republican ranks since the 1988 election. Overshadowing the trip were the promise of release _ and then threatened delay _ of an American hostage in Lebanon. Those concerns were compounded by new Soviet coercion in Lithuania. Fitzwater said that Syria, which exerts military control in Lebanon, ``still believes there's a possibility of release'' of a hostage even though the kidnappers said they were postponing it. The captors, the radical Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, blamed the delay on Bush's refusal to meet their demand to send Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly to Syria to accept a hostage. ``That was just a smokescreen and we think people realize that,'' Fitzwater said. In a countermove, Bush sent the U.S. ambassador to Syria, Edward Djerejian, back to Damascus to be on hand for hostage developments. While holding out hope for release of a hostage, Fitzwater said, ``We'll just wait and see if it's real.'' Asked if the kidnappers were toying with the United States, Fitzwater replied, ``They do it every time.'' To highlight the environment, Bush went to Birmingham-Southern College to view a model recycling program that enlists the help of inner city youngsters as well as college students. In Orlando, Bush announced the addition of five new sites, including waterways around Boston's polluted harbor, to the Environmental Protection Agency's National Estuary Program. The designation leads to the development of comprehensive management plans to protect the areas. The new sites are: Tampa Bay and the Indian River Complex, both in Florida; the Barataria-Terrebonne Estuarine Complex in Louisiana; Casco Bay, Maine, and the Massachusetts Bays in Massachusetts. Bush also used his Orlando appearance to unleash tough criticism against Democrats. ``Sadly, the other party has no firm principles, and no new ideas to offer the world at this critical time,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: President Calls For Remembrance of Armenians Killed By Turks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush paid respects Friday to the more than 1 million Armenians killed in ``terrible massacres'' at the hands of the Turks from 1915 to 1923. Bush, in a written statement issued during a visit here, said he joined with Armenians and others who will observe April 24 as a day of remembrance. ``I call upon all peoples to work to prevent future acts of inhumanity against mankind, and my comments of June 1988 represent the depth of my feeling for the Armenian people and the sufferings they have endured,'' Bush said. In 1988, as a candidate for president, Bush referred to the killings as a ``genocide.'' As president, he has refrained from using that term out of sensitivity toward Turkey, a NATO ally. The Bush administration opposed a Senate resolution sponsored by Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., which called the killings genocide. Bush said that through their history, the Armenians have shown strength and resilience in the face of numerous tragedies. ``Those tragedies include the earthquake of 1988 and, most prominently, the terrible massacres suffered in 1915-1923 at the hands of the rulers of the Ottoman Empire,'' the president said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Invokes 75-Year-Old Curfew to Keep Kids in at Night
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of this old milltown reached back to 1915 to find a way to keep teen-agers off the streets after 10 p.m. Mayor Patrick Hildreth said he dusted off a 75-year-old law imposing a 10 p.m. curfew in an effort to curb vandalism and excessive noise on the streets of the town of 5,300, 20 miles north of Albany. ``It also brings parents and children closer together,'' he said Friday. ``In this day and age, when both parents are working, that's important.'' Parents of first-time violators will get off with a warning, Hildreth said. If their kids are caught a second time, parents face a $25 fine. After that, parents could find themselves behind bars. The youths who violate the curfew face no penalty. The ordinance, which police began enforcing Monday, applies to anyone under the age of 16. Each night, even on weekends, a horn that sits atop a telephone pole next to the local McDonald's sounds the start of the curfew. ``Nobody has been arrested yet,'' said Hildreth, who's found some opposition in his own back yard from his son Kevin, 13. ``My son doesn't like it, but he was never allowed out after 10 anyway,'' Hildreth said. ``It's been on the books since 1915. I had to comply with the law when I was a kid, and the curfew then was 9:30.'' Hildreth said he hasn't received any complaints yet from parents, but the New York Civil Liberties Union is looking into the matter and may challenge the ordinance. ``Forget it, the law could never stand up in court,'' said the group's executive director, Norman Siegel. ``It's unconstitutional.''

DOC.HEAD: Toddler's Mother Sentenced to 30 Years
DOC.TEXT: A mother who pleaded guilty in the killing of her 2-year-old son during potty training was sentenced Friday to an agreed-upon 30 years in prison. Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, dressed in her navy blue jail uniform, stared blankly as she listened to the sentence, part of a deal made last month in which she agreed to plead guilty to second-degree murder in the July 27 death of Bradley McGee. Mrs. Coe's husband, Thomas Coe, told authorities he repeatedly dunked Bradley head-first into a toilet for soiling his pants, and then he and his wife beat the child with pillows until he collapsed. While Mrs. Coe's 30-year sentence exceeds the recommended 12 to 17 years for second-degree murder, a first-degree murder conviction would have brought a sentence of life in prison without parole for at least 25 years. Under the plea deal, Circuit Judge Randall McDonald imposed the 30-year sentence, which with good behavior and gain time translates to about 10 years in actual time behind bars. ``I don't think it was harsh enough,'' said Kip Lyles, who once cared for Bradley in a foster home. ``I think she should have received the death penalty for what she did. ... She did nothing to protect the child and she participated in it.'' Prosecutors say Mrs. Coe will be subpoenaed to testify against her husband at his first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse trial, set for July in Fort Myers. Bradley McGee had been in foster care since his parents abandoned him at a Lakeland mall when he was 3 months old. The state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services returned the child to his parents despite repeated warnings from foster parents and relatives that he might be in danger. Bradley died two months after being returned. Three HRS child protection workers were later charged with failing to report suspected child abuse. One HRS supervisor was acquitted in February and the others still face trial. Outrage over the toddler's death also prompted lawmakers last fall to pass the ``Bradley McGee Bill,'' allocating an extra $78 million for the HRS to hire more child-protection workers.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Puzzled by 51 Slaughtered Burros
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of 51 burros have been found in the Black Mountain foothills, and authorities are looking for those responsible for killing the wild animals, a Bureau of Land Management official said Friday. BLM crews in a helicopter spotted 11 more carcasses Friday, bringing the week's total to 51, said Bureau of Land Management wrangler Kelly Grissom. The carcasses all were found in the same area of the foothills, about 15 miles southwest of this western Arizona town, where 38 others were found earlier this week. Grissom said an investigation was under way, adding that bullets removed from the carcasses indicate more than one weapon was used. Some of slaughtered burros likely would have been rounded up for the BLM's ``adopt-a-burro'' program begun in 1976, under which some of the animals are given away, said Elaine Marquis, area managner for the BLM. The BLM maintains about 2,100 wild burros on public lands throughout western and central Arizona. The local Humane Society and other animal protection groups have begun offering rewards for information about the burros' deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Brings Promise for Future
By MARLENE AIG
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Honduran President Rafael Leonardo Callejas said Friday his country was donating $25,000 to build a recreation center in the neighborhood where 87 people died when fire swept through an illegal social club. Cardinal John O'Connor said the archdiocese of New York also was committed to building the center to diminish the need for illegal social clubs in the Bronx neighborhood. The announcements were made at a memorial Mass for the victims of the Happy Land Social Club tragedy. Callejas told the more than 750 people inside St. Thomas Aquinas Church and more than 100 people listening through loudspeakers outside that the Honduran people raised the money, and that $1,000 of it was from his own pocket. O'Connor said the church would match the contribution if the city would donate the land. He promised to donate $999.99 of his own. Most of the 87 people who died March 25 when fire ravaged the club were Honduran immigrants. Julio Gonzalez, 36, a Cuban immigrant, has been charged with setting the blaze. The Mass, originally scheduled for Sunday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, was shifted to St. Thomas, two blocks from the gutted social club building, so Callejas could attend, officials said. ``Too many immigrants in our country are forced to live in crowded, inadequate and dangerous housing conditions,'' O'Connor, speaking in Spanish, told families and friends of the victims. These immigrants have menial jobs because they are illegal, and ``it comes as no surprise that they are forced to use crowded and dangerous facilities for various forms of social activities because they are so poor,'' O'Connor said. Callejas told the crowd that ``we are together in your pain.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Expand Embargo on Lithuania to Include Food, Other Goods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th pvs, `The message... with Landsbergis quoted on possible compromise. Picks up 10th pvs, `In Birmingham...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Moscow on Friday expanded its energy embargo on Lithuania to include certain shipments of food, metal and industrial parts in its continuing effort to crush the republic's independence drive, Lithuanians said. Dozens of Soviet soldiers also stormed a printing plant and beat civilian guards and a local legislator Friday, witnesses said. The Kremlin ``is seeking to stop the plants, put the workers on the streets, and encourage social unrest,'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis charged at a news conference Friday night. Thus far in the 5-week-old standoff, no such unrest has occurred. Despite military and economic pressure, Lithuanians have refused to back off their March 11 declaration of independence from the Soviet Union, as demanded by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and have solicited Western material and political support. ``I'll have to sacrifice,'' said Aviea Kishnevskaya, a Jewish mother in her 30s interviewed in Vilnius, the capital. She said that requiring her 7-year-old daughter to share those sacrifices will be the hardest part. The city was calm Friday, and traffic was quieter than usual. Vilnius radio said the Presidium of the Lithuanian parliament messaged Gorbachev reiterating Lithuania's readiness to negotiate with Moscow. It said Landbergis disclosed details Friday night and quoted the message as reading in part, ``All countries big and small ... can and must find a solution worthy of civilized societies to any complication if these countries are guided by the principles of humanity. And it is only political dialogue that must underlie the search for the wisest solution.'' The message also said, ``We have no doubt that brutal assault and battery of ordinary people, like the one ... launched by units of the Soviet armed forces in Vilnius today, will call forth your condemnation and that those guilty ... will be punished accordingly.'' Landsbergis was quoted as saying that a freeze on putting Lithuania's independence fully into effect could form part of a compromise. ``If somebody authorized by Moscow to negotiate presented us with a package of proposals including this, we could have a discussion,'' The New York Times' Saturday editions quoted him as saying in a telephone interview. In Birmingham, Ala., where President Bush spoke at a political rally, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the White House is ``increasingly concerned'' by reports of the Soviet economic crackdown on Lithuania and that Bush will be ready to brief Congress early next week on possible retaliation. Lithuania was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Two ships from Cuba carrying raw sugar were diverted from the Lithuanian port of Klaipeda and a shipment of fish due from Latvia was sent elsewhere, Lithuania Deputy Prime Minister Romualdas Ozolas told reporters Friday night. Lithuania produces more meat and milk than it consumes, and is in no danger of starving. But Lithuania's Communist Party chief, Algirdas Brazauskas, said Friday this Baltic republic of 3.8 million people must compromise on its pro-independence decisions or face critical shortages of oil and natural gas in two weeks, following Soviet cut-offs and reductions the previous two days. Brazauskas said Moscow also has cut off the supply of rubber tires, polyesterol, cables, bearings and caustic soda. Large scheduled shipments of metal and wood failed to appear, he said. Most factories here are expected to close if no solution emerges. ``In two weeks we will have a critical situation,'' Brazauskas told the Lithuanian parliament. ``The price for independence must have limits.'' Algimantas Cekuolis, a newspaper editor and former Lithuanian representative in the Soviet parliament, told reporters Lithuanians may offer to freeze their new laws backing up independence, ``if Moscow gives us guarantees of something.'' Gorbachev has refused to negotiate unless Lithuania rescinds its declaration of independence. Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene was in Norway on Friday learning about buying oil for hard currency at world-market prices instead of low-cost oil for Soviet rubles. She offered to trade Lithuanian dairy products and said she will seek financial aid from the West. Despite all this, Foreign Minister Lennart Meri of neighboring Estonia said in Finland on Friday his republic rejects Soviet threats and inducements and refuses to rescind a March 30 declaration proclaiming itself an occupied, independent state. Armed soldiers stormed a Communist Party printing plant in Vilnius Friday afternoon, beating at least 12 civilian guards and a local legislator, witnesses said. Soviet soldiers previously occupied more than a half-dozen party and public buildings, but without violence. Lithuanian legislator Zigmas Vaisvilas told reporters the civilian guards arrived Friday at the plant, which already was occupied by a few Interior Ministry troops without weapons. The Soviet news agency Tass said the colonel in charge asked the 27 civilians to leave and called in reinforcements when they did not. Helmeted Soviet soldiers carrying automatic weapons and truncheons arrived in two trucks, surged into the building and beat some of the civilians, said witness Angele Guobiene, who works for the trade union journal Darbas Ir Poilsis that is printed at the plant. Newspaper editor Algimantas Cekuolis said the civilians, including legislator Vaisvilas, were hurt when they tried to bar the soldiers. Two or three people were hospitalized, Cekuolis said. Tass said the civilians were hurt when soldiers shoved them bodily out the door. Police kept reporters out of the building. Soldiers were visible in the building's courtyard. Some workers barricaded themselves near printing presses and looked out of open windows. About 500 people gathered outside. They sang nationalist songs and carried the hammer and sickle of the Soviet Union merged with the Nazi swastika. Soldiers began occupying buildings in Vilnius a month ago, among them a plant that prints the republic's newspapers. The plant occupied Friday prints non-political magazines. Lithuania on Friday limited gasoline to just under eight gallons a month for private cars and some large factories planned to give workers a day off Saturday _ the only conservation steps reported to deal with the cut-off of oil and loss of 80 percent of its supply of natural gas. The energy embargo left Lithuania with only 15 percent to 17 percent of the 18 million cubic meters of natural gas it uses daily for homes and industry. Gorbachev has demanded repeal of new republic laws that halt conscription of Lithuanians into the Soviet army and introduce identity cards for all citizens. He also complained about alleged seizure of Communist Party property. Brazauskas said the March 11 declaration should not be reconsidered, but urged lawmakers to compromise on Gorbachev's other demands ``to take us out of this dead end.''

DOC.HEAD: Body of U.S. Ferry Fire Victim Returned Home
DOC.TEXT: The body of a Michigan woman who was one of 161 people killed after arsonists torched a Scandinavian ferry was returned home on Thursday. The body of Ruth Rome, 27, arrived at Detroit Metropolitan Airport about 5 p.m., said her mother, Winifred Rome. The young woman had moved from East Lansing to New York before taking a singing job on the Scandinavian Star. She had been employed about a week when the ferry burned April 7. The fire remains under investigation. Services for Ms. Rome were scheduled for 10:30 a.m. Sunday at Congregation Shaarey Zedek in East Lansing, her mother said. Mrs. Rome said endowments in her daughter's name are being established at Okemos High School, from which she graduated in 1980, and at Shaarey Zedek. ``I think it will be for music-related activity,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Tap Career Diplomat to be Ambassador to Liberia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate James Keough Bishop, now ambassador to Liberia, to be the ambassador to Somali, the traveling White House announced Thursday. Bishop, 51, is a career diplomat. He would succeed Trusten Frank Crigler. The White House also said Bush will nominate: _Lawrence U. Costiglio, 73, a Uniondale, N.Y., lawyer and former New York Savings Bank Association executive, to be a director of the Federal Housing Finance Board. _Daniel F. Evans, an Indianapolis lawyer, to be a director of the Federal Housing Finance Board. _Daniel H. Carter, a Houston consultant, to be a member of the National Commission on Libraries and Information Science.

DOC.HEAD: Four Die in Crash of Single-Engine Plane in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine Cessna stalled and plunged into 8 feet of water in the Gulf of Mexico shortly after taking off Thursday, killing all four people aboard, Coast Guard officials said. The crash occurred about 5 p.m. on the north end of Upper Captiva Island, said Petty Officer Luis Diaz. The plane had taken off from Pine Island Airport near Fort Myers. ``Unfortunately, we couldn't rescue them,'' Diaz said after failed efforts by the Coast Guard, the Lee County Sheriff's Office rescue unit and the Florida Marine Patrol. The four people aboard were fire chiefs from different counties but no further information on their identities was immediately available, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys NRC Inspector's House After Threats
DOC.TEXT: Fire gutted the home of a Nuclear Regulatory Commission inspector Thursday, just hours after he received several threatening telephone calls, authorities said. Nobody was hurt in the fire, which occurred about 11 a.m. at the suburban home of Kenneth Jenison, senior resident NRC inspector at Sequoyah Nuclear Plant. Jenison was at Sequoyah when he learned of the blaze; he later found that the lugs on the wheels of his car had been loosened, said NRC spokesman Ken Clark. Hamilton County arson officials were investigating the cause of the fire, which erupted after Jenison received phone threats Wednesday night and earlier Thursday morning, Clark said from his Atlanta office. ``We are asking the FBI to look into the matter,'' Clark said. ``We will take whatever steps are necessary to protect our resident inspectors, their families and their property.'' Details of the threats were not disclosed. Oliver Kingsley, head of the Tennessee Valley Authority's nuclear program, said TVA officials were ``shocked and outraged by the apparently deliberately burning'' of Jenison's home. ``TVA is cooperating fully with the investigation into this matter and immediately began an internal examination to see if anything in TVA could be tied to this incident,'' said Kingsley. Jenison, one of three NRC inspectors at Sequoyah, has been at the TVA plant for about five years, Clark said.

DOC.HEAD: 30,000 in Outback Isolated by Floods
DOC.TEXT: More than 30,000 people in the Australian outback have been isolated by near-record floods, police said Friday. Farming districts in central and southern Queensland state were hardest hit by rising flood waters that followed three weeks of heavy rain. Meterologists said the flooding was the worst in the area for 40 years. Most of the normally dusty roads in the region were awash, forcing animals to high ground and many families from their homes. Families were evacuated from two towns, and another city had been cut off from overland travel for nearly a month. Among those isolated were 80 campers near Carnarvon Gorge but they were in no danger, a police spokesman said. Two Royal Australian Air Force Caribou transport planes dropped supplies to small rural communities Thursday and planned similar flights over the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Police Frustrate Terrorist Attack on Medellin Airport
DOC.TEXT: Police on Thursday foiled a plan by two Spanish Basque mercenaries to attack the Medellin airport with rocket and rifle fire, authorities said. Officials have accused members of the ETA, the separatist Basque group in Spain, of carrying out terrorist attacks in Colombia for drug traffickers. Gen. Huberto Camero, the city's police chief, said police found a rocket and two automatic rifles in a raid on a house across from Medellin airport. He said in a communique the two terrorists fled moments before the raid. Camero said the two were planning to carry out ``a large-scale attack, presumably against either presidential candidates or aircraft.'' The candidate for the opposition Conservative Party, Rodrigo Lloreda, was in Medellin on Thursday campaigning for May 27 elections. In Bogota, Gen. Miguel Maza, chief of Colombia's security police, told reporters the two mercenaries arrived in Medellin on Wednesday, apparently to prepare the attack on the airport. Mercenaries from the ETA _ which stands for Basque Land and Liberty in the Basque language _ have been implicated in two of the worst terrorist attacks by drug traffickers in their war against the government. Police blame the terrorists for bombing a Colombian jetliner last Nov. 27, killing all 107 people aboard. A car bomb targeting security police headquarters killed 63 people and wounded about 1,000 on Dec. 6. ETA members fabricated the car bomb, police said. Terrorists working for the Medellin cocaine cartel exploded a car bomb on a busy Medellin highway last week, killing 20 people, including eight police. The attacks were in retaliation for a government antidrug campaign, now in its eighth month. In Bogota, the capital, the government told Colombia's biggest leftist guerrilla group Thursday to end hostilities if it wants a peace agreement similar to that of other rebels who disbanded. Hours later, six leftist guerrillas were killed in a battle with a special army brigade created to fight the rebels. The deaths brought to 28 the number of rebels killed by the brigade in its first two weeks in operation. President Virgilio Barco's emissary for guerrilla contacts, Rafael Pardo, sent a message demanding that the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces, known as the FARC, cease attacks if it wants to begin peace talks. The statement was revealed in an official communique. The FARC says it has about 10,000 combatants. The Defense Department puts the number at about 4,400. By either measure, the FARC is the largest of Colombia's four guerrilla groups. It was founded in the 1950s. The FARC has expressed interest in peace talks, but has continued its attacks and kidnappings, Pardo said. The government successfully negotiated an end to hostilities by another guerrilla group, the April 19 Movement, known as M-19, last January and the M-19 leader, Carlos Pizarro, is running in the May 26 presidential elections. Another guerrilla group, the People's Liberation Army, or EPL, said this month that it, too, is interested in peace talks. The six guerrillas killed Thursday belonged to EPL, a Maoist group, an army communique said. Rebels fought soldiers in Montelibano, 250 miles north of Bogota. Colombia's most active guerrilla group, the National Liberation Army, known as the ELN, says it will fight until it overthrows the government.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Loans Hidden in Hocus-Pocus, Prosecutor Says
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of dollars in payoffs to U.S. Rep. Harold Ford were covered up with ``hocus-pocus'' and bogus loans from two crooked bankers, a prosecutor said Thursday in closing arguments in Ford's fraud trial. For more than 10 years, loans Ford wasn't expected to repay were bounced from bank to bank, Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Clancy told the U.S. District Court jury. Several loans in the Memphis Democrat's name ended up in his father's name or as the responsibility of a vague company called Tenn-Ford Inc., Clancy said. ``Hocus-pocus, now-you-see-it-and-now-you-don't, and his name is taken off,'' Clancy said. Ford, 44, is accused of taking payoffs from former Tennessee bankers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr. He is charged with 19 counts of conspiracy, bank and mail fraud, and faces up to 95 years in prison if convicted of all charges. Also on trial are three former Butcher aides: accountant David Crabtree and attorneys Douglas Beaty and Karl Schledwitz. C.H. Butcher was indicted with Ford in 1987, but has pleaded guilty to bank fraud and is serving a 20-year prison sentence. His brother Jake, who was named as an unindicted co-conspirator, is serving a 20-year sentence in another bank fraud case. Ford started getting loans between $6,000 and $7,000 from the Butchers in 1976, two years after he was first elected to Congress, but his political value to the bankers grew over the years, according to the government. In 1982, he got $350,000 from C.H. Butcher through Tenn-Ford, which was created by the bankers' aides. ``As his influence increased, so did his ability to talk them into giving him more money,'' Clancy said. The Butchers once controlled the largest string of banks in Tennessee, but their financial empire collapsed in 1983 under the weight of mismanagement and fraud. After C.H. Butcher's Southern Industrial Banking Corp. collapsed, Ford settled his obligations under the Tenn-Ford arrangement by paying a bankruptcy trustee $25,000. He told the trustee in a sworn statement that Tenn-Ford was set up to handle an investment by C.H. Butcher in the N.J. Ford & Son's Funeral Parlor in Memphis. Clancy said records of Ford's personal accountant showed that much of the Tenn-Ford money went to pay the congressman's personal debts, including credit card and department store bills. ``The funeral home didn't have an account at Neiman-Marcus. The funeral home didn't have an account at Saks Fifth Avenue,'' Clancy said. Ford says the government has failed to show what he supposedly did for the alleged payoffs, but Clancy said the motive for the Butchers giving him money is clear. ``Since you know who got the money, you know what they got for it. There was only one thing to get. ... They needed a United States congressman,'' he said. Financial records offered as evidence showed that Ford had so many debts in 1982 that his expenses exceeded his income by $12 a month even though he was not paying anything on his Butcher loans, Clancy said. Ford has acknowledged he was in bad financial shape and that he turned to C.H. Butcher to help line up investors in the Ford family business. Ford, the only black member of Tennessee's congressional delegation, has said since his indictment that he is the victim of racist prosecutors who dislike him personally. Clancy has denied those allegations. The defense was to present its closing argument Friday, and the case may go to the jury.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Man Innocent Because of Flub
DOC.TEXT: A man on trial for resisting arrest was freed Thursday after a judge agreed that he wasn't actually charged with anything because the wrong name was listed on the official papers. Anthony Martinez's lawyer, Peter Collins, waited for prosecutors to rest their case before telling Dade County Judge Morton Perry about the error. Over the protests of the state attorney's office, Perry on Wednesday found Martinez innocent. ``We don't feel a case should be decided on a typographical error,'' complained Chief Assistant State Attorney John Hogan. Prosecutors said they would try to file new charges against Martinez, a jail guard from Miami. But Collins said there were no grounds for such action, because the case ended in an acquittal, not the dismissal of charges. ``They can't appeal a not-guilty verdict,'' said Collins. ``The case is history.'' Martinez was arrested after allegedly threatening his girlfriend with a gun. But the paperwork in the case mistakenly listed two different names as the accused _ neither of which was Anthony Martinez. The two assistant prosecutors on the case, Lisa Kreeger and Tammera J. Ferrari, failed to notice the mistake. When Collins pointed it out, the judge gave the prosecutors 10 days to come up with a reason why he shouldn't throw out the case. The prosecutors tried to argue that since Martinez was not named, the trial never happened. But the judge rejected that reasoning.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Killed, 15 Houses Burned in Haitian Clash
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Soldiers fired Thursday into a crowd of protesters throwing stones and the mob retaliated by beating a soldier to death and burning his body, radio reports said. Two people suffered gunshot wounds and 15 houses were burned in the protest over the quality of utility services in Cabaret, a village about 20 miles north of Port-au-Prince, the reports said. Privately owned Radio Haiti Inter said clashes began after villagers blocked a highway. Soldiers used billy clubs to scatter the crowd, protesters threw stones and soldiers fired, wounding two people, the radio said. It said the mob turned on one soldier who fired and killed him. The report said troop reinforcements burned 15 houses in retaliation. But the local military commander, Lt. Atin Voltaire, denied soldiers were involved in the burning, according to Radio Metropole, another independent station. The violence came as doubts grew over the army's pledge to let the new civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot lead this impoverished Caribbean nation to democratic elections. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot became president on March 13 after a popular uprising forced military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril to flee into exile. She promised to hold democratic elections as soon as posssible. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a popular priest, on Thursday accused the government of lacking the political will to control the 8,300-member army, and expressed doubt over the possibility of free elections. ``If the army isn't under control, what sort of elections can we expect?'' he told a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Bull Family Dissolves Space Research Firm; Deny Illegal Arms Link
DOC.TEXT: The company of Gerald V. Bull, the U.S. rocket scientist who was mysteriously slain at his Brussels apartment last month, will be going out of business, his family said Thursday. It denied the firm, Space Research Corp., was linked to shipping steel tubes from Britain to Iraq that British officials say can be made into the barrel of a giant gun. ``The Bull family has decided to cease all SRC operations and dissolve companies within the SRC Group,'' the company said in a brief statement. ``The Bull family contests to be or to have been involved in any illegal acts or arms traffic of any nature.'' Bull, 62, a Canadian-born American, was an aerospace scientist and reputed to be an artillery expert. He was slain March 22. His killer remains at large. British customs officials seized eight steel tube sections on April 12 as they were about to be shipped to Iraq. The manufacturer has denied the tubes can be used as a gun barrel. Police have ruled out robbery as a motive in Bull's slaying. They said they found $20,000 in the victim's pockets. Bull built a 6,000-acre compound for his Space Research Corp. in North Troy, Vt., on the Canadian border in the late 1970s. He moved SRC to Brussels in 1980 after serving a six-month term for selling howitzer technology to South Africa in violation of a U.S. law and a United Nations arms embargo.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Claims Heavy Rebel Casualties
DOC.TEXT: Chadian soldiers killed 517 Libyan-backed rebels and took 208 prisoners in heavy fighting along Chad's eastern border with Sudan, the government announced Thursday. A communique said government forces ``completely destroyed'' a column of the so-called Islamic Legion in the combat Wednesday, but gave no specific location and said nothing of government losses. It said troops also captured 40 light pickup trucks, two multiple-rocket launchers, seven single-rocket launchers, 31 artillery pieces, three heavy trucks and numerous small arms, and destroyed a like amount of material. The Islamic Legion infiltrates into Chad from Sudan's Darfur province, an area over which the Sudanese government exercises virtually no control. The communique stressed the soldiers' ``ferocious determination'' to crush the rebels. Chad claims the Legion is armed by Libya. Tripoli denies the group exists. Fighting in the sporadic civil war broke out last month when rebels took government outposts at Bahai and Tine. Chadian troops retook the positions in fighting which N'Djamena said killed 330 guerrillas. The battles prompted France to reinforce its garrisons in eastern Chad with 146 paratroopers, a second transport aircraft and a military surgical unit. France had been stationing about 1,000 troops in its former African colony. Libya once occupied most of northern Chad, but was chased out three years ago. Tripoli still claims a strip of land on Chad's northern border, the Aouzou Strip.

DOC.HEAD: Study Concludes Small Cut In Illegal Immigration Since 1986 Reform Act
DOC.TEXT: The number of illegal aliens caught entering the country per year dropped nearly by half from 1986 to 1988, but sanctions on employers played a small role in cutting the flow, said a study released Thursday. Employer sanctions in the Immigration Reform and Control Act alone slowed the rate of illegal entry into the United States by less than 20 percent, according to a joint study by the Rand Corp. and the Washington-based Urban Institute. The study concluded that if the sanctions portion of the law was expected to merely stop the increase of illegal immigrants, the reform act has succeeded. But if officials expected a major drop in such numbers, then the sanctions have failed and they probably should be reviewed by Congress, the study's authors said. Among the considerations would be increasing the level of enforcement or considering the cost of continuing the sanctions against such limited results. Congress approved the Immigration Act in November 1986. The employer-sanctions section was one of the most controversial. For more than a year, the Immigration and Naturalization Service conducted seminars and contacted businesses about their obligations under the law. Then businesses were checked for compliance. Only in 1989 were repeat offenders prosecuted and punished for disobeying the law. The study looked at various statistics to make its conclusions, including counts of people passing through Canyon Zapata north of Tijuana, Mexico, a favored spot of illegal entry of the United States. The raw data showed more than 1.7 million apprehensions in 1986, down to just over 1 million apprehensions in 1988, the last year for which the statistics were available. Immigration waiting lists of several countries also were investigated. Researchers theorized that if immigration reforms were effective, more people would be convinced to try entering the United States legally. Also reviewed were the wages for jobs traditionally taken by illegal immigrants: dishwashing and car washing. A rise in wages would indicate a decrease in the supply of such workers, but no rise was detected. ``Alone, none of our data sets provides conclusive evidence that employer sanctions have or have not reduced undocumented immigration,'' the study said. ``Together, the preponderance of the evidence points to some decline in the flow.''

DOC.HEAD: First Half of April Set Record For Political Violence in Peru^
DOC.TEXT: At least 300 people were killed in political violence in the first half of April, the bloodiest 15-day period in Peru's decade-long guerrilla war, according to a Senate commission. Sen. Enrique Bernales of the Socialist Left coalition said Thursday the guerrillas launched 178 attacks against government and civilian targets in the same period, also a record. Much of the violence occurred before the April 8 general elections. Rebels tried to sabotage the elections by assassinating candidates and threatening to kill people who voted. Peru's elected government is currently battling two violent leftist insurgencies. The most radical group is the Mao-inspired Shining Path, which began fighting 10 years ago in the southern Andean highlands. It now operates throughout the Andes and in the coca-producing jungles of the northeast. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement is a smaller and less violent group that operates mainly in Lima and some regions of the northern jungle. The pro-Cuban group took up arms in 1984. Bernales, head of a respected Senate commission on violence, said 150 of the April deaths were confirmed by the military or police. The rest were unofficial reports received by his office. More than 18,000 people have been killed since 1980. He said a great majority of the dead were civilians killed by both sides. Bernales criticized President Alan Garcia's government for telling the public it is winning the war against the guerrillas. ``This is dramatic evidence that terrorism has not been slowed but has increased,'' Bernales said. The highest monthly death toll was recorded by the commission last June when 470 people were killed.

President Bush is expected to name a female career diplomat as U.S. ambassador to Nicaragua as that country prepares for a new era under President-elect Violeta Chamorro, according to informed sources. The sources said Thursday it is virtually certain the appointment will go to Melissa Wells, 57, currently ambassador to Mozambique. They said the administration believed a female ambassador could relate better than a man to Mrs. Chamorro, who takes office Wednesday. They also said the administration is eager to have more women in key posts. Only rarely have U.S. ambassadorships in Latin America gone to women.

Despite a pact to disband the Contras, President Daniel Ortega said Nicaraguans can't be sure their 9-year-old civil war is over until the last rebel lays down his gun. The Contras signed an accord Thursday with the United National Opposition and the Sandinistas to begin turning in their weapons next Wednesday, the day the 14-party bloc and President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro are to take office. The Contras are to give up all of their arms by June 10, and all sides agreed to a cease-fire that went into effect at noon Thursday. There has been widespread speculation the Sandinista government might not transfer power as pledged _ despite its loss in Feb. 25 elections _ if the Contras did not disarm. The situation has created an atmosphere of mutual suspicion, and Ortega appealed for trust. ``We still can't say that peace has arrived, but we can say today that we are much closer to peace and are distancing ourselves from war,'' he said after a meeting with Bernard Aronson, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs.

Bugs Bunny, Alf and the Slimer share an honor usually reserved for the president: They're appearing simultaneously on NBC, CBS, ABC and four cable networks. The TV program granted these State-of-the-Unionlike privileges is titled ``Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue,'' a half-hour special warning youngsters about drug and alcohol abuse. The networks, cable channels and more than 200 independent stations will show the program at the same time Saturday in different time zones. ``They want to be able to reach every single kid who watches television, and we know from experience with kids that the way to grab their attention is to use characters they know to convey a story and a message,'' said Phyllis Tucker Vinson, NBC vice president for children's programming.

An international task force is recommending a worldwide plan to uncover billions of dollars being hidden by narcotics dealers through intricate money-laundering transactions. A major element of the plan, according to Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, is a requirement that financial institutions report questionable dealings by their customers. ``Specifically, the task force recommends that, as in the United States, financial institutions must be able to report suspicious transactions to law enforcement, in good faith, free from fear of liability under secrecy laws,'' Robson said at a news conference Thursday. ``Suspicious transaction reporting has proven to be very valuable to U.S. law enforcement,'' he added.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv27
For Release PMs Friday April 27 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Haiti's Women Hope for Change
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Women till the poor land, toil in sweatshops and perform the other drudgery that moves Haiti's meager economy, but the choice of a woman as president in March was their first real taste of power. ``They dominate in agriculture, trade and industry,'' sociologist Daniele Bazin said. ``They, in fact, run this country.'' Until Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, 46, was installed March 26, women were virtually excluded from power in Haiti, which has been ruled by dictators through much of its 186 years. As recently as the early 1980s, women were regarded as ``legal minors,'' barred from opening bank accounts, buying property or traveling without the consent of their husbands. Those laws have been repealed, but little has been done to improve the hard lot of most Haitian women. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, the only woman ever to serve on the Supreme Court, has become a symbol of women's aspirations since taking office as provisional president. ``I accept in the name of Haitian women,'' she said at the inauguration. Her civilian administration, which is to govern as caretaker until democratic elections can be held, replaced the 18-month-old military government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, who was driven into exile by a popular uprising. The choice of Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot by a coalition of opposition groups ``had psychological impact,'' historian Suzy Castor said. ``When the army gives up power to a civilian, and to a woman at that, it has a lot of meaning,'' she said. ``I don't have illusions, but it represents a few steps.'' Symbol she may be, but the elegant, highly educated president has little in common with her illiterate, improverished sisters. Women from privileged families have gained ground in Haiti _ about half the doctors are women, for instance _ but only one-fourth of university students are women. What money is available for higher education usually goes to a son. Haiti, which shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic, is the Western Hemisphere's poorest nation. Most of its 6 million people live in the countryside, working tiny mountain plots of coffee, sugar cane, rice and corn with primitive tools. Agriculture accounts for 32 percent of a gross national product valued at $1.5 billion annually. Half the work force is unemployed and average annual pay for those who find jobs is only about $370. Most city dwellers live in slums without electricity, potable water or adequate sewers, and life expectancy is 53 years. The 8,300-member army is a way out of poverty for men. Women run the households, care for the children and support the economy in countless ways. Most of the distribution and sale of crops is carried out by peasant women who walk long distances in the mountains to sell their goods at outdoor markets. Women called ``Madames Sara,'' for a migratory bird, handle most of the trade with the rest of the Caribbean, traveling to the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Martinique, Curacao, and Panama to buy kitchenware, shoes and food for sale at home. Government tax incentives and low wages attract foreign-owned manufacturing plants that produce electronics, clothing and sporting goods for sale abroad, mostly in the United States.
