Women make up about 75 percent of the factory workers, who are paid only $3.20 a day. Paul Latortue, a Haitian economist at the University of Puerto Rico, said women's conomic contribution is ``overwhelming.'' ``Though we don't have the data, I believe women produce the better part of Haiti's GNP,'' he said. About 80 percent of Haitian mothers raise their children alone. Marriage is commonly viewed as a preserve of the upper class and most children are born out of wedlock. Couples who live together consider themselves married, but men have no legal obligation to pay child support or alimony. Men change wives at will and may have several at the same time. ``Men run around a lot to prove their virility,'' said Irene, a 22-year-old housemaid who asked that only her first name be used. Claudette Werleigh, social affairs minister and the Cabinet's only woman, said men often have several ``wives'' in a lifetime. ``Among the poor, the man has many women, so he is absent,'' she said. ``He escapes the problems, the sick children, the crying.'' Haiti has an infant mortality rate of 135 per 1,000 births, highest among Western nations, and women tend to have several children so a few will survive. Children are a woman's protection when the man leaves, and often go to work when very young. ``The only thing a woman has to look forward to in Haiti is that her children will have a better life than she does,'' said Mrs. Bazin, the sociologist. ``They are her insurance policy, and she will slave so her child can get an education.'' Violence against women is common, but usually goes unreported because abused women have nowhere to turn. ``There are no women's shelters,'' said Lilian Pierre-Paul, a popular radio newscaster. ``When they are beaten they come here. They come on foot, in trucks, to talk to me and ask for help.'' Feminists say attempts to organize have been difficult because Haitian women's priority is economic survival. ``Women don't have time to go to meetings,'' said Michele de Ronceray, a sociologist and political activist. Women's groups have sprung up in recent years, however, and some observers see Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's government as a turning point. ``We go the countryside and women are saying they are concerned about their lives,'' said Daniele Fouchard, founder of am education and health center for illiterate women and children that has 300 branches. ``For years, they weren't able to say what they were thinking; they were afraid to talk,'' she said. ``People are thinking something can change with a new person, with a woman as president.''

DOC.HEAD: Student Groups Plan Spring Offensive Against ROTC Anti-Gay Rules
DOC.TEXT: College campuses across the country will be the scene of a spring offensive in the battle between gay activists and the Pentagon over its policy barring homosexuals from military service. Activists led by a University of Wisconsin-Madison group are in the process of organizing simultaneous news conferences to take place May 4. The thrust will be joint attacks on Reserve Officer Training Corps programs that exclude homosexuals from receiving financial aid or being commissioned as officers. The groundswell of student interest has come as a surprise to some national gay leaders. Until ROTC emerged as an issue last year on college campuses, gay activists had been focusing primarily on the courts and Congress in their effort to change Pentagon policy. ``I don't understand this _ why the schools in the Midwest are getting so revved up about this, but they are,'' said Sue Hyde, director of the Gay and Lesbian Military Freedom Project, based in Washington. In recent weeks, Hyde said, she has fielded inquiries from students and faculty at about a dozen schools seeking information and advice on how to shake up their ROTC chapters or continue protests already begun. The effort has begun to show some results. Several universities already have written the Pentagon warning that ROTC's future on campuses is in jeopardy unless the policy changes. In a recent letter to the Defense Department, John M. Deutch, provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the exclusion of homosexuals runs counter to MIT's ``priniciple of non-discrimination against individuals on the basis of sexual orientation.'' About 96,000 students participate in ROTC programs on 585 campuses, according to the Defense Department. In 1989 alone, students or faculty at least six schools _ the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Yale, Harvard, the University of Minnesota, Northwestern and the University of Iowa law school _ took action against ROTC chapters for their discriminatory policies. Those actions ranged from barring ROTC from using Iowa law school buildings to refusing to reinstate the corps at Harvard and Yale. (ROTC was ousted from the latter two campuses 20 years ago to protest the Vietnam War.) At the University of Wisconsin, the student and faculty senates voted in December to recommend that the board of regents phase out ROTC by 1993 unless the military changes its anti-gay policy. The following month, Chancellor Donna Shalala instead recommended working within the system to pressure the Pentagon and allowing the ROTC to remain indefinitely. Many students contend that Shalala's solution violates the university's own anti-discrimination policy and a state law prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, said Jordan Marsh, university affairs director of the Wisconsin Student Association. ``I think it's important to start a comprehensive mobilization effort,'' said Marsh, a senior who is organizing the simultaneous news conferences. He said he has invited about 120 colleges to participate. Alan Berube, a San Francisco-based historian whose book ``Coming Out Under Fire: The History of Gay Men and Women in World War Two,'' was published this month, said he had just returned from a talk at Chico State College in California and was surprised at how quickly interest was spreading. ``The whole issue in the last six or eight months has become much more public,'' he said. He pointed to the cases of Joe Steffan, a naval cadet who was expelled from Anapolis for admitting his homosexuality, and James Holobaugh, a former ROTC cadet at Washington University in St. Louis who in January was denied an Army commission for the same reason. At least two other ROTC cadets have also come out recently, leading the military to try to make them pay back their scholarships. Several dozen members of Congress have sent protest letters to the Pentagon. The cases are still open. The Defense Department policy says flatly that ``homosexuality is incompatible with military service.'' The Defense Department contends that the presence of gay people would undermine discipline, order and morale; and that homosexuals in the military would be particularly susceptible to blackmail. However, internal Defense Department studies _ which the Pentagon had tried to suppress but which leaked out anyway _ disputed those arguments and concluded that gay people perform their military duties as well as straight people. Nevertheless, the military expels about 1,400 people every year on charges of homosexuality, according to the DOD's own estimates. Nan Hunter, who heads the Lesbian and Gay Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union in New York, predicted that campus protests would resonate all the way to Washington. ``In general I think the tide is turning in our favor,'' she said. ``I think the irrationality of the policy is becoming more clear even within the military.'' But gay leaders are divided on how and when change might come. Sue Hyde said she doesn't see the political courage in Congress to pass even a symbolic amendment on the subject right now. Hunter said she does not see much evidence that the courts will confront the military, either. ``There is a longstanding tradition of deference to military on a whole range of issues,'' she said, pointing to the U.S. Supreme Court ruling that it was constitutional to discharge an Orthodox Jew from the Air Force for wearing a yarmulke. Another option would be for President Bush to change the policy by executive order, much as President Harry Truman integrated the military in 1948. But Hyde said she believes change is still a long way off. ``One of the big questions we always grapple with at our project meetings is, `What time is it?' meaning, do we think the moment is really ripe for some kind of clear statement by Congress,'' she said. If midnight is the goal of passing legislation, ``I think it's about 6:30,'' she said. ``P.M.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday PMs April 23

For Release Sunday, April 22, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Recycling the Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, ``The 1,000 ... evening air,'' to reflect that most of the guests carpooled; PICKS UP 5th graf, ``It was ... other gas-guzzlers''; also moving on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Corporate Ecology
DOC.TEXT: Do celebrities really care about spotted owls, the ozone layer and rain forests? Or are they simply tree-hugging the cause of the week? The evidence suggests that while numerous entertainers _ actor Ed Begley Jr. and singer Jackson Browne among them _ have adapted environmentally friendly living practices, many others are slow to practice what they preach. At a recent Beverly Hills benefit for the Brazilian rain forest, an array of Hollywood celebrities _ superstars like Jane Fonda and agent Michael Ovitz _ were warned of the dangers of global warming and pollution. The 1,000 or so guests, who dined on organic foods, raised $1.2 million for the environment. Most carpooled, but the scores who didn't went for their limos, which idled patiently, stretching for blocks. Exhaust filled the evening air. It was scarcely an isolated slip. When Hollywood's blue-ribbon Environmental Media Association held its first organizational meeting at producer Norman Lear's house, EMA founders arrived in Mercedes, BMWs, Rolls-Royces and other gas-guzzlers. Producer Ted Field and wife Susie, who hosted the Beverly Hills rain forest benefit, are longtime contributors to the Natural Resources Defense Council and charter members of EMA. They also have been known to fly to their spacious Aspen home in a private jet. ``It's great celebrities are getting involved,'' said Bob Hattoy, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club. ``But it's not about doing lunch. It's about changing the way that we live. Lifestyles of the rich and famous are often lifestyles of the wasteful and indulgent.'' ``The entertainment industry is symbolic of the values of everyone in our culture,'' said Bonnie Reiss, who founded the Earth Communications Office. ECO seeks to add environmental themes to television shows and movies. ``We have to get the rich and famous to truly examine their lifestyles,'' Reiss said. Environmentalism has yet to become Hollywood's flavor of the month. It has long been the land of excess, and tradition does not die easily. At an April news conference for ABC's Earth Day special, celebrity performers were ferried to the event in _ you guessed it _ limousines. Tom Cruise has visited the Amazonian rain forest and is a member of the ECO. So is his next movie about global warming? Not quite. Cruise stars next in ``Days of Thunder,'' a movie about the hardly fuel-efficient sport of auto racing. Scientists estimate a third of all global-warming gases are transportation-produced; neither Paramount Pictures nor Cruise's publicist could say how many thousands of gallons of fuel were used making ``Days of Thunder.'' Olivia Newton-John, a top environmental activist, is damaging a stretch of the Southern California coastline, her Malibu neighbors have charged in a civil complaint. Newton-John and her husband have polluted the ocean with tons of dirt and sand removed during the construction of their 6,000-square-foot home overlooking the beach, the complaint charges. ``It's blown way out of proportion,'' Newton-John said. ``I had an environmental specialist look at the property. I care about the environment.'' Die-hard environmentalists don't wear furs or leather. So how did people dress at the Beverly Hills rain forest benefit? Singer Don Henley, who performed at the fund-raiser, said he had visited the cloakroom before coming on stage. What did he see? ``About a quarter of a million dollars' worth of dead animals.'' Actor Begley is one of the handful of personalities who has reordered his life to save the planet. He rides a bicycle or takes the bus to work, has a compost heap in his backyard and has installed 15-watt bulbs in his house. ``We don't need any more definition of environmental problems,'' Begley said. ``We need action.'' David Zucker, co-director of ``Airplane!'' and the director of ``Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad,'' now drives an electric car. Dennis Weaver, star of the TV series ``McCloud,'' has designed an ``ecologically balanced'' house in Colorado. ``We're building it out of old tires packed with dirt,'' the actor said. ``The electricity will come from solar cells and all water will be heated by the sun.'' Other leading earth activists include Ted Danson, Lloyd Bridges, Hart Bochner and Melanie Mayron. Reiss said that Cruise organized a recycling program on the ``Days of Thunder'' set, lives in a modest house and rides his motorcycle to save fuel. ``I feel Tom Cruise is extremely committed,'' Reiss said. ``Does he have room to grow? Everyone has room to grow.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, April 22

DOC.TEXT: Minneapolis retailer Dayton Hudson Corp. added a new jewel to its department store crown, announcing an agreement to buy Marshall Field & Co. for about $1.04 billion. Dayton Hudson said Thursday it expects to complete the deal for Field's, which operates 24 stores in Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin and Texas, within the next two months. The company said it had no immediate plans to close any Field's stores or make dramatic changes in Field's strategy, and reiterated a commitment to the ongoing renovation of Field's flagship store in Chicago.

Crude oil futures rose sharply after OPEC ministers agreed to hold an emergency meeting on May 2 to try to brake the recent price slide that pushed crude to its lowest levels in 16 months. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on Thursday called a special session of its eight-member monitoring panel. Sadek Boussena of Algeria, OPEC's acting president, said the meeting was necessary ``given the persistence of the deterioration registered on the international oil market.''

New England recorded the highest per capita personal incomes in the nation in 1989 but sluggishness in its manufacturing, service and construction industries slowed growth for the second straight year, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Thursday that incomes of New England residents averaged $21,509, up 6.6 percent from 1988. That growth was down from 8.3 percent in 1988 and 8.6 percent in 1987. On the other hand, residents of the Southwest averaged only $15,231 _ 13.3 percent below the U.S. average of $17,567, according to the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis.

The Bush administration told Congress the U.S. trade deficit, after narrowing for the last two years, could worsen in 1990 and an administration official said Japan must do more to lower its huge trade surplus. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said Thursday that Japan's closed markets pose ``important risks for the world economy'' and added that nations such as Japan need to protect the trading system from protectionist onslaughts.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made it easier for big institutional investors to trade privately in unregistered stocks and bonds, a move expected to help lower the cost of raising money for U.S. companies. The new rule, announced Thursday, helps cut costs partly by easing disclosure requirements for companies making so-called private placements. It also is seen as making the market for such securities more liquid by clearly defining who may buy and sell them.

The nation's factories released 4.6 billion pounds of toxic chemicals, including scores of carcinogens, in 1988, the Environmental Protection Agency reported. More than half of the pollutants went into the air. The pollution, emitted from 19,762 industrial plants nationwide, was 9 percent less than a year earlier, but the EPA said Thursday that the decline may be a result of better record keeping.

Frank Lorenzo, whose control of Eastern Airlines has been seized by a federal bankruptcy judge, pledged to help the court-appointed trustee assuming the helm. ``We're going to help in all reasonable ways that we can,'' Lorenzo said Thursday, the day after U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland designated a trustee to run financially sagging Eastern. Lifland granted the request of Eastern's unsecured creditors to take control of the airline from Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp.

The Senate Agriculture Committee voted to increase spending for research on organic farming nearly tenfold. The committee voted Thursday to increase the $4.5 million being spent this year on organic farming to $40 million annually. It also authorized $10 million a year to train thousands of extension agents in non-chemical farming methods.

The federal government has told Perrier to remove the phrase ``naturally sparkling'' from bottles of the imported mineral water, and the U.S. distributor said it plans to comply. The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that Perrier's claim to be ``naturally sparkling'' is false because the water is not naturally carbonated as it comes out of the ground at a spring in Vergeze, France. The water from the spring is mixed with carbon dioxide from a gas reservoir beneath it and are combined in the factory after impurities in the gas are filtered out.

The stock market recorded its second straight loss Thursday, beset by persistent worries about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.94 to 2,711.94. The dollar was mixed in foreign exchange trading. Bond prices stabilized at a slightly lower level. Oil futures prices rebounded strongly; grain and soybean futures rose; livestock and meat were mostly higher; and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Approves Rule to Ease Trading of Private Placements
DOC.TEXT: A new securities rule designed to help big institutions investing more than $100 million also should benefit people across the country who never dabble on Wall Street, regulators said. The Securities and Exchange Commission's Rule 144a will make it easier for big banks, insurance companies and pension funds to trade in unregistered stocks and bonds that may not be sold to the general public. The SEC requires companies offering stock to the public to register and make extensive disclosures about their ownership, financing and other issues to protect American investors. But the agency voted Thursday to ease restrictions on trading privately offered securities, which aren't required to register and aren't bound by disclosure regulations. The 4-0 vote applies only to institutional investors that can prove they are big enough to handle the risk of dealing in unregistered securities. But SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said the measure would have a broader impact. ``We hope this rule will have a beneficial effect even on people who don't buy securities at all,'' Breeden told reporters after the meeting. ``To the extent that we can reduce the cost of U.S. companies raising capital, that'll benefit the people who work for those companies, benefit the U.S. economy broadly by helping make us more competitive.'' Breeden noted that some estimates put the market for privately placed securities at $170.4 billion last year, up from $15.8 billion in 1980. But two congressional leaders expressed concern about ``the possible development of a two-tiered securities market for U.S. investors, one public and one private.'' In a letter to Breeden released after Thursday's vote, Reps. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., and Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., asked the SEC to report periodically to Congress on the new rule's impact. Dingell, powerful head of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and Markey, chairman of its finance committee which oversees the SEC, said they also were concerned that Rule 144a may be ``beyond the scope of the powers of the commission'' because it allows for exemption from registration _ and thus disclosure _ requirements. ``Full and fair disclosure of the character of securities'' sold across state lines is a key element of federal securities law, they said. The rule sets a $100 million threshold for participating in the private placement market to screen out unsophisticated investors who might not be able to make wise choices without the disclosures required on public offerings. Registered broker-dealers that either own and manage $10 million in securities, or act as riskless principals for qualified institutional buyers, are exempt from the $100 million requirement. Banks and savings and loans, on the other hand, must have a net worth of $25 million in addition to holding at least $100 million in securities. The move is expected to lower the cost of raising money for U.S. companies while wooing foreign corporations _ sometimes put off by onerous U.S. disclosure requirements _ to raise capital here. The SEC also approved rule changes that would: make the National Association of Securities Dealers' PORTAL trading system the market place for such unregistered securities; and clarify regulations governing foreign transactions of unregistered securities. ``This is an historic day for the commission and its international program,'' said Breeden, who has been pushing to make the U.S. securities laws and markets more competitive with foreign markets. ``These rules will have a profound and beneficial effect upon the ability of issuers to raise capital in the context of today's global marketplace, and will enhance the competitiveness and efficiency of our domestic markets,'' Breeden said at the beginning of the three-hour meeting before a standing room only crowd of more than 200.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson To Buy Marshall Field's
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Co. said its winning $1.04 billion bid for Marshall Field & Co. gave it a ``once-in-a-lifetime opportunity'' to add one of the nation's top retailing names to its Midwest department store chain. The Minneapolis retailer beat out several bidders, including a group of Field's managers, to win the 24-store chain. The company expects to complete the deal within two months. ``The fact is that the Dayton Hudson bid was clearly superior in financial terms,'' said Arthur Martinez, senior vice president of Batus Inc., the U.S. subsidiary of Field's current owner, BAT Industries PLC of Britain. Dayton Hudson Chairman Kenneth Macke said the company had no plans to close any of Field's stores in Illinois, Texas, Ohio and Wisconsin, or make dramatic changes in strategy. He also reiterated a commitment to continue the renovation of Field's flagship store in Chicago's Loop. ``We view this as a once in a lifetime opportunity,'' Macke said at a Chicago news conference. ``This is a great strategic fit for us.'' Analyst Marcia Raley of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis agreed. ``I think it's a very very strong strategic bid for them,'' she said, adding that the price appeared fair. She said the deal stands out given the current distress in the retailing industry, where the bankruptcy filing of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. has raised fears of possible fire sales of store chains to raise cash. ``There's been a lot of distressed merchandise that has been on the market,'' Raley said. ``But Marshall Field is not a distressed operation _ it's a very high-quality operation.'' The acquisition will be financed with internally generated funds and debt, Dayton Hudson said. The company does not plan an equity offering. ``We will have absolutely no problem financing the deal,'' said Macke, adding junk bonds would play no role in the purchase. Dayton Hudson's stock fell $1.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange to $69.12{ Thursday. Philip Miller, Field's chairman and chief executive and the man widely credited with helping turn Field's around in the past five years, said he was disappointed his management team had lost the bidding. He said he was taking a wait-and-see attitude for the moment. ``We don't have any indication as to what Dayton-Hudson's plans are,'' Miller said. ``Until we understand that, we're encouraging all our people to keep their powder dry.'' While saying it was too early to discuss management changes, Macke and Dayton Hudson President Stephen Watson said they planned to meet with Miller soon. ``Phil Miller and his team have done an extraordinary job ... of building this company,'' Watson said. Others said to be in the bidding were May Department Stores Co., based in St. Louis, and Dillard Department Stores Inc., based in Little Rock, Ark. BAT put Marshall Field up for sale last year as part of a restructuring to defend itself against a hostile takeover bid by Sir James Goldsmith. BAT, a British conglomerate with interests ranging from tobacco to financial services to retailing, also is selling Saks Fifth Avenue. Dayton Hudson's department store division operates 37 stores known as either Dayton's or Hudson's in seven Midwestern states. Dayton Hudson also owns the Target chain, one of the country's biggest discounters with 408 stores in 32 states, and Mervyn's, a moderate-priced department store company with 221 stores in 15 states. In 1989, the department store division had an operating profit of $179 million on revenues of $1.8 billion. The division employs 22,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Norwood Candy Distributor, Nine Associates Named in Racketeering Indictment
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a multimillion-dollar candy enterprise has been arrested on federal racketeering charges of kidnapping, burning vehicles and assaulting rivals to squelch competition in 30 states, authorities said. Formed in 1958, the enterprise created at least 20 seemingly charitable organizations that employed hundreds of teen-agers who went door-to-door selling candy, according to a federal indictment unsealed Thursday. The money was never delivered to charity, going instead into the pockets of Gerald Winters of Norwood, a community just west of New York City, U.S. Attorney Samuel A. Alito Jr. said. ``The Winters group operated a 20-year reign of terror,'' Jeremiah Doyle Jr., assistant special agent in charge of the FBI's Newark office, said at a news conference. If convicted, Winters, 49, faces up to 135 years in prison and $2 million in fines. Nine of his associates also were indicted on related extortion charges. Winters and one associate, Anthony Allen, 24, of Passaic, were being held without bail after their arrests by FBI agents on Thursday. U.S. Magistrate Ronald J. Hedges scheduled a bail hearing for Winters for this afternoon. A bail hearing for Allen was scheduled for Monday. Four other Winters associates also were arrested Thursday, and authorities continued to search for four others. The indictment, the result of a three-year investigation, alleges that Winters and the others threatened the lives and property of competitors and others, beat them and burned vehicles. Prosecutors cited 22 separate incidents of violence in 10 states between January 1971 and October 1988. The indictment does not mention any charges of abuse or exploitation of youths who sold candy. ``It was a profitable organization that made money over a long period of time,'' he said. Federal authorities began their investigation in October 1987 after Winters and two men named in the indictment allegedly kidnapped a competitor, Alito said. The indictment alleges that Winters brought Carl Jonas from Hawaii for a meeting in New Jersey, where he was beaten with a baseball bat and kept hostage for two days at a home in River Edge. The indictment did not say how or where Jonas was released, and Alito said he could not comment beyond the indictment. Winters-operated organizations for which youths went door-to-door selling candy include: American Youth Club; Arizona Teens; Bay Area Teens; California Youth Club; Fund Raiser Products; Future Careers; Goals Unlimited; Inner City Youth Corps; Junior Careers; Junior Salesmen of America; Junior Salesmen of Florida; Midwestern Youth Opportunities; Midwest Teens; Student Aid Program; Student Work Program; Team Youth Program; Wisconsin Youth Club; Youth Advancement; Youth Careers and Youth Incentives. Names under which the Winters operated organizations in New Jersey include: Ron Kelso Marketing Program, Inc.; Kelron Associates, Inc.; Miller Candy Sales, Inc.; Winters Candy Co., Inc.; Winters Equipment Co., Inc.; Automobile Dealers Leasing, Inc.; Fund Raiser Products, Inc.; Global Home Products Co., Inc.; Rothschild Candy, Inc.; International Candy and Food Co., Inc.; Processing Sales, Inc.; and Winters Martin, Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Urge Stop to Norton Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts lawmakers united to urge the Bush administration to block a British conglomerate's hostile takeover bid for Norton Co. All 13 members of the state's congressional delegation argued that the Worcester, Mass., abrasives maker is the leader in a field with defense and national security applications. The lawmakers attended a news conference Thursday at the Capitol calling for federal action to stop the takeover attempt by BTR PLC. ``Norton is Worcester,'' said Rep. Joseph Early. ``Norton is the world's leading manufacturer of abrasives and the largest employer in Worcester.'' The jobs of Norton's 3,100 employees would be jeopardized, Early said, if a foreign owner decided to relocate or sell off Norton's assets. The delegation signed a joint letter to President Bush urging him to step in and block the takeover. Early said the delegation would unveil legislation next week designed to make it easier for the president to act. A law already on the books allows the president, following an investigation, to block a foreign takeover if it would threaten national security. It has been invoked only once. A BTR spokesman, who asked to remain anonymous, said the existing law is ``inapplicable'' to BTR. ``BTR and its subsidiaries in the U.S. have sensitive and secretive clearance with the Department of Defense and other federal government agencies,'' the spokesman said. ``We believe those clearances are more sensitive than Norton's.'' The spokesman added that BTR has no plans to move Norton's headquarters or lay off workers. The stance taken by the congressional delegation came a day after Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a law that would prevent BTR from wresting immediate control over the Norton board. The law requires Massachusetts companies to elect directors over staggered terms, with one-third being elected at a time. That would prevent BTR from replacing a majority of directors at Norton's annual meeting next Thursday. Norton tried to delay the meeting for two months, but that move was blocked this week by the U.S. Court of Appeals. Norton also has filed a lawsuit in federal court alleging that state law prohibits BTR from exercising any voting power at Norton's shareholders meeting. BTR called Norton's claim ``frivolous.'' A key player in the effort to involve President Bush in the Norton battle is likely to be Rep. Silvio Conte, the only Republican in the delegation and the most senior member from Massachusetts. ``When a foreign company attempts to acquire an American company that has important industrial and technological capabilities, the president is required to determine if the acquisition is in the best interests of our national security,'' Conte said. ``Norton's research projects, manufacturing technologies and government contracts are of great importance to our national security and our industrial base.''

DOC.HEAD: Trustee Says Eastern Is Back on Course; Union Leaders See End Strike
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: The man appointed to take control of Eastern Airlines from Frank Lorenzo told customers the troubled carrier was back on course after a bitter court fight for the cockpit. ``I want to reassure the community of travel agents and the flying public that Eastern is flying, that it is flying safely and reliably, and with an unparalleled level of service and enthusiasm,'' said Martin Shugrue, who was appointed trustee to run the airline. Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., endorsed Shugrue Thursday as an ``able'' manager and promised to work with him to try to turn the airline around. Eastern's Machinists, meanwhile, celebrated Lorenzo's ouster and the prospect of an end to their 13-month strike, although they acknowledged they faced the prospect of still more hard times ahead. ``There obviously is going to be tremendous sacrifices over the next year, maybe two years or more, to bring us back to normalcy ... but it's not going to be done in the interest of Frank Lorenzo,'' Eastern Machinist president Charles Bryan told about 100 strikers at union headquarters near Miami International Airport. After a four-day hearing in New York City that offered some harsh assessments of Lorenzo's stewardship, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland late Wednesday granted the request of Eastern's unsecured creditors to appoint a trustee. The creditors, who are owed about $980 million, were angered by Eastern's continuing losses and management's plans to slash debt repayments. It was sweet news for the unions, which had sought Lorenzo's departure since Eastern filed for bankruptcy in March 1989, five days into a crippling strike. ``Frank Lorenzo has finally been exposed as the incompetent, conniving, greedy airline wrecker he is,'' said Machinists national president George Kourpias. Shugrue is a former president of Eastern's sister carrier, non-union Continental Airlines. He resigned from Continental under pressure from Lorenzo last year. In an interview Thursday, Lorenzo said the decision to let Shugrue go was made by Continental's board of directors. He also said he wouldn't appeal Shugrue's appointment and pledged to work with him. ``We're going to help in all reasonable ways that we can,'' Lorenzo said. ``Marty is an able airline operator. And he's going to have our support.'' Some analysts were encouraged by the naming of Shugrue. ``There aren't a lot of messiahs standing on street corners,'' said Robert Joedicke of Shearson Lehman Hutton. ``As far as understanding the industry and the relationships at Texas Air, Marty's probably the best qualified man out there.'' However, the change at the top could prompt some Eastern managers to leave, Lorenzo said. ``It's very difficult to project the future. There may well be people leaving ... but we're just going to have to see,'' he said. Strikers, however, are eager to return. ``If it was up to me, I'd be back to work today,'' said Willie Washington, 47, who worked part-time as a substitute teacher during the strike. ``Our main goal now is getting back to work,'' said Frank Ortis, president of the Machinists' Miami local. ``But we will remain on strike until an agreement is reached. We've worked too hard to make any moves now that we'd regret later.'' Bryan said Thursday night he had had only ``a brief introductory conversation'' with Shugrue. ``I hope to probably speak with him tomorrow, get things started,'' he added. About 7,500 of the 9,000 Machinists who walked off the job last year have said they'd go back to Eastern, Ortis said. About 2,500 workers could be brought back immediately following a strike settlement, he added. Eastern shrank considerably during the strike. Billionaire Donald Trump bought its profitable Northeast shuttle last year, and American Airlines has received tentative federal approval to acquire its Latin American routes. Eastern spokesman Bob Hunter said the court's decision to release $80 million from escrow will keep the carrier in the air through mid-1990. All reservation systems and flier-incentive programs will remain in effect. ``It's still business as usual,'' said Hunter.

DOC.HEAD: Cash Seems The Right Stuff to Jittery Japanese Investors
DOC.TEXT: The hottest investment in Tokyo this year is cash. With uncertainty reigning over Japan's stock and bond markets and U.S. Treasury bond prices tumbling, many investment managers have sought shelter for their funds. They are finding it in Tokyo's overnight money markets, short-term certificates of deposit and other interest-bearing cash investments, brokers and analysts say. True, this week's rebound in the yen and in stock prices have led some analysts to believe the bear market might be over. But they have not washed away the caution. ``People are hiding in cash and CDs from all of the unpleasant possibilities,'' said William H. Brown, president the investment advisory firm of Scudder Stevens and Clark (Overseas). The rate for unsecured overnight call loans, the shortest-term cash investment, has been above 7 percent recently. That's less than a quarter percentage point below the yield on the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond. What's more, three-month certificates of deposit have been quoted on the open market this week at more than 7.5 percent. Such high rates offer investors a rewarding hedge for their money while market turbulence continues. ``Who wants to be the first to stick out their neck by taking a stand, when you can get those kinds of rates on the overnight calls?'' said one dealer, who spoke on the condition she not be identified. ``If I'm 20 percent in cash and you're 40 percent in cash and the equities market crashes again, who wins? You do.'' At County NatWest Securities, analyst David Threadgold remarked, ``I'd be very surprised if a lot more money weren't going into cash.'' As a result, Japan's money supply is growing far faster than the economy with its relatively stable prices justifies, according to the Bank of Japan. The broad money supply, which includes short-term instruments, rose 11.7 percent from January through March, the central bank reported this week. In that period, the stock market has lost a quarter of its value, the yen has fallen more than 10 percent against the dollar, and government bond prices have dropped to about 85 percent of their face value. The central bank had forecast only a 9 percent expansion of the money supply for the quarter. Bank of Japan officials said a major cause of the ``excessive'' growth was the ``merry-go-round'' of funds slushing through cash instruments as investors darted in and out of various markets. The cash glut shows no sign of abating. The central bank now predicts 11 percent money growth for the March-May quarter. That could trigger a viscious spiral if fast money growth further erodes the yen's value. ``It means more inflation, and that will result in higher interest rates whether the BOJ does anything about it or not,'' Brown said. Turbulence in the U.S. bond market also is pushing money into Japan's cash markets. A worsening of the U.S. inflation outlook sent Treasury bonds plunging this week, driving the yield on the bellwether 30-year bond up a quarter point this week to 8.84 percent Thursday. Some Japanese investors are selling U.S. Treasuries, long a staple of overseas investment for them, and repatriating the money, dealers said. Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a currency dealer with Daiwa Bank, said the yen's rise this week resulted partley from life insurers selling Treasury bonds and converting the proceeds into yen for short-term investment in Japan. The popularity of cash investments indicates hesitation rather than any fundamental shift in strategy, analysts said. Kinugasa said he thought the life insurers would probably reinvest in U.S. Treasury bonds at next month's auction. Masahiro Yamada, general manager of overseas investments for Nippon Life Insurance Co., possibly the biggest overseas investor of all, said his firm will invest about the same amount abroad this year as last. The only difference might be a stronger interest in Western Europe and Canada, he said. Marshall Gittler of UBS Philips and Drew International said that if money continues to pour into short-term investments and if Japanese investors prove unenthusiastic at next month's U.S. Treasury auction, the yen ``is bound to rise.'' That would take pressure off short-term interest rates, he said. With rates falling, it's possible ``greed would exceed fear,'' allowing the financial markets to rebound, he said.

DOC.HEAD: International Plan Recommended to Combat Drug Money-Laundering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: An international task force is recommending a worldwide plan to uncover billions of dollars being hidden by narcotics dealers through intricate money-laundering transactions. A major element of the plan, according to Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, is a requirement that financial institutions report questionable dealings by their customers. ``Specifically, the task force recommends that, as in the United States, financial institutions must be able to report suspicious transactions to law enforcement, in good faith, free from fear of liability under secrecy laws,'' Robson said at a news conference Thursday. ``Suspicious transaction reporting has proven to be very valuable to U.S. law enforcement,'' he added. The 40 ``action recommendations'' were adopted by the Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering on Feb. 7 in Paris and announced Thursday by the participating nations. Robson headed the U.S. delegation on the panel. The task force was established following last summer's economic summit of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Paris to assess current anti-money-laundering efforts and ``to consider additional preventive efforts in this field.'' In addition to the G-7 nations of Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States, task force members included Austria, Australia, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland and the European Community. President Bush and other leaders of the G-7 nations will consider the recommendations at their July economic summit in Houston, Robson said. Many of the recommendations will require government approval elsewhere, but most already conform with U.S. laws, he added. In addition to the reporting requirement, the task force recommendations include requirements that financial institutions adopt procedures to identify their customers and to maintain adequate records about customers and their transactions. ``With money-laundering cases being investigated months and even years after transactions take place, adequate recordkeeping is essential,'' Robson said. ``At the same time,'' he added, ``the recommendations reflect a recognition that law enforcement objectives need to be balanced with burdens on the financial system.'' He contended the recommendations would not transform financial institutions into policemen. The task force report said the United Nations has estimated that drug trafficking proceeds worldwide totaled $300 billion in 1987. Drug trafficking and money-laundering are ``inextricably connected'' and require an international solution, Robson said. Thus, ``countries must link together to have strong domestic anti-money laundering programs for detection and prosecution and must cooperate freely with each other in the many cases that cross international borders.'' The recommendations, he added, ``should establish a network of comprehensive programs to address money-laundering and will facilitate greater cooperation in international investigations, prosecutions and property seizures.''

Stock prices hovered in a narrow range today against a background of continuing inflation and interest-rate worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 2.47 to 2,714.41 in the first half hour of trading. Losers slightly outnumbered gainers in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 411 up, 457 down and 548 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 19.60 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said enthusiasm for stocks was dampened by renewed upward pressure on interest rates over the past several days. Fears have been increasing in the financial world that the increase in rates might hurt the chances for a recovery in corporate earnings later in the year. Brokers said traders also were unsettled by the news late Thursday that Moody's Investors Service was reviewing its ratings of some of the debt of Citicorp. Such a move would come as a fresh setback to the trouble-plagued U.S. banking industry. Citicorp shares fell } to 23[ in active trading. Stocks of other prominent money-center bank holding companies were steady to fractionally lower. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .11 to 185.68. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .10 at 350.83. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 20.94 to 2,711.94, extending its loss over the last two sessions to 53.83 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 489 up, 962 down and 537 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 152.93 million shares, against 147.13 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Two Big Canadian Food Companies to Join Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollars are Canadian. Based on current exchange rates, the deal is worth about $860 million (U.S.).
DOC.TEXT: Two major Canadian food companies, Maple Leaf Mills and Canada Packers, plan to merge in a $1 billion deal designed in part to build their competitiveness in the U.S. market, it was announced today. The British owner of Maple Leaf Mills, Canada's biggest flour miller, announced the plan for its subsidiary to join forces with what is the country's largest public food-processing company. Hillsdown Holdings PLC will have a 56 percent stake in the combined company under the proposed transaction which must be approved by both companies' stockholders. Their boards of directors back the proposal and are recommending that shareholders endorse it. The merger must be approved by Canadian regulators. ``The combination of these two businesses creates a powerful new force in the North American food industry,'' said Harry Solomon, chairman of Hillsdown. ``The size, scope and resources of the combined company enables it to take full advantage of the opportunities of the Canada-U.S. free-trade agreement.'' Maple Leaf Mills, which was taken over by Hillsdown in August 1987, sells baked goods and poultry. Its brand name products include Monarch flour and Dempster's bread. Canada Packers sells about $3 billion worth of food products each year, which include the brand names York, Maple Leaf and Tenderflake. It has been on the auction block since last October. The new company will have combined sales of $4 billion and will be the largest publicly traded food-processing company in Canada and one of the largest in North America, Hillsdown said in a news release. Under the deal, Hillsdown will exchange its entire interest in Maple Leaf Mills for approximately 29.5 million newly-issued Canada Packers shares. That's equivalent to a 45-per-cent holding in the new company. In addition, Hillsdown wants to buy $119 million worth of Canada Packers shares at $16.50 per share to boost its holding in the new company to a majority share of 56 per cent. Canada Packers shares ended trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange on Thursday at $13.25, down 38 cents on the day. The shares had soared to more than $20 after the company announced it was up for sale last year but then sagged when no offers for the company appeared. Analysts suggested the poor profit of Canada Packers' meat division was discouraging potential buyers. The family of William McLean and their associates, who together own 29 per cent of Canada Packers, have agreed to tender their shares to the offer, Hillsdown said. Canada Packers employs about 12,000 people, while Maple Leaf Mills employs 4,000. There was no immediate indication whether jobs would be lost.

DOC.NOTE: $adv23
For release Monday April 23
DOC.HEAD: `Credit Crunch' or Prudent Lending?
DOC.TEXT: It probably was inevitable that after the debt-engorged 1980s, one of the first scares of the `90s would be the fear that a shortage of credit would tilt the economy into recession. After all, with estimates of the thrift bailout now reaching as high as $500 billion and regulators keeping a closer eye on the books, savings and loans won't be pushing out loans like the good old days. Banks also are feeling the pinch of bad loans, as last week's first quarter results showed clearly. Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank and biggest real estate lender, reported a 56 percent drop in profits, largely because of problems with loans for real estate and corporate takeovers. The situation has raised anxiety on Capitol Hill. Responding to a question from a congressman worried about businesses at home, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said last week that a ``large majority'' of the nation's top banks had become less willing to make construction or land development loans. Does that add up to a growth-snuffing credit crunch? Many analysts say not quite. To the extent that some borrowers are getting turned down, it may not be a bad thing. Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics in New York, says evidence seems clear that banks are extending less credit. The amount of big certificates of deposit or interbank deposits banks buy _ the raw material for their lending _ actually has contracted over the past year, he says. One reason for the pullback is the growing effect of an international agreement on capital standards, which will require banks to hold capital equal to 8 percent of their assets as a cushion against losses, Fabbri says. The standards require more capital for riskier assets, so banks are likely to cut back first on loans for smaller companies, construction and takeovers, he says. ``I think we're clearly at a point where we're witnessing banks and thrifts reducing their extensions,'' Fabbri says. ``The small, the less creditworthy borrowers no doubt will have less wherewithal to expand.'' But some other economists think the problem isn't a lack of money to lend. It's a shortage of borrowers. Big companies haven't been borrowing much from banks in recent months because it has been far cheaper to raise money via commercial paper, the market for corporate IOUs, says Kevin Logan, chief economist at Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. Thirty-day commercial paper costs just over 8.3 percent today, compared with the bank prime rate of 10 percent. Logan concedes that some more speculative borrowers are facing a squeeze, especially in areas like real estate, but he says that only reflects a welcome return to more prudent lending after years of easy money. Drop the ``credit crunch'' headline, he says. Make it read, ``Liquidity flood recedes.'' Edward Yardeni, director of economics at Prudential-Bache Securities, agrees. ``We would be more concerned about the outlook for the economy if Mr. Robert Campeau was still buying department stores with other people's money,'' he wrote in a recent forecast. ``We would be more concerned if Mr. Alan Bond was still purchasing Van Goghs on margin from Sotheby's. We would be more concerned if Mr. Michael Milken was still in business.'' Tighter lending may hurt industries like construction and some manufacturing sectors, Fabbri says, but it isn't likely to trigger a widespread recession. That's because so much of the economy is based on service industries that don't have big credit needs, he says. Stricter lending also may reduce pressure on the Fed to raise interest rates to stem inflationary pressures. That pressure heated up last week with reports showing that inflation ran at an 8.5 percent rate in the first quarter _ an eight-year high _ while industrial production surged. ``They don't have to raise interest rates to prevent credit extension...because it's not happening anyway,'' Fabbri says of the Fed. ``This should eventually lessen inflation pressure and help reduce domestic demand for foreign goods.''

DOC.TEXT: The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 428.99 down 0.01 from the previous day's close.

Stock prices gave ground today in selling attributed to continuing inflation and interest-rate worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 53.83 points Wednesday and Thursday, slipped 1.80 to 2,710.14 by 11 a.m. today on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 442 up, 671 down and 575 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 45.42 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said enthusiasm for stocks was dampened by renewed upward pressure on interest rates over the past several days. Fears have been increasing in the financial world that the increase in rates might hurt the chances for a recovery in corporate earnings later in the year. Brokers said traders also were unsettled by the news late Thursday that Moody's Investors Service was reviewing its ratings of some of the debt of Citicorp. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Gain on Talk of Soviet Corn Purchase
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk that the Soviet Union bought at least one million metric tons of U.S. corn in recent days. But there was no official confirmation of a large Soviet corn purchase and doubters said this morning's lower cash corn prices conflicted with the market rumors. One analyst who believed the Soviets bought corn said the lower cash prices reflected a big jump in farmer selling of corn after yesterday's moderate price rally. The analyst, William Biedermann of Allendale Inc., said there was ``pretty good confirmation'' that the Soviets bought up to 2 million metric tons of U.S. corn. The futures markets were further supported by a weekly Agriculture Department report showing strong export sales of U.S. grains and soybeans, Biedermann said. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.70 a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent higher wiith May at $2.77 a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent higher with May at $1.58\ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 2 cents higher with May at $6.01 a bushel. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed while pork futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent lower to .13 cent higher with April at 79.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .40 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 84.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .28 cent higher with April at 57.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .17 cent lower to .78 cent higher with May at 62.20 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly higher on Thursday, paced by a sharp, technically inspired advance in pork belly futures.

DOC.HEAD: Tribune Co. Posts Profit Drop
DOC.TEXT: The Tribune Co. Friday reported a 9 percent drop in its first quarter earnings and blamed operating losses at the New York Daily News and weakness in its newsprint business for the slump in profitability. The company had net income of $33.5 million, or 43 cents per share, in the three months ended April 1, down from $36.8 million, or 49 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 6 percent to $584 million from $553 million in 1989's first quarter. The company's holdings include the Chicago Tribune and Chicago Cubs baseball team, television and radio stations in several major markets as well as other newspaper holdings. Operating profit for Tribune Co.'s newspaper publishing group declined 10 percent to $55.7 million from $61.6 million. The company said the decrease was due to larger operating losses at the Daily News resulting from weaker market conditions and costs related to contract negotiations with the newspaper's 10 unions. Operating profit improved for the rest of the newspaper group largely due to stronger Chicago Tribune results and lower newsprint costs, according to the company. The broadcasting and entertainment group reported operating profit of $6.2 million, compared with a loss of $1.4 million in the first quarter last year, with higher income at the company's television stations given as the reason for the increase. Operating profit for the newsprint group sagged 63 percent to $6.3 million despite a 4 percent increase in revenue to $114 million, Tribune said. A stronger Canadian dollar, lower newsprint prices and higher shipment costs were given as reason for the decline in profits of the group.

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Announces Lower Profits, Hiring Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. today announced it has implemented a white-collar hiring freeze after the company's profit fell short of last year's performance for the second consecutive quarter despite record sales. Caterpillar earned $99 million in the first three months of 1990, a 30 percent from from last year when the first-quarter profit was $141 million. The quarterly income translates to 97 cents per share of common stock for Peoria-based Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of earth-moving equipment. In the first quarter of 1989, per-share income was $1.39. ``We certainly are not ecstatic but we're not extremely disappointed,'' said Len Kuchan, Caterpillar treasurer. ``We won't be happy until we get our costs down. ``The results are generally what we expected, although sales were stronger than we anticipated,'' he said. Income dropped despite record first-quarter sales of $2.86 billion _ a 10 percent increase from the first quarter of 1989 when Caterpillar reported sales of $2.62 billion. Total revenue, which includes sales plus revenue from financial subsidiaries, was $2.9 billion for the quarter, the second-best quarter in Caterpillar's 75-year history. The company's revenue was $2.68 billion in the same quarter last year. The all-time high for revenue was $3.04 billion in the second quarter of 1989. The hiring freeze applies to all management or salaried employees, said Kuchan. He said a company reorganization, which created profit-driven management centers, has resulted in a reduction of middle-management jobs and some salaried workers. Workers with two years experience or more have been given the opportunity to be retrained for new jobs or wait in a transitional pool of displaced workers until an opening is created. Kuchan said no layoffs of salaried, or blue-collar workers, is anticipated in 1990, although they could occur if the nation's economy sinks into a recession. Kuchan blamed the low profit level on increased costs due to soaring health care expenses, plant modernization programs, higher material costs and the trouble in key markets. He said the U.S. housing industry has been sluggish, along with commercial and industrial development, giving Caterpillar fears of a recession. Overseas, the company has been hurt by ecomonic chaos in Brazil and recessions in Australia and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Flora, Fauna Beat Out Fashion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT that pumice is at Jemez and CORRECTS vote to 391-1, sted 291-1. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `It also ...' INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs `We had ...' to UPDATE with quote. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Fashion is losing to flora and fauna with a House vote to ban strip mining the scenic beds of New Mexico's Jemez River for the pumice used in making stone-washed jeans. A bill, approved 391-1 on Thursday, would put the 11 miles of the East Fork of the river under the protection of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers Systems. It also protects 20.5 miles of the Pecos River from anyone who would permanently change the contours of the land, such as in the strip-mining of block pumice used by jeans manufacturers. The section of the Jemez River being protected features rugged canyons, thick forests, lush meadows and is a popular trout stream that also provides a habitat for the unique Jemez Mountain Salamander. The segment of the Pecos River is known for granite canyons, waterfalls and mountain meadows. ``We had a legislative proposal to designate the rivers and at the same time we had a regulatory action going forth on a mining claim,'' said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., who sponsored the bill with Reps. Bill Richardson, D-N.M., and Steven Schiff, R-N.M. ``In a very real sense, the East Fork of the Jemez River was the nation's first river threatened by stone-washed jeans,'' Richardson said. Vento said the mining would substantially change the surfaces around the river. ``Congress has a right to designate the river and prevent this type of misuse or abuse,'' he said. ``The mining claims in question within the proposed Jemez River corridor are for pumice, a material used in the manufacture of stone-washed jeans,'' said Rep. Nick Joe Rahall II, D-W.Va. ``For my part, I would forego the jeans in order to preserve the environmental values of the river,'' he said. The bill would allow existing claimholders to mine land in the river corridors, but maintains the land as federal property. It would require that after mining, claimholders return the area to its natural condition. The measure would prohibit the sale of mining patents under the federal 1872 mining laws used by speculators looking for valuable minerals. The block pumice found in rich quantities along the river is considered a valuable mineral because it is difficult to find. Its largest market is in the manufacturing of stone-washed blue jeans, said a House Interior Committee staffer. The bill is supported by the administration. Similar legislation already has passed the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Profit 1st-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: The Adolph Coors Co. said Friday it had a profit of $7.6 million in its first quarter in contrast to a loss of $4.8 million in the same period a year ago. Earnings per share amounted to 21 cents for the three months ended March 25 in contrast with a loss per share of 13 cents a year earlier. Sales rose 21.7 percent to $394.3 million from $324.1 million a year earlier. Its Coors Brewing Co. subsidiary said it shipped a record 3.9 million barrels of beer in the first quarter of this year, up nearly 30 percent from a year ago. The company said Coors Light continues to enjoy double-digit growth, and the company's newest beers, Keystone and Keystone Light, are continuing to grow.

DOC.HEAD: High Crude Prices Cut Lyondell Profits
DOC.TEXT: Lyondell Petrochemical Co., spun off last year from Atlantic Richfield Co., reported Friday a 41.8 percent decrease in first quarter earnings as higher crude prices offset increased sales. For the quarter ended March 31, the company's net income was $78 million, or 98 cents per share, compared with $134 million, or $1.67, in the same quarter last year. Revenues increased 17.3 percent to $1.49 billion from $1.27 billion. Lyondell spokeswoman Jackie Wilson said the lower earnings were mainly due to increased costs of crude oil, which helped push cost of sales from $1.02 billion in the 1989 quarter to $1.32 billion this year. Arco spun off Lyondell in early 1989 in a $1.2 billion initial public offering, the third largest ever for an American company. Los Angeles-based Arco retains about half of Lyondell's stock. Lyondell manufacturers petrochemicals including various plastics and methanol, plus gasoline, heating oil, jet fuel and lubricants.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Fall 62 Percent for 1st-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Inland Steel Industries Inc. said Friday its first-quarter earnings fell 62 percent from results a year ago. Net earnings for the quarter were $18.7 million, or 37 cents a share, down from $49.4 million, or $1.38 a share, in 1989. Revenue fell 9.7 percent to $992.5 million from $1.10 billion in the first quarter of 1989. Chairman Frank W. Luerssen said steel order bookings for second-quarter deliveries are at capacity levels for its principal steel mill products. ``The strong order book, improving cost performance and stable prices in the steel segment, coupled with some improvement in steel service center margins, promise better second-quarter results,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Income Up 6.9 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Borden Inc. on Friday posted a 6.9 percent profit gain on 4.1 percent sales growth for the first quarter as strong earnings in the grocery and specialty foods division more than compensated for an income decline in the snacks and international consumer products unit. The company said it earned $63.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, up from $59.04 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $1.89 billion from $1.82 billion in 1989's first quarter. Commenting on the results in remarks prepared for the company's annual meeting, R.J. Ventres, chairman and chief executive officer, said Borden's broad product diversity helped its profitability. ``Earnings in the Grocery and Specialty Products Division were particularly strong, led by pasta and our niche grocery brands,'' Ventres said. ``This more than offset lower income in the Snacks and International Consumer Products Division, where snack marketing expenses were increased to counter heavy domestic competition.'' Borden, which has its corporate headquarters in New York, makes and markets products ranging from milk and other foods to glue, adhesives and other industrial items.

DOC.HEAD: No Movement in Milken Case as Deadline Arrives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors and attorneys for financier Michael Milken continued negotiations over a possible settlement Friday, but no plea deal or new indictment was announced. The government had promised to return a new, broader set of charges by Friday in the racketeering and fraud case against the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive. Milken, his brother, Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg were named in a 98-count indictment handed up in March 1989 alleging wideranging securities fraud violations including insider trading in takeover deals. Lawyers for Milken, the Manhattan U.S. Attorney's Office and the Securities and Exchange Commission have been negotiating a possible plea bargain to avoid what was expected to be a long and costly trial. In addition to the criminal counts, Milken still must settle civil allegations made by the SEC in 1988. Almost all the charges against Milken are based on information supplied by former stock speculator Ivan Boesky, who recently completed a prison term. Individuals close to the case said Friday that talks were continuing. A U.S. Attorney's Office spokesman said no announcement was planned related to the case. Under the terms of a reported plea offer by the government, Milken would pay about $650 million in fines and plead guilty to six felonies _ the same terms that Drexel agreed to in its settlement last year. The government then would recommend that Milken serve a maximum of five years in prison, but the length of any term would be up to U.S. Disctrict Judge Kimba Wood. The Wall Street Journal reported that the government gave Milken a Friday deadline to accept a plea bargain or face additional charges in an expanded indictment. Prosecutors have said for more than a year that a new indictment was planned. Milken pleaded innocent to the original charges and has said through his attorneys that he planned to fight the case in court. The Journal said negotiations also were over the extent to which Milken would have to cooperate with the government in the future and the status in the case of Lowell Milken, who worked as a lawyer at Drexel and assistant to his brother. Milken resigned from Drexel last June to set up his own consulting and investing firm. Drexel was forced to sever ties with Milken under terms of its SEC settlement. Drexel has been liquidating since its parent filed for bankruptcy court protection in February. Milken, 43, is credited with reshaping corporate America in the 1980s through the use of high-yield bonds used to finance businesses and takeovers. Once considered one of the most powerful men in U.S. finance, Milken was paid more than $1 billion from 1983-87, including $550 million in 1987 alone.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp Review Another Indication Of Big Bank Problems
DOC.TEXT: A major credit-rating agency's decision to review the health of Citicorp's debts reflects the hard times the banking industry is enduring with weakening foreign and real estate loans. Several other insitutions already have had ratings on their securities downgraded as credit agencies express concern over the quality of the debt. ``It's hardly unusual,'' said Mara Hildeman, a senior analyst at Moody's Investor Services Inc., which put some $31 billion of Citicorp's senior debt undeis month downgraded $2.8 billion of First Chicago Corp. senior debt by one notch, to A-3 from A-2. And last month Marine Midland Banks Inc. saw Moody's lower its rating on $1.3 billion of its senior debt, to Baa-1 from A-3. Moody's review of Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company with $230 billion in assets, didn't send tremors through the banking community. ``The industry is already shaken,'' said Mark Gross, a senior vice president at IBCA Inc., the New York arm of the London-based rating agency. The review of Citicorp ``just adds to it.'' A lower credit rating could make it more expensive for Citicorp to borrow money by prompting investors to demand higher interest to compensate for increased risk. The ratings have no affect on customer deposits. Currently, Citicorp outranks many banking institutions. Its senior debt carries an A-1 rating, well above Moody's current rating of some of Chemical Bank's debt. Moody's characterizes A-1 bonds as possessing ``many favorable investment attributes.'' But ``elements may be present which suggest a susceptibility to impairment sometime in the future.'' Moody's pointed specifically to Citicorp's nonperforming loans in real estate and to developing countries as well as loans made in ``highly leveraged transactions'' like buyouts financed mainly with debt. According to IBCA, 7 percent of Citicorp's real estate loans, excluding residential mortgages, were non-performing in 1989. Though that figure does not rank Citicorp at much greater risk than its peers, analysts expect the amount of nonperforming real estate loans _ those on which payments are not being made _ to increase. ``Citicorp is fairly geographically diverse in its real estate portfolio, but nevertheless, given their location in New York, they have a fairly large concentration'' of loans in the Northeast, where the economy is expected to deteriorate, Hildeman said. About 5 percent of Citicorp's highly leveraged transactions were nonperforming, the fifth-worst showing in IBCA's review of 50 major banks. But Citicorp has $7.8 billion in highly leveraged loans outstanding, roughly twice as much as the next biggest player. In comparison, IBCA said that in 1989 Chase Manhattan Bank had $4.5 billion in outstanding highly leveraged debt, 1.1 percent of which was nonperforming. In terms of capital ratios, in which assets are adjusted to reflect total risk to the corporation, Citicorp barely met the government's minimum 4 percent requirement. With a ratio of 4.04 percent, Citicorp ranked 49th out of 51 institutions, although the bank is in the process of raising its capital ratios. Once a company is under review, Moody's likes to act quickly before speculation runs rampant. ``I don't see how they can downgrade (Citicorp) very much,'' said Anthony Naylor, a senior vice president of fixed-income securities at Rodman & Renshaw Inc. ``And one notch isn't going to make a whole lot of difference. Citicorp isn't in the credit squeeze that some regional banks are ... It's so diversified,'' he said. If Moody's takes action, it might ``encourage (Citicorp management) to be more quick in terms of what they do to remedy the situation,'' said Richard Mueller, an analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago. ``No bank likes to see any downgrading, but it brings more sharply into focus the issues management has to deal with,'' he said. Earlier this week Citicorp reported its first-quarter earnings declined 56 percent, mainly because of problems with weakening real estate loans.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Deal to Sell Avon's Japanese Unit Appears Dead
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc.'s tentative deal to sell its majority interest in a Japanese subsidiary to one of that country's private mail order companies appears to have fallen apart. The cosmetics company said Friday that Tokyo-based Friends of Freesia Co. Ltd. had notified Avon that it will not close on the $450 million deal by April 27, the rescheduled closing date. The Japanese company had sought to postpone the closing again, this time until late June. The original closing date of March 30 already had been put off for a month at Freesia's request. Avon said it turned down the second request and plans to pursue other options. Avon still intends to sell all or part of its 60 percent stake in Avon Japan. The company said it will resume discussions with other interested Japanese investors after April 27. ``We are confident we will sell our interest in Avon Japan this year,'' Avon spokesman John Cox said. He said after April 27 Avon plans to collect the $6.3 million held in escrow while the deal was pending. Avon did not say why Freesia balked at completing the deal. Cox said Avon Japan's shares have not suffered a significant price erosion during this year's slump on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The deal between Avon and Freesia, which has interests in direct mail marketing, land development as well as hotel and hospital management, was announced Feb. 21. Freesia and the company's president, Veji Sasaki, had agreed to pay $408 million at the closing, which included $338 million in cash and $70 million in advance royalties on future sales. Another $42 million in advance royalties was to be paid 18 months after the transaction was completed. Avon, the world's biggest direct seller of beauty products, made a decision to withdraw from Japan after concluding that it would be too costly to try to prosper there, an intensely competitive environment in which Avon has had little success expanding its market share. Proceeds from the sale of the Japanese stake will be used to reduce Avon's debt, the company has said in the past.

DOC.HEAD: Swedes to Let Robots Pump Their Cars
DOC.TEXT: A Swedish gas station chain is introducing a robot pump that fills the tank while the driver sits in the car, a company official said Friday. The robot's arm is guided to the fuel tank by a radar signal that reacts to a reflector on the tank's cap, said Per Soderberg of the OK gas company. The pump is activated by a plastic credit card. It takes only 90 seconds to put about 13 gallons of gas into the car, compared with 3{ minutes when the driver has to get out, open the tank, fill up, and return to the driver's seat, Soderberg said A prototype has been in operation since October, he said, and the robot will go into commercial use before the end of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Inventor Of Campbell's SpaghettiOs And Chunky Soup Retiring
DOC.TEXT: The man behind the creation of SpaghettiOs and Campbell's Chunky Soup is retiring after a 35-year career with the food-products giant, Campbell Soup Co. announced Friday. Donald E. Goerke, 62, who led creative teams that developed the products that have combined sales of more than $500 million, is retiring on May 1, the company said in a statement. ``He's the guy who got the idea and brought it to fruition,'' said company spokesman James H. Moran. ``He's generally regarded as the inventor.'' Goerke cooked up the idea for Franco-American SpaghettiOs in the mid-60s to create demand in the canned pasta market. SpaghettiOs were introduced in 1965 with a catchy slogan ``Uh-Oh! SpaghettiOs!'' Campbell owns Franco-American, in addition to Pepperidge Farm, Vlasic Foods, Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, Godiva Chocolatier and Casera Foods. ``We were looking for a product that would especially appeal to kids,'' said Goerke. ``We looked at hundreds of different pasta possibilities and decided that spaghetti shaped like small circles would be a hit with kids.'' In the late 1960s, Goerke began working on increasing Campbell's soup sales. He helped develop Chunky varieties _ the first major Campbell soup line that was not condensed. ``The company was build on condensed soup and we had to overcome a lot of skepticism to introduce a ready-to-serve soup,'' recalled Goerke, who joined the company in 1955 as a marketing analyst. He is currently a manager of a microwave soups division. Goerke, of Riverton, said he plans to form a marketing consulting business when he retires.
