DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher On Soviet Tensions
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher on world currency markets Friday as investors sought a safe haven amid heightened tensions between Lithuania and the Soviet Union. Gold prices mostly were lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion settled at $376.60 a troy ounce, off 60 cents from Thursday. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $376.25 an ounce, down 75 cents. Traders said the market focused on events in the Soviet Union, where the government toughened its economic embargo against Lithuania by diverting some shipments of food, metal, wood and industrial parts. Earlier this week the Kremlin cut off most of the natural gas and all of the oil it supplies to the Baltic republic, which is attempting to secede from the Soviet Union. Further rocking the currency market was a report that dozens of Red Army soldiers stormed a Lithuanian printing plant and beat at least a dozen people. In times of world turmoil, investors flock to the dollar, which is viewed as a ``safe-haven'' currency. As tensions in the Soviet Union escalate, the market is concerned over ``the possibility that either the U.S. or Europe will be drawn into it,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Volume was heavy. Shortly after midday, the dollar took a dive as traders turned their sights to weakening U.S. stock and bond markets, but the currency managed to finish higher. Earlier in Europe, the dollar rose in modest activity. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 157.60 yen, down 0.15 yen from Thursday's close. In late trading in London, the dollar rose to 157.90 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 157.50 yen, up from 157.25 yen on Thursday. The British pound declined to $1.6357 in London from $1.6448 late Thursday. Later in New York, sterling dipped to $1.6388 from Thursday's $1.6450. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6872 West German marks, up from 1.6787; 1.4895 Swiss francs, up from 1.4847; 5.6655 French francs, up from 5.6425; 1,238.20 Italian lire, up from 1,233.50, and 1.1628 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1623. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6895 West German marks, up from 1.6755; 1.4910 Swiss francs, up from 1.4815; 5.6695 French francs, up from 5.6325; 1.8910 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8820; 1,240.00 Italian lire, up from 1,231.25; and 1.1619 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1618. Gold prices were mixed overseas. Gold traded in London at a late bid of $374.75 a troy ounce, down from $376.55 per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid for gold was $376.50 an ounce, up from $376.25. In Hong Kong, gold dropped 11 cents to close at $377.69 a troy ounce. Silver prices also were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery rose to $5.099 a troy ounce from $5.067 on Thursday. In London silver traded at a bid of $5.08 a troy ounce, down from $5.10.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Rose in Latest Week
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are currently averaging 10.41 percent, up from 10.25 percent last week and the highest since last June, according to a survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.48 in the week ending last June 2. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, up from 8.5 percent the week before.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Sink On Improved Supply Prospects
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid improved supply prospects and perceptions that demand for the metal is entering a seasonal decline. On other commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; coffee futures climbed; energy futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and soybeans advanced while grain futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 1.5 cents to 4.05 cents lower with the contract for delivery in April down 1.5 cents at $1.185 a pound and the most-active May contract off 4.05 cents at $1.1255. Analysts attributed much of the selling to speculation that Monday's weekly London Metal Exchange stocks report will show a rise of as much as 15,000 metric tons in supplies of copper certified as deliverable on the exchange. The expectation of larger London stocks reflects a general perception that copper demand is declining, fabricators having already filled most of their needs ahead of the summertime construction season. Analysts said further selling was prompted by speculation that a five-week strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corp. may be nearing a settlement after workers at a state-owned Peruvian copper mine returned to work this past week. Both strikes began on March 12. ``People are thinking, `How long can these guys stay out when this other group went back to work,''' said Steve Platt, a metals analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Gold futures edged lower on the Commodity Exchange while silver futures advanced moderately. Gold settled 70 cents to 80 cents lower with April at $376.60 a troy ounce; silver was 3 cents to 3.7 cents higher with May at $5.108 a troy ounce. On New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, coffee futures were boosted by trade buying amid reports of cooler weather moving toward Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer. Coffee settled 1.57 cents to 2.44 cents higher with May at 95.61 cents a pound. Oil futures had a mixed day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting uncertainty about what action the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might take to prop up prices at its May 2 emergency meeting. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents lower to 4 cents higher with May at $17.95 a barrel; heating oil was .59 cent lower to .14 cent higher with May at 52.94 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .15 cent to .32 cent higher with May at 61.93 cents a gallon. Livestock and meat futures finished mixed ahead of three Agriculture Department reports that were interpreted as neutral to bearish for cattle futures and bullish for pork bellies. The USDA's monthly and quarterly cattle-on-feed reports showed a larger-than-expected number of cattle placed on feedlots in the first quarter, which traders initally perceived as bearish for cattle futures. But analysts noted the June live cattle futures contract is already trading nearly 7 cents below the cash market, indicating the futures market has discounted the likelihood of greater supplies this summer. ``I would say you're going to get a negative response to the report on balance ... but I think that if the market drops 50 or 75 points, there will be a lot of support to buy the futures,'' said Chuck Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. In its monthly cold-storage report, the USDA's tally of pork bellies in the nation's commercial freezers was below market expectations. The April live cattle cattle contract expired at noon at 80 cents a pound; the April hog contract expired at 57.30 cents a pound. Other live cattle futures finished .13 cent to .33 cent higher with June at 73.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 84.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .35 cent higher with June at 61.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to .90 cent higher with May at 62.32 cents a pound. Soybean futures rose moderately in a technically inspired rally on the Chicago Board of Trade while grain futures ended narrowly mixed. Wheat was 1{ cents lower to 1} cents higher with May at $3.70} a bushel; corn was 1} cents lower to \ cent higher with May at $2.77\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with May at $1.57{ a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents to 5{ cents higher with May at $6.04} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern's President and CEO Resigns
With AM-Eastern-Shugrue Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Phil Bakes resigned Friday as president and chief executive officer of Eastern Airlines, as a court-appointed trustee replaced parent Texas Air Corp. as head of the airline. Bakes, a long-time cohort of Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo, urged Eastern employees to support trustee Martin Shugrue, who was appointed Wednesday by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland. The judge appointed Shugrue over the opposition of Eastern and Texas Air after the airline's unsecured creditors argued that present management appeared unable to halt the company's financial deterioration. ``I know you will give Marty the complete support and commitment you afforded me. I have been privileged and inspired to be associated with you,'' said Bakes in a statement issued to Eastern's employees. ``The last 12 months, in particular, have been the most satisfying of my life because of your accomplishments. I am confident you will continue to succeed,'' Bakes said. Eastern has lost $1.2 billion since Machinists, pilots and flight attendants walked off their jobs in March 1989, prompting the airline to seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Lorenzo has denied reports that he had offered Bakes' resignation to creditors this past week in exchange for withdrawing their request for a trustee. Bakes' announcement came hours after Shugrue met Friday morning with Eastern's officers. Company spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said Bakes' resignation was freely offered and was not part of a deal with creditors. Ms. Ceremsak said no other resignations were expected. Bakes joined Texas Air in 1980 and became president of Eastern's sister carrier, non-union Continental Airlines, before leaving to run Eastern in October 1986. Under Bakes, Eastern suffered continued financial losses _ including $852.3 million in 1989 _ and labor turmoil culminating in the strike and bankruptcy filing. During bankruptcy court hearings this past week, Bakes warned that the appointment of a trustee could make it tougher for Eastern to improve its business, by further shaking the confidence of consumers and travel agents. He also warned that such a move could spark departures by members of Eastern management, causing additional problems. Shugrue also has had close ties to Texas Air, serving as president of Continental until Lorenzo pressured him to resign in February 1989. Before that, he had been a high-ranking executive at Pan Am Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Shugrue Faces Challenge in Piloting Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Martin Shugrue is a rare bird in the airline industry: an executive who started as a pilot. As the new trustee for Eastern Airlines, he faces a challenge in trying to pilot the carrier out of its financial tailspin. Shugrue picks up many of the problems that saddled Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., who was stripped of his control over Eastern by a federal bankruptcy judge on Wednesday. Shugrue must find ways to drum up more revenue, restore consumer confidence in the airline and hammer out new labor contracts with pilots, flight attendants and still-striking Machinists. The task was complicated by the resignation Friday of Phil Bakes, Eastern's president and chief executive and the company's top officer after Lorenzo. ``He's going to be under tremendous pressure to show progress very quickly,'' Raymond Neidl, an analyst at Dillon, Read & Co., said Friday. ``He's probably got one of the toughest jobs in the airline business right now.'' Eastern's unsecured creditors succeeded in persuading the bankruptcy judge, Burton R. Lifland, to take the drastic step of appointing a trustee. But the creditors, who are owed around $980 million, also could become impatient with Shugrue very quickly, Neidl said. Shugrue, 49, moved quickly Friday to soothe jangled nerves. In a meeting at Eastern's Miami headquarters, he told top executives ``this trustee is not a liquidator,'' according to Eastern spokesman Robin Matell, who attended the session. In the course of the four-day hearing in bankruptcy court, Eastern officials had warned that appointment of a trustee would spark the resignations of top managers and eventually lead to the airline's liquidation. Shortly after Shugrue met with the executives, Eastern announced the resignation of Bakes, its president and chief executive since October 1986. Before being relieved of control, Lorenzo had served as Eastern's chairman. Jose Smith, Eastern's senior vice president of operations, resigned earlier in the week. In an era when aviators have long since been replaced by businessmen in most airline boardrooms, Shugrue knows the business from the ground up. He worked his way through the ranks at Pan Am Corp., starting as a pilot in 1968 and becoming vice chairman in 1984. He added the title of chief operating officer a year later. At financially troubled Pan Am, as No. 2 to then-chairman C. Edward Acker, Shugrue developed a reputation for efficiency, fairness and good relations with labor. ``He was the bridge between top-level management and the workers,'' said William F. Genoese, director of the Teamsters' airline division and a long-time adversary of Pan Am's management. ``He never beat up on the workers.'' Shugrue and Acker clashed in late 1987 over a proposed merger of Pan American World Airways, the company's main airline business, with Braniff Inc. Shugrue had favored keeping Pan Am intact, while Acker had pushed for a deal with Braniff, now reorganizing under bankruptcy court protection. The two were ousted in a management shuffle at Pan Am in January 1988. A few months later, Lorenzo hired Shugrue as president of Continental Airlines, Eastern's non-union sister carrier. Shugrue resigned under pressure in February 1989, after Lorenzo brought in former TWA executive Joseph Corr over Shugrue as Continental's chairman and chief executive. Shugrue became Continental's sixth former president in as many years. ``Marty is an able airline operator,'' Lorenzo said Thursday in an interview. ``And he's going to have our support.'' So far, at least, Shugrue also seems to have the support of Eastern's unions, who bitterly fought Lorenzo. Officials of the Machinists union indicated Thursday they could negotiate a back-to-work pact with deep concessions. Eastern also must reach long-term contract agreements with its pilots and flight attendants.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Offers Anti-Money Laundering Recommendations
DOC.TEXT: Recommendations designed to establish worldwide controls against laundering of hundreds of billions of dollars by drug dealers were announced Thursday by an international task force. The 40 ``action recommendations ... should establish a network of comprehensive programs to address money laundering and will facilitate greater cooperation in international investigations, prosecutions and property seizures,'' Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson told reporters. The recommendations were adopted by the Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering last Feb. 7 in Paris and announced simultaneously Thursday by the participating nations. Robson headed the U.S. delegation on the panel. The task force was established following last summer's economic summit of the Group of Seven nations in Paris to assess current anti-money laundering efforts and ``to consider additional preventive efforts in this field.'' In addition to the G-7 nations of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States, other task force members included Austria, Australia, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland and the European Community. Robson said the recommendations will be on the agenda at the July meeting of the G-7 nations that President Bush will host Houston. The task force report noted that the United Nations estimated drug trafficking proceeds worldwide at $300 billion in 1987. Money traffickers use a complex web of financial transactions to hide the money in their accounts. ``The Financial Action Task Force was born of the ideas that narcotics trafficking and money laundering are inextricably connected and that money laundering is an international problem that requires an international solution,'' Robson said. ``Countries must link together to have strong domestic anti-money laundering programs for detection and prosecution and must cooperate freely with each other in the many cases that cross international borders,'' he said. Central to the recommendations is that financial institutions must be the first line of defense by reporting suspicious dealings by their customers, Robson said. ``Specifically, the Task force recommends that, as in the United States, financial institutions must be able to report suspicious transactions to law enforcement, in good faith, free from fear of liability under secrecy laws,'' he said. ``Suspicious transaction reporting has proven to be vary valuable to U.S. law enforcement,'' he added. Robson said other recommendations include requirements that financial institutions have procedures to identify their customers and maintain adequate records about customers and their transactions. ``In most cases, current U.S. laws and regulations are in conformance with the recommendations,'' Robson said. Robson said the announcement of the recommendations was the ``starting point of missionary efforts'' to attract support throughout the international community.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market suffered another broad setback Friday in selling attributed to inflation and interest-rate worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 15.99 to 2,695.95, closing out the week with a 55.85-point loss. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 401 up, 1,079 down and 500 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 174.26 million shares, against 152.93 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 205.96 million shares. Analysts said enthusiasm for stocks was dampened by renewed upward pressure on interest rates over the past several days. Fears have been increasing in the financial world that the increase in rates might hurt chances for a recovery in corporate earnings later in the year. In the credit markets Friday, prices of long-term government bonds fell about $10 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.94 percent-8.99 percent range. Treasury-bond yields have climbed this week to their highest levels since last May, propelled in part by inflation statistics that many economists have described as worrisome. Brokers said traders also were unsettled by the news late Thursday that Moody's Investors Service was reviewing its ratings of some of the debt of Citicorp. Such a move would come as a fresh setback to the trouble-plagued U.S. banking industry. Citicorp shares fell { to 23] in active trading. Among stocks of other prominent money-center bank holding companies, Chase Manhattan dropped | to 27; Manufacturers Hanover 1] to 32; Chemical Banking | to 23\, and J.P. Morgan ] to 33|. Losers in the blue-chip industrial sector included DuPont, down 1 at 36|; Philip Morris, down } at 41; General Electric, down \ at 65{, and Procter & Gamble, down | at 68|. On the plus side, International Business Machines rose \ to 109] and Exxon was up ] at 46]. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich led the active list, down \ at 4. The stock rose sharply in the two previous sessions on takeover rumors and speculation that hadn't been borne out by the time the market closed for the week. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $28.42 billion, or 0.88 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slumped 1.51 to 184.06. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.84 to 389.90, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.97 at 335.12. DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Co. in $42 Million Fight Over Clothing Line
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss apparel maker charged in a $42 million countersuit Friday that The Coca-Cola Co. lured it into a dead-end deal to manufacture a line of clothing with the famous Coke logo. The countersuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Atlanta, alleges that Coke withheld information that the market for the clothing had gone flat because of a fiasco involving a previous licensee. Spira Textile Investments SA also contends that actions by the soft drink maker have prevented it from making deadlines for the spring and summer season for the Coke clothing line, which helped spark the late-1980's fad of corporate logo attire. A Coca-Cola spokesman branded the allegations in the countersuit ``laughable.'' STI's countersuit is in response to a federal suit filed in February by Coca-Cola charging breach of contract by the clothing maker. Last October, Coke nullified its licensing agreement with Spira. Coke has accused the Porrentrury, Switzerland, company and two co-defendants of defaulting on $1 million in licensing fee payments and failing to provide the soft drink maker with certain financial reports. The $1 million represented the first of several payments that were to total $10 million and serve as the non-refundable portion of a $23 million licensing fee that would have given STI the right to make, market and sell Coca-Cola clothing through 1993, according to the Coke suit. Coke said in its suit it ``has reason to believe ... that defendant STI will not pay the remaining $9 million of the non-refundable licensing fee due during 1990.'' STI admits in its countersuit that it has failed to pay Coca-Cola the licensing fees, but paints itself as the victim of a dupe whereby Coke used the company in an attempt to recover losses from a failed deal with Murjani International Ltd., which made the clothing line from 1984 until last year. Murjani's initial success with its line of sweatshirts, sportswear and children's clothes emblazoned with the Coca-Cola logo spawned an outpouring of garments by other manufacturers featuring the insignias of some of America's best-known consumer products. But Coke's relationship with Murjani soured, and the licensing agreement was terminated last summer. Murjani also mass merchandised low-priced inferior goods ``that left a negative impression of (Coke) apparel within conventional trade channels,'' STI said. STI contends in its countersuit that Coke never informed the company of the extent of the problems with Murjani. ``The Murjani relationship turned out to be a very bad experience for Coca-Cola, financially and otherwise,'' said STI attorney John R. Lowery. ``They were looking to find someone to step into that bad situation.'' Coca-Cola spokesman Mark Preisinger said STI's allegations contained ``such wanton disregard for the facts as to be laughable. The countersuit is without merit.'' The countersuit said alhough Coca-Cola originally suggested that STI replace Murjani as the clothing licensee, Coke later refused to publicize its new agreement with Spira, ``apparently in order to stem the flow of negative publicity from the Murjani situation.'' Coke also blocked the clothing manufacturer's attempts to arrange distribution arrangements with stores such as J.C. Penney, Sears, K mart and Montgomery Ward, the countersuit said. Spira contends that Coke has caused the company to lose $7 million in business, which the countersuit seeks in damages along with $35 million in punitive damages and attorneys fees.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Earnings Jump Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Lotus Development Corp., one of the nation's largest computer software companies, reported Thursday a sharp increase in earnings in the first quarter as the company rebounded from product delays last year. Lotus, which recently announced plans to merge with Novell Inc., a Provo, Utah, computer products company, said net income totaled $22.8 million, or 53 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31, compared with $5.3 million, or 13 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Earnings were depressed in 1989's first quarter when Lotus delayed releasing a new version of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet program, its mainstay product. Sales in the first quarter rose 38 percent to $165.5 million from $120 million last year. Company officials said Lotus has seen particularly strong demand in Japan, and 50.7 percent of its revenue during the quarter came from abroad _ the first time international revenue outpaced domestic revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 1st-Qtr Profit Drop
DOC.TEXT: Kellogg Co. is aiming at breakfast tables as far off as the Soviet Union and offering new products at home to regain market share competitors have chewed away, the world's largest cereal maker said Friday. Kellogg reported its first-quarter profit dropped 39.6 percent from first-quarter 1989 earnings that were boosted by a tax accounting change. Spending to research, develop and market new products caused part of the decline, William E. LaMothe, chairman and chief executive, said at the annual shareholders' meeting. Kellogg has introduced four new products in the past eight months, trying to rebuild the market lead that analysts said narrowed as the company lagged in meeting demand for oat bran products last year. LaMothe said the company also may be nearing a decision in talks it has carried on for two years on a possible cereal-making venture in the Soviet Union. If the project moves forward, it would take about two years to build a plant to manufacture ready-to-eat cereal from Soviet grain for sale in the Soviet Union, he said. He also said Kellogg's plant in Bremen, West Germany, has capacity to produce cereal for sale in East Germany should that market open up soon. Kellogg currently makes cereal in 16 countries and sells it in 130. Last year, the company reported its first annual earnings decline in 37 years as its 1989 profit fell 2.1 percent to $470.2 million. Kellogg said first-quarter 1990 profits dropped to $96.3 million, or 79 cents a share, from $159.5 million, or $1.30 a share, in January-March 1989. Without an income-tax accounting change, first quarter 1989 earnings would have been $111.4 million, or 91 cents a share, and 1990 first-quarter profits were down 13.6 percent from that figure, the company said. Net sales for the quarter were $1.21 billion, up 6.6 percent from $1.13 billion a year earlier, the company said. ``Although first-quarter earnings declined, our overall results are in line with our long-term plan to enhance our market position in the United States and achieve consistent worldwide business growth,'' Lamothe said.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Fall Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell sharply Friday amid concern about a wider-than-expected federal budget deficit and a regional report that showed the economy improving. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell a full point, or $10 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.94 percent from 8.84 percent late Thursday. Bond prices rose slightly after the day's trading began, but were sent lower by the release of a survey of companies in the Philadelphia region that showed economic activity picking up, said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Government Securities Inc. Reports of an improving economy tend to hurt bond prices due to concern that the Federal Reserve will not see a need to ease interest rates. Later, the government said the budget deficit for March totaled a record $53.3 billion, up to $13 billion higher than Wall Street expected, Ricchiuto said. A larger deficit causes concern in the bond market that the goverment might have to sell additional issues to meet the shortfall. Increased bond supply can depress prices temporarily. Ricchiuto said the market already was concerned about upcoming supply issues, including the May Treasury refunding auction. Traders said the price drops Friday were exacerbated by the relatively light trading volume. It was the sixth session in a row bond prices fell, largely due to concerns about upcoming supply and inflation. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-return securities such as bonds. The market also has been shaken by reports that Japanese investors were selling their U.S. government bonds. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell from 1-16 point to 7-32 point, intermediate maturities lost between 11-32 point and 19-32 point, and long-term issues were off from 15-16 point to 1 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 3.52 to 1,134.46. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 5-32 point to 90 20-32 point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.59 percent from 7.58 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.94 percent as the discount fell 6 basis points to 7.69 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.22 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points to 7.80 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.42 percent as the discount dropped 1 basis point to 7.83 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, down from 8 15-16 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 20 Percent Increase in First Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: Schering-Plough Corp. posted a 20 percent increase in its first quarter profit on Thursday, citing stronger showings by its worldwide pharmaceutical businesses. Net income increased to $150.4 million, or $1.33 per share, compared with $125.7 million, or $1.12 per share, during the same period in 1989, the pharmaceutical company said in a statement. First quarter sales rose 4 percent to $865.1 million, compared with $831.8 million last year. However, sales were reduced by the 1989 divestitures of Schering-Plough's European cosmetics business and a majority interest in its Brazilian affiliate. Robert P. Luciano, chairman and chief executive officer, said sales by the company's worldwide pharmaceutical businesses rose 14 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 3.7 Percent Earnings Rise in First-Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Hasbro Inc. said Thursday its first-quarter earnings rose 3.7 percent on a 4.4 percent sales increase and a strong international performance. The toymaker reported a profit of $19.4 million, or 33 cents per share, for the period through April 1, up from $18.7 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $301.1 million from $288.3 million for the three months. Alan G. Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive officer, said the company had a very strong quarter internationally. ``While virtually all our European units reported increases in both revenues and earnings, Germany, Italy and Spain showed exceptional growth,'' he said. Hasbro was helped in its international sales by favorable exchange rates on foreign currency. Even excluding the exchange rate effect, the growth was better than expected, Hassenfeld said. The company did not break out the results of its foreign operations from its overall financial report. Domestically, Hasbro reported that the greatest strength was in its Playskool division, which ``continued to show strength in the preschool market with increased revenues and earnings.'' The games and puzzles produced by the Milton Bradley division of the company also performed well, but Hasbro Toy ``experienced mixed results. The company did not disclose the specific financial figures for each individual division.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Urge Stop to Norton Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts lawmakers, in a show of unity, urged the Bush administration Thursday to block a hostile takeover of Norton Co. of Worcester, Mass., a maker of industrial abrasives. Arguing that Norton is the leader in a field with defense and national security applications, all 13 members of the state's congressional delegation attended a news conference at the Capitol calling for federal action against the proposed takeover by Great Britain's BTR PLC. ``Norton is Worcester,'' said U.S. Rep. Joseph Early, D-Mass. ``Norton is the world's leading manufacturer of abrasives and the largest employer in Worcester.'' The 3,100 Norton employees would see their jobs jeopardized, Early said, if a foreign owner decided to relocate or sell off Norton's assets, such as plant equipment and patents. The delegation members signed a joint letter to President Bush urging him to step in and block the takeover. Early said the delegation would unveil legislation next week designed to make it easier for the president to stop bid. A law already on the books allows the president, following an investigation, to block a foreign takeover if it would threaten national security. But it has only been invoked once. A BTR spokesman, who asked to remain anonymous, said the existing law is ``inapplicable'' to BTR. ``BTR and its subsidiaries in the U.S. have sensitive and secretive clearance with the Department of Defense and other federal government agencies,'' the spokesman said. ``We believe those clearances are more sensitive than Norton's.'' The BTR spokesman added that BTR has no plans to move the Norton headquarters or lay off workers. The stance taken by the congressional delegation came a day after Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a law that would prevent BTR from wresting immediate control over the Norton board. The law requires Massachusetts companies to elect directors over staggered terms, with one-third being elected at a time. That would prevent BTR from replacing a majority of directors at the Norton annual meeting, scheduled for next Thursday. Norton tried to delay the meeting for two months, but that move was blocked this week by the U.S. Court of Appeals. Norton also has filed a lawsuit in federal court alleging that state law prohibits BTR from exercising any voting power at Norton's shareholders meeting. BTR called Norton's claim ``frivolous.'' A key player in the effort to involve President Bush in the Norton battle is likely to be U.S. Rep. Silvio Conte, the only Republican in the delegation and the most senior member from Massachusetts. ``When a foreign company attempts to acquire an American company that has important industrial and technological capabilities, the president is required to determine if the acquisition is in the best interests of our national security,'' Conte said. ``Norton's research projects, manufacturing technologies and government contracts are of great importance to our national security and our industrial base.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures finished mostly lower Friday as the dramatic rebound that started a day earlier on the New York Mercantile Exchange ran its course. The contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, slipped 11 cents per 42-gallon barrel to settle at $17.95. On Thursday, the contract jumped $1.10 to $18.06. The May contract expired Friday. Most other contract months showed smaller declines. Crude prices rallied Thursday after word spread that a special session of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' eight-member monitoring panel would meet May 2 in Geneva, Switzerland. The market was anticipating cutbacks in OPEC's overproduction, analysts said. Oil analysts estimate the 13-nation cartel is pumping more than 24 million barrels of crude a day, well over its ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day for the first half of the year. Chris Gohler, an analyst at Elders Futures Inc., said the rally continued into Friday morning but later tapered off as the effects of the OPEC news faded. Refined petroleum products traded on the exchange were mixed. The contract for May delivery of wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 0.15 cent to settle at 61.93 cents a gallon. Other contract months posted larger gains, with the June contract advancing 0.32 cent to 60.93. Wholesale home heating oil for May delivery rose 0.14 cent to 52.94 cents a gallon. Other contract months declined, however. The June contract dropped 0.51 cent to 50.88 cents. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery finished at $1.543 per million British thermal units, down from $1.570 on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Takes $5 Million Writedown Due to International Swindle
DOC.TEXT: Seattle-First National Bank had to write off $5 million against first-quarter earnings because of an international swindle in which $14.5 million in phony U.S. Treasury checks were cashed at one of its branches, officials said. A federal grand jury in Seattle handed up a 29-count superseding indictment Thursday, charging two Canadians and an Oregon businessman in the case. If convicted on all 29 counts, each man could face up to 510 years in jail and fines of more than $12 million. Seafirst accepted eight checks at its Vancouver, Wash., branch on two days in February, said Stan Carlson, Seafirst's general counsel. Seafirst, Washington state's biggest bank and a subsidiary of BankAmerica Corp., said it set up a $5 million reserve to cover possible losses from the checks. Seafirst Chairman Richard Cooley said the charge was the biggest factor in a 12.7 percent drop in the bank's first-quarter profit to $24.9 million. The indictment charges Harvey To-Kong Wong, 41, Siu-San Lam, 30, both of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Michael C. Busher, 38, of West Linn, Ore., U.S. Attorney Mike McKay said. The defendants are charged with conspiracy to deliver and to pass counterfeit U.S. Treasury checks and with money laundering, McKay said. Some of the proceeds from the checks were transferred to banks in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Canada and Oregon, McKay said. The indictment supersedes a five-count indictment against Wong and Lam returned March 15.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders' Committee Agrees on Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A committee representing Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp.'s shareholders has given conditional approval to the steelmaker's Chapter 11 reorganization plan, officials said. The committee voted Wednesday to recommend that all shareholders vote in favor of Wheeling-Pittsburgh plan once the company revises it to provide them with greater dividends. Wheeling-Pittsburgh filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from its creditors in April 1985. Last week, the company, its creditors and Goldman Sachs & Co., a New York investment firm that owns 34.2 percent of the company's stock, agreed on a plan under which Wheeling-Pittsburgh would give 1.5 million shares of common stock to two classes of shareholders. Holders of common stock would receive 1.5 million common shares and two million warrants in the reorganized company, which would issue 20 million new shares of stock in all. The plan also must be approved by a committee representing the company's unsecured creditors.

DOC.HEAD: BankAmerica Profit Up 1 Percent; PNC Profit Down 39.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: BankAmerica Corp. said Thursday its first-quarter profit edged higher while PNC Financial Corp., another major banking company, posted a 39.7 percent profit decline due to provisions for possible loan losses. BankAmerica, the San Francisco-based parent of Bank of America, earned $278 million in the three months ended March 31, up 1 percent from $275 million in 1989's first quarter. The company noted that during the quarter it received no interest payments on loans to Brazil, which has enacted a severe economic austerity plan to cool inflation, while Brazilian interest increased net income in the year-earlier period by $38 million. Earnings per share fell to $1.23 in this year's first quarter from $1.38 a year earlier. The number of common shares outstanding increased 12 percent over the year. ``First-quarter earnings demonstrate continuing success in managing the fundamental areas of our business, producing growth in the volumes of deposits and loan originations, as well as continuing strong credit performance,'' said Chairman A.W. Clausen. Pittsburgh-based PNC said its net income dropped to $74.5 million, or 77 cents per share, from $123.6 million, or $1.29 per share, in the first quarter of 1989. The drop reflected a $108.9 million provision for possible credit losses, taken in recognition of continuing softness in regional real estate markets and the slowing national economy, PNC said. About $36.4 million was set aside for possible loan losses in the same quarter of 1989. ``Our first quarter results reflect the strength of our fundamental business which enables us to take appropriate action when necessary to deal with cyclical economic problems,'' PNC Chairman Thomas O'Brien said. ``Recognizing the current operating environment, 1990 will continue to be a very challenging year for PNC and the entire banking industry,'' he said. As of March 31, PNC's total nonperforming assets totaled $831.6 million, up from $581.3 million as of Dec. 31. PNC blamed the increase on softening real estate markets, changing economic conditions and the results of a recent regulatory examination of an affiliate bank. Management applied similar examination criteria throughout the company. PNC operates 529 community banking offices in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Indiana, Ohio, Delaware and New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Upjohn To Pay $1.8 Million To Settle Water Pollution Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The Upjohn Co. has agreed to pay $1.8 million to settle a federal lawsuit stemming from more than 1,000 waste water discharge permit violations at the company's North Haven fine chemicals plant, two environmental groups announced Thursday. Upjohn will contribute just over $1.2 million to the New Haven Foundation to establish a trust fund for projects beneficial to the Quinnipiac River, New Haven Harbor and their watersheds, the groups said. The remainder of the settlement will be used to cover the legal costs incurred by the Connecticut Fund for the Environment and the Natural Resources Defense Council, said Kate Robinson, senior staff attorney for CFE. Robinson said she believed it was the largest pollution penalty ever paid for permit violations in Connecticut. The two environmental groups sued Upjohn in 1985 under a citizens suit provision of the Federal Clean Water Act for exceeding limits on the toxic materials it could discharge into the Quinnipiac River. A federal judge in Hartford ruled in 1987 that Upjohn was liable for more than 1,000 permit violations, and a hearing to determine the fine was held in late December and early January. A settlement was reached then, but details had to be worked out, Robinson said. By settling the case, the environmental groups were able to make sure the money paid by Upjohn is used to help clean up the Quinnipiac, Robinson said. Had the court imposed a penalty, the money would have gone to the federal treasury, she said. Upjohn had argued that it had done all that was possible to treat its industrial waste, and that it viewed permit standards established in 1983 as goals and not enforceable limits. ``We regret the misunderstanding which followed our installation of what was, at the time, the best available technology to control our waste water discharges,'' Pete Mass, a spokesman at Upjohn's Kalamazoo, Mich., headquarters, said Thursday. On the settlement, he said: ``We are pleased that this is not only finished but that most of the proceeds will be used for such a worthy cause as improving the Quinnipiac River.'' Upjohn announced in December its plan to phase out operations at the North Haven plant over three years.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Ford Recall Some Models
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. agreed to recall about 72,000 vehicles from the 1983 model year that fail to meet federal emission standards, the Environmental Protection Agency announced. Affected models are the 2.2-liter Plymouth Horizon, Turismo and Reliant; the Dodge Omni, Charger, Aries, 600ES and 400; and Chrysler LeBaron. Only vehicles with manual transmissions are involved, and California vehicles are excluded, the EPA said in a statement released Thursday in Washington, D.C. In another automotive notice, Ford Motor Co. issued a voluntary recall of 268 Korean-made 1990 Festivas, citing faulty circuit boards that could keep some seat-belt, engine oil-pressure and battery-charging warning lights from working properly in cold temperatures. ``Those 268 cars got out before we caught the problem,'' Ford spokesman Jim Trainor said Thursday. ``We notified the customers as soon as we had the parts in to fix the problem.'' No injuries have been reported because of the problem, which dealers will fix at no cost to the owners, he said. The EPA said the Chrysler emissions failure involved carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons and was first detected in an agency test. Chrysler said it will install an air-bleed assembly to provide additional air to the intake manifold, and the ignition timing and idle speed will be reset. The repair will take about 30 minutes and will be free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: Norton Reports Buyout Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 13 new grafs with Norton acknowledging higher bidder; Picks up 5th graf pvs, ``It's going ...
DOC.TEXT: Norton Co., fighting a hostile $1.6 billion takeover bid, disclosed Friday it had received a better buyout offer but did not accept the proposal because the company was trying to line up investors who would buy a minority stake in the company. Norton's disclosure, in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, came less than a week before the company's annual meeting. BTR PLC, a British conglomerate, plans to wage a proxy fight at the meeting to place its own directors on the Norton board. Norton last month rejected a $75-per-share offer from BTR, and in the meantime Norton has been looking for other investors. In the federal documents, Norton said one party that it did not identify indicated it was interested in acquiring the company at a higher price. But Norton continued: ``No negotiation of such transaction has taken place.'' Norton said it advised the suitor that the company is continuing to look for investors who would buy a minority interest. Other third parties also have shown interest in buying some of Norton's business units, but no decision has been made, the company said. ``We find Norton's announcement today encouraging because maybe it will cause the Norton board to begin focusing on shareholder value,'' BTR said in a statement. It said the announcement ``makes the proxy contest that we are undertaking that much more critical to shareholders who want to maximize the value of their investment.'' Analysts said the disclosure added confusion to the takeover battle as the two sides prepare for next Thursday's annual meeting in Worcester. One of Norton's biggest weapons is a new state law that would prevent BTR from taking immediate control over the Norton board. But analysts said Friday that this legislation could also bring a year of hardship for the company, a leading maker of abrasives. The law zoomed through the Legislature this week and was signed by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, taking immediate effect. It permits a Massachusetts corporation to elect only one-third of its directors at a time, unless the company opts out of the requirement. BTR says it will not back down, despite the state law, which creates a likely scenario that the Norton board will have a minority bloc of dissident directors for at least a year. ``It's going to be a hell of a first meeting,'' said John Lubin, a professor of management at The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. ``Suddenly, you bring in a whole bunch of guys who are against you. It's going to be difficult,'' he said. Norton representatives concede that one-third of the company's directors probably will be voted out at the meeting. So while the Norton board would retain its majority and have a year to plan its options, the dissident directors would sit in on the discussions and gain insight to the strategy, analysts said. They also would have more opportunities to persuade the majority toward BTR's position. ``Basically, the question is are those people going to get together and do what's best for the shareholders, or get themselves in a political donnybrook and have a standoff for a year,'' said Jay Lorsch, a Harvard Business School professor. ``If things become polarized, it's going to be a very difficult year,'' he said. ``I don't think it bodes well for anybody.'' Since the directors are liable for their decisions, the minority bloc can challenge the majority's actions, using a threat of shareholder lawsuits, observers said. In fact, a flurry of lawsuits would be expected if the majority directors took any more steps to protect Norton from the takeover. ``I don't think anybody will win except the lawyers,'' said Eli Lustgarten, an analyst at Paine Webbe. ``It's not a pleasant situation.'' A source close to Norton, who asked not to be named, said the board is aware of the potential difficulties but is determined to fight BTR. ``The real question is who cracks first,'' the source said. The bickering between the directors also could harm the company's long-term performance, Lubin said. ``The good boards work together,'' he said. ``The board of directors should be trying to help the company move forward strategically.'' ``It's obvious there would be a temporary instability,'' he said. ``I think there's a danger Norton will drift.'' One uncertainty about next week's meeting was a lawsuit filed by Norton that claims a mechanism in state law prevents BTR from exercising any voting power. BTR said the claim was meritless, and the suit has been considered a long shot.

DOC.HEAD: 3M First-Quarter Profits Rise
DOC.TEXT: Strong sales in foreign markets contributed to 5.3 percent profit growth at 3M Co. in the first quarter, the diversified manufacturer said Thursday. Net income was $335 million, or $1.51 a share, compared with $318 million, or $1.43 a share, in the first period a year ago. Sales totaled $3.16 billion, up 4.9 percent from $3.02 billion in the 1989 first quarter. Allen F. Jacobson, chairman and chief executive officer, said 3M's international unit volume rose 12 percent from the same quarter last year. International markets accounted for 49 percent of 3M sales during the quarter, Jacobson said. ``Our international operations are off to a strong start, and we look for continued solid real growth abroad,'' he said. ``We also look for somewhat better U.S. volume growth as the year progresses, with most of this improvement coming in the second half.'' Domestically, 3M's unit volume increased about 1 percent in the first three months of 1990, he said. Sales were slowed in the sector serving automotive, housing, general industrial and other markets, Jacobson said. Telecommunications and medical products were among the domestic sectors showing gains.

DOC.HEAD: President of Tektronix Resigns
DOC.TEXT: David P. Friedley resigned Friday as president and chief executive officer of Tektronix Inc., a financially-troubled electronics manufacturer. Friedley, 50, had been with Tektronix for 14 years and had been president since 1987. Before that, he was vice president and general manager of the communications group. ``It was probably a joint decision,'' Tektronix spokeswoman Jeanine Navarra said of Friedley's departure. ``As you know, our results have not been good.'' Tektronix has been involved in a major cost-cutting campaign and announced a loss of almost $25.5 million, or 88 cents a share, for the third quarter ended March 3 in contrast to a profit of $6.38 million, or 22 cents a share, in the previous year's third quarter. Robert W. Lundeen, chairman of the board, was named acting chief executive officer. William D. Walker, a director, was named acting president. Navarra said a search for a new president and chief executive officer had begun. The company has reported that expenses associated with its belt-tightening efforts, including severance pay to laid-off employees, reduced earnings by $8.8 million in the most recent quarter. Tektronix had 15,708 employees at the end of the quarter, down 882 from the previous year. The company has announced plans to move to Beaverton its 1,200-employee operation in Clark County, Wash. Plans to reduce employment by another 600 people by May 25 and to close a plant in the English Channel also have been announced. Tektronix produces oscilloscopes, which measure and display electronic signals, and other measuring and testing equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island Publisher Sells Cellular Phone Operations to GTE
DOC.TEXT: The Providence Journal Co. said Friday it will sell its cellular telephone business to GTE Corp. for $710 million and use the money to improve and expand its media operations. GTE will acquire the systems in North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia, expanding its potential customer base by 3.5 million to more than 26 million, the Stamford-based telecommunications company said. The Journal Co., based in Providence, R.I., and owner of The Providence Journal, The Evening Bulletin and The Providence Sunday Journal, said the sale will allow the company to concentrate on its media operations, which include four television stations and a cable system in five states. It said it will use the funds to acquire more papers and stations and expand the cable system. ``Some people like golf and others like tennis. Well, our area of expertise and comfort is in the media. We like it and we want to stay there,'' said Jack C. Clifford, vice president of the company's broadcasting and cable operations. He said the company has been negotiating to buy a group of weekly newspapers owned by DCI Publishing Inc. of Alexandria, Va. He would not identify any television stations, saying negotiations have not progressed to the point where he can discuss them. The deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, will allow both GTE and the Journal Co. to concentrate on their core businesses. GTE, which operates in 46 states and 41 countries, had $17.4 billion in sales last year from its telecommunications, lighting and precision materials companies. ``We've really in the last three years pulled into those three core businesses,'' said spokesman Tony Hamilton. ``This is a particularly good acquisition because it's an area where we do not have any cellular right now and basically it's an area of contiguous operations that will be fairly easy to manage.'' The purchase will be GTE's largest since it bought US Sprint for $750 million in 1983, he said. The Journal, which began publishing in 1820, entered the cable business in 1969 and the television business in 1984. It now owns WHAS-TV in Louisville, Ky., WCNC-TV in Charlotte, N.C., KMSB-TV in Tucson, Ariz., and KGSW-TV in Albuquerque, N.M., and also operates Colony Communications, the cable operation with 300,000 subscribers in Rhode Island, Massachusetts, New York, California and Florida. The company entered the cellular business in Raleigh, N.C., in 1985, its first non-media venture. ``We thought there was a lot of synergism with our cable operations,'' Clifford said. ``But we're fundamentally a media company and with the escalating values that were being promoted in cellular and our own background in media, it just really wasn't our game,'' he said. ``Like every company, every individual, we chose to examine the marketplace to see if we could convert a very valuable asset into another very valuable asset that is more like what we want to do.'' The Journal Co. announced in January it was looking for buyers, and GTE was one of 10 companies that made serious offers, Clifford said. The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin have daily circulation of about 200,000. The Sunday Journal has circulation of about 300,000.

DOC.HEAD: First Chicago Earnings Fall 45.7 Percent in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Troubled real estate loans sent First Chicago Corp.'s earnings tumbling 45 percent in the first quarter, the banking company announced Friday. Net income for the first quarter of 1990 was $68.6 million, or 93 cents per share, down from $124.7 million, or $1.85 a share, a year earlier. First Chicago said its results were hurt by an increase in the loan loss provision due to troubled real estate loans. Its provision for the first quarter was $160 million compared with $50 million a year earlier. The company also said its latest earnings included a pretax gain of $52 million from the partial settlement of The First National Bank of Chicago's pension obligations. ``We expect that the loan loss provision will return to normal levels in future quarters and we are optimistic about our prospects for the remainder of the year,'' said Barry F. Sullivan, First Chicago chairman. On March 29, the bank announced troubled real estate loans would cut its first-quarter earnings in half compared with last year's first quarter. Standard & Poor's Corp. and Moody's Investors Inc., the major debt rating agencies, promptly reduced First Chicago's credit rating.

Former junk bond financier Michael Milken has agreed to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $600 million in penalties to settle the largest securities fraud case in history. The plea bargain disclosed Friday by sources is a stunning reversal for Milken and caps negotiations between the government and attorneys for the ex-head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department. Milken and Drexel were implicated by speculator Ivan Boesky, who cooperated with the government in settling charges that he ran an insider trading network. Boesky's disclosures implicated major financial figures and shocked Wall Street in the 1980s. Milken is expected to enter the guilty plea to the felony counts and agree to pay fines and restitution next week in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, said individuals close to the case, who asked not to be named.

Norton Co., fighting a hostile $1.6 billion takeover bid, says it received a better buyout offer but did not accept the proposal because it was trying to line up investors who would buy a minority stake in Norton. Norton's disclosure, in documents filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, came less than a week before the company's annual meeting. BTR PLC, a British conglomerate whose offer of $75 a share was rejected by Norton last month, plans to wage a proxy fight at the meeting to place its own directors on the Norton board.

The Providence Journal Co. says it will sell its cellular telephone business to GTE Corp. for $710 million and use the money to improve and expand its media operations. GTE will acquire the systems in North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia, expanding its potential customer base by 3.5 million to more than 26 million, the Stamford-based telecommunications company said Friday.

The government posted its largest monthly budget deficit on record in March _ a $53.34 billion imbalance. The Treasury Department reported Friday that the huge March gap between spending and revenue pushed the deficit for the first six months of the fiscal year to $150.85 billion and past the Gramm-Rudman target of $100 billion for all of fiscal 1990.

More Japanese than American companies ranked among the top 10 recipients of U.S. patents in 1989, the Commerce Department says. Half of the top 10 spots went to Japanese firms and four of those companies outranked any American company, the department's Patent and Trademark Office said Friday. Three U.S. companies were in the top 10 for the fiscal year which ended last Sept. 30.

Farmland prices rose again last year but at a slower pace than in 1988, the Agriculture Department said. The department's Economic Research Service said Friday that as of Jan. 1 the average value of U.S. farmland, including buildings, was $693 per acre, up 4 percent from $597 on Feb. 1, 1989.

Greyhound Lines Inc. said it had laid off almost one-fifth of its maintenance force, citing reduced workloads caused by a 7-week-old strike by bus drivers. Greyhound said Friday that 275 of the current 1,395 mechanics, mechanics helpers, storekeepers, truck drivers and service workers were laid off beginning Monday. Union officials said the layoffs were a sign the company is struggling.

Phil Bakes resigned as president and chief executive of Eastern Airlines, as a court-appointed trustee replaced parent Texas Air Corp. as head of the airline. Bakes, a long-time cohort of Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo, urged Eastern employees to support trustee Martin Shugrue, who was appointed Wednesday by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland. Bakes resigned Friday.

Avon Products Inc.'s tentative deal to sell its majority interest in a Japanese subsidiary to one of that country's private mail order companies appears to have fallen apart. The cosmetics company said Friday that Tokyo-based Friends of Freesia Co. Ltd. had notified Avon that it will not close on the $450 million deal by April 27, the rescheduled closing date. The Japanese company had sought to postpone the closing again, this time until late June. Avon said it turned down the request and plans to pursue other options.

The stock market suffered another broad setback Friday, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 15.99 to 2,695.95, closing out the week with a 55.85-point loss. Bond prices fell sharply. The dollar closed higher on world currency markets. Copper futures prices fell sharply; precious metals were mixed; coffee futures climbed; energy futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and soybeans advanced while grain futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Buys 19.5 Percent Stake in Six Flags
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. has agreed to buy a 19.5 percent stake in Six Flags Corp., which owns seven theme park attractions, with an option to purchase up to half the company, officials said Friday. Six Flags owners, Wesray Capital Corp. and Six Flags management, will sell Time Warner the stake for $19.5 million. Time Warner's Warner Bros. unit has licensed Six Flags the use of its Looney Tunes cartoon characters, such as Bugs Bunny, in its parks since 1984. ``Closer ties with Time Warner present a broad array of fresh opportunities, and will lead to expanded use of Warner cartoon characters,'' said Larry Cochran, Six Flags chairman. The deal also gives Time Warner the option to increase its investment up to 50 percent of the company for up to an additional $30.5 million. Cochran said Time Warner subsidiaries will represent Six Flags in corporate sponsorships and merchandising efforts. Six Flags owns or manages theme parks in Arlington, Houston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New Jersey, Atlanta and St. Louis. The company's parks have annual attendance of about 17 million people and revenue of some $400 million.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Confirms Northeast Utility Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A bankruptcy reorganization plan for Public Service Company of New Hampshire was confirmed Friday in federal court, two years after the state's largest utility filed for bankruptcy protection. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge James Yacos confirmed the $2.3 billion Northeast Utilities takeover plan for Public Service a week after confirmation hearings on the plan were completed. Northeast, based in Berlin, Conn., was one of four bidders, including Public Service itself, for the utility. Public Service was crippled by losses from the delayed Seabrook nuclear power plant, in which it was a major investor, when it sought bankruptcy court protection in January 1988. The takeover plan calling for seven annual 5.5 electricity rate increases won the support of creditors, shareholders and the state in November, beating out United Illuminating Co., of Connecticut and New England Electric System of Massachusetts. The state Public Utilities Commission is holding hearings on the complicated rate agreement this month. ``The rate agreement is fair, reasonable, consistent with public policy and the public interest and is in the best interests of creditors and equity security holders,'' Yacos said. Yacos' confirmation means Northeast can begin managing Public Service on April 30 and until the acquisition formally is completed, said Public Service spokesman Nick Ashooh. The takeover requires state and federal regulatory approvals, which utility officials do not expect until the spring of 1991. Until then, an interim company run by Northeast and owned by Public Service's creditors and stockholders will control the utility.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Posts Profit Despite Drop In Many Segments
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. posted a first-quarter profit of $2 million Friday, as improved earnings in combat aircraft helped offset a large loss in transport aircraft and lower earnings in other segments. The profit compared with net income of $169 million in the year-earlier period, although those results included a one-time tax gain of $179 million. Without the gain, McDonnell Douglas would have posted a $10 million loss. Earnings per share totaled 5 cents in the three months ended March 31, compared with $4.43 in first quarter 1989. Revenue rose to $3.8 billion from $3.2 billion. The St. Louis-based defense contractor said its combat aircraft segment saw earnings rise sharply because of higher earnings rates in the F-15 and FA-18 programs and because of lower development costs in its Advanced Tactical Fighter program. Earnings in the combat aircraft division rose to $104 million from $32 million during the same period last year. But this improvement was offset by a loss of $84 million in transport aircraft, compared with a loss of $37 million during the same period last year, and by lower earnings in the missiles, space and electronic systems segment, the company said. The loss in transport aircraft stemmed primarily from higher development costs for the MD-11 tri-jet entered a flight test and certification program. There also were increased costs in other programs, the company said, and the MD-80 program posted a loss. The missiles, space and electronic systems division showed earnings of $13 million, down from $41 million a year earlier. The company said the drop resulted from lower earnings rates in several highly competitive missile programs. McDonnell Douglas carried out three successful Delta II satellite launches during the period, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Telesis First Quarter Earnings Down; Bell Atlantic Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Pacific Telesis results.
DOC.TEXT: Pacific Telesis Group said increased expenses and a forced California rate cut depressed its first quarter earnings by 14.5 percent. Bell Atlantic Corp. said broad-based growth boosted its net by 7.4 percent. San Francisco-based Pacific Telesis, the regional telephone company for California and Nevada, said its earnings fell to $262 million, or 65 cents a share, from $317 million, or 76 cents a share, in the first three months of 1989. Revenues rose 1.3 percent in the quarter to $2.37 billion from $2.34 billion last year. The results reflected the impact of a $391 million annual rate cut required under a new California regulatory framework that took effect Jan. 1. ``We're seeing a decline in earnings just as we said, but the good news is our business fundamentals are still very strong,'' said Sam Ginn, chairman and chief executive officer. He said the company will continue to expand its cellular and cable operations. Expenses for the quarter rose 6.5 percent because of contract-related labor costs, depreciation and increased expenditures to improve the telephone network and internal operation systems, the company said. In Philadelphia, Bell Atlantic said net income rose to $355.5 million in the first quarter from $330.8 million in the same period of 1989. The company said the increase reflected strong volume in its network services business, growth in non-telephone businesses and the acquisition of Control Data Corp.'s third-party maintenance business. Earnings amounted to 90 cents a share in the latest quarter, up from 84 cents a year earlier, adjusted for a two-for-one stock split effective April 10. Revenue rose 9 percent to $3.02 billion from $2.77 billion. Operating expenses rose 8.3 percent to $2.36 billion from $2.18 billion. Bell Atlantic is the parent of New Jersey Bell, Bell of Pennsylvania, Diamond State Telephone and the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Companies.

DOC.HEAD: SCEcorp Chief Blasts Van de Kamp for Opposing Utility Merger
DOC.TEXT: SCEcorp's chairman accused state Attorney General John Van de Kamp of angling for votes by opposing the company's proposed $2.5 billion buyout of San Diego Gas & Electric Co. The merger of San Diego Gas with SCEcorp's Southern California Edison subsidiary would create the nation's largest investor-owned utility, but it faces strong opposition in San Diego. Shareholders of both companies approved it a year ago and it is now tied up in regulatory hearings. Edison maintains the merger will produce $1.7 billion in savings to be passed on to customers in the form of lower rates. Van de Kamp, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, has opposed the merger, claiming it would be anti-competitive. At SCEcorp's annual meeting Thursday, a shareholder suggested Van de Kamp's motives were political, causing Chairman Howard Allen to erupt in anger. ``You said it, I didn't! But I agree with you 100 percent,'' said Allen. ``I'm just so disgusted with it. I thought he had a higher sense of intellectual honesty and competence, and I'll tell you it really infuriated me as you can tell.'' So angry was Allen that another shareholder stepped up to the microphone to chastise him. ``You have a duty to hold your temper back,'' the shareholder said. Allen retorted: ``You're entitled to your opinion and I'm entitled to mine and I thank you very much.'' The merger is the subject of federal hearings under way in Washington and also needs approval by the state Public Utilities Commission, which has scheduled hearings later this year. Allen said he was confident the deal would be approved by the end of the year. But he acknowledged opposition from some San Diego residents fearful of losing a utility with local headquarters. The merger calls for SCEcorp to trade stock for SDG&E rather than pay cash. The combined company would have 4.8 million customers. SCEcorp contends the merger will result in far lower rates for utility users throughout its area. But the staff of the PUC has opposed the merger, saying there is no guarantee rates would be lower after 1993. Edison spokesmen have said they believe the deal can be modified to placate those critics. SCEcorp also announced that first quarter profits rose 46 percent to $172 million, or 79 cents a share, from $118 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 2 percent to $1.56 billion from $1.53 billion. Allen said the higher profits were due almost entirely to a PUC decision shifting some earnings to the first, second and fourth quarters from the third quarter, without affecting annual earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Opens Newsprint to Competition
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who has made economic liberalization one of the hallmarks of his administration, has opened up the newsprint monopoly to competition. Productora e Importadora de Papel, S.A., known as Pipsa, has had the monopoly on newsprint production and importation since its founding in 1935. By controlling the supply of newsprint and extending credit on Pipsa bills, the government has been able to muzzle its enemies by controlling the supply of newsprint and credit. The government has at times withheld newsprint supplies from critics. But that control ends Friday when anybody can produce or import newsprint. Salinas announced the change Thursday in remarks at a special meeting of Pipsa's board of directors _ made up of newspaper publishers _ at the presidential palace. The president said competition would make Pipsa more efficient and fortify press freedom. ``A stronger Pipsa will strengthen our democracy,'' Salinas said. Although they now have the freedom to purchase newsprint from other suppliers, publishers said they were unsure whether they would switch right away. When Salinas proposed last year that Pipsa be liquidaded, publishers howled in protest. Pipsa for many years allowed cash-short buyers to pay when they were able, and the company was a perennial money-loser. But last year, Pipsa turned around and made nearly $12 million in profits. Mexico, which manufactured 400,000 tons of newsprint last year, is the world's 11th-largest producer. But domestic production can't keep up with demand; last year Mexican publishers bought 430,000 tons of newsprint. Interior Minister Fernando Gutierrez Barrios said that after turning a profit, ``Pipsa is an efficient and productive public company which guarantees the existence of a free and pluralistic press that Mexican society requires.'' The head of Pipsa said Salinas' announcement ``opens the options for newspapers.'' Rene Villareal, the organization's director general, said he didn't know whether newsprint prices would rise or fall. ``Like anything, the market will determine the prices,'' he said. Publishers enthusiastically supported the move. ``It's an excellent decision. It opens the possibilities to buy on the free market. It will be very beneficial for all publishers,'' said Benjamin Wong Castaneda, publisher of Punto. But Wong, like other publishers, said it was too soon to say whether he would seek a new supplier.
